In addition, two RJD MLAs—Awadh Bihari Choudhary and Harishankar Yadav—tried to meet late Shahabuddin's wife Hena Sahab at her Pratappur residence in Siwan but in vain. They, however, called on the former Siwan MP's son Osama Sahab, when the family returned to Pratappur from New Delhi after burial on Wednesday. The family expected Tejashwi to help the family bring the body to Siwan for burial, which didn't materialise. As a result, the body was buried at the ITO burial ground in the national capital. On the other hand, former CM and HAM(S) national president Jitan Ram Manjhi took a swipe at Lalu Prasad on the latter's decision to attend a virtual meeting after being released from jail. Manjhi tweeted, “Kitna hin virtual meeting kar lijiye. Ab sabko pata lag gaya hai ki bure waqt mein aap apno ka saath chhod dete hain.” Manjhi didn't stop there. He reminded Lalu Prasad of the treatment meted out to 'sahab', which could never be forgotten. With Lalu becoming active in politics after a lull, the political temperature in Bihar is set to rise in the days to come.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/patna/lalu-to-address-rjd-netas-for-first-time-after-getting-bail-on-may-9/articleshow/82439316.cms||Ramashankar
---||Vadodara||Covid spreads menacingly in Vadodara rural pockets||Vadodara: Covid-19 seems to have taken rural areas of the Vadodara district under its control. From just around 15 per cent of cases in these pockets in the beginning of this month, more than half of the cases reported at present are from areas outside the Vadodara city limits. It was always believed that the rural areas of the district were better off despite having nearly half the population of the district. Roughly, the remaining half is in the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) areas. In the first wave too, only some towns in the district and areas adjoining the city had shown a large number of cases with only stray cases in the remaining areas. But with no lockdown and free movement, Covid-19 seems to have reached even the interiors of the district. Cases are being reported from several villages that are away from the city and towns in the city or do not have industrial areas with high movement of workers and employees from the city. While the city’s contribution to the total number of cases may have stabilised, there will be no immediate respite. “This will not reduce hospitalisations. We are seeing some stabilisation in the city presently, but will have to wait for some time,” said VMC’s medical officer (health) Dr Devesh Patel. Sources pointed out that as long as he situation in the districts surrounding Vadodara and even areas of Vadodara district outside VMC limits did not improve, hospitalisation would continue. On Monday evening itself, officer on special duty for Covid-19 Vinod Rao noted, that 776 patients were admitted at the SSG Hospital and almost all ventilators were in use. “Inflow of patients still continuing,” he stated. The situation of vacant ICU and ventilator beds in the city is also grim on Moneday evening with only 14 ventilator beds and 104 ICU beds without ventilators vacant. Of the 14 ventilators beds only seven were BIPAP ventilators that the much needed. A senior official had said last week that the next two weeks could be a bad time to fall ill with Covid-19.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vadodara/covid-spreads-menacingly-in-vadodara-rural-pockets/articleshow/82439268.cms||Sachin Sharma

According to medical experts, the demand is close to 500 MT. The reports of the central government acknowledge the fact and estimate it at 400 MT. Yet the above letter on the supply plan for medical oxygen did not have the name of Tmil Nadu in it. Maharashtra, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Haryana, Punjab, Kerala, Rajasthan, Andhra Pradesh, Goa, Odisha, and Union Territories of Puducherry and Jammu and Kashmir figure in the list. As many as 13 people died at the Government Medical College Hospital in Chengalpattu on Tuesday night. As many as 309 out of the 447 admissions required oxygen. The similar situation prevails throughout Tamil Nadu. Hospitals are seeing an increased number of patients and there are a lot of complications with the fear of losing lives. ---||Kolkata||Buzz missing at markets but timing tweak saves the day||Kolkata: Wholesale markets in Posta and Burrabzar wore a deserted look on Thursday, a day after the administration decided to suspend suburban train services and imposed curbs on movement of goods vehicles. Many retailers from the vicinity ferried essential items on their bikes or rickshaws. Limited number of goods vehicles were used to transport items to markets in different areas. Labourers were around because many traders had arranged for them to stay in the godowns because most of them travel from areas in Howrah, Hooghly and the two 24 Parganas. “The business did not take a hit because we had made arrangements yesterday as soon as the government announced about the train and bus restrictions,” said Mukesh Saraf, a wholesaler of spices in Posta. “But we do not know how long we can continue like this because it is going to be a long-drawn process,” said Saraf. The traders witnessed better business after the slot in the second half was changed from 3pm to 5pm to 5pm to 7pm. In the morning, shops and stores selling non-essential items can open for business between 7am and 10am. “We received more customers today than we would during the 3pm and 5pm slot. It would be very hot that time and people would be at offices. Today, many people did shopping after shutting their establishments or while returning home from office,” said Anwar Khan, a vegetable vendor in Tiretta market in central Kolkata. Several people fasting during Ramzan were also facing problems purchasing vegetables and fruits in the evening. “I had to go out at 3pm when it would be very hot. By 4pm, shops could be very crowded. But the revised timing is much better,” said Mohammad Ishtiaque, a resident of Bow Street. Kolkata Police has also formed dedicated teams at all police stations to ensure twice a day that local markets shut down on time. The cops also employed drones at some of the bigger markets to ensure that the crowd dispersed after 10am in the morning. In at least two places — Chakraberia and Gariahat — the cops had to intervene and ask the vendors to leave. Police have decided to shift some of the bigger community markets to nearby parks and grounds to control the access, a process that earned them dividends during the partial lockdown last year. Some of the markets that have either been shifted or will be shifted soon are in areas like Beliaghata, Maniktala, Muchibazar and Bagmari Bazar. Beniapukur Market and Mominpore Chhoti Bazar, too, are likely to be shifted to nearby open spaces like last year.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/buzz-missing-at-markets-but-timing-tweak-saves-the-day/articleshow/82441254.cms||Zeeshan Javed
---||Kolkata||Class XI e-lessons start as boards prepare mark sheets||Kolkata: For the first time ever, children of Class XI in CBSE and CISCE schools have joined classes without sitting for their board examinations. While some schools started classes earlier this week, several began on Thursday. Schools are also preparing the students’ board results simultaneously — CISCE schools will send in the marks by May 15 and CBSE schools have formed their committees and started tabulations after submitting the internal marks of 20% to the board. Getting provisional admission to Class XI in the different streams, before the board results are declared, has been a norm in city schools for long. Schools have always depended on marks scored throughout classes IX and X to decide on the stream selection and admission. The board scores were never a criteria for getting admission to Class XI, but were always taken as formality for changing the provisional admission to a final one. The refrain that one heard in schools was that this tradition has come in handy for the boards this time since the results are being prepared for keeping the students’ school performances in mind, something that is done by educational institutions abroad. On Tuesday evening, an instruction from CBSE said there should be no watertight compartment of streams during Plus-II admissions. Most city schools said admissions were over and since the board has always been flexible over choosing of the fifth and sixth subjects, even humanities students have been allowed to take science and mathematics papers. “We started lessons for Class XI in the online mode from Monday. In our school, we offer a large number of subjects and have allowed students to choose after checking their performances in classes IX and X,” said Meena Kak, director of Lakshmipat Singhania Academy. Lessons for Class XI started on Thursday at Birla High School, DPS Ruby Park and Asian International School, while schools like La Martiniere, Rammohan Mission and Heritage started earlier this week. “CBSE has reiterated what we were doing,” said Vijaylakshmi Kumar, principal of Asian International School. At Rammohan Mission, where Class XI lessons have started, no outside admissions were possible for the science stream but 30% students have taken admission from other schools in humanities, said principal Sujoy Biswas. “It would have been great to see my child write her first board exam. But we are happy that her new classes have started,” said Snehendu Koner, whose daughter Anushka started her Class XI lessons at La Martiniere for Girls.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/class-xi-e-lessons-start-as-boards-prepare-mark-sheets/articleshow/82441241.cms||Jhimli Mukherjee Pandey
---||Kolkata||Metro slashes services, hours as staffers depend on spl trains to report to work||Kolkata: Suspension of suburban trains has had its effect on the north-south Metro. The carrier will run fewer trains from Friday for reduced operational hours because several Metro staffers from the suburbs who commute by local trains are now entirely dependent on the staff-special trains run by Eastern and South-Eastern Railway. From Friday, there will be 192 services along the north-south corridor on weekdays. The first trains will leave the terminal at 8am and the last trains at 8pm. Sunday services of the north-south line will start at 10am instead of 9am. The city’s transport lifeline has been registering a lower passenger count over the last fortnight with people keeping indoors to avoid infection. With only around 1.2 lakh daily footfall, Metro Railway had already announced reducing the number of services from 238 to 216 along the north-south corridor from Thursday. But after chief minister Mamata Banerjee announced suspension of local trains, Metro Railway general manager Manoj Joshi said some more services will have to be cut. On Wednesday, the GM had said, “There will be 216 services tomorrow. But we will have to reduce trains further in the absence of local trains. Our staff members will now have to depend on the Eastern Railway and South-Eastern Railway staff specials to come to work. We need to match operational hours with these staff specials.” On Thursday, Metro pushed its starting service from 7.10am to 7.30am and the last service was at 9pm instead of 9.10pm. From Friday, the first trains will leave Dakshineswar, Dum Dum and Kavi Subhas stations at 8am instead of 7.30am while the last trains will leave Dakshineswar at 7.48pm instead of 8.48pm. The last trains from Dum Dum and Kavi Subhas stations will leave at 8pm instead of 9pm. On Sundays, there will be 82 services instead of 98 and the last trains will leave Dakshineswar at 7.48pm and at 8pm from Dum Dum and Kavi Subhas stations. “We had to revise timings and will run fewer services because our staff members won’t be able to report to work early in the morning since there are no local trains and they will be commuting by staff-special trains,” an official said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/metro-slashes-services-hours-as-staffers-depend-on-spl-trains-to-report-to-work/articleshow/82441263.cms||Ajanta Chakraborty

There were fewer public buses since Thursday morning, adding to the discomfort of officer-goers. With shops selling non-essential items operating from 7am to 10am and again from 5pm to7p and wholesale and retail markets remaining open throughout the day, thousands of owners and employees need to reach their workplace. Many of them took multiple connecting autos from their homes to workplaces while others settled for a combination of bus and auto journey. Passengers alleged on some routes auto charged them almost double the fare. “The number of commuters on Wednesday and Thursday were almost same but transport options have been more than halved, which has created immense crisis,” said Vaibhav Pachisia, standing in the auto queue at Ultadanga. “On other days, I take a bus from my residence in Baguiati to reach MG Road. But today, even after waiting for over 20 minutes, I did not get a bus. So, I took an auto from Baguiati to Ultadanga. From here, I will go to Sovabazar in an auto and walk half a kilometre till BK Pal to take another auto to reach MG Road,” said the hosiery trader. Autos on routes culminating in or around the central business district witnessed maximum rush of passengers. ---||Coimbatore||IMA against allotting 50% hospital beds to Covid-19 patients||Coimbatore: Pointing out that the new government order mandating allotment of 50% of their bed strength to Covid-19 patients is impossible to practice, a growing number of private hospitals in the district says they don’t have the wherewithal to handle Covid patients including the necessary staff strength, oxygen facilities, facilities for their doctors and nurses to quarantine, pulmonologists and intensive care specialists, among others.The Indian Medical Association, Tamil Nadu branch, plans to meet the newly appointed health minister on Friday and explain to him that every hospital across the state cannot afford to allot 50% of their bed strength.“It would lead to mixing of Covid-19 patients with non-Covid patients, which would lead to more spread. There are also other difficulties such as providing a separate entry and exit for Covid patients, a separate floor for doctors and nurses to quarantine and adequate oxygen supply,” state secretary IMA A K Ravikumar, who runs Mouthi Hospital at Vadavalli, said.The 550-bedded Ganga Hospital, which had initially allotted 35 beds for Covid-19, has now allotted an additional 130 beds for infected people. They say they cannot increase it further to 50% in this situation. “People who were injured in accidents, develop orthopaedic tumours and spinal injuries during these times also need treatment otherwise they will get paralyzed or disabled,” chairman of the hospital’s orthopaedic and spinal surgery ward Dr S Rajasekaran said.“Handling Covid-19 requires a lot more nurses and doctors because of the treatment involved. In Covid-19, all staff who work for one week need to be quarantined for one week. They also work only six-hour shifts, compared to eight-hour shifts, and if one nurse gets infected, the entire shift goes into isolation,” he said.Most single speciality hospitals are accepting only mildly symptomatic patients, who do not have breathing difficulties.“We can’t manage patients who crash into a cytokine storm affecting their organs and requiring ventilator support,” said a doctor at a gastroenterology hospital in the city.“We don’t have pulmonologists and even enough oxygen to provide high flow oxygen to all our Covid patients if they worsen,” he added.IMA instead suggests a system wherein every area, one hospital is converted entirely into a severe Covid-19 patient hospital. “If one 100-bed hospital among every two or three hospitals is converted into a Covid-19 hospital, they can follow all norms. Surrounding hospitals can hand over their oxygen and ventilators and even staff if required. This way, there won’t be mixing of Covid and non-Covid patients and only one hospital in an area will run around for oxygen,” Dr Ravikumar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/coimbatore/ima-against-allotting-50-hospital-beds-to-covid-19-patients/articleshow/82442843.cms||---

---||Coimbatore||Ganga Hospital research team bags international award||Coimbatore: The spine research team of city-based Ganga Hospital has won the Outstanding Paper Award of the North American Spine Society (Nass) for the third consecutive year, setting a record for being the first institution to achieve the feat. The team won the award for identifying that pain generating inflammatory molecules were present in back pain patients, whose end plates were inflamed. Patients with severe back pain may also have bacteria in the end plate, which also probably needs to be addressed while treating them.The paper, titled ‘Why do modic changes result in poor clinical outcomes? Novel insights from Proteomic analysis of lumbar discs with modic changes’, will be published in the Spine Journal. “Many patients have low back pain. While 85% become alright on their own, 10% require medical therapy and 5% need surgery. Among this group itself, there are patients who don’t do as well as others even after therapy or surgery,” said Dr S Rajasekaran, chairman of the department of orthopaedics and spine surgery at Ganga Hospital.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/coimbatore/ganga-hospital-research-team-bags-international-award/articleshow/82442845.cms||---
---||Business||Non-profit, social cos may get to raise funds||Mumbai: A Sebi-appointed panel has proposed that social enterprises may be allowed to raise funds using the proposed social stock exchange (SSE) platform through instruments like zero coupon bonds, mutual funds and development bonds. It also recommended that an initial corpus of Rs 100 crore should be put in a fund that will be managed by Nabard and should be used for initial training and capacity building, mainly among NGOs, relating to the SSE. The Sebi panel also proposed that social enterprises that include for-profit enterprise (FPE) and not-for-profit organisations (NPOs) would be allowed on the SSE. It said corporate foundations, political and religious organisations, among other entities should not be allowed on this platform. The permitted entities should pass strict scrutiny, the panel report said. “To inculcate a cultural shift towards a disclosure based regime, (the panel) has recommended prior registration of NPOs with SSE before fundraising,” a Sebi release said. “All (social enterprises) on SSE will be required to make disclosure of social impact on an annual basis consisting of strategic intent and planning, approach and the impact scorecard.” The panel also recommended that the entities be audited by social auditors and only reputed firms/institutions having expertise in the area of social audit shall be allowed to carry out social audits. “These concepts of social auditors and capacity building fund are unique to fundraising for social enterprises in India, and would facilitate SSE in its activities,” the report said. The regulator has sought comments from the public till June 20 on the report.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/non-profit-social-cos-may-get-to-raise-funds/articleshow/82443195.cms||---

Patel’s cement and building material manufacturing unit, Nuvoco Vistas Corp has filed a draft prospectus for an IPO to raise Rs 5,000 crore. About nine years ago, Patel had taken Nirma private through delisting. Over the last few years, Nuvoco Vistas has emerged in the current form through the merger of Lafarge’s India arm and the cement division of Kolkata-based Emami. Both these units were bought over by Patel’s Nirma group and merged to form a single unit which is currently the fifth largest cements and building material company in India. Of the total Rs 5,000 crore being raised through the IPO, up to Rs 1,500 crore will go to the company as it will issue new equity shares. The balance Rs 3,500 crore will accrue to the promoters who are selling part of their stake in the company. ---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Parents’ masks delay babies’ smiling, cooing skills||VADODARA/SURAT: New dad Nitin Parikh (name changed) started worrying when his six-month-old baby boy wasn’t responding to the gestures and smile. He called up a paediatrician and the diagnosis left him stumped. The doctor told him that the Covid pandemic is having a totally different level of effect on babies, particularly those below two years of age. Masks are indeed a saviour from Covid-19 infection but the constant screen of parents’ and grandparents’ faces at home is adversely affecting the development of babies’ social milestones like smiling and cooing. Paediatricians across the state are unanimous about the adverse effect of face masks on the newborns’ social skills in the new normal. “The sensory stimulation among many kids below two years of age is missing. They are not able to understand the facial gestures quickly and their social milestones are also getting delayed by an average 2-3 months,” said Dr Tushar Shah, executive board member, Academy of Paediatrics Gujarat. “Since they were born and began to understand the world around, babies below two years are seeing everyone wearing face masks. They can’t see facial gestures like anger, laughter or joy when they meet anyone. Except at home, these kids see their parents too in face masks,” Shah told TOI. “Usually babies start smiling, cooing and responding to gestures after they turn three months old. But now these skills are getting delayed by a few months. I have been getting calls from worried parents over the last several months,” Shah, former secretary of Indian Medical Association (IMA) Vadodara, said. Experts said that lack of social interaction and strict home confinement is affecting their ability to integrate with the society. Doctors in Surat too have been getting calls from anxious parents having kids aged between six months and 18 months. “Every fifth day, we are getting a case wherein parents notice that their child’s interaction is problematic. Some babies are actually behaving like autistic kids,” said Dr Sanjeev Rao, a senior paediatrician in Surat. Dr Viraj Patel, a veteran paediatrician in Ahmedabad, said, "Long-term effects can be delayed speech, poor social interaction and even learning disabilities.” She suggested that family members, especially, mothers should constantly keep talking and interacting with their babies while doing the routine chores like changing diapers. “If the children are grown up to 1-1.5 years, flash boards and soft music can also be used to develop concentration," Dr Patel said. Parents noticed the delayed development of responses in their kids, said Rao, adding that masks are screening children from developing their skills in understanding or grasping facial gestures and emotions. Dr Shah further added that spending most of their time at home and hardly any interaction with outsiders have affected kids’ social and learning skills. Dr Bankim Parikh, a paediatrician in Vadodara, said, “Kids usually start learning from the world around by the time they turn two. But over the last one year, there is minimal fraternisation so the social skills among younger ones are getting delayed. In some cases, the children’s speech skills may also get delayed due to lack of communication. (With inputs from Jay Pachchigar)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/parents-masks-delay-babies-smiling-cooing-skills/articleshow/82442499.cms||Tushar Tere
---||Business||Banks ready health booster shot||Mumbai: Banks are set to launch multiple schemes under the RBI’s Rs 50,000-crore on-tap liquidity window announced on Wednesday. The schemes are aimed at rapidly boosting private investment in healthcare and financing individuals who have contracted Covid. In a meeting with the finance ministry, large public sector banks discussed the possibility of making available credit online using the liquidity facility. Banks will go to the drawing board and will design the schemes with extremely competitive rates and draw up the eligibility criteria. According to bankers, a ramp-up in capacity in pharma and hospitals can be done only through brownfield projects, where existing units expand. This includes adding new lines for drugs, adding oxygen plants, and increasing the number of beds in hospitals. The creation of private capacity in healthcare is seen as important as government hospitals may find it difficult to get doctors. Greenfield capacity is expected to come up in the form of new diagnostic centres and nursing homes in smaller towns. The advantage of an off-the-shelf scheme is that terms and conditions are standardised and loans can be sanctioned without delay. Banks can monitor it better by creating a vertical for the special schemes and smaller loans for Covid treatment can be sanctioned at all branches across the country. Meanwhile, two large loans to vaccine makers Serum Institute of India and Bharat Biotech, which had received in-principal approval from public sector banks are likely to get the advantage of the scheme. According to sources, Rs 500-crore fund and non-fund-based credit line have been extended to Serum Institute — makers of Covishield by Bank of Baroda. The loan is understood to have been sanctioned ahead of RBI’s measures, but the final approval came on Wednesday when the Rs 50,000-crore liquidity facility was announced for the healthcare sector. Bank of Baroda did not comment on the matter. According to reports, SBI has extended a credit line to Bharat Biotech — makers of Covaxin. While the bank did not comment on the report, sources said the country’s largest lender is supporting many government initiatives to control Covid. A research report by the SBI said that the Rs 50,000-crore funding is 9% of India’s total health spending of Rs 6 lakh crore under private final consumption expenditure in FY20. Bankers say that besides vaccine makers, pharma companies are expected to pick up another major chunk of this facility as the creation of fresh capacity would require major investment. The finance minister had allotted Rs 35,000 crore in the Union Budget, which saw a 138% jump in allocation to health. Even this increased allocation is expected to be insufficient as the cost of vaccination is estimated to be twice the budgeted amount. According to a report on healthcare by rating agency ICRA, the sector is expected to record a 20% growth in revenue during the current fiscal as against a 19% contraction in FY21. Hospitals, which had planned expansion, had to hold back last year as Covid resulted in many Indians postponing elective procedures. As a result, non-Covid hospitals saw low occupancy for several months last year. Occupancy is expected to bounce back to 60% in FY22 from 50% in FY21.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/banks-ready-health-booster-shot/articleshow/82442934.cms||Mayur Shetty

When people gathered, the accused fled towards Naraingarh. Ramesh was admitted to General Hospital, Sector 6. Police registered a case under Sections 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) and 34 (act done by several person with same intention) of the IPC at the Raipur Rani police station.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/grooms-uncle-stops-unruly-guests-from-dancing-gets-thrashed-after-wedding/articleshow/82407402.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क

Sharma said, “As you all know the current ongoing Covid-19 situation where beds are not available in hospitals, I have converted my farm house into a temporary isolation ward for all people who are Covid-19 positive. We are providing all the facilities for free.” He said if anybody is looking for any help or bed or oxygen can call on 9501287100 and he will be taken care of well. The temporary hospital admitted five patients on day one, who were put on oxygen. One of the patients said, “We were running from pillar to post to get oxygen bed, but we could not find one. Here at N K Sharma’s farm house, we were able to get bed with oxygen cylinder as well as food. We are attended by the doctors also.” Sharma said the farm house has ample space to accommodate even 200 beds, and if the scenario remains grim, they would add more beds. He said many people are coming forward for help in the form of paramedics.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/mla-converts-farm-house-into-100-bed-hospital-in-zirakpur/articleshow/82442857.cms||---
---||Coimbatore||Tamil Nadu: Three tribal men attack wild elephants in Udumalpet, booked||TIRUPUR: The forest department has registered a case against three men from the Thirumurthymalai tribal settlement in Udumalpet forest range under the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972 for attacking wild elephants on Wednesday. The department has formed a team to nab them. Several videos that went viral on social media on Thursday showed the men throwing stones at elephants and beating them with sticks. “Preliminary inquiry revealed that P Selvam, 32, T Kalimuthu, 25 and J Arunkumar, 30, were herding cattle when they saw two elephants and a calf. They tried to shoo away the animals and threw stones at them. When the elephants charged towards them, the men ran away and again attacked the animals using sticks and stones. Their friends, who sought refuge atop trees, recorded the scene using mobile phones,” an official said. A team led by assistant director of Anamalai Tiger Reserve (ATR) Ganeshram visited the tribal settlement on Thursday morning to nab the trio. “But they had escaped to the reserve forest to evade arrest. We met the head of the settlement and asked him to hand over the men to the department. He has agreed to do that,” the official said. “We also warned the tribal people against attacking wild animals.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/coimbatore/three-tribal-men-attack-elephants-booked/articleshow/82442848.cms||A Subburaj
---||Lucknow||IITian who engineered political career in rural hinterland||LUCKNOW: Ajit Singh was at the peak of his engineering career in the US when his ailing father and former PM Chaudhary Charan Singh called him back to Delhi in the early 1980s. An alumnus of IIT-Kharagpur and Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, Singh, in fact, was one of the very few Indians who had worked with software giant IBM. But Singh, born in a small village Bhadola in Meerut on February 12, 1939, was destined for a long political journey that started with getting elected to Rajya Sabha in 1986 on a Lok Dal ticket. After Charan Singh’s death in 1987, Ajit formed Lok Dal (Ajit) and became the president of Janata Party in 1988. He became the general secretary of Janata Dal which was formed after the merger of various political factions to take on the Congress. In 1989, he first got elected to Lok Sabha from Baghpat and became industry minister in the then National Front government led by VP Singh. Singh again won from Baghpat on a Janata Dal ticket in 1991 but switched over to the Congress in 1995 to become minister of food in the then PV Narasimha Rao government. He then got elected from Baghpat on a Congress ticket in 1996 but soon resigned from the party and Lok Sabha to form Rashtriya Lok Dal (RLD). Singh, subsequently, got re-elected to Lok Sabha in 1997 byelections. The influential Jat leader, who was known for allying with politicial parties across the spectrum, however, lost Baghpat to BJP’s Sompal in 1998 but managed to wrest it back in 1999 Lok Sabha elections. In 2001, he joined hands with the BJP and became union agriculture minister in the Atal Behari Vajpayee government. Singh managed to win the Lok Sabha elections from Baghpat in 2004 and then again in 2009. In 2011, he allied with the Congress-led United Progressive Alliance (UPA) government and became the civil aviation minister. The emergence of BJP as a massive political force under the leadership of Narendra Modi, however, brought Singh’s political career to a screeching halt. In 2014 Lok Sabha elections, Singh lost Baghpat to BJP’s Satyapal Singh. In fact, Singh finished a distant third in his own stronghold securing barely 19.86% votes. Experts said that the setback to Singh’s political fortunes was the result of a dramatic shift in Jat votes in favour of the BJP. The phenomenon repeated itself in 2017 UP assembly elections when RLD got completely routed, winning just one seat – Chhaprauli. Its lone MLA, Ramendra Singh Ramala, too, later switched over to the BJP. A politically bruised Ajit Singh quit Baghpat to contest from Muzaffarnagar in 2019 Lok Sabha elections but got defeated by BJP’s Sanjeev Baliyan by a margin of around 6,000 votes.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/iitian-who-engineered-pol-career-in-rural-hinterland/articleshow/82444858.cms||Pankaj Shah

---||Pune||22 temporary jails opened in state for isolation of nCoV + ve inmates; More to come up||Pune: The state prisons department has opened 22 temporary jails and five Covid care centres (CCCs) in various districts across Maharashtra, including Pune and Mumbai, since April 20 for isolation and treatment of undertrial prisoners or inmates testing positive for Covid-19 virus. The department recently asked the superintendents of all 60 jails in the state to co-ordinate with their respective local administrations for setting up at least two temporary jails in their districts on a priority basis. The objective is to ensure that there is no spread of the virus in main prison complexes, which already have inmates much more than their sanctioned capacities. As was the case during the first Covid-19 wave last year, schools and hostel buildings located near the main jail complexes will be utilised as temporary jails. “Newly-arrested persons remanded in judicial custody will first be tested for nCoV and then kept in one of the temporary jails till their test reports are received. Only those testing negative will be moved into the main prison complex ,while those testing positive will be isolated for treatment and care at the second temporary jail. They will be moved to the main complex only after full recovery,” additional director general of prisons Sunil Ramanand told TOI on Thursday. He said, “During the Covid surge last year, the respective local administrations had helped us in opening over 30 temporary jails. All these facilities were later closed after the cases declined and the situation came under control. Since the number of positive cases has again started increasing this year, we have asked all our jail superintendents to re-acquire temporary jails.” The prisons chief said, “We have opened 22 temporary jails and CCCs in Pune, Mumbai and other places in the state as of now. We hope to open 38 more such jails in about 10 days’ time. The prisons department and the local administration will provide medical staff for treating inmates testing positive. The department will maintain internal security, while the police commissioners and the district superintendents of police offices will maintain external security at the temporary jails.” “I have also issued instructions to all jail superintendents to hold meetings with the principal district and sessions judges at district levels to carry out a review of the inmates released on temporary bail and emergency parole,” he added. ---||Surat||One held with four vials of remdesivir in Bharuch||Surat: The local crime branch of Bharuch police nabbed a man for the illegal sale of remdesivir injections on Wednesday. Police said that they had received information about a man named Mubin Chauhan selling the injections near his house at Vasila society in Bharuch town. Based on the information, cops laid a trap for Chauhan by sending a dummy customer to purchase the injection from him. When Chauhan arrived at a pre-decided spot to sell the vials, cops nabbed him. Four vials of Remdesivir were found on Chauhan. When questioned, Chauhan told cops that he had got the vials from Maqbool Chauhan, who is absconding. Chauhan also told police that he was planning to sell each vial for Rs 20,000. The accused was later handed over to B Division police station where an offence was registered against him and his father. Police have appealed to citizens to not purchase such life-saving medicines and oxygen cylinders from those involved in their illegal sale. “We understand that people need these medicines only under emergency circumstances, but instead of encouraging such people by purchasing from them at high prices, public should inform us,” said a police official.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/surat/one-held-with-four-vials-of-remdesivir-in-bharuch/articleshow/82439540.cms||---

---||Mumbai||Mumbai: 11-hour power cut angers residents of Goregaon West||MUMBAI: Residents of Link Road and M G Road in Goregaon (West) faced a harrowing time on Thursday as many had no power supply for as long as 11-12 hours. It was a major inconvenience for those working from home, and also those in isolation due to Covid-19. The summer heat and humidity added to the woes. Adani Electricity said in a tweet that the outage was “due to multiple high tension network abnormality.” Social media was abuzz with complaints on Thursday morning, with Adani getting several tweets from citizens. TimesViewWith residents working from home, a power outage for a few hours can be an ordeal. Power experts say as per regulations, consumers who are put to hardships due to prolonged power outage can directly approach the utility firm to seek compensation and make them liable for the disruption. Power providers must strengthen the infrastructure to ensure it can take a higher load during a surge in demand and minimise technical faults.Among the first to complain was Nishchay Agrawal in a 5am tweet: “@Adani_Elec_Mum There is no power in Goregaon West Mumbai since midnight hours. No customer care, no authentic information about the restoration...” To this, Adani Electricity replied : “Dear Customer, The outage is due to multiple high tension network abnormality. Our technicians are striving hard to have this resolved at the earliest...”  Consumer Parth @Twistedparth tweeted: “It’s been 12 hours there is no electricity at Motilal Nagar in Goregaon West. Crying babies, patients and elders in distress while Adani Electricity keeps sending messages of restoration every hour.” An Adani official said: “The outage was due to multiple faults in our HT (high tension) network and increase in demand due to a rise in temperature and humidity. We restored supply by alternate arrangement/diesel generator sets. Entire load could not be restored due to system constraints, but the network was normalised by early afternoon." Consumer Mohammed Basit Khan tweeted: “The entire colony along Badi Masjid Road, Motilal Nagar no-2, Goregaon West is impacted. Here we have 20,000 people which include kids, medical patients and so on. I would want compensation for the pain which I have to bear.” He had no power since 1am. Power expert Ashok Pendse said the faults are mainly due to overload in hot weather. “Work from home has added to it. The need of the hour is for the power utility firm to ensure load augmentation.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-11-hour-power-cut-angers-residents-of-goregaon-west/articleshow/82441203.cms||Somit Sen

The traders, while protesting at Phase VII and 3B2 in Mohali on Thursday, said either the government must allow all the shops to open or no shop must be allowed to operate during the lockdown. Phase VII market association president Gurmukh Singh Walia said, “We believe that the Punjab government is adopting pick and choose policy. It is hard to believe that liquor comes under essential category, whereas traders selling stationery, cosmetics do not fall under essential category. We demand the government to either shut down all the shops or allow all of them to operate.” The traders have also opposed the revised curfew directions of closing the shops by 5 pm. They said they have already faced huge losses due to the lockdown last year, and now when the time had come to earn, another lockdown has further pushed them into debts. Mohali Beopar Mandal president Sarabjit Singh Paras said, “We appeal the chief minister to relax the day curfew by allowing shops to open during the day as closing the same by 5 pm is against them. We have already sustained huge loses and many traders are on the verge of closure due to the last year’s lockdown and again we are on the verge of incurring huge losses.” Other traders said the daily night curfew from 6 pm to 5 am on all days is prohibiting all the non-essential activities. Week-end curfew from 5 am on Saturday up to 5 am on Monday has further dented their earnings. Deputy commissioner Girish Dayalan said following the orders of the chief minister, the home department has issued a detailed order imposing additional restrictions to be strictly imposed throughout the state.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/traders-on-roads-against-pb-govts-pick-and-choose-policy/articleshow/82442899.cms||---

---||Pune||Availability of hospital beds with O2 support improves||Pune: Availability of beds with oxygen support has improved across the district with an increase in the number of such facilities.Around two weeks ago, the district had 14,068 beds. These included oxygen supported beds and intensive care unit (ICU) beds, with and without ventilator support. Of these, only 476 beds were available.The number of such beds increased to 16,185 by Thursday, of which 1,984 are available. The vacancy has particularly improved in the Pimpri Chinchwad civic limits, where 882 oxygen supported beds and 127 ICU beds (without ventilator support) are vacant. In Pune civic limits, the number of oxygen supported beds has improved (See graphic). Experts said the improvement in oxygen supply in the region, its judicious use by hospitals and a dip in the out-patient department patients was expected to ease the situation further in the coming days.Rajesh Patil, commissioner of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC), told TOI, “The main reason for the improvement in the number of oxygen support beds in the twin towns is that we have focussed on the health of patients in home isolation. We ensured that their health updates are collected on time and they recover while in home isolation. It has worked and the bed vacancy has improved. The war room inspection, dedicated call centre and the helpline are some of the measures that have played a key role.”He added that the number of positive patients per day was steady with a 21% positivity rate from last week. “The positivity rate had gone up to 32% two weeks ago,” he said.Subhash Salunke, adviser to the state government on Covid-19 and former director general of health services (Maharashtra), told TOI that the bed availability was indeed improving across the region. “But we are focussing on improving the vacancy of ICU beds. Even the cases seem to be going down. But we cannot afford to be complacent,” he said.Sanjay Patil, chairman of the Indian Medical Association’s Hospital Board of India, said the use of oxygen, as well as the availability of oxygen supported beds, has improved in the region. “We should, however, be aware that it can be a temporary trend,” he said.Kiran Thorat, owner of Care Lifeline Hospital in Thergaon, said the streamlining of oxygen supply in the civic limits had helped in easing O2-related emergencies. Pune Municipal Corporation’s Congress leader Ulhas aka Aba Bagul claimed that the civic body’s helpline was not offering adequate information about bed availability. “Instead of providing urgent and immediate information, the person offering assistance via helpline seeks patients’ details such as oxygen saturation and HR-CT score. This leads to delay in treatment,” Bagul said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/availability-of-hospital-beds-with-o2-support-improves/articleshow/82442909.cms||Piyush Bhusari
---||Surat||Vaccination stalls spread of virus among cops this yr||Surat: Altogether 711 personnel from city’s more than 5,600-strong police force had been infected with coronavirus since the pandemic began. Of these, eight have died, four in 2020 and the other half this year. The four victims of this year had not been vaccinated, said a senior police official. In 2020, nearly 500 cops got infected, while the remaining 211 turned Covid-19 positive during 2021. According to officials, the rate of infection in the second wave has remained low among the ranks is because of vaccination. “Surat city police is at the top of vaccination list in the state with 95 percent of its staff getting the first dose of vaccine, while 86 percent got the second dose as well. Due to vaccination the cases are less in police even when they come in direct contact with many people daily,” city police commissioner Ajay Tomar told TOI. Of the 5,609 personnel in city police 5,320 have got their first dose of vaccine. Those who are yet to get the jab include those who have been advised by doctors. Currently 163 cops are Covid-19 positive, of whom one has been shifted to hospital for treatment while others are in home isolation. “Due to vaccination, those who are infected have minor illness and are recovering well. I talked to cop Jaswantsinh Bariya who is in the hospital on Thursday and he is now out of oxygen support. He will be discharged soon,” said Tomar.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/surat/vaccination-stalls-spread-of-virus-among-cops-this-yr/articleshow/82439585.cms||Yagnesh Bharat Mehta
---||Pune||Demand rises for drive-in vaccination hub in city||Pune: Political leaders have sought a drive-in vaccination centre for areas in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) limits on the lines of the facility that will be provided by Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC). “Physically challenged citizens and senior citizens will be able to get the vaccine there without getting down from their cars,” said MLA Chetan Tupe. The drive-in vaccination centre administers vaccine to people while they are seated in their vehicles. After getting their shots, they can spend the mandatory 30-minute observation period inside their vehicle as well. The beneficiaries must pay the parking charges until they drive out. The drive-in vaccination centre has been set up following a demand for home vaccination of those unable to queue up outside centres and the inoculation drive is still to take off in housing societies. “The initiative is a must for Pune residents. It isn’t possible for such people to visit vaccination sites, so it should be provided to them at the doorstep,” said Tupe. He has written to the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) urging the civic body set up a drive-in vaccination site. PMC officials said the civic administration will carry out vaccination as per instructions provided by the state government. “The civic administration has been carrying out vaccinations across the city areas. Vaccination drives are being held even at workplaces. The decision about a drive-in vaccination facility will be taken in due course of time, subject to availability of doses,” said a senior PMC official. Earlier this week, Mumbai’s first drive-in vaccination centre started at BMC’s Kohinoor Parking Lot in Dadar. Hundreds queued up to get the elderly and immobile patients vaccinated.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/demand-rises-for-drive-in-vaccination-hub-in-city/articleshow/82442911.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Anil Deshmukh can move vacation bench, says Bombay HC||MUMBAI: A bench of Justice S S Shinde and Justice Manish Pitale on Thursday adjourned the petition filed by former home minister Anil Deshmukh and observed that since the CBI had been served it on Wednesday and had asked for time, it should be given reasonable time to file its reply. In the petition, Deshmukh sought quashing of the FIR field against him by the CBI. The high court then gave Deshmukh liberty to move the vacation bench in case of extreme urgency with 48-hour notice to the CBI. The bench passed an order stating that Singh had sought four weeks, which is “vehemently opposed by Desai” who submits “there is an urgency”. The high court said it was inclined to grant the CBI reasonable time to file its reply, but on Desai’s request, granted Deshmukh liberty to approach the court for any extremely urgent relief during the court vacation, but with prior notice to the CBI. Deshmukh’s petition said the FIR followed a “biased, dubious” inquiry, “with ulterior motive at the behest of those having political or other vendetta” against him. Calling the first information report (FIR) against him “false”, Deshmukh said that prior sanction was necessary to register the FIR against him as he was a minister when the offence was alleged to have occurred. He said the FIR made “bald and vague allegations” and no case of allegations of “illegal gratification” under Section 7 of the PCA or criminal conspiracy under Section 120B of the IPC. The FIR is to have him “arrested, with an ulterior motive”, said the former minister. The petition said the high directed the CBI to conduct a preliminary inquiry and to take further steps “in accordance with law”. He said since the state had last year withdrawn its general consent to the CBI for investigation of offences occurring here, barring a direct order by the high court or the Supreme Court, which was lacking in the case, the agency could not lodge an FIR and investigate it.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/deshmukh-can-move-vacation-bench-says-bombay-hc/articleshow/82443033.cms||---
---||Pune||Zoo officials step up safety of big cats||Pune: Authorities at the Rajiv Gandhi Zoological Park have stepped up monitoring of big cats at the facility after eight lions tested positive for Covid-19 at a Hyderabad zoo recently. Zoo director Rajkumar Jadhav said that instructions have been given to the entire staff taking care of big cats to be on high alert and ensure optimum sanitization and hygiene. “As per instructions of the Central Zoo Authority, all measures are being followed since last year. However, with information coming in from the Hyderabad Zoo, we have become even more alert. The team of veterinarians have been instructed to observe the cats each day and look for any unusual behavior,” he said. The zoo, which is under the Pune Municipal Corporation, houses two lions, six tigers and three leopards apart from other animals. The official said that special care has been taken to ensure that the meat was safe for animal consumption. “Instructions have been given to put the meat in boiling water for at least 10 minutes before serving it to big cats. Also, before starting work in the cages, attendants must wear masks, boots, gloves and ensure that their boots are disinfected. Unless it is urgent, the cats should be left alone,” he said. All municipal gardens, including the zoo, have been closed due to the pandemic. “The stress is on daily examination of big cats by the team of doctors. If needed, we will contact the Central Zoo Authority. Presently, all big cats at the zoo are doing fine. Every staff member at the zoo has taken one or two doses of the vaccine,” Jadhav said. The staff members have been asked to keep two different sets of clothes on campus. They are not allowed to wear the same clothes while commuting to work when they are on duty. An arrangement was made at the entry gate of the zoo for disinfectants and sanitisation, an official said. (With inputs from Prasad Kulkarni)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/zoo-officials-step-up-safety-of-big-cats/articleshow/82442918.cms||Joy Sengupta

---||Lucknow||Uttar Pradesh Cabinet nod to 25% honorarium for health staff on Covid-19 duty||LUCKNOW: The state cabinet on Thursday approved a Covid honorarium, entailing the payment of additional 25% over and above the regular pay, for heatlh workers deployed in Covid wards at government hospitals. The decision will be applicable retrospectively from May 1, 2021. Principal secretary (medical education) Alok Kumar said the step had been taken to not just increase available manpower in the state but also to boost the morale of health workers who had been working hard to combat the pandemic for over a year. The approval came three days after chief minister Yogi Adityanath declared that an honorarium would be given to health workers. “The cabinet on Thursday approved the additional pay to health workers, including doctors, ward boys, nurses, cleaners and anyone who is performing duty in Covid wards. They will get an additional 25% of their salary above their monthly payout," Kumar said. The increment will also be applicable on outsourced employees who will get 25% additional payment over their monthly remuneration,” Kumar said, adding that it was the government’s way of letting them know that it was with them in the hour of crisis. Citing the possibility of the third wave of coronavirus later in the year, as suggested by experts, Kumar said it was necessary for the government to arrange for trained manpower. “For this, the government has taken two crucial decisions. It has been decided for the first time ever daily stipend would be given to MBBS interns or those in their final year, and final year students of MSc and BSc (nursing) and technicians. The government has fixed daily stipend of Rs 500 for those doing internship after MBBS, Rs 400 for MSc (nursing), Rs 300 for BSc (nursing), and Rs 300 for those in MBBS final year. Active quarantine will be included in this package along with allowance for food, as is given to other Covid staff,” he said. Through the health and medical education departments, the government will also release an advertisement for hiring of retired health workers and those in private sector who would volunteer to work in Covid wards. They will be paid 25% more than the approved rate under the National Health Mission. The hiring of such persons will be decentralised. Interviews and appointments will be conducted by principals of medical colleges and the district health committee of health department, which is headed by the district magistrate and the chief medical officer as secretary. “We are expecting a monthly expenditure of Rs 50 crore on these initiatives. This will be applicable from May 1 to July 31, 2021 and will be extended, if necessary,” Kumar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/cabinet-nod-to-25-honorarium-for-health-staff-on-covid-19-duty/articleshow/82444985.cms||---

We have alerted the state police and nearby police stations about the incident,” police said. Ravi Solanki was recently arrested in house break-in crime while Gordhan Nayak, a native of Madhya Pradesh, was arrested in a murder case a few months ago. ---||India||Media has right to report exchanges during hearings: SC||NEW DELHI: Moving away from a nine-year-old judgment putting curbs on coverage of court proceedings to protect the rights of the accused, the Supreme Court on Thursday said the media had an unfettered right to report exchanges during hearings as it rejected the Election Commission's plea that the media be restricted to publishing only court orders and judgments. A bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and M R Shah said, "This court stands as a staunch proponent of the freedom of the media to report court proceedings. This, we believe, is integral to the freedom of speech and expression of those who speak, of those who wish to hear and to be heard and above all, in holding the judiciary accountable to the values which justify its existence as a constitutional institution." Citing the fillip the freedom struggle got from the reportage of Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak's sedition trial, the bench said, "The heart of the matter, which is the first prayer that the EC has raised - that of seeking a restraint on the media on reporting court proceedings. The basis of its application was that nothing apart from what forms a part of the official judicial record should be reported. This prayer of the EC strikes at two fundamental principles guaranteed under the Constitution - open court proceedings, and the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression." Importantly, the court brought up the issue of livestreaming of court proceedings, as is the practice in the Supreme Courts of the US and the UK. Justice Chandrachud said though the SC three years ago in the Swapnil Tripathi case had in principle approved the live telecast of SC hearings and suggested the modalities, it is yet to implement the same in letter and spirit. Times ViewCourt orders are important. So are observations made during the hearings. These days several online media organisations also tweet observations live. Objecting to news flow in any form would actually mean denying people the right to full information. It is great that the apex court has embraced the need of the times."Unless livestreaming and archival of court proceedings sees the light of day (three years have elapsed since the decision in Swapnil Tripathi), the absence of records of oral proceedings will continue to bedevil the system," Justice Chandrachud said while ruing the absence of material to confirm Madras HC's purported hurtful remarks against the EC, which was widely reported in the media, causing consternations to the constitutional body mandated to conduct free and fair elections. "With the advent of technology, we are seeing reporting proliferate through social media forums which provide real-time updates to a much wider audience. This is an extension of the freedom of speech and expression that the media possesses. This constitutes a virtual extension of the open court. This phenomenon is not a cause of apprehension, but a celebration of our constitutional ethos which bolsters the integrity of the judiciary by focusing attention on its functions," the bench said. Watch Courts can't stop media from reporting: Supreme Court||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/media-has-right-to-report-exchanges-during-hearings-sc/articleshow/82447140.cms||Dhananjay Mahapatra
---||Kanpur||Lion tests Covid positive at Etawah Safari||Faiz.Siddiqui@timesgroup.com Kanpur: An Asiatic lion has tested positive for the novel coronavirus infection, aaising an alarm in Etawah Lion Safari. Swabs of 14 Asiatic lions in Etawah Safari had been sent to Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), Izatnagar, Bareilly, for RT-PCR tests for Covid-19. The institute conducted the tests and found one lion positive for the infection, while another was considered as a suspected case. Rest 12 lions have tested negative. As per sources, Safari authorities had raised an alarm a few days ago when they came across two lions coughing and suffering from a runny nose besides loss of appetite. Talking to TOI, joint director Centre for Animal Disease Research and Diagnosis (CADRAD) at IVRI, Bareilly, Dr KP Singh said, the Covid test report of one lion was positive while one seems to be a suspected case. Dr Singh said the chain of transmission of virus could have taken place through any asymptomatic human carrier, probably caretakers, working at the Safari. “We have asked the safari authorities to shift the infected animals in complete isolation and to instruct the caretakers to wear protective gear and masks,” he added. The Safari has been shut for public as a precautionary measure. The Etawah Lion Safari authorities said the two lions are undergoing treatment at the veterinary hospital in the premises and all necessary precautions are being taken.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kanpur/lion-tests-covid-positive-at-etawah-safari/articleshow/82442593.cms||Faiz Rahman Siddiqui

---||Kanpur||Uttar Pradesh: 11 out of 15 new containment zones located in rural areas||PRAYAGRAJ: With the number of containment zones rising in trans-Ganga and trans-Yamuna pockets, the officials of the health department have intensified sample collection exercise in rural areas. Sample this: 11 out of 15 new containment zones, declared by the joint team of police, health and administration on Wednesday, are located in rural areas. Officials said that testing will not only detect new Covid cases, but will also help in mapping high containment zones and framing an intervention plan. The massive testing drive is an effort towards breaking the chain of the deadly virus in villages and blocks. Nodal officer and additional chief medical officer (ACMO) Dr Rishi Sahai told TOI, “An aggressive door-to-door surveillance has been taken up in all 23 blocks of the district. He added, “A total of 60 health teams are monitoring the situation in Naini, Phaphamau, Soroan, Jari Bazar, Chak Dodi (Arail), Phulpur, Tikri, Esmileganj, Jhunsi and other rural areas after a surge in Covid cases was reported in these areas this week.” Teams are focusing on looking for people with Covid-like symptoms, and getting them tested. Random antigen and RT-PCR tests in crowded pockets have also been carried out. As vegetable markets and mandis operate only in the mornings in trans-Ganga and Yamuna areas, a testing drive among vendors has also been planned. A senior health official, meanwhile, said that rising Covid cases has also impacted the vaccination drive. Less number of beneficiaries is turning up at vaccination centres in rural areas. RRTs (rapid response teams) are surveying and testing every house in each ward, whenever required. Now, teams have also been engaged to conduct contact tracing of positive patients and ensure their treatment. Teams, with the help of monitoring committees, have also been asked to visit the houses of migrants who had recently returned from big cities like Mumbai, Delhi, Ahemdabad and Benguluru. Between May 1 and 5, a total of 58,292 samples were collected for testing—11,743 on May 5, 11,434 on May 4, 11,770 on May 3, 10,006 on May 2 and 13,339 on May 1. As many as 4,271 positive cases were detected, including 596 on May 5, 683 on May 4, 863 on May 3, 984 on May 2 and 1,145 on May 1. A majority of cases was detected from rural areas, and this forced the health authorities to turn their attention towards rural pockets for carrying out 3Ts (testing, tracking and treating).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kanpur/11-out-of-15-new-containment-zones-located-in-rural-areas/articleshow/82442782.cms||---
---||Goa||Entry into Goa only with Covid -ve certificate: HC; difficult, says CM||PANAJI: With Goa’s “high positivity rate” of Covid-19 cases continuing to wreak havoc in the tiniest state, the high court of Bombay at Goa on Thursday directed the government to ensure that no persons are permitted entry into the state from May 10 onwards without a negative certificate. Remarking that the state should have imposed these minimum restrictions on its own, a division bench comprising justices M S Sonak and M S Jawalkar—hearing a slew of public interest litigations on the government measures to stop the spread of the pandemic—in an interim order told the “state administration to ensure that no persons are permitted entry into the state unless they possess a negative certificate obtained within 72 hours from the time they seek entry into the state.” Hours after the high court order, chief minister Pramod Sawant said seeking a Covid-negative certificate from every person entering Goa will burden the already strained state administration and infrastructure. “It is okay if it is a tourist you are asking for a certificate. What about those who come by train? What do we do when one does not have a Covid-negative certificate? State will again have to do their tests for free, provide them food. Already there is such a strain at present on the entire administration. But we will submit the affidavit sought from us,” he said. Earlier advocate general Devidas Pangam had told the court that Goa relies on neighbouring states for most essentials and the insistence on a negative certificate will impact supplies. He submitted that the central government does not support sealing borders of any state during these times. “We see no justification in the state of Goa not insisting on a negative certificate from persons who seek entry into Goa at this crucial juncture when reports indicate that the positivity rate in Goa is as high as 52%. Some suitable mechanisms can always be formulated by the state to ensure that some testing facilities are available at the borders or entry points so that the supply of essentialities or the ingress of essential personnel are not affected,” the court observed. TOI in a series of reports for over a month has been highlighting the state’s unpreparedness in dealing with the second wave and insisting on stringent curbs to stop the spread of the killer virus and transparency measures to benefit the people of Goa. Sawant said if the state starts asking every person entering Goa for a negative certificate, then they would have to ask from even truckers who bring in milk, vegetables and chicken. “If we ask them for certificates, they will be unable to produce it... we need to give this a thought,” he said. But the high court had made it clear that the state government can formulate a protocol to deal with the issues of essential supplies and the procedure for entry of persons involved in essential supplies and said, “Citing such instances to justify wholesale waiver of restrictions in such critical times is not justifiable in any case. This issue will arise mainly to travellers by road”. Referring to those entering the state by train and flight, the HC said, “It is too much to suggest that all such travellers are mainly involved in supplying essential services or goods in Goa. The state government will, therefore, have to insist upon a negative certificate before such persons enter Goa.” The HC said the interim direction will be effective from May 10 to enable the state administration to publicise the new measures. With the situation “spiralling out of control”, the court has also sought to know from the government whether there is any thought process on the issue of lockdown. The court was hearing PILs filed by South Goa Advocates’ Association, Armando Gonsalves and Roshan Mathias regarding the difficulties faced in terms of oxygen supply, medical infrastructure, supply of essential medicines, testing facilities and vaccination drive. The petitions also sought to know the measures adopted by the government to prevent the spread of the epidemic, including banning mass gatherings, social distancing, entry of persons into the state and lockdown. While seeking an affidavit regarding the oxygen requirement and stock of essential medicines, the court asked the government to bring in transparency about the availability of medical facilities by putting the information in the public domain. It observed that this would avoid “unnecessary anxiety” and “rumour mongering”. The court also sought information about the steps taken to augment stocks of essential medicines available in the state. The case is likely to come up for hearing on May 11. The court directed the government to provide adequate protection to healthcare professionals at hospitals. Regarding their security, the court said, “We are quite mindful of the fact that patients and their relatives are stressed out and even desperate. Nevertheless, a message must go out loud and clear that there will be zero tolerance for any form of physical or verbal violence against healthcare professionals. Such violence is simply not acceptable and must be dealt with by a firm hand.” Referring to Supreme Court directions issued to the Centre to collaborate with states to prepare a buffer stock of oxygen for emergency purposes, the high court asked the state administration to indicate whether all such facilities are in place. The court also sought to know about the status of oxygen availability. It has directed the government to file an affidavit on oxygen requirements and the steps taken by the administration to have plants to manufacture oxygen in the state itself.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/entry-into-goa-only-with-covid-ve-certificate-hc-difficult-says-cm/articleshow/82445384.cms||---
---||Pune||Low vaccine reserves likely to impact 45-plus drive in Pune district||PUNE: A rapid depletion of Covishield reserves in the district is now likely to impact the vaccination drive for the 45-plus age group. Officials said this category is dependent on Covishield supply from the Centre to the state, which then distributes it to districts. On Tuesday night, Pune district got around 73,800 doses of the vaccine. Thursday’s drive used up 65,000 doses. Officials said Pune district received around 25,000 Covishield doses on Thursday evening from the Centre, which will be used for the 45+ category. But preference will be given to those who are due for their second dose. Sanjay Deshmukh, assistant director (medical), Pune circle, said, “PMC and Pune rural have been given 10,000 doses each. Since these doses are coming from the Centre to the state, they will be used only for the 45-plus age group.” As for Covaxin, Deshmukh said the earlier batch of 32,000 doses the district received was procured by the state directly from Bharat Biotech. He said, “This stock is being used for the 18-44 group.” Rajesh Patil, PCMC commissioner, said, “We have been told that vaccine supply will improve. Until then, we are managing with whatever stock we have.” On Thursday, as many as 22,957 beneficiaries in the district got their Covid shots. A total of 6,500 were from the 18-44 age group. More than 1,000 people in the 45-plus group were given their second jab.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/low-vaccine-reserves-likely-to-impact-45-plus-drive-in-district/articleshow/82442935.cms||Piyush Bhusari
---||Varanasi||3 panchayat poll resultsrevised after recounting||GORAKHPUR: After supporters of two district panchayat member election candidates staged massive protests and set afire a police post alleging anomalies in counting, Gorakhpur district magistrate supervised booth-wise matching of votes and declared revised results and also ordered action against the returning officer. On Wednesday afternoon, two candidates, Ravi Nishad from district panchayat ward number 60 and Kodai Nishad from ward number 61 had claimed they had won the election with over 2,000 votes but the certificate of victory was given to Gopal Yadav for ward number 60 and Ramesh aka Gabbar Yadav for ward number 61. The candidates and their supporters alleged anomalies and staged protests that went on till late evening. The recounting started at around 11pm on Wednesday under the supervision of DM K. Vijayendra Pandian during which difference of 2,000 votes was detected. In revised results after recounting, the DM declared Ravi Nishad as winner from ward number 60 and Kodai Nishad from ward number 61. The DM handed them certificates of victory on Thursday morning. In another case of result correction, Devsharan was declared winner from ward number 45 after probe found that the returning officer had sent correct report declaring him as the winner, but there had been a clerical mistake at district headquarters. There were complaints from ward number 21 and 32, but the results were found correct. Speaking to reporters, the DM said, “There were complaints of errors in counting in district panchayat ward numbers 21, 32, 45, 60 and 61. After booth-wise matching of votes, the results of ward number 21 and 32 were found correct and clerical mistake was found in the result of ward number 45.” “An FIR has been lodged against the returning officer Virendra Kumar, who is executive engineer in irrigation department and a letter for action against him would be written to Election Commission,” he added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/varanasi/3-panchayat-poll-resultsrevised-after-recounting/articleshow/82442690.cms||---
---||Pune||Experts for audit of dead-stock of oxygen cylinders idle at private isolation centres||PUNE: Medical experts involved in treating patients at Covid-19 hospitals have urged officials to conduct audit of the dead stock of medical oxygen cylinders lying idle with the private isolation centres in the city. Altogether 33 private facilities, most of them offering paid care along with meals and comfortable ambiance, have come up at hotels, recreational centres and wedding halls in the past two months. Besides, there are five Pune Municipal Corporation-run Covid care centres meant for asymptomatic and mild patients who do not have separate room and toilet at home and cannot afford care at the private facilities “The current scene is paradoxical. On one hand, the city has so many private isolation facilities with a sizeable amount of dead-stock of oxygen cylinders lying unused. On the other hand, several small Covid hospitals with ICU units either stopping new admissions or shifting their patients to big hospitals for want of medical oxygen,” said Sanjay Patil, chairman of the Indian Medical Association's Hospital Board of India (Pune branch) — an association of small and medium-sized hospitals in Pune. “Keeping a few cylinders for emergency use is reasonable enough. But many private Covid care centres in the city have made a provision of huge oxygen storage tank, called Dura, which is equivalent to 30 jumbo cylinders. We want the Pune Municipal Corporation authorities to audit the use of oxygen cylinders at such CCCs and give out some of this stock to the small hospitals on a rotational basis," Patil said. “Many asymptomatic or mildly infected patients from affording class want to remain under medical supervision 24X7. The private isolation facilities mainly cash in on them,” said health activist Abhijit More.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/experts-for-audit-of-dead-stock-of-o2-cylinders-idle-at-pvt-isolation-centres/articleshow/82442942.cms||Umesh Isalkar
