---||Hyderabad||Hyderabad: HCA wrangling refuses to end||HYDERABAD: The administrative tug of war in the Hyderabad Cricket Association (HCA) continues. In a contentious move, secretary R Vijayanand, on Thursday morning named M Narayana as Officer on Special Duty (OSD) to ombudsman Justice (retd) Nisar Ahmed Kukur and ethics officer Justice (retd) T Meena Kumar. President Mohammed Azharuddin termed the appointment illegal and a serious violation of the rules and procedures laid down by the Lodha committee. “He (Narayana) will be available during office hours and all complaints will be received by him and the same will be referred to the ombudsman and ethics officer depending on the case,” reads a communication from the secretary to HCA members. The appointment of ombudsman and ethics officer has been a bone of contention with two groups naming different judges for the position. Recently the Ranga Reddy court had stated that “the ombudsman and the ethics officers hadn’t taken charge.” HCA has sought clarification of the high court judgment by filing a Special Leave Petition (SLP) in the Supreme court, which is pending for listing.” “When the officials haven’t still taken charge, what was the necessity to appoint an OSD for them,” questioned a club secretary. In his letter to the club secretaries, Azharuddin questioned the move and spelt out reasons why the appointment was illegal. “Under rule 19 (2) & rule 24 (13), the power to lay guidelines and manage day to day affairs of the association is the function of the CEO. The secretary cannot assume the powers of the CEO and therefore the order is in violation of the rules,” he said. The president added that the AGM on April 11 ratified the appointment of Justice (retd) Deepak Verma as ombudsman under Rule 8(3)(f) — an appointment contested by the secretary. “Any other name projected as the ombudsman is illegal and contrary to rules." Azhar also said that five members of the Apex council, including the secretary, are facing an inquiry by the ombudsman under Rule 41 (1) (b) of the HCA constitution and cannot make such appointments. He urged the members to ignore the illegal communication of the secretary. “I have been fighting a battle since the last 18 months to prevent illegality in functioning of the HCA. The clean-up should start from the top of the structure. I request you all to ignore the illegal communication of the secretary,” Azharuddin said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/hca-wrangling-refuses-to-end/articleshow/82442946.cms||Solomon S Kumar
---||Shimla||Markets crowded on ‘corona curfew’ eve||MANALI: People in the hill state thronged markets to stock up on groceries, medicines and other essentials on the eve of the 10-day corona curfew, which is to begin on Friday. Long queues of customers were seen outside grocery, bakery, medicine and other shops in all districts. SOPs regarding corona curfew reached people late on Wednesday night. Although shops selling essentials will remain open, private vehicles will be allowed only for emergency purposes. For the first time in many days, markets received many customers with everyone stocking up on essentials. Newlywed couple Pradeep and Shalini bought ration for two months and stocked vegetables for a few days. Pradeep said SOPs on curfew were unclear but all he could understand was that people could travel only using public transport facilities. “Travelling in buses is not safe these days and private vehicles will not be allowed by the police. I’m not stocking essentials but buying them in advance to avoid any problem during the curfew,” he said. People also thronged medicine shops, with most buyers getting vitamin C, zink, multi-vitamins, face masks and sanitiser bottles. Gagan Chaudhary, who bought a packet of medical face masks and a few bottles of hand sanitiser said, “The cost of all products required to protect us from Covid-19 is likely to increase in the coming days. Consumption of these masks has increased in the last few days as we are using double masks – one woollen mask and one medical mask.” Even electronics, readymade garments, hair and beauty salons received many customers all day. People also flocked at petrol pumps. Corona curfew will remain in force in Himachal from 6am on May 7 to 6am on May 17. Most people feel that the government will extend curfew after 10 days. Emergency movement will continue and construction, farming as well as horticultural work will not be stopped. Public transport will be allowed to operate at 50% capacity. Movement of labourers for various construction works will also be allowed. Deputy commissioners of all districts on Thursday also issued guidelines regarding corona curfew.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/shimla/markets-crowded-on-corona-curfew-eve/articleshow/82442940.cms||---
---||Pune||3.6 crore Covishield doses sent from Pune airport last month||PUNE: As many as 3.6 crore doses of the Covishield vaccine, manufactured by the city-based Serum Institute of India, were dispatched from the Pune airport in April — the highest so far and nearly three times the number dispatched in January. As per figures provided by the Pune airport authorities, 1.26 crore doses were transported in January, 1.39 crore in February and 2.03 crore doses in March. Officials said large consignments were being transported this month too. Further, officials said, 2.16 lakh doses were sent from the Pune airport to other countries in February; a chartered flight had carried 18 boxes of the vaccine to Suriname, St Kitts, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Antigua, Barbuda, and St Lucia. “It is a continuous process and we are providing all the help to the airlines and the cargo logistics company under the Airports Authority of India. Ninety-seven boxes containing 9.87 lakh doses were transported on two flights to Delhi, Kolkata, Bengaluru, and Hyderabad on May 5. On May 4, as many as 37 boxes containing 4.20 lakh doses were sent to Delhi, for onward delivery to cities like Karnal, Dehradun, Jammu, and Srinagar. On May 3 too, 127 boxes containing 15.04 lakh doses were sent to Jaipur, Delhi, Hyderabad, and Bengaluru. Two lakh doses were sent to Jaipur on May 1,” an official said. Airport officials close to the development said vaccine transport was one of the reasons for the postponement of the complete closure of the airport for runway repairs||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/3-6cr-covishield-doses-sent-from-pune-airport-last-month/articleshow/82442945.cms||Joy Sengupta
---||Allahabad||Only 87 cops infected in second Covid wave so far||PRAYAGRAJ: Call it the impact of vaccination or strict adherence to Covid protocol, only 87 policemen have tested positive in the second wave of coronavirus in Prayagraj range so far. The number of infected policemen in the second Covid wave is one-eighth of that in the first wave. In the first wave last year, as many as 669 policemen tested positive, and four of them also lost their lives. The 669 infected cops included 295 in Prayagraj, 78 in Kaushambi, 101 in Fatehpur and 194 in Pratapgarh. Four infected policemen who died included one in Prayagraj and three in Pratapgarh. In the ongoing second wave, a total of 87 policemen, including 39 in Prayagraj district, nine in Kaushambi, six in Fatehpur and 33 in Pratapgarh district tested positive so far. IG (Prayargaj range) K P Singh told TOI that the number of policemen who got infected with Covid-19 in the second wave is one-eight of that in the first Covid wave. He added that there are a total of 14,769 policemen posted in Prayagraj range—6,889 in Prayagraj district, 2,053 in Kaushambi, 2,958 in Fatehpur and 2,889 in Pratapgarh district. Out of the 14,759 policemen, 13,915 have take the first dose of Covid vaccine. Out of these 13,915 policemen, 13,292 have taken the second jab as well. There are only 858 policemen in Prayagraj range who have not taken the first jab yet, while 1,477 policemen are yet to take the second dose of vaccination. In Prayargraj district, out of 6,889 policemen, 6,493 have taken the first jab, while 6,471 policemen have taken the second dose as well. In Kaushambi district, out of 2,053 policemen, 1,983 have taken the first jab and 1,815 policemen have taken second jab also. In Fatehpur district, out of 2,958 policemen, 2,653 have taken the first dose and 2,445 have taken the second dose also. In Pratapgarh district, out of 2,889 policemen, 2,786 have taken the first jab, while 2,561 have also taken the second dose of vaccination. The IG said that the 858 policemen in the range who haven’t taken even the first dose of vaccine include 376 in Prayagraj, 70 in Kaushambi, 305 in Fatehpur and 103 in Pratapgarh. Similarly, 398 policemen in Prayagraj, 238 in Kaushambi, 513 in Fatehpur and 328 in Pratapgarh have not taken the second dose yet. IG Singh further said that all policemen are frontline workers and the SPs of all four districts have been asked to ensure cent per cent vaccination of the police forces.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/allahabad/only-87-cops-infected-in-second-covid-wave-so-far/articleshow/82442747.cms||---

---||Kanpur||BHU closed till May 15,exams not before June 30||VARANASI: In a bid to halt the spread of the second wave of coronavirus, the Banaras Hindu University (BHU) authorities have decided to suspend all academic activities, including online classes till May 15, but the official work will be conducted in work from home mode. BHU spokesperson Rajesh Singh said, “A high-level meeting presided over by vice-chancellor Prof. V K Shukla was held on Wednesday to discuss measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus and it was decided to close BHU till May 15.” The directors of all institutes, deans, controller of examination, dean of students’ welfare, registrar, chief proctor and other senior officials had attended the meeting. “It was also decided that the university examinations would not be conducted before June 30. Online classes will also remain suspended during this period but official work will be done in work from home mode. All the officials and employees will remain available on phone. However, the heads of departments can call staff if it becomes necessary,” Singh added. Attempts are on to start a vaccination drive soon.” There are 200 forest personnel in every district and their total strength is approximately 5,000 across the state. It is also stated as summers have approached, many a times the staff have to combat wildfires with the assistance of local villagers. As forest staff have an interface with villagers, it exposes them to the virus. Also, Chief Medical Health Officer (CMHO) certificate is required to authenticate the patient’s fitness and avail quarantine leaves. The new employees can avail earned leaves, casual leaves, and medical leaves only after completing service of three years. Moreover, procuring medical staff from a CMHO remains a task.” It was further informed that it is also difficult to procure certificate from the CMHO if a treatment has taken place in a private hospital or at home. Narayana’s wife Shanta Bai was also asking for an acre and he was unwilling to give them any share. Angry with Narayana, the accused killed him,” the SI said. Department employees have been engaged in Covid duties in hospitals in many districts, but not a single preventive measure like PPE kit or masks were provided by the government. They also do not come under frontline workers. Rajasthan Veterinary Service Association general secretary Arjun Singh said, “This is quite shameful that our lives do not have any value. We need support from the administration, but even after losing 10 employees, not a single reaction from our minister Lal Chand Kataria shows that government is not serious about us. ---||Goa||Civic bodies must aid those in home isolation, says govt||Panaji: Panchayats and municipalities have been instructed by the state disaster management authority to help in keeping Covid-19 patients in their areas indoors. The local bodies should help those in home isolation in procuring essentials, the directives stated. Civic bodies have also been asked to maintain confidentiality of the patients while helping them so that the infected persons do not face social stigma. “Covid positive in home isolation need to be monitored to avoid spread of infection. Panchayats and municipal bodies have been asked to monitor the infected. The list will be shared by the respective health officers of the directorate of health services,” member secretary of state disaster management authority, Sanjay Kumar said. Panchayats and municipalities may provide support to these persons with provisions like medicines, food or any other items required by them. The local bodies should also help to provide the patients with ambulance support in case they need it to be taken for hospitalisation, Kumar has said. Civic bodies should ensure that the restrictions imposed by the collectors under Section 144 are being strictly adhered to in the respective areas and to make sure that establishments which have been directed to remain shut follow the orders. “They may take the support of local police for the same in coordination with the deputy collectors, who may also be informed in case of violation or non-compliance of orders,” Kumar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/civic-bodies-must-aid-those-in-home-isolation-says-govt/articleshow/82445139.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Ahmedabad: Dip in new cases but bed availability still an issue||AHMEDABAD: For the second consecutive day, new cases in Ahmedabad city were less than patients discharged, reducing the number of active cases. Against 3,884 new cases, 5,013 patients — 1,129 more than the new cases — got discharged. The state health department website put the number of active cases in Ahmedabad district at 66,466, or about 38% of the state’s total active cases. The fall in cases reduced bed occupancy marginally. On Thursday, 86% of 6,696 beds were occupied. The number was 92% on Wednesday. “After a long time, 7 beds with ventilator and 29 ICU beds were vacant. It’s sa good sign. Occupancy went below 90% after about one and a half months. Bed availability, however, might still be an issue at major hospitals,” said a senior member of Ahmedabad Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association (AHNA). The long queues of ambulances on the Civil Hospital campus were non-existent. Sources, however, attributed the phenomenon to a change in protocol where hospitals call ambulances to bring in patients depending on vacancies. Meanwhile, there was ruckus at Dhanvantari Hospital due to delay in handing over a body. The kin raised a stink after the phone line to talk to patients went kaput. The authorities, claimed the issues were later ironed out. On Thursday, the state health department issued a new directive for admission of Covid patients where positive RT-PCR reports was no longer a necessity if a patient showed Covid symptoms. S/he can be admitted and treatment would be started, said officials. Gujarat on Thursday crossed 8,000 Covid deaths. The state is 10th in mortality in India. Analysis of the figures reveal that the last 1,000 deaths were recorded in seven days, the second fastest. The fastest 1,000 deaths were recorded in six days between April 24 and 29.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/dip-in-new-cases-but-bed-availability-still-an-issue/articleshow/82441299.cms||---
---||Hyderabad||‘Some sold plots at higher price, made crores’||Hyderabad: The CID further alleged that the accused in the case orchestrated notification of GO No. 41 much against the opinions expressed by senior officials, then advocate general and then law secretary in violation of law. As per GO 41 issued in 2016, the beneficiaries fall under encroachers’ list in objectionable land, which was originally part of Krishna river. “Claims of several individuals in violation of the law were considered and annuity was paid, causing loss to the APCRDA,” the CID alleged.  The GO was not placed before the council of ministers or the legislative assembly as mandated by the APCRDA Act. “Claimants who offered land under the LPS were close associates and strong activists of TDP,” it said. The CID further alleged that these persons had prior knowledge about GO 41 and created a panic among gullible persons that government would take away their lands with no returnable benefits. “After creating panic, the accused entered into unregistered sale agreements and sales with the assignees by paying meagre amounts. After the agreements, they submitted the land for pooling and got plots worth crores from the APCRDA. Some of them sold these allotted plots at higher prices and made crores,” it added. tnn||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/some-sold-plots-at-higher-price-made-crores/articleshow/82442963.cms||---
---||Jaipur||Rajasthan: Fuel demand crashes 70% due to restrictions, VAT mop up takes a hit||JAIPUR: Demand for auto fuels has crashed 70% lending a heavy blow to the state’s VAT revenue collections. Rajasthan Petroleum Dealers’ Association said the daily loss could be around Rs 17 crore. The restriction on the movement of private vehicles is not the only reason. The association said the state’s guidelines for controlling the Covid is playing an equal hand. “By limiting the fuel retailing time to five hours, the state is losing many customers. While goods carriers are allowed to tank up round the clock, a significant number of the vehicles are avoiding Rajasthan and buying from neighbouring states. The five-hour window has caused an uncertainty and the drivers are wary of taking any risk,” said Suneet Bagai, president of the association. “Secondly,” Bagai said, “There are many private vehicles which travel to the state or through it for emergency work. Here again, they buy fuel from other states as they cannot get petrol in Rajasthan after 12pm.” He said when there are already restrictions for people on coming out on the road, the need to again limit the time for fuel stations does not have any logic. “If people are not allowed to come on the road after the relaxation time up to 11am, on what logic they will go to the fuel stations. It only creates discomfort for people who are travelling due to emergency and uncertainty for goods carriers on the highways,” added Bagai. Giving a back of the envelope calculation, he said the state sells about 70 crore litres of petrol and 400 crore litre diesel in a year. “The annual VAT collection is roughly about Rs 9,000 crore. Since the demand has decreased by around 70%, the lost tax per day works out to be around Rs 17 crore. But some of the loss can be mitigated if time for sales is made 24 hours on the highways,” added Bagai. TOI tried to reach Ravi Jain, commissioner, commercial taxes department, to ascertain the impact of the Covid guidelines on VAT collections from the auto fuels, but could not get a response.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/fuel-demand-crashes-70-due-to-restrictions-vat-mop-up-takes-a-hit/articleshow/82442967.cms||---

---||Jaipur||Rajasthan: Miscreants assault 2 on-duty traffic cops||JAIPUR: Two traffic police personnel, including a woman, were injured after they were attacked by two bike-borne siblings flouting Covid protocol at Ajmeri Gate T-Point at 10am on Thursday. The woman constable Sukhjit Singh and home guard Rajvir Singh, regulating traffic at the Ajmer Gate saw two youths — Ibrar and Fardeen, wearing a helmet but without masks coming from the other end. Since unnecessary movement is restricted in the city due to a surge in infections and masks are compulsory, the duo attempted to stop them to inquire why they were loitering on the roads. “The bikers appeared to have got panicked on seeing traffic police approaching them and applied brakes and fell on the ground. Upon seeing Sukhjit and Rajvir rushing towards them, Ibrar with his helmet hit Sukhjit on her head and on the chest of Rajvir. He ran away towards his home at Kareem Manzil on MI Road while Fardeen was caught by traffic police,” said Ishwar Singh, investigation officer, Vidhayak Puri police station. Both were rushed to SMS hospital where they were given medical aid. “Both are out of danger,” said Singh. The drama didn’t stop here. Ibrar, who went to his home on MI Road, brought along his family who started arguing with the traffic police for endangering the lives of the brothers for stopping them abruptly. Sensing trouble, traffic police called the Vidhayak Puri Police which came in a few minutes. The family was asked to leave since they were disrupting government’s work and flouting Covid protocol. “Both Ibar and Fardeen were arrested for assaulting government servants,” said Singh.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/miscreants-assault-2-on-duty-traffic-cops/articleshow/82442961.cms||---

Petrol and diesel prices have witnessed a hike for the third consecutive day on Thursday, after remaining unchanged for 18 days, between April 6 to May 3, 2021. जब तक पांच राज्यों में विधानसभा चुनाव चल रहे थे, मोदी सरकार ने पेट्रोल डीजल की कीमतों में कोई बदलाव नहीं किया जबकि… https://t.co/8cM2VURmRW— Ashok Gehlot (@ashokgehlot51) 1620294082000He said the central government should reduce the tax on petrol and diesel and give relief to the “already troubled” people. The chief minister stressed that as long as the assembly elections were underway in five states, the Modi government did not make any changes in the prices of petrol and diesel while crude oil prices were changing daily in the international market. “As soon as the results of the elections came, the central government increased the prices of petrol and diesel and started putting burden on the people who are already affected by the pandemic,” he tweeted. “The Modi government is charging many times more tax on diesel, petrol than the UPA government, due to which inflation is continuously increasing,” he said. In one of the steepest increase since daily price revision was started, petrol price on Thursday was hiked by 24 paise per litre and diesel by 31 paise as oil companies raised rates for the third straight day to pass on to consumers the increase in international oil prices. The joint team seized nine Remdesivir injection vials and over Rs 1.5 lakh cash from their possession. Police officials registyered a case and said the accused procured Remdesivir, an anti-viral drug used in the treatment of Covid-19, illegaly and sold them to the needy at premium. “They have confessed to selling one Remdesivir vials for around Rs 40,000,” said DCP Crime branch Salman Taj Patil. The accused, identified as Aman Deep Singh, Anshu Sachdeva, Amrish Gupta and Sita Charan Gupta, were booked and arrested. “Besides, Remdesivir, we also recovered 26 oximeters and Rs 1,52,900 cash from the four accused,” he added. ---||Jaipur||16 oxygen plants to come up in Rajasthan, 4 in Jaipur||JAIPUR/JAISALMER: Out of the 581oxygen plants that the DRDO and the NHAI plan to set up in the country, 16 units of 1,000, 500 and 200 LPM (litres per minute) capacity will come up in eight districts of Rajasthan including Jaipur and Ajmer. These are expected to start in next seven days. While DRDO will set up 400 plants, NHAI will instal 181 with the help of HLL Infra Tech Service. With the help of DRDO and NHAI, work on the 12 plants in Rajasthan started from Thursday. The Centre had ordered the states to identify locations for oxygen plants in hospitals by May 5. Land has been identified in 12 hospitals in Rajasthan including four in Jaipur, two in Ajmer, one each in Barmer, Pali, Nagaur, Rajsamand, Kota and Sikar. The funds for the plants will be provided from the PM Cares. NHAI has been made the nodal agency for setting up these units. One of the plants will be set up at Nahata Hospital Balotara where 1,000 litres of oxygen will be generated in a minute. Different companies are setting up oxygen plants in different parts of the country. Work has started in most of the places from Thursday and these plants will be ready in next 7-10 days and will be handed over to the hospitals concerned. Apart from this, four oxygen plants of 250 LPM capacity will also be set up in the state. With setting up of 16 plants in Rajasthan, 2,400 Covid serious patients will be provided oxygen. The rest of the plants will come up in Andhra Pradesh (21), Nagaland (2), Haryana (11), Uttar Pradesh (21), Kerala (1), Daman and Diu (3), Himachal Pradesh (6), Odisha (6), Assam (4), West Bengal (70), Gujarat (20), Maharashtra (6), Tamil Nadu (113), Telangana (37), Mizoram (1), Uttarakhand (7), Delhi (13), Punjab (11), Karnataka (16) and Bihar (15). NHAI Barmer manager Jitendra Choudhary said DRDO and NHAI will set up these plants in the entire country||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/16-o2-plants-to-come-up-in-raj-for-covid-treatment/articleshow/82443009.cms||---
---||Chandigarh||Punjab government to facilitate relief from overseas||CHANDIGARH: In the ongoing fight against coronavirus, the Punjab government has appointed two nodal officers to facilitate the individuals and organisations in getting tax exemption on any Covid relief to be imported into the state from abroad. Divulging the details, a spokesperson of the Punjab government said in order to fight the challenge of the pandemic more effectively and to facilitate the flow of aid from outside India, the Union government had provided exemption from customs duty and integrated tax on goods for Covid-19 relief imported into country. He said the same concessions could be availed for such imports if they were sent free of cost from outside India and are distributed free within India. The spokesperson said for claiming these exemptions anyone could approach the nodal officers — Kumar Rahul (phone 9876164787), email: mdnrhmpunjab@gmail.com & sha.phse@gmail.com, and Ravneet Singh Khurana (9560954405) and email: gst.audit@punjab.Govgin  Further, any entity in Punjab willing to import Covid relief could apply on the portal https://taxation.punjab.gov. in /imports.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/pb-govt-to-facilitate-relief-from-overseas/articleshow/82443001.cms||---

When Shaikh visited Syyed’s resident, he was found dead with injuries on the right side of his head.” “Shaikh informed the police of the incident. We sent the victim’s body to Sassoon general hospital for post-mortem. Preliminary investigations suggest that the assailant may have used a blunt object,” Kadam said. “We are questioning local residents and people known to the scrap vendor for collecting more details relating to the murder. ---||Mumbai||Maharashtra State: Will send cops to Hyd, not arrest Shukla till next HC date||Mumbai: Maharashtra government on Thursday informed Bombay high court that it was willing to send a police team to Hyderabad to video record the statement of former state intelligence chief Rashmi Shukla in connection with the FIR registered against unknown persons over ‘leaking’ her confidential report on alleged politician-police nexus on transfers and postings. The state further said it would not arrest Shukla before the next date—June 14—as HC adjourned the matter beyond its summer vacation, that starts next week. Shukla is currently posted in Hyderabad as additional director general, south Zone, CRPF. Claiming that she was being “hounded because she was a whistleblower to the rotten nexus between politicians and policemen in assigning powerful po-sts”, Shukla, a 1988 batch IPS officer, had petitioned the HC apprehending arrest. She sought ord-ers to stay a April 26 summons to appear before BKC cyber crime police station and to quash the FIR or transfer the probe to CBI. On Thursday, during the videoconference hearing before a bench of Justices S S Shinde and Manish Pitale, former advocate general Darius Khambata and public prosecutor Deepak Thakare, appearing for the state, stated its willingness to send a team to Hyderabad to record her statement under CrPC Section 160, which provides that a woman shall in response to a summons not be required to “attend any place other than the place” in which she resides. Khambata said if she is unable to travel due to the pandemic, the state team would go and record her statement, but she should be alone. But senior counsel Mahesh Jethmalani, appearing for Shukla, said the law permits the presence of her lawyer. The HC said all legal provisions to be followed. Stating that Shukla would “fully cooperate” with the police team, Jethmalani pointed out that her statement was already recorded by the CBI as part of the preliminary enquiry on April 16. The HC had on April 5 directed the PE into former Mumbai police commissioner Param Bir Singh’s letter to the CM alleging “corrupt malpractices” by then home minister Anil Deshmukh, which was the basis of a complaint filed at Malabar Hill police station by advocate Jaishri Patil. Khambata said there can be no investigation in this matter by the CBI. Additional solicitor general Anil Singh for CBI said it was only following HC’s orders. The HC directed both, Shukla and the state to “strictly abide by the statements made by them before the court through their respective senior advocates”. The HC order further said its observations “may not be construed as an impediment for the CBI” to further probe the FIR against Deshmukh. The HC clarified that its observations “are restricted” to Shukla’s petition and would have no bearing on the various quashing petitions filed by Singh, Deshmukh and the state.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/maharashtra-state-will-send-cops-to-hyd-not-arrest-shukla-till-next-hc-date/articleshow/82445209.cms||---
---||Patna||HC asks chief secretary to file report on Covid health infra in Bihar||PATNA: The Patna high court on Thursday directed the state’s chief secretary to file a report on health infrastructure in the state showing the number of oxygenated and ICU beds and other equipment, count of doctors and paramedics available at hospitals involved in the treatment of Covid-19 patients. The high court also asked the chief secretary to give details on the availability of oxygen, medicines for Covid-19 treatment, hospitalizations, disposal of PPE kits, vaccination drive along with Covid deaths and cremation process. It also sought a response on deaths reported due to lack of oxygen. The division bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice S Kumar was hearing the PILs filed by Shivani Kaushik, Rahul Kumar and Gaurav Kumar Singh on the grim situation of the pandemic in the state on Thursday. The matter has been posted for further hearing on Friday. Till Tuesday, the matter was heard by the division bench of Justice Chakradhari Sharan Singh and Justice Mohit Kumar Shah who had made scathing remarks against the state government for its failure to control the pandemic. During the hearing, the state government submitted that it could procure only 154 metric tonnes of liquid oxygen on Wednesday against the increased daily quota of 214 metric tonnes. The state government also pressed its demand for 300 metric tonnes of oxygen daily from the Centre. Appearing for the state, Supreme Court counsel Vikash Singh submitted that they don’t have enough cryogenic tankers for procuring liquid oxygen and assistance from the Centre on this matter. Following this, the bench asked the Centre to respond by when it would make available cryogenic oxygen tankers to the state. The state government at present has six cryogenic tankers and the Centre is scheduled to provide seven more. Of the seven, four will come from Jharkhand and three more would be provided by the Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL). The bench directed the Centre’s additional solicitor general KN Singh to apprise it by Friday about the status of all seven cryogenic oxygen tankers. The bench orally observed that it was not for governing the state but to see the governance. “Let us save the lives of the people first and crooks would be taken care of later on,” the bench orally observed. The high court also directed the three-member technical team headed by AIIMS-Patna anaesthesia department head, Dr Umesh Kumar, Bhadani to file its report on the situation as per earlier direction. Besides Singh, advocate general Lalit Kishore appeared for the state, PK Shahi appeared for the PMCH, Binay Kumar Pandey for AIIMS-Patna, Sumeet Kumar Singh for one of the petitioners and a few other counsels appeared before the bench virtually during the hearing.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/patna/hc-asks-chief-secretary-to-file-report-on-covid-health-infra-in-bihar/articleshow/82440439.cms||Debashish Karmakar

---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: MLAs must allot Rs 50 lakh for health infrastructure||GANDHINAGAR: It was resolved at a meeting of the core committee for Covid control on Thursday that all MLAs will have to compulsorily allot a minimum of Rs 50 lakh from their local area development funds to upgrade facilities at hospitals. Every MLA will be required to allot the sum which will be used to purchase medical equipment for civil hospitals, district hospitals, community health centres (CHC), primary health centres (PHC) and hospitals run by civic bodies. A government statement said MLAs can allot the funds to such hospitals in their constituencies. It was also decided that MLAs can also donate from their grants to hospitals run by charitable trusts, provided these are working on a not-for-profit basis. Listing down items that can be bought from grants made by MLAs, the government release said 10-litre oxygen concentrators, high-flow oxygen therapy devices, BiPAP machines, multi-para monitors, syringe infusion pumps, liquid oxygen storage tanks and pressure swing adsorption (PSA) oxygen generation units can be purchased.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/mlas-must-allot-rs-50l-for-health-infrastructure/articleshow/82441277.cms||---
---||Chandigarh||Haryana: Police SUVs to transport Covid patients||CHANDIGARH: In a bid to help Covid patients find transport easily, Haryana Police has temporarily provided 440 Covid-19 Hospital Transport Service (COV-HOTS) vehicles for free transportation of needy infected patients from their homes to hospitals/nursing homes and vice-versa. Manoj Yadava, director general of police (DGP), Haryana, said each police district would get 20 Toyota Innova SUVs for the purpose. The move came in the wake of reports of shortage of ambulances or overcharging by private ambulance service providers. Out of the total, 126 COV-HOTS vehicles have been provided to all districts. A total of 26 SUVs were given to Hisar Range, 20 each to Gurgaon police commissionerate and Rohtak Range, 10 each to Faridabad and Panchkula commissionerate, 12 each to Ambala and Karnal range and 16 to South Range, Rewari. “As many as 70 SUVs would reach the districts today and the remaining 244 would be delivered by Sunday evening, he added. Amid rising cases of coronavirus, the DGP said these vehicles were provided exclusively to provide transportation to Covid patients. Persons in need can dial 108 or the police control room number of the district to which they belong for free transportation from their homes to hospitals or vice-versa.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/police-suvs-to-transport-covid-patients/articleshow/82443049.cms||---

Sagar has urged the Bombay high court to intervene in the matter. “While Mumbaikars are being made to run from pillar to post for a jab, Congress and NCP ministers have used their clout to divert vaccines to their hometowns. More ministers could be involved in the fraud,” he told TOI. Sagar urged the Bombay high court to take cognizance of the “grim situation” and intervene, suo motu, in the matter to provide immediate relief to Mumbaikars.tnn||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-bjp-mla-accuses-cong-ncp-netas-of-hoarding-vaccines-remdesivir/articleshow/82441256.cms||---

---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Worker killed for stalking woman||HYDERABAD: A 26-year-old worker who was stalking a woman was killed allegedly by her uncle at Metpalli town in Jagtial district on Wednesday night. The deceased, M Gopi, 26, was a labourer from Venkatraopet in Metpally town. Gopi was in love with a woman from the neighbourhood three years ago but despite them being from the same community, the relationship did not work out, circle inspector (CI) Srinu. “But Gopi continued to stalk the woman. In 2019, she lodged a police complaint. A case was registered against Gopi and subsequently it was closed as both the parties reached a compromise,” the CI said. Police said that in addition to the harassment case, the victim was also accused in property offences. After the case was closed, Gopi again started stalking the woman and he also started harassing her family members. Unable to put up with his harassment, the woman’s family left the town and moved to Hyderabad two years ago, police said. Even after her family left the town, Gopi used to harass her uncle, B Narender, who lives in Metpally. On Wednesday night, Gopi went to Narender’s house in an inebriated condition and picked up an argument with him, asking him to bring his niece back from Hyderabad and arrange their marriage. Fed up with the harassment of Gopi, Narender stabbed him with scissors and then hacked him to death using an axe, the CI said. With severe injuries, Gopi died on the spot and alerted by the locals, police rushed to the spot. The body was shifted to local government hospital for post-mortem examination and a murder case was registered under Section 302 of the IPC against Narender. He has been taken into custody.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/worker-stabbed-to-death-for-stalking-woman/articleshow/82443066.cms||---
---||Jaipur||School to be converted into Covid hospital in Rajasthan||JAIPUR: The Rajasthan State Road Development & Construction Corporation Limited (RSRDC) in collaboration with Hindustan Zinc is in the process of converting a school in Rajsamand’s Dariba into a 250-bed Covid hospital. The total cost of converting the school into a 250-bed hospital will be Rs 2.6 crore, said PWD principal secretary and RSRDC chairman Rajesh Yadav. “A school near Hindustan Zinc’s factory in Dariba (Rajsamand) will be converted into a 250-bed hospital. It has been just a week since the decision has been taken and we will complete the work in another 5-6 days. We will take oxygen from Hindustan Zinc and use it for the hospital,” said Yadav. “We are working on a war footing to complete the work in 10-15 days,” he added. According to the state government’s portal on Covid info, there are currently 393 Covid hospitals in the state with 10,990 general beds, 16,834 oxygen beds, 2713 ICU beds without ventilator and 2181 ICU beds with ventilators. For any kind of Covid-related queries, one can contact state corona Sampark Helpline Number: 181 and state Covid control room Number: 0141-2225624. ---||Hyderabad||Andhra Pradesh high court interim order gives boost to anti-corruption probes||HYDERABAD: An interim order given by the AP high court last week to the Anti Corruption Bureau (ACB) in the Sangam Dairy case to unravel the truth behind Guntur Dairy’s conversion from a cooperative entity to a mutually cooperative entity and finally into a private company of its former chairman Dhulipalla Narendra Kumar may give a fillip to anti-corruption probes. Experts said the interim order gives strength to investigation agencies as it made it clear that a change in the law need not necessarily be read as an impediment to the investigators. AP advocate general S Sriram said the Prevention of Corruption Act’s (PCA) repealed provisions can be applied for carrying out an investigation. “Repeal of the law does not negate the offence,” he contended. Senior counsel B Adinarayana Rao, who appeared for Narendra Kumar, however, argued that the ACB had no powers to investigate in 2018 an ‘old crime’ that took place prior to the amendment of the PCA, 1988. The ACB had booked the case against the accused under provisions like 13(1)(c) and 13(I)(d) which had been repealed without any saving clauses, he said. Rao said the alleged crime was not investigated when it was committed or at least during the time the law was in force. “Now, the law has been repealed and hence the probe agency has lost the power under this section to inquire into the issue,” the senior counsel contended. Sriram argued that the general clauses Act allows investigation to be initiated even after the repeal of the law. “As long as the ingredients required for making out a case are there, a probe into a case of huge public importance cannot be stopped under the guise of technicalities,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/andhra-hc-interim-order-gives-boost-to-anti-corruption-probes/articleshow/82443071.cms||---

The inquiry commission submitted its report after the division bench lifted a stay granted by a single judge on submission of the report. The stay was ordered in response to the petition filed by Kalpit Shah and others seeking certain reliefs including permission to visit the Shrey Hospital ICU with a photographer and their demand for documents placed before the inquiry commission by other parties. They made this demand to the inquiry commission in February after the commission sought to record their evidence. The commission refused their request and this resulted in litigation. At around 2am, the lone operator entered the first floor of the G+1 building at Gandimysamma area of Dundigal. The unknown offender then entered the office by making a hole in the wall. “The wall is made of four-inch brick, and it was easy for the offender to make a hole in it,” Pet Basheerabad ACP, VVS Ramalinga Raju, said. After gaining entry into the office, the accused tried to make another hole in the strong room’s wall. But the wall had thicker concrete making it difficult for him. “He had come with a hammer, and after failing to break into the strong room, he fled,” the police said. Meanwhile, Muthoot finance staff, who saw the movement of the accused through live CCTV feed, alerted the police. However, by the time cops reached the spot, the accused had left the place. ---||Rajkot||High vaccination, low cases: This village shows how to control nCov||Rajkot: Nana Ankadiya village lies just 8kms away from Amreli town. Many among the village’s population of 3,100 daily visit Amreli for employment purpose or purchase of essential commodities that are not available at Nana Ankadiya. Despite the proximity and dependence on Amreli town, the second wave of Covid-19 hasn’t created the kind of havoc at Nana Ankadiya like it has at other parts of the state. Only 20 from the village have tested positive for the coronavirus in the second wave and none of them needed to be hospitalized. The secret behind the village’s resistance against the deadly virus is high percentage of vaccination. “The credit for less infection goes to maximum vaccination. Almost 85% villagers above the age of 45 have been vaccinated,” informs Prant officer C K Unghad. Nana Akadiya village has witnessed just two deaths in last three months, both of them because of ailments related to old age. “The village has zero-casualty due to Covid. The village crematorium is used to cremate Covid bodies from Amreli city. A team of villagers also collect woods for this purpose,” Unghad added. Despite the low Covid numbers the village is not letting the guard down. The village has 10-bed Covid Community Centre for those who need isolation. There is no charge for admission at this centre and food is also provided by the village panchayat. Damji Javiya, the sarpanch of the village said, “We are observing people’s health in consultation with the health department staff. They do home-to-home surveillance and prescribe medicines. We ensure that people get tested at the initial stage and suspect patients are isolated early.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/rajkot/high-vaccination-low-cases-this-village-shows-how-to-control-ncov/articleshow/82439898.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Crematoriums in Bopal, Ambli turning bodies away||AHMEDABAD: An advocate practising in the Gujarat high court, Kaivan Patel, had to bring his relative’s body to the Thaltej crematorium from Bopal after a crematorium in Bopal refused to allow her cremation. When Patel and his family members inquired at the Ambli village crematorium, they were forwarded a message doing the rounds on social media. The message was in the name of one Khodiyar Yuvak Mandal and was addressed to residents of Ambli village telling them that in this Covid-19 situation, nobody except a resident of Ambli village will be allowed cremation in the village crematorium. It also asked Ambli villagers to communicate this to residents of housing societies around the village, and that no cremation of a person who had died of Covid-19 would be permitted. This message was enough for Patel to ask the hearse van driver to take the body to Thaltej crematorium, where he had to wait in a queue to cremate the 90-year-old grandmother of his wife. “She died a natural death and there was nobody from the family who could help because most of the members are quarantined. We inquired with Bopal crematorium but got a refusal. And then we received such messages from Ambli,” the lawyer said and added that he decided to take up the issue in the high court. DySP Ahmedabad rural, K T Kamaria, said police have not yet received any complaint in this regard. But he said, “Earlier too when there was no Covid-19 pandemic, these villagers did not allow others to cremate bodies at their crematoriums.” Officials at the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) said though these areas now fall under the civic body’s jurisdiction, operation and management of the crematoriums at Bopal and Ambli have not been taken over yet.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/crematoriums-in-bopal-ambli-turning-bodies-away/articleshow/82441294.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Accused bought antibiotics online||AHMEDABAD: City crime branch, which is inquiring into a spurious remdesivir injections racket — where 2,400 vials of injections meant for Covid-19 patients were seized from two men in Vadodara — found that the accused bought antibiotics from an online shopping portal, which they sold as remdesivir. This was revealed after crime branch got custody of the prime accused, Vivek Maheshwari, 34, a resident of Siddharth Vatika on Sama-Savli Road in Vadodara, from Vadodara police on Thursday. He runs a medical store in Anand. Ahmedabad city crime branch has got Maheshwari’s custody till May 8. During his interrogation, he revealed that the other accused, Dishant and Nitesh Joshi, conspired with him to sell spurious remdesivir injections at exorbitant rates to make quick money. “During his interrogation, he told the cops that Nitesh Joshi had found antibiotics which could be used for lungs infections or for other respiratory issues on a website named Indiamart and procured antibiotics from it,” said a crime branch officer. The officer said the accused pasted labels of HETERO and Jubi-R on the vials and began selling them as remdesivir. The racket was busted on April 29, by when the accused had been selling the spurious injections for 10 days and had sold 350 spurious injections.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/accused-bought-antibiotics-online/articleshow/82441272.cms||---
---||Delhi||Working on how to make O2 distribution transparent: IIT-Delhi||NEW DELHI: Indian Institute of Technology-Delhi is looking to assist Delhi government by streamlining their portal for oxygen distribution to hospitals and people in home isolation. On Wednesday, Delhi High Court had told the government to consider taking the help from IIT-D and DTU. The high court had directed the government to ask the two institutes to prepare a blueprint for the supply and distribution infrastructure of liquid medical oxygen and oxygen cylinders to the national capital, TOI had reported. “The estimations should be prepared on the basis of the plans that are worked out by the consultants/experts in consultation with other wings of the GNCTD, such as DGHS and the various hospitals and nursing homes,” said justices Vipin Sanghi and Rekha Palli. Sanjay Dhir, associate professor for strategic management in the department of management studies said the institute had already begun discussions on this. “On Thursday morning, director V Ramgopal Rao connected me to the secretary of the government, who is looking for IT solutions for the management of the oxygen supplies,” he said. Dhir said that the institute even gave a demonstration to the high court on Thursday. “We have been working on the Co-Win portal and the government’s Remdesivir distribution portal, which is created to curb the black marketing of the injections. IIT-D showed a flow chart and technical expertise on how to involve stake-holders and make the system transparent,” he said. The institute can help Delhi government in deciding how to distribute oxygen, what would be the checkpoints and how to track it, said the associate professor. As there is no time to create new technology for this, IIT-D said it will try to ensure the tech currently used by Delhi government is being fully utilised. “We will make the tracking system robust, so that everyone knows where the oxygen is. We are still in the midst of the peak of the second wave, so it is necessary to streamline the processes,” Dhir added. Earlier, IIT-Delhi had distributed oxygen cylinders from their laboratories to the Delhi government. Director Rao, who had also contracted Covid, on his recovery tweeted that the institute was handing over “many cylinders to local administration” and will be giving more. The high court has also asked Delhi government to approach DTU for assistance. Yogesh Singh, DTU vice-chancellor told TOI that the institute has not communicated with the government yet. “We have a number of supply-chain experts who can help the government with the distribution of resources,” said Singh.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/working-on-how-to-make-o2-distribution-transparent-iit-d/articleshow/82443116.cms||Mohammad Ibrar

Following Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) the Greater Warangal Municipal Corporation (GWMC) and Khammam Municipal Corporation (KMC) will also get woman mayors. Apart from these two corporations, four municipalities will have women chairpersons. Elections to the mayoral and chairperson posts will be held on Friday. The KMC mayoral post is reserved for general women, while it is reserved for BC general in GWMC. The TRS has reportedly assured mayor post to former MP and TRS mahila wing president Gundu Sudha Rani in GWMC though it is reserved for BC general candidate. Party sources said generally a leader who had already been an MP won’t contest as a corporator in the civic elections. But in Sudha Rani’s case, the party leadership had assured her of the mayoral post and fielded her as a corporator from division 29 in the GWMC elections. Though half a dozen people are trying to secure the coveted post, the party is most likely to prefer Sudha Rani in Friday’s election. In Khammam, minister Puvvada Ajya Kumar tried to field his wife in the elections with an eye on the mayor post. His wife Vasantha Laxmi filed her nomination but withdrew it later following the directions of the party leadership. More than half a dozen corporators are trying for the post. Meanwhile, the TRS leadership has handed over names of the mayoral and deputy mayor candidates’ names to the party observers, which will be opened on Friday morning asking the corporators and councillors to obey the party’s decision. The party has also decided to issue whip to corporators though there is no chance for opposition parties to secure mayor and chairperson posts. ---||Delhi||Panel for a fresh round of parole to decongest jails||New Delhi: A meeting of Delhi High Court’s high-powered committee headed by justice Vipin Sanghi and other senior officers over de-congestion of Delhi prisons has revealed that as on May 3, 2021, there were 319 Covid-positive inmates, of whom 65 recovered, five died and 249 were active cases; whereas 135 staffers were positive, of whom eight recovered. Also, in February 2021, a total of 5,124 inmates were released on bail and parole from the prisons to reduce risk of infection spread and maintain social distancing norms. It also came on record that so far more than 85% of the jail staff have been vaccinated, besides 564 inmates being inoculated. The committee also observed that currently India in general and Delhi in particular were “engulfed” by the second wave of Covid-19, which according to medical experts was more virulent and fatal in comparison to last year’s strain. “In a matter of a few weeks, this wave has left everyone gasping for air. It has led everyone to struggle to breathe or with asphyxia, which is the most terrifying human experience,” the committee said. Justice Sanghi suggested that as the new variant of Covid-19 was more virulent, the jail staff as well as inmates be directed and provided with double masks – one surgical mask and a cloth mask. Director general (prisons) Sandeep Goel assured to provide these masks to the jail staff and inmates. Considering that the present situation had taken a “360 degree turn”, the committee deliberated upon the urgent need to take steps to prevent the outbreak inside jails. Therefore, it was highlighted that it was essential to identify and determine the categories of prisoners who could once again be released on interim bail or parole.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/panel-for-a-fresh-round-of-parole-to-decongest-jails/articleshow/82443205.cms||Aamir Khan
---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Indian gaur rescued from well||HYDERABAD: An Indian gaur that fell into an agriculture well in Komaram Bheem district on May 5 was rescued by forest department officials on Thursday. According to officials, the buffalo fell into the well around 11pm on May 5. “A villager noticed the buffalo struggling in the well on early Thursday morning and informed the sarpanch, who reached out to us. We suspect the wild animal must have accidentally fallen into the well as there was no light around, and the well has no compound wall or fence,” said Prakash, deputy forest range officer, Sirpur. He said that since the water level was low, the animal could survive the night. Around 7am, forest officials reached the spot with an earthmover. “We pulled it out and guided it towards the forest, helping it cross the river,” said Prakash. Officials suspect that a herd of Indian gaur may have crossed the Maharashtra border in search of food.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/indian-gaur-rescued-from-well/articleshow/82443107.cms||---
---||Goa||ESG suspends film shoots, revokes nod to applicants||Panaji: In the wake of the rising number of Covid-19 cases, the Entertainment Society of Goa (ESG) on Thursday suspended all film shoots in the state. They have also revoked NOCs that had been granted earlier. “Considering the unprecedented rise in the number of Covid-19 cases in Goa, as per the directions of the government of Goa, film shooting in the state in both private and public properties have been suspended until further orders. All NOCs that have been issued by this office stand suspended with effect from May 6. The line producers of ESG and all concerned are hereby instructed to strictly comply with the same,” a statement released by the ESG read. Speaking to TOI, ESG vice-chairman Subhash Phaldesai said that the existing NOCs were granted only till May 4 and no permits have been issued thereafter. “We have emailed and telephonically informed the filmmakers not to indulge in any shootings. We are in the middle of a pandemic and we cannot assure anybody of getting back in the business (on a set date),” he said. On Wednesday, videos of Fatorda MLA Vijai Sardesai barging onto the set of a Marathi television show and demanding to stop the shooting went viral. Reacting to the move, Phaldesai said that cases are rising, and everybody has anxiety regarding the same.“It may be not proper, maybe he should have contacted any of the enforcement authorities and then gone there. He is an elected representative. We do not know what made him go and stop it. Maybe he has consulted some officers, but I don’t wish to comment whether he was right or wrong.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/esg-suspends-film-shoots-revokes-nod-to-applicants/articleshow/82445320.cms||---

Police said that the men also uploaded defamatory texts along with the photographs. Police arrested a man on Thursday in the case. ---||Goa||Forced to do jugaad, sharing one O2 port with 3 patients: GMC docs||PANAJI: Supply is yet to meet the rising demand for oxygen at Goa Medical College. Critical Covid patients, lucky enough to get a bed and be connected to centralised oxygen via ports, struggle to breathe during pressure fluctuations, while those connected to cylinders must source it from outside when refills don’t come in time. A relative told TOI that oxygen pressure to his relative’s NIV would drop every morning between 4 am and 8 am. Doctors at the hospital said that they have no option, but to allow relatives to arrange for their own oxygen cylinders. “It has come to this stage where no matter what tell the administration we are not getting sufficient supply. The government has been depending on one supplier all these years for reasons best known to it. If a patient requires a cylinder and arranges for it, and if I cannot provide it myself, why should I say no? I want to keep my patient alive,” the doctor said, adding “We are not making money out of this. We are not even getting our salary on time.” Another doctor working in a Covid ward said oxygen is being rationed. “Basically, we are doing juggad and sharing one oxygen port with as many as three patients. It’s not supposed to be this way, but we have no option. This way nobody gets enough oxygen, but everybody gets something. Oxygen is more important than money,” the doctor told TOI. After the hue and cry, oxygen concentrators were installed in many Covid wards on Thursday delivering up to five litres per minute. “It's something better than nothing and only requires electricity. It won’t be useful for the really bad patients, but is ok for those with very low oxygen requirements. It’s less advanced, but useful when nothing else is available and welcome all the same,” a doctor said. Doctors at GMC told TOI that the infrastructure is old and wasn’t upgraded after the first wave and central oxygen pressure drops at times contributing to untimely deaths. The administration does not have to deal with angry relatives, one doctor said. “We are the ones seeing so many die due to lack of oxygen.” “It’s easy to know when oxygen pressure drops. All the non-invasive ventilators (NIVs) monitors start showing an error ‘O2 regulation’ and a red light begins to blink, indicating that the central supply is very low. We scramble to call the oxygen supplier and tell them to get the oxygen as soon as possible as we see oxygen saturation of patients on NIV dropping. Relatives have gotten used to identifying this as they see the patients beginning to feel uneasy, and are getting their own cylinders as backups,” another doctor told TOI. A healthcare worker at GMC said that the scene was different during the last wave when the variant was much milder and when most patients’ oxygen levels could be maintained on room air without external oxygen. “Today practically everybody coming to GMC is extremely bad with severe pneumonia and almost all are reaching the CCRR breathless, requiring oxygen. They come with their lungs badly damaged with bad CT scores of 20+/ 25.” As a result the healthcare worker said that it takes longer to treat patients. “Few people are lucky enough to be on NIVs. The rest of the people are just as bad, but will not get machines unless someone on a NIV dies. Last year, patients were recovering within five to seven days and going home. This time patients require NIV in the initial stages itself, which is a bad prognostic factor and will require that much longer to recover and will continue using NIV until then,” the healthcare worker said. Increasing the number of NIVs in the hospital is of no use as the infrastructure cannot deliver the required amount of piped oxygen with the strain of so many machines, the health worker said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/forced-to-do-jugaad-sharing-one-o2-port-with-3-patients-gmc-docs/articleshow/82445290.cms||Lisa Monteiro

They have been booked under the Disaster Management Act and under Section 188 (disobeying an order of the public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) for violating the official orders. Phagwara SP Sarabjit Singh Bahia said the clip reached them on Wednesday and they registered the case. The Punjab government has restricted number to 10 for marriage functions and this restriction was in place when Sugandha’s marriage was held. ---||Mumbai||Fuel prices up for 3rd day in a row, petrol in Mumbai at Rs 97.34/l||Mumbai: Fuel prices went up for the third day in a row on Thursday, with Parbhani in the state now just 28 paise short (Rs 99.72) of the Rs 100/litre mark for petrol. Similarly, diesel price in Amravati is just five paise shy of the Rs 90-mark. In Mumbai, petrol price went up by 22 paise to touch Rs 97.34 per litre while diesel soared by 30 paise to Rs 88.49 per litre. Petrol and diesel are both rallying northwards once again, pinching the pockets of motorists and adding fuel burden on goods transportation. In neighbouring Thane and Navi Mumbai too, petrol saw an increase of 22 paise to touch Rs 97.46 per litre while diesel price jumped 30 paise and stood at Rs 88.61 per litre on Thursday. Fuel prices have been fluctuating for the past one year. In fact, diesel price in Mumbai had gone up by a record Rs 22 a litre over the past one year while petrol escalated by around Rs 21 during the same period.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/fuel-prices-up-for-3rd-day-in-a-row-petrol-in-mumbai-at-rs-97-34/l/articleshow/82445322.cms||Somit Sen
---||Kolkata||Kolkata: 100 workers fix water line in just 6 hours||KOLKATA: Water supply from Garden Reach Waterworks resumed ahead of the schedule on Thursday evening, with the engineering and maintenance team from Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s water supply department completing the work in double quick time despite being able to deploy only one-third of the workforce due to Covid restrictions. “We had initially decided to go for a shutdown till dawn on Friday. But given the hot weather and difficulties that people face without water, we worked on a tight schedule and completed it by evening. Supply was resumed at 4.45 pm,” a KMC water supply department official said on Thursday. Water supply had been suspended at 10am. However, it was an uphill task for the civic body to complete the work amid the pandemic where the civic engineers had to keep in mind the Covid-protocols while engaging mechanics and labourers for the repair and maintenance work conceded the civic official. What should have been a routine shutdown turned into a major challenge for the civic body as it undertook the work and completed it on time with 100 workers instead of 300, who would have otherwise deployed. Besides repairing leakages in major pipelines at Garden Reach Waterworks and routine maintenance of valves and electrical installations, the KMC also undertook installation of pipes and valves at the waterworks. Pre-summer maintenance work was also undertaken at several water booster pumping stations in Kalighat, Chetla, Behala, Daspara, Siriti, Garfa, Bansdroni, Ranikuthi and Layelka. The preventive maintenance work will help ensure uninterrupted supply during the summer months to entire Behala, Tollygunge, Jadavpur, Garia, Chetla, Kalighat, Rashbehari, Kasba, Garfa, Dhakuria, Golf Green, and some areas located adjacent to EM Bypass. The last time KMC water supply department had taken up such a major repair work was at Garden Reach Waterworks in January. “We are trying to go for a comprehensive repair process keeping in mind heavy demand for potable water during peak of summer,” said a KMC senior official.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/100-workers-fix-water-line-in-just-6-hours/articleshow/82441362.cms||Saikat Ray
---||Nagpur||Govt projects drop to 41k active cases, 3,208 surplus beds in dist by May 16||Nagpur: Considering the declining trend in Covid-19 positive cases over last one week, the state government has projected active positive cases in the district will drop from existing 64,597 to 40,919, leaving 3,208 surplus beds in hospitals by May 16. As per government data, weekly growth rate and test positivity rate (TPR) of the district are also on decline. All these parameters indicate April was the peak of second wave and cases will continue to drop further in May. It is probably for the first time the government has given projection of decline in cases and surplus beds in the district. In its latest projection sent to Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and district administration a day ago, the government said the district will have 1,353 surplus beds with oxygen supply, 1,496 in ICU and 359 beds with ventilators for a total of 3,208 surplus beds in hospitals as per projections for May 16. The government has also projected deficit of 6,871 beds in Covid Care Centres (CCC) whereas scenario in the district is totally different. Less than 1% of total active positive patients are in CCCs since the beginning of second wave, and many CCCs are yet to be brought into use citing patients preferring home isolation. Around 80% patients are in home isolation. On April 21, the government had projected steep rise in active cases to 1,23,680 by May 2. In reality, there were 74,127 active cases on May 2 as district started to see decline in cases from April 30. With decline in weekly growth rate and TPR to some extent, the government revised projection of active cases to 1,13,093 by May 11. The district witnessed consistent decline in cases from April 30 to May 4. From 7,496 cases on April 29, cases came down to 4,182 on May 4. The cases slightly increased to 4,399 on May 5 and 4,900 on May 6. With reduction in active cases, government and private hospitals have started to see vacant beds after more than a month. In the evening on Thursday, 1,225 beds were vacant, 1,112 with oxygen supply, 112 in ICU and one with ventilator. As per state data, weekly growth rate of the district was 1.54 as on May 4 whereas it was 2.03 on April 27 and 2.24 on April 19. Similarly, weekly TPR of the district is also on decline. Weekly TPR was 35.02% on April 19 and dropped to 32.65% on April 27 and further to 29.03% on May 4. Infectious diseases specialist Dr Nitin Shinde told TOI, “There is all possibility of steep fall in number of cases in next two weeks in the district. I used to get over 90 patients in OPD on daily basis, of which around 20 required admission. For last couple of days, I am seeing only 40 patients in OPD, of which just two need hospitalization.” As per state’s projection, active cases will also come down in Yavatmal from 6,786 on Thursday to 3,173 by May 16, Bhandara 8,571 to 6,209 and Chandrapur 26,842 to 26,124 in Vidarbha. The government had projected increase in active cases in seven districts; Amravati district 8,638 on Thursday to 9,337 by May 16, Akola 4,838 to 5,489, Washim 3,981 to 4,777, Buldhana 14,809 to 21,415, Wardha 7,123 to 12,408, Gondia 4,991 to 7,418 and Gadchiroli 3,884 to 7,232. STANDINGS OF VID DISTRICTS IN STATE * Nagpur district second after Pune among 35 districts in highest active cases with 64,554 active cases on May 4, which was 10.06% of state’s active cases. Chandrapur district on 6th place with 28,597 (4.45%) cases * Nagpur district (3,85,412) second after Mumbai in highest number of tests per million population, Bhandara (2,52,842) at 5th, Wardha (2,16,817) on 6th and Gondia (1,81,606) on 10th * Buldhana district (2.83) second after Ratnagiri in highest weekly growth rate, Yavatmal (2.48) on 6th, Gadchiroli (2.39) on 7th, Wardha (2.3) on 8th and Chandrapur (2.16) on 9th * Buldhana district (39.25%) second after Palghar in highest weekly TPR and Wardha (29.97) on 8th and Nagpur (29.03%) on 11th * None of 11 districts of Vidarbha in red mark in highest case fatality rate||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/govt-projects-drop-to-41k-active-cases-3208-surplus-beds-in-dist-by-may-16/articleshow/82443152.cms||Anjaya Anparthi
---||Pune||Collector says 25 PSA plants in district to come by May-end||Pune: Collector Rajesh Deshmukh on Thursday said the district would get 25 pressure swing adsorption medical oxygen plants by the end of May. “These PSA plants will come up in the Pune and Pimpri-Chinchwad civic limits and also the rural areas. These should ease oxygen supply in the district,” he told TOI. The pressure swing adsorption (PSA) is a technology used to separate gas species from a mixture of gases under pressure. On Thursday, the collector conducted a detailed oxygen audit meeting and directed all major health hubs to judiciously follow the standard operating procedure (SOP) on using the gas essential for the treatment of Covid-19 patients. “The district administration has checked the use of oxygen in three major hospitals and could curtail the consumption of the gas by 48% in 10 days,” Deshmukh said. “We had told the health hubs — the jumbo units in the PCMC limits and Auto Cluster — to follow the SOPs as issued by the Centre,” he added. The district gets about 315 tonnes of oxygen from five units, four from Pune and one from Thane. However, the actual requirement is 331 tonnes. “The additional supplies have been drawn from the existing units and 10 tonnes have been procured from Jamnagar by road,” Deshmukh said, adding that around 85 doctors were on Thursday trained on the SOPs to be followed for using oxygen judiciously. Meanwhile, state health minister Rajesh Tope in a statement said he would raise with the Centre its decision to reduce 50 tonnes of oxygen supply to Maharashtra. “If the Centre does not provide oxygen, the state will face a serious shortage,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/collector-says-25-psa-plants-in-district-to-come-by-may-end/articleshow/82443184.cms||Nisha Nambiar
---||Delhi||Saved over 2L litre fuel with TaxiBot: IGI||New Delhi: Indira Gandhi International Airport on Thursday said that 1,000 flights have parked with the help of TaxiBots, thereby helping save 2,14,000 litres of aviation turbine fuel and reducing 532 tonnes of CO2 emissions. TaxiBots are semi-robotic machines, which help aircraft to park without the engine having to be turned on. “Introduced two years ago, TaxiBots have helped in reducing around 532 tonnes of carbon emissions at Delhi airport. It also helped airlines in saving around 214,000 litres of aviation turbine fuel (ATF), which would have been burned by the aircraft during taxiing,” said a Delhi International Airport Limited spokesperson. ---||Mumbai||Mumbai: City police reserve Goregaon hotel for +ve cops with mild symptoms||Mumbai: Policemen with mild symptoms of Covid-19 need not worry about finding a place to isolate themselves any longer. The department has reserved all rooms of a hotel in a western suburb to accommodate such personnel, so that their families do not risk catching the infection. A senior IPS officer said, “Those suffering from mild symptoms or those who are asymptomatic are required to be home quarantined. But a majority of the constabulary lives in cramped quarters and has no separate room for isolation. They are constantly worried about passing the infection to their spouse or parents.” When these personnel were advised to get admitted to Covid care centres, they showed reluctance. The reason was they feared staying in the midst of critical patients. The force, too, has a Covid care centre in Santacruz for symptomatic and seriously ill cops. The department then hit upon the idea of having an isolation centre reserved only for policemen. They approached household appliance manufacturer Cello and an NGO to get a sponsorship. “All 89 rooms of The Fern, Goregaon, have been reserved for three months. Each room has double occupancy. If a spouse or a child of a policeman has tested positive with him, they can join him at the isolation centre and keep the rest of the family safe at home,” said Dilip Sawant, additional commissioner (north region). The BMC has agreed to allocate six doctors, working in shifts, to monitor those isolating. “In home quarantine, there is nobody to check the oxygen level and other parameters of an isolated policeman. In case his health condition deteriorates, his family would have to run helter skelter to get him hospitalised. This can be avoided if he is isolating at the hotel and is being monitored by doctors,” said Sawant. Even personnel with comorbidities like diabetes or blood pressure can be monitored regularly at the centre. Medicines and immunity boosters will be provided at no cost, besides nutritious breakfast, lunch and dinner. The hotel started operating as an isolation centre on Wednesday and within 24 hours, four personnel checked in. The centre is open for officers as well as constables across ranks, police stations and branches. The Mumbai police force has lost 110 offiers and staff since the outbreak began in March last year. Overall, more than 8,600 personnel have tested positive since the pandemic started. Currently, about 384 personnel are positive.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-city-police-reserve-goregaon-hotel-for-ve-cops-with-mild-symptoms/articleshow/82441468.cms||Nitasha Natu
---||Goa||Sheikh Hassan Haroon, Goa’s first Muslim minister, passes away at 84||Panaji: Former speaker of the Goa Legislative Assembly and five-time Mormugao MLA, Sheikh Hassan Haroon passed away on Thursday at his residence in Caranzalem after a lengthy battle with diabetes. The first Muslim minister of Goa, Haroon played a key role in the establishment of the Bombay high court in Panaji and setting up of the industrial estates at Verna, Canacona and Cuncolim. He was 84 when he passed away, said his family members. Goa police accorded him a traditional salute when his final rites were conducted at St Inez. BJP as well as the opposition paid tributes to him and to his family. “Saddened to hear about the demise of Sheikh Hassan Haroon. My condolences to his family,” minister of state for defence Shripad Naik said. Though he served as a Congress MLA in the Goa Legislative Assembly from 1977 to 1994 and from 1999 to 2002, he switched over to BJP after leading a breakaway group of five Congress MLAs to merge with BJP. “Deeply pained by the passing away of Sheikh Hassan Haroon. He lived a simple life and contributed for the betterment of Goa. My condolences to his family,” opposition leader Digambar Kamat said. Haroon served as the industry minister from 1999 to 2002, speaker from 1991 to 1995 and as law and revenue minister from 1980 to 1989. After leaving the Indian National Congress, he floated his own political party called Indian National Congress (Sheikh Hassan) on August 17, 2002. Later, this party merged with BJP. “Deeply saddened by the sad news of demise of former minister and speaker Sheikh Hassan Haroon. For five terms he represented Mormugao constituency in Goa Assembly. My condolences to his family members and admirers,” former South Goa MP Narendra Sawaikar said. In the 2002 state elections, Hassan stood as a BJP candidate, but lost. In the aftermath of the anti-Muslim communal riots in Curchorem, Hassan moved away from BJP. In the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, he lent his support to South Goa Congress candidate Francisco Sardinha. “Saddened to hear the sad news of the passing away of Haroon, the former Goa speaker and minister. He will be remembered for his contribution to the growth of Goa. The Congress party extend our deepest sympathies to his son Arif and family. May he rest in everlasting peace,” state Congress president Girish Chodankar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/sheikh-hassan-haroon-goas-first-muslim-minister-passes-away-at-84/articleshow/82443308.cms||---

Those associated with the business claim that meeting the conditions introduced for home delivery of liquor is a daunting task. The list of conditions include designating a person for home delivery, this person should undergo screening to ensure he is not infected. The negative test report should be submitted to the excise department, which will issue ID cards.
