---||Pune||Chinchwad: Police arrest lady doctor for taking money to arrange bed at DCH||PUNE: The Pimpri Chinchwad police on Wednesday arrested a lady doctor on the charges of accepting money from the patients for arranging beds in the 200-bed dedicated Covid hospital (DCH) at the Auto Cluster in Chinchwad.  The hospital has been set up for providing free treatment for the Covid-19. The Pimpri Chinchwad police on May 2 had arrested three doctors including one attached to the DCH and two from a private hospital for accepting Rs 1 lakh from a woman patient on April 23 to admit and arrange a bed for her at the hospital. The arrests were made on the basis of an FIR filed by Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation’s additional municipal commissioner Ulhas Jagtap. “During the questioning, one of the doctors attached to the private hospital revealed the name of the lady doctor. He said that the woman had taken Rs 5,000 each from the relatives of two patients for arranging beds inside the dedicated Covid hospital. Based on that information, we arrested the lady doctor. We are questioning her,” an officer from the Pimpri police said. The police also carried out searches at the homes of the arrested doctors. “We have recovered Rs 3.1 lakh from one of the arrested doctors, who was attached to the private hospital,” he said. The officer said that the police are also investigating whether there are more people involved in the racket.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/police-arrest-lady-doctor-for-taking-money-to-arrange-bed-at-dch/articleshow/82443266.cms||---
---||Rajkot||Ayurveda Univ to distribute 2lL Ayush tablets||Rajkot: The Jamnagar-based Gujarat Ayurved University has started systematic distribution of Ayush 64, the poly herbal drug repurposed by the Central Council for Research in Ayurvedic Sciences (CCRAS) for Covid-19 patients. Last week, scientists from three research institutes had completed a multi-centre study and found that this drug, which was originally developed to treat malaria in 1980, was effective in asymptomatic patients or those having mild or moderate symptoms.At an average 700 patients per day, Jamnagar district has been witnessing the highest number of per day Covid cases in Saurashtra region over the last few days. This drug is recommended in addition to the conventional treatment and according to clinical study claims it reduced the hospitalization period of the patient. Anup Thakar, incharge vice chancellor of the university said, “In the first phase, we will procure two lakh tablets and distribute them in Jamnagar city to those with mild and moderate symptoms. We will also monitor the patient’s condition through a mobile application and remain in contact with them.” These tablets will be prescribed to patients who are taking treatment in home isolation or Covid care centers. According to the ministry of Ayush, Ayush 64 comprises of alstona scholaris (aqueous bark extract), picrorhiza kurroa (aqueous rhizome extract), swertia chirata (aqueous extract of whole plant) and caesalpinia crista (fine-powdered seed pulp).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/rajkot/ayurveda-univ-to-distribute-2ll-ayush-tablets/articleshow/82439978.cms||---
---||Kolkata||Cov bins go missing, waste dumped on roads||Kolkata: Water supply from Garden Reach Waterworks resumed ahead of the schedule on Thursday evening, with the engineering and maintenance team from Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s water supply department completing the work in double quick time despite being able to deploy only a third of the workforce due to Covid restrictions. “We had initially decided to go for a shutdown till dawn on Friday. But given the hot weather and difficulties that people face without water, we worked on a tight schedule and completed it by evening. Supply was resumed at 4.45 pm,” a KMC water supply department official said on Thursday. Water supply had been suspended at 10am. However, it was an uphill task for the civic body to complete the work amid the pandemic where the civic engineers had to keep in mind the Covid-protocols while engaging mechanics and labourers for the repair and maintenance work conceded the civic official. What should have been a routine shutdown turned into a major challenge for the civic body as it undertook the work and completed it on time with 100 workers instead of 300, who would have otherwise deployed. Besides repairing leakages in major pipelines at Garden Reach Waterworks and routine maintenance of valves and electrical installations, the KMC also undertook installation of pipes and valves at the waterworks. Pre-summer maintenance work was also undertaken at several water booster pumping stations in Kalighat, Chetla, Behala, Daspara, Siriti, Garfa, Bansdroni, Ranikuthi and Layelka. The preventive maintenance work will help ensure uninterrupted supply during the summer months to entire Behala, Tollygunge, Jadavpur, Garia, Chetla, Kalighat, Rashbehari, Kasba, Garfa, Dhakuria, Golf Green, and some areas located adjacent to EM Bypass. The last time KMC water supply department had taken up such a major repair work was at Garden Reach Waterworks in January. “We are trying to go for a comprehensive repair process keeping in mind heavy demand for potable water during peak of summer,” said a KMC senior official.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/cov-bins-go-missing-waste-dumped-on-roads/articleshow/82441466.cms||Saikat Ray
---||Mumbai||Maharashtra: ‘Decide in 2 weeks on Rs 50L cover for frontliners’||MUMBAI: Bombay HC on Thursday directed the state to take a decision within two weeks on continuing Rs 50 lakh Covid-19 insurance cover for frontline workers in case of death on duty. A bench of Justices K K Tated and Nitin Borkar heard a PIL by Dilip Sawant to direct the state to continue operation of the May 29, 2020, GR till the pandemic is declared over. Sawant’s petition said the GR is not continued after December 31, 2020. The letter said the GR is extended from January 1 till June 30, 2021. “A decision will be taken in 8-10 days,” he said. Sawant’s advocate Ramesh Ramamurthy then urged HC to keep the matter pending for compliance since the relief sought is to continue the scheme till the pandemic ends.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-decide-in-2-wks-on-rs-50l-cover-for-frontliners/articleshow/82445412.cms||Rosy Sequeira
---||Nagpur||Wardha lab prepares first batch of 25,000 Rem vials||Nagpur: Genetek Lifesciences Private Limited on Thursday produced the first batch of 25,000 vials of Remdesivir at its laboratory at Sewagram in Wardha district. “The first batch would be put through seven-day sterility test from Friday. On May 15, the batch is likely to be handed over to Hetero Labs,” said Mahendra Kshirsagar, owner and managing director of Genetek. US-based Gilead Sciences, which holds the patent for the anti-viral drug, had granted licence to seven pharmaceutical companies in India, including Hetero Labs Limited, to produce the drug. Genetek had procured loan licenses from Hetero for five years to manufacture the drug. “We would be able to produce 25,000 vials daily for seven days,” said Kshirsagar. Union minister for road transport and highways, Nitin Gadkari on Thursday visited Genetek. Gadkari has been instrumental in starting Remdesivir production in Vidarbha. Underlining the significance of producing the anti-viral drug here, Gadkari said it was challenging to get approvals from the department concerned as the drug is patented. “We had to seek a way out as Remdesivir shortage was leading to many complications, including Covid deaths,” he said. Kshirsagar said following the two-day ingredient testing, Genetek labs’ team of 25 scientists managed to complete filling of the first batch. In yet another development, vials meant for testing of the ‘Form fill seal’ (FFS) technology, in which medical-grade plastic would be used as vials, too were prepared. They would be put through separate suitability and stability testing. FFS testing would take place for one-and-half month following which approval would be sought. “We would be able to produce 2.5 lakhs vials of Remdesivir in plastic vials but the quantity would depend on availability of raw material and intermediates which need to be brought from foreign countries,” said Kshirsagar.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/wardha-lab-prepares-first-batch-of-25000-rem-vials/articleshow/82443264.cms||Vaibhav Ganjapure
---||Mysuru||Karnataka govt says curfew ineffective, lockdown call on May 10||BENGALURU: Halfway down the two-week curfew, Karnataka health minister K Sudhakar on Thursday admitted that it has not had desired effect in stopping the surge of Covid-19 cases amid strong indications that the Karnataka government may opt for a full-scale two-week lockdown at a crucial meeting on May 10. The present curfew ends at 6am on May 12. Health minister K Sudhakar said, “I needn’t say how this ‘janata curfew’ has been ineffective with congregations continuing. The trend is not limited to Bengaluru; districts, too, have failed to see its strict implementation. The result is not to our expectation,” he told reporters. Deputy chief minister CN Ashwath Narayan, who heads Covid-19 task force, admitted that the situation “is, of course, grim, but it (announcing a complete lockdown) would be the chief minister’s call”. Sources said the chief minister was taking inputs from all stakeholders. Cannot leave citizens of Karnataka in lurch says SC, refuses to interfere with HC orderThe Supreme Court Friday said it will not leave Karnataka citizens in lurch as it refused to interfere with the Karnataka High Court order asking the Centre to increase the daily oxygen allocation for the state from 965 MT to 1200 MT for treating Covid-19 patients. A bench of justices D Y Chandrachud and M R Shah said the high court order of May 5 is a well calibrated, deliberated and judicious exercise of power". It refused to accept the Centre's contention that if every high court starts passing orders for allocating oxygen, it would make the supply network of the country "unworkable". The bench told Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, appearing for Centre, that it has read the sequence of events and it can say that it is "well calibrated, deliberated and judicious exercise of power after taking into account the number of COVID-19 positive cases. We will not interfere with it". (With inputs from PTI)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mysuru/curfew-ineffective-govt-lockdown-call-on-may-10/articleshow/82449462.cms||B V Shiva Shankar

---||Delhi||6 cases of Covid-induced ‘black fungus’ reported||New Delhi: Doctors at a leading private facility here are seeing a rise in the number of Covid-triggered mucormycisis cases, according to a statement from the hospital. Mucormycisis is a fungal infection triggered by Covid-19. Black fungus or mucormycosis has been a cause of disease and death of patients in transplants, ICUs and immunodeficient patients since long. According to Dr Manish Munjal, senior ENT surgeon at the Sir Ganga Ram Hospital, “We are seeing a rise again in this dangerous fungal infection triggered by Covid-19. In the last two days, we have admitted six cases of mucormycisis. Last year, this deadly infection caused a high mortality with many patients suffering from the loss of eyesight and the removal of the nose and the jaw bone.” Dr Ajay Swaroop, the chairman of the ENT department at the hospital, said the use of steroids in the treatment of Covid-19 coupled with the fact that many coronavirus patients have diabetes could be one of the reasons for this rise in the number of black fungus cases again. He said the infection is commonly seen in patients who have recovered from Covid-19 but have comorbidities such as diabetes, kidney or heart failure or cancer.  PTI||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/6-cases-of-covid-induced-black-fungus-reported/articleshow/82445449.cms||---

The Velsao-Pale-Issorchim panchayat has also called for an 11-day lockdown. Besides this, four wards of the Mormugao municipal council from ward numbers 21 to 24 of the Dabolim constituency are observing a lockdown for a week after their newly-elected councillors submitted a memorandum to the Mormugao deputy collector informing him of the plans. Essential services were open from 6am to 11am and remained closed for the rest of the day. Social distancing was also being strictly followed while purchasing essential supplies from stores. ---||Mumbai||Mumbai to get six more drive-in vaccination centres for 60+ citizens||MUMBAI: Following the success of its first drive-in vaccination centre within a civic parking lot in Dadar, the BMC has decided to set up one such facility for citizens above 60 years of age in the other six administrative zones too within 24 hours. BMC commissioner I S Chahal, in his order issued on Thursday, listed a few options where such a drive-in vaccination facility could be created, including Andheri Sports Complex, Cooperage ground, Oval Maidan, MIG grounds, MCA grounds, Wankhede stadium, and Ghatkopar police grounds. According to the directive, citizens aged above 60 can get their Covishield doses at the new facilities by appointment only. The beneficiary to be vaccinated should not drive to the centre; he/she should be accompanied by an attendant or a driver to deal with adverse events following immunization, if any. Following positive reviews from people who got vaccinated at the Dadar drive-in centre, there was a demand for similar facilities across the city. Mulund MLA Mihir Kotecha said he has written to the civic body demanding a drive-in vaccination centre on Kalidas auditorium premises in his constituency. “The auditorium has adequate space to accommodate those coming in vehicles to take the jab with separate entry and exit gates. Mulund has almost 60,000 senior citizens, and even if 25,000 of them may have already taken the jab, there are many left to be administered the vaccine. Hence, there is a need for such a facility for those persons who are not very mobile,” he added. On May 4, in a first for the city, the multi-storey Kohinoor parking lot in Dadar was turned into a civic vaccination centre with a drive-in facility where senior citizens and the differently abled were given their jabs while seated in their parked vehicles. After getting their shots, they were made to spend the mandatory 30-minute observation period inside their vehicles as well. Citizens who brought in their vehicles had to pay parking charges—Rs 60 an hour. On day one, 417 persons took the jab while seated in their cars at Kohinoor parking lot. Meanwhile, the BMC has decided to take in only 350 vehicles daily following cars at the Dadar vaccination centre, after cars were found queuing up on the road leading to a traffic jam on Wednesday.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-city-to-get-six-more-drive-in-vax-centres-for-60-citizens/articleshow/82443350.cms||Richa Pinto

---||Delhi||Covid-19: Positivity rate continues declining trend in Delhi, at 24%||NEW DELHI: The positivity rate of Covid-19 in Delhi declined for the fourth consecutive day on Thursday.  From 30% on May 3, it dipped to 27% on May 4, 26% on May 5 and 24% on May 6. In April third week, Delhi’s positivity rate—number of positive cases from those tested—had touched 36%, which was among the highest in the country. The numbers of new cases and deaths have also reduced significantly raising hopes of improvement in the outbreak situation. On Thursday, the city recorded 19,133 new cases from 78,780 tests conducted in 24 hours. This is the third time in the last four days that the number of new cases remained below 20,000. Earlier, on May 3 and May 4, the city had recorded 18,043 and 19,953 new cases, respectively. The number of fresh fatalities recorded on Thursday was 335. “There are signs of improvement. But we cannot be complacent yet. A positivity rate of 24% is still very high. We still have a huge rush of patients in hospitals and most of the ICU beds are running full,” said a senior health official. Data shared by the state health department shows there are 90,629 active cases of Covid-19 in Delhi at present. Of them, 50,562 are in home isolation. Around 25,000 patients are admitted in various hospitals. There are a total of 22,057 Covid beds in the city, of which 20,274 are occupied. The total number of ICU beds is 5,569, of which 5,545 are occupied. ICU bed with ventilator support is available in only one hospital in Karo Bagh. “My friend needs an ICU bed urgently. I have been calling on all numbers and helplines. But no hospital is willing to admit. Where are the vacant beds?” Nikhil Kumar, a resident of Malviya Nagar, asked. He added that most of the beds that are available do not even have high flow oxygen and other facilities needed for critical care management. On the brighter side, the recovery rate has picked up. In the last one week, nearly 1.5 lakh people have recovered from the infection. “The lockdown has really helped reduce the spread of the disease. It should continue for a few more days to gain complete control over the disease and expand the health infrastructure to cope up with the patient rush,” the official said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/positivity-rate-continues-declining-trend-at-24/articleshow/82443341.cms||Durgesh Nandan Jha

---||Nagpur||Officials make web series to push vax, tests in Melghat||Nagpur: In remote Melghat Hills of Amravati, the district administration is now trying its hand on YouTubing to convince the tribal population to get vaccinated and Covid tested. Health officials have been facing a strong resistance to vaccination and testing drives in the tribal pocket.To counter this, administration is coming up with a web series in the local Korku language to dispel the myths. The series has been posted on the YouTube, apart from being widely shared on the WhattsApp.With internet having a decent penetration even in Melghat, once infamous for malnutrition, the web series may help change people’s minds, the officials are hoping. The move was initiated by the sub divisional officer (SDO), Deepali Sethi. It is titled Corona Haritva Melghat Jituva – which translates to Corona loses and Melghat wins. “Corona Chuj Hoy” (what is Corona), starts the health counselor who is interviewing Dr Dayaram Jawarkar from the sub-divisional hospital at Dharni. He replies in the same language. Another episode in the series is planned by this Saturday.In the first video, the basics are explained. Jawarkar tells Covid spreads from one person to another but there is no need to be scared. They can get well if they reach hospital in time. All they have to do is follow the precautions.“Even people of Melghat, especially the young, have smartphones. The video has been spread on WhatsApp groups also. Though it is available on YouTube, not everyone will be watching it directly. Fowarding it will bring the message to their phones,” Jawarkar told TOI. “There are a lot of misconceptions about Covid that need to be cleared. The series needs to be circulated deeper in the villages,” he said.“The results can be already seen. Since last two three days, the locals have started voluntarily reaching the primary health centre (PHC) at our village for a test,” said Mamta Sonkar, the health department’s counsellor, who is seen interviewing the doctor in the video. The locals fear that if they test positive, they may be sent to Amravati, but we are telling them many will only need home isolation.“One out 5 to 6 who turned up was found positive. He has been isolated at home,” she said.“The video is already running at tribal department’s office. It has got over a thousand views in a short time,” said Sethi, the SDO. “There was a strong reluctance among local population to vaccination and testing. It was realized talking to them in their own language may help,” she said.Sethi said in the subsequent videos, success stories may be presented. There would be interviews of people including featuring old people who remain perfectly healthy after vaccination.“Even the local panchayats will be roped in. One of the NGOs has extracted the audio part which is being played on loudspeakers in remote villages,” said Sethi.No positive cases found in testing drive Last month, the district administration had conducted a drive to test close contacts after a number of unexplained deaths were found. The drive continues but most of contacts were found negative.“The rules don’t allow testing of bodies, so we started a drive to test the contacts. Positive cases were not found. The toll has also stabilized with no major incident reported,” said Deepali Sethi, Dharni sub-divsional officer (SDO).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/officials-make-web-series-to-push-vax-tests-in-melghat/articleshow/82443348.cms||Shishir Arya
---||Delhi||AIIMS RDA writes to PM Modi on salary payment to foreign docs||New Delhi: Amid the raging second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Resident Doctors Association (RDA) of All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) said that 65 foreign nationals, including those from Nepal, training at the institute have not received their salaries. ---||Pune||Still to early to say if weather boosts Covid: Experts||PUNE: The country's leading public health experts have said that it's still too early to say if Covid-19 is seasonal as the virus that causes it is new. There are concerns that Covid may surge during the upcoming monsoon, particularly because of higher humidity levels. But Samiran Panda, head of the ICMR's epidemiology and communicable diseases division, said scientists are yet to determine if there's a clear link between weather and the virus. "So far, only endemic diseases can be connected to seasonal weather changes. Only when Covid-19 reaches an endemic stage, can it be gauged which season causes a spurt in SARS-CoV-2 infections." Panda said a virus takes on pandemic proportions when it efficiently transmits across countries - like the flu pandemic did in 1918. But the flu is no longer a pandemic; it's now endemic, he said. He added, "When an infectious disease affects a large number of people within a country or region, it is called an epidemic. Gradually, it simmers down to less extensive levels, becoming endemic to a community or country. So seasonality usually plays a role when an infectious disease becomes endemic. Covid-19 is yet to achieve that state." Maharashtra disease surveillance officer Pradeep Awate said, "So far, we have not found a distinguishable link between weather and Covid spread in India. Several countries have seen Covid waves during different seasons. Many infections do have a weather connection, but so far, that connection has not been established in case of the Covid-19 pandemic." Awate, however, said the monsoon does cause a spike in vector-borne and water-borne diseases such as dengue, malaria, cholera, influenza, hepatitis, typhoid and may slightly increase the possibility of Covid co-infections. "We have geared up our surveillance system, with specific stress on improving water quality," he said. Shashank Joshi, member of the state Covid-19 task force, said, "Temperature and humidity still remain an area of research in case of Covid-19. The northern hemispheric, temperate regional Covid waves in winters and the tropical Indian wave in hotter, humid environments merit scientific scrutiny. That said, we need double preparedness during the upcoming monsoon season as it is a time when monsoon-related infections surge."||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/still-to-early-to-say-if-weather-boosts-covid-experts/articleshow/82443376.cms||Neha Madaan
---||Mumbai||Lockdown lowers WR track deaths by more than 50%||MUMBAI: Call it a silver lining to pandemic induced curbs, casualties due to track crossing have reduced by more than half on the Western Railways. Trespassing related deaths reduced from 528 in 2019-20 to 222 in 2020-21. Besides the fact that the volume of passengers has been much lower than pre-Covid times, the completion of infrastructural works on WR has also contributed towards bringing down the number of fatalities. The Goregaon to Dahisar section had the highest deaths for two consecutive years— 169 casualties in 2019-20 and 63 in the past financial year. It was followed by the Mira Road-Vaitarna section. “Stations like Borivali, Nalasopara and Virar are densely packed during peak hours and many travellers take a short-cut by hopping across the tracks. But a key reason for trespassing deaths is the presence of slum colonies adjacent to the tracks,” said GRP senior inspector Bhaskar Pawar, who has headed police chowkies in both these sections. At Dahisar, for instance, shanties have come up inside railway land. There are slum colonies at Kandivali and Goregaon. Residents frequently cross the tracks to go to work or youngsters to travel to college. In the fringes of the city, people use tracks to walk for large distances when there is no permanent road constructed by rural authorities. WR officials said 276 encroachments have been removed from the suburban section and drives will continue. “We roped in civil engineering officials to devise infrastructural solutions to prevent deaths. About 15 kms of boundary wall has been constructed in the suburban section and wherever walls couldn’t come up, strong fencing was put up as a physical barrier to deter trespassing. Gaps in 71 boundary walls were plugged in the past two years,” said Sumit Thakur, WR spokesperson. Gates, manned by private securitymen, were installed at 33 locations where existing boundary walls had to be broken for construction. Platform height was raised at 145 locations to reduce the gap between the door of the rake and the platform. Nearly 14000 people were prosecuted for trespassing in the past two years. “We want to encourage commuters to use FOBs and dissuade them from hopping across tracks and that prompted the installation of dividers between two seats of tracks at all stations. Our mission is to achieve zero deaths on the railways,” said Thakur.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-lockdown-lowers-wr-track-deaths-by-more-than-50/articleshow/82443419.cms||Nitasha Natu

---||Kolkata||Vaccine drive at airport for employees in 18-44 age group||Kolkata: The vaccination drive for the 18-44 age group got underway at the Kolkata airport on Thursday with young employees of air traffic services (ATS), communication, navigation & surveillance (CNS) team, fire fighting personnel and ground operations staff receiving their first jab. “Around 200 persons from the four departments, including around 120 ATCOs, received the jab on Thursday. Given the limited number of vaccines available for the 18-44 age group, all 500-odd that are eligible could not be inoculated in a single session. Another session will be organised for the 300 people that are left,” said an Airports Authority of India (AAI) official. A 28-year-old ATCO, who was among the youngest lot to get the jab along with a few 27-year-old new joinees, said he was extremely relieved to now have some sort of protection against the virus. “We have all been working right through the pandemic and are frontline workers. But unlike healthcare staff, policemen, civic workers and even those who were deputed for election duty, we did not get the frontline staff status. The Air Traffic Controllers’ Guild, the umbrella organisation of ATCOs, made the appeal to AAI that organised the session,” the ATCO recounted. Around 700-odd employees and contractual staff of private airlines including ground staff and baggage handlers are yet to be enrolled in the vaccination programme. “All of us have worked through the pandemic and should not be discriminated,” said Kolkata AOC chairman Rahul Wadhwa.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/vaccine-drive-at-airport-for-employees-in-18-44-age-group/articleshow/82441471.cms||Subhro Niyogi
---||Surat||Medical officers went on strike demanding salary hike||Surat: Around 73 medical officers (MO) working on contract basis at the Surat Municipal Institute of Medical Education and Research (SMIMER) hospital went on flash strike on Thursday morning demanding pay hike at par with state government’s recent announcement for newly appointed contractual doctors. The doctors resumed duty in the afternoon after they were assured of consideration of their demands by senior officers of the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC). The MOs at SMC-run SMIMER are currently getting Rs 60,000 per month salary. These MOs have been working with SMIMER since last one year on contract. As per state government’s recent announcement MOs recruited in government hospitals will get Rs 1.25 lakh salary. “We are demanding that we should get the salary as per government’s salary structure for MOs in government hospitals. Freshers will be getting higher salaries than those who are working since last one year,” said one of the protesting MOs. “We have submitted an application to SMC officials on Wednesday and informed them about our demands in the past as well. But they did not do anything hence we had to go on strike,” said an MO. “We are also not being allowed to apply again and terminating our existing contract. In New Civil Hospital MOs will get Rs 1.25 lakh salary,” he added. “SMC will consider the demand and take necessary steps. But going on strike is not the option and we have asked the doctors to continue working,” said a senior health department official in SMC.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/surat/medical-officers-went-on-strike-demanding-salary-hike/articleshow/82440067.cms||---
---||Goa||GMC doctors suffer mental trauma at high death rate||PANAJI: Doctors at Goa Medical College and Hospital (GMC), which reported 45 deaths in Wednesday’s health bulletin, say they’re mentally traumatised. “We are the ones extremely used to seeing patients die throughout our career, but not in these numbers and not so quickly. We see many young patients too and this is very disturbing,” a doctor handing Covid patients told TOI. Most who are dying are severe pneumonia cases who have a bad CT score, the doctor said. “Few are getting proper treatment and adequate oxygen support as there are too many patients who are bad,” the doctor added. Another doctor said that while they can handle the pressure, the relatives often cannot cope with it. “They panic as they see their loved ones literally gasping for breath and dying. We see so many deaths continuously. Relatives are not used to it and want to do everything possible to save their loved one. We are doing all we can,” the doctor at the GMC said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/gmc-docs-suffer-mental-trauma-at-high-death-rate/articleshow/82445476.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क
---||Delhi||HC on black marketing, hoarding of O2: ‘Moral fabric dismembered’||New Delhi: In the time of crisis, unfortunately everybody is not coming together and that is why there is black marketing and hoarding, Delhi High Court remarked while hearing matters related to Covid-19 resource management in the national capital. Justices Vipin Sanghi and Rekha Palli further noted, “Otherwise whose conscience would allow hoarding of oxygen? Moral fabric has been dismembered. And we can see the effects of that.” Earlier, an advocate Tarun Chandiok, a Covid-19 survivor who has just recovered, joined the proceedings. “How are you doing?” the bench enquired. Chandiok, who had difficulty in breathing, responded, “I have been advised 10 days of bed rest by doctors.” “Wish you a fast recovery,” the court told him. Chandiok shared his experience of being hospitalised for nine days. “I just got discharged. As far as Remdisivir is concerned, last week the hospital did raise the requisition for us to arrange it privately. Thankfully we have resources, but everyone doesn’t have the wherewithal to pay Rs 30,000-40,000,” he said. After Chandiok reasoned with the hospital, pointing out its responsibility regarding medicines and other resources and ensuring there was no black marketing, an indent was raised. A requisition, he learnt, first goes to the hospital pharmacy and then it raises a request with the dealer on a demand-to-demand basis. “People are running from pillar to post. There are unscrupulous people procuring medicines,” the lawyer claimed. Another issue faced by Chandiok was blood plasma. When plasma was sought, 16 people were arranged, but 15 were rejected. There is also only one centre, The Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, at Vasant Kunj, in the city for plasma, he pointed out. He said citizens had fundamental rights and the state had an obligation to set up more centres. “Everybody can’t rush to Vasant Kunj from different parts of Delhi.” He said those who were hospitalised were in dire need of plasma. “After three months, antibodies are useless. There is information on volunteers circulating on social media. People are asking for Rs 80,000-90,000 to donate plasma,” he said. The lawyer suggested that donating plasma should be made mandatory for every individual who had recovered from Covid-19. “Any defiance should be penal. It is also your responsibility as a citizen. If we don’t stand together in these times, what kind of society are we? Breaching a lockdown can attract penal consequences, then why should a recovered Covid patient refuse to donate plasma?” asked Chandiok. He further pointed out that the city was at war and running out of foot soldiers. Another suggestion, which the court has been insisting upon, is the inclusion of those medical professionals who can offer their services via digital means. “A large section of doctors might not want to go in the field because of age, comorbidities… one has to respect that. Still they can render needful services through teleconferencing,” the court observed. The amicus curiae, senior advocate Rajshekhar Rao, underlined that Chandiok was making some important points.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/hc-on-black-marketing-hoarding-of-o2-moral-fabric-dismembered/articleshow/82443452.cms||Aamir Khan
---||Goa||Tar balls grab eyeballs on Salcete’s coastal belt again||Colva: Tar balls have surfaced along the beach stretch in Salcete from Colva to Cavelossim. Thick skewed lines of this oily substance are seen deposited on the stretch where the high tide line reaches.  Traditional fishermen say it’s an annual phenomenon. Fishermen claim that as the monsoon approaches, churning of the currents in the sea takes place. The oil released by vessels coagulates with the agitated tidal movement and reaches the coast.  Tar balls are lumps of solidified crude oil found in or on the sea that get washed up on the shore. Experts say that tarball pollution has severe consequences not only on the beauty of the beach, but also marine life like crabs and shrimps.  Sources in the department of tourism informed that they are aware of the tar balls getting deposited in the Salcete coastal area and the cleaning process has already begun. The Salcete coastal stretch consists of villages of Betalbatim, Colva, Benaulim, Varca, Carmona and Cavelossim.  Surfacing of tar balls in the coastline is an undesirable seasonal occurrence every summer, in the weeks preceding the rains.  Tar balls have been spotted on the beaches of Goa for decades. Earlier the incidence was less, but in the past few years there is a marked increase as the gooey substance is being washed ashore in larger quantities.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/tar-balls-grab-eyeballs-on-salcetes-coastal-belt-again/articleshow/82443414.cms||---
---||Chandigarh||Chandigarh prepares back-up plan to get oxygen from Punjab and Haryana||CHANDIGARH: The UT administration is preparing a back-up plan to get medical oxygen supply from Punjab and Haryana to handle a crisis at the eleventh hours. The administration has formed a team to prepare the plan. The team will coordinate with the neighbouring states and assure them that the oxygen provided by them will be replenished from the next supply quota of UT. Yashpal Garg, nodal officer of oxygen supplies in UT, said, “UT official Sorabh Kumar Arora and medical officer Dr Manjit Singh will supervise the overall supply, distribution and consumption of medical oxygen in Chandigarh and prepare a back-up plan to handle any crisis.” The order issued by Garg reads, “All the oxygen generators within Chandigarh are directed to cater to the need of health institutions within the city only. Further, they will ensure that industrial cylinders are not accepted for refilling. The cylinders which are prescribed for medical oxygen should only be used. The cylinders should be tested as per the prescribed guidelines / standards to avoid any mishap during the process of refilling and transportation.”  “The refilling of medical oxygen cylinders for each of the private healthcare institution will be decided by PCS Jagjit Singh. To check delay in supply, the requirement of cylinders should be indicated to the oxygen generators / private refilling vendors in advance daily,” the order adds. ‘Mini Covid centres to make their own O2 arrangements’ Considering acute shortage of medical oxygen for patients admitted to government hospitals, the UT in its order said the mini Covid care centres will make their own arrangements for oxygen either through cylinders or oxygen concentrators. “Till proper oxygen arrangements are made, they may cater to only those patients who do not require oxygen,” states the order.  Request to Punjab govt The UT has written to the Punjab government that the remaining medical oxygen quota of the UT be allowed to be filled in cylinders at Ms Jalan Gases, Rajpura, Patiala. In the letter, it has been requested that M/s Chandigarh Gases, Industrial Area, Phase 1, be permitted to get the cylinders refilled at M/s Jalan Gases before transporting them back to the government and private hospitals in Chandigarh.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/ut-prepares-back-up-plan-to-get-o2-from-pb-and-hry/articleshow/82441472.cms||Rajinder Nagarkoti
---||Nagpur||Vax for 45-plus resumes after 5 days, 12k take jab in city||Nagpur: Hit badly for five days, Covid-19 vaccination of 45-plus age group resumed in city on Thursday after Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) received fresh vaccine stock a day ago. Despite availability of Covaxin doses, two centres at GMCH had to shut twice. Mayor Dayashankar Tiwari on Thursday wrote to CM Uddhav Thackeray asking NMC be allowed to procure vaccine directly from manufacturers. He also urged all legislators of the city to give funds for it. Accordingly, leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis and MLC Pravin Datke handed over letters committing Rs 1 crore each from legislators’ fund. With 20,000 doses of Covishield received on Wednesday evening, NMC resumed vaccination for 45-plus age group at 87 centres in government-run hospitals and its primary health centres, satellite centres on Thursday. People in large numbers, especially senior citizens, thronged the centres from 9am. But the centres started inoculation only around 12noon when team from centres brought doses from NMC store house. 8,698 people from 45-plus age group took first and second dose. Many centres closed before normal schedule as they exhausted stock allotted to them. Some centres distributed tokens to people for Friday. A few healthcare workers (HCW) and frontline workers (FLW) waiting for second dose of Covishield also happened to complete their vaccination on Thursday. NMC additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi and chief medical officer Dr Sanjay Chilkar said vaccination for 45-plus age group will continue on Friday. “Priority will be given for people due for second dose. NMC is not having sufficient doses,” they said. NMC was left with around 10,000 doses of Covishield that will likely be used up on Friday. Vaccination will again take a hit on Saturday in case fresh stock is not received. Vaccination of Covaxin for 45-plus continued normally at NMC’s Mahal Diagnostic Centre. Two centres at GMCH shut down in morning after administering second dose to around 100 people. For the first time since roll out of vaccine, GMCH’s centres were shut for want of doses. Dr Chilkar arranged 300 doses from Mahal Diagnostic Centre for them allowing them to resume inoculation. They were again shut well before closure timing of 10pm as those 300 doses were exhausted. Dr Chilkar said, “NMC requested and got 3,000 doses of Covaxin from Bhandara last week. It helped in uninterrupted vaccination at three centres. We are trying our best to get doses from other districts or government.” NMC received 6,000 doses of Covaxin from the state government on Wednesday. But the doses are meant for only 18-44 years age group. After allowing this age group, the central government had revised guidelines of vaccination. Centre will provide doses for HCW, FLW and 45-plus age group. State will facilitate for 18-44 years age group. Doses provided by Centre cannot be used for 18-44 years and stock of 18-44 years for 45-plus. Hence, the civic body was unable to provide doses to GMCH despite having it with it. The same is likely to continue on Friday. With arrival of 6,000 doses of Covaxin for 18-44 years age group, NMC has increased their centres to six. 1,638 people from this age group took the jab on Thursday. Thus, NMC conducted vaccination at 96 centres on Thursday. None of 45 private hospitals procured vaccine from manufacturers and remained closed for sixth consecutive day. Vaccination increased to 11,906 on Thursday from just 1,688 on Wednesday. On April 30, in all 10,725 had taken the jab. Since then, the number fell down for want of doses. 4,960 got the jab on May 1 followed by 2,408 on May 2. It was 1,741 on May 3 and 1,647 on May 4.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/vax-for-45-plus-resumes-after-5-days-12k-take-jab-in-city/articleshow/82443105.cms||Anjaya Anparthi

---||Aurangabad||School bag, uniform producers turn to body bag biz||Aurangabad: With educational institutions shut since the coronavirus pandemic began, manufacturers of school bags and uniforms in Marathwada have turned their focus to body bags, PPE kits and masks. The exodus of migrant workers from places like Mumbai is benefiting the industry in the region, as local producers have started getting bulk orders from hospitals and NGOs from the bigger cities. Prince Chordiya, a manufacturer of school bags, says he would never have imagined that he would be re-directing his trade to making body bags for Covid victims. He has a unit in Pandharpur on the outskirts of Aurangabad city. Chordiya, who supplies body bags to major hospitals, including GMCH here, told TOI, “We have also got an order of one lakh body bags from an NGO in Mumbai. The orders are coming from metro cities as labourers, fearing complete lockdown, have returned to their home states.” The manufacturers from the region say their body bags are much in demand as their sale price is cheaper due to comparatively less wages being paid here than in metro cities. Several hospitals and NGOs from places like Pune, Nashik and Mumbai prefer placing orders for body bags and PPE kits with them. Manoj Khandelwal, who has a unit in Aurangabad and also outsources work to other parts of Marathwada, says that he has made slight modifications to his unit for manufacturing PPE kits. “We had produced thousands of school uniforms before March 2020 for educational institutions. However, the entire stock could not be sold due to the lockdown and restrictions. We have kept our stock in the godowns and hope that schools start soon. Since April 2020, we started manufacturing PPE kits and body bags,” he said. Khandelwal said that more manufacturers are getting into this new business, which has resulted in stiff competition and slashed profit margins. Smaller set-ups unable to compete with major players have switched over to manufacturing OT gowns and aprons. Abdul Azim Pasha, who is also into school and sports uniform manufacture, says the industry is desperately waiting for resumption of schools. “Due to lack of infrastructure, we cannot meet the demand for PPE kits and body bags in large numbers, so we have started preparing OT gowns and aprons,” he says. Pasha had closed his unit in Mumbai due to a shortage of manpower and started a unit in Aurangabad as workers are available. Pasha said he supplies body bags in smaller numbers only when major players run out of stocks and he is approached by hospitals. Ghansham Pawar, who is into manufacturing uniforms for security guards and industrial workers, says the industries are yet to completely recover from the labour exodus it faced last year. “Due to the lockdown, uniforms are not a priority for many industries. Hence, I have started making face masks and selling them to industrial labourers,” Pawar says. According to rough estimates, there are over 1,000 units across the state manufacturing body bags, PPE kits, OT gowns and masks.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/aurangabad/school-bag-uniform-producers-turn-to-body-bag-biz/articleshow/82437936.cms||Mohammed Akhef
---||Mumbai||Air ambulance makes ‘belly landing’ at Mumbai airport after wheel falls off||MUMBAI: An air ambulance with a lung transplant patient and four others carried out a ‘belly landing’—touchdown sans landing gear—at Mumbai airport after a wheel of the aircraft fell off during takeoff from Nagpur on Thursday evening. The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) has initiated a preliminary investigation into the serious incident. The Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau might take over the investigation, said a source. Early in the evening, the Beechcraft King Air C-90 air ambulance (VT-JIL), operated by Delhi-based Jet Serve Aviation, with two pilots, a doctor, a patient and a relative from Durgapur landed in Nagpur to refuel. The patient was being flown to Mumbai for a lung transplant, said an official from Jet Serve Aviation. “During takeoff from Nagpur airport around 5.50pm, a wheel of the aircraft fell off. A CISF personnel posted on ground saw that and informed the air traffic control. The pilots were informed and they radioed the Mumbai air traffic control asking for an emergency landing,” said a source. A pilot, requesting anonymity, said: “The aircraft has no warning system to alert the pilots about the missing portion of the landing gear. Had the CISF personnel not made that life-saving observation, the aircraft would have had an eventful landing in Mumbai airport and with so much fuel on board it would have turned into a major accident.” By 6pm, the Mumbai airport air traffic control and the local DGCA office were informed about the tyre-less aircraft heading towards the city airport for an emergency landing. Around 8.30pm, even as the pilots circled over Mumbai airport, burning off fuel to lighten the aircraft in preparation for a belly landing; on ground, the runway 27 was sprayed with foam to prevent a fire. “The airport’s emergency response team, including fire and rescue responders, follow-me vehicles, CISF personnel, medical team, ambulance and others were on standby to handle the emergency,” said a Mumbai International Airport Ltd (MIAL) spokesperson. With all the eyes set on it—DGCA officials posted at the Mumbai air traffic control, Mumbai airport emergency response team, officials from the charter industry among others-—the aircraft landed safely around 9.10am on its ‘belly’, that is it landed on the underside of the fuselage and came to a halt within the runway. “All passengers were evacuated safely. Flights operating in/out of Mumbai airport were not affected,” said the MIAL spokesperson. A source from the charter industry said the flight was commanded by Capt Kesri Singh, a highly experienced pilot. An official from Jet Serve Aviation said that none on board were injured, the aircraft had no damage and the patient was moved to Nanavati Hospital. Watch Mumbai: Air ambulance loses tyre during take off, lands safely||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-air-ambulance-makes-belly-landing-after-wheel-falls-off/articleshow/82443468.cms||Manju V

---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: ‘Use distilled water for oxygen, ensure medicines are available’, says experts||AHMEDABAD: The mucormycosis crisis plaguing hundreds of Covid-19 recovered patients in the past one month has led to specialist doctors and public health experts pressing the panic button, asking for steps to check fungal spread and regulate availability as well as price of anti-fungal medicine like Amphotericin B that is fast growing scarce. “The crisis of mucormycosis triggered by the second wave of Covid-19 is huge. We are seeing unprecedented flow of patients struggling with black fungus invading their nose, sinuses, eyes, and even brain. Surgeons are working hard to debride (surgically remove) the fungus but anti-fungal medicine is its cure,” said Dr Neena Bhalodiya, head of Ear, Nose, Throat (ENT) department at Sola Civil Hospital. Dr Bhalodiya said, “It is the need of the hour to create major awareness about mucormycosis invasion in the aftermath of Covid-19 among patients and local doctors across cities and villages as early detection is key to patient’s survival.” Top sources in the state government said that an alert has been sounded about mucormycosis outbreak in Covid-19 recovered patients. “A team of specialists is being drawn up to create awareness amongst medical staff in towns and rural blocks about early signs and treatment of mucormycosis to prevent large number of people from catching the infection, which is highly morbid and has high death rate also,” said a senior health department official. He said that government is also taking stock of the availability of the anti-fungal injections to treat mucormycosis and a system will be soon put in place to ensure its availability to patients detected with the infection. ENT surgeon at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital, Dr Devang Gupta, said that some 20% mucormycosis patients end up losing their eye-sight.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/use-distilled-water-for-o2-ensure-meds-are-available/articleshow/82441628.cms||---

---||Kolkata||Young professionals don chef’s garb for Cov families||Kolkata: Young professionals, many of them in their 20s, have stepped forward to deliver home-made meals to the doorsteps of Covid-affected families. These young professionals are reaching out to those in distress with the comfort of at least taking care of their nutritional needs. Agrata Datta (29), a resident of Lake Gardens and a banker working from home, is shuffling between her 9am-7pm job to cook meals for at least 7-8 persons daily for the last two weeks. “I was inspired by a social media post where a group of men in Hyderabad were serving free meals to Covid patients,” said Datta, who caters to people living in Jodhpur Park, Lake Gardens and surrounding areas. Swastik Pal (29), a professional photographer who took up his second love — cooking — during the pandemic to help Covid-affected families — supplies meals in the Rajarhat-New Town-Baguiati belt. “My friends have also joined the initiative and we are serving meals for 16 people daily,” said Pal. Most of them have taken to cooking for the first time in their life. The meal includes protein-rich diet comprising chicken stew or egg with rice, dal and a vegetable. A family in Behala has taken it upon themselves to feed 11 families two times a day regularly for the last 10 days. While Tapasi Saha (54) cooks the meals at her home kitchen, her husband does the packaging. Their children Anurag (29) and Asmita (23) attend calls, verifies them and lists daily requirements. ---||Mumbai||Mumbai: 2 bizmen held for Sunrise hosp fire by Bhandup cops||Mumbai: Bhandup police on Thursday arrested the proprietor of Pona corporation, Haresh Joshi and Privilege Healthcare CEO Goerge Putthu Sherri for a fire at Dreams Mall in Bhandup in which 11 patients undergoing treatment at Sunrise Hospital died on March 26.Seven patients who died due to the fire were in ICU; three were in general wards and many were on oxygen support when the fire broke out. Officials said they died of asphyxiation due to smoke inhalation. Privilege Healthcare runs the hospital. Bhandup police headed by ACP (Mulund division) Priya Dhakne on Thursday produced them before the metropolitan magistrate court, which remanded them to police custody till May 10.Bhandup police had booked mall owners Rakesh Wadhwan, Nikhita Amit Singh Trehan, Sarang Wadhwan, Deepak Shirke, Sunrise hospital’s directors Amitsingh Trehan, Nikhita Amitsingh, Sweety Jain and other directors responsible for running Sunrise hospital. Mumbai fire brigade found water pumps and smoke detectors were non-functional. Sources said Pona corporation, a government licensed agency, tested the fire system, after which fire brigade gave the NOC. “It transpired that Joshi, in connivance with Sherri, submitted bogus fitness certificates to fire brigade and obtained an NOC,’’ said DCP (zone VII) Prashant Kadam. S Ahmed Ali||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-2-bizmen-held-for-sunrise-hosp-fire-by-bhandup-cops/articleshow/82443485.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Medical teachers stage demonstration, threaten strike||AHMEDABAD: Medical teachers at BJ Medical College staged a demonstration on Thursday morning in protest of the government apathy towards their long-pending demands with regard to their service conditions. The teaching staff even threatened to go on a strike. The Gujarat Medical Teachers Association wrote to the chief minister two days ago and listed the demands, which are pending for more than a decade. The association urged immediate response from the authorities. But when they did not get any response, they staged a demonstration and threatened to go on a strike at all six government-run medical colleges across the state to press for their demands. The association has even threatened to go on a hunger strike, if their demands are not met. The medical teachers said that in this time of Covid-19, all the demands made by any unit of health department have been accepted after they have gone for a strike. The medical teachers, who have been silently asking for their rights, would be constrained to stage demonstration and go on a strike. The medical teachers have demanded that all ad hoc teachers in government colleges should be regularized by way of a single resolution. They have demanded benefits of the 7th Pay Commission with regard to the pay limit as adopted in the 2017 resolution by the state government. They have been demanding a stop to the appointment of medical teachers on contractual basis. They have also asked for an option of private practice for a medical teacher, once s/he has spent 10 years in service. They have also demanded that the exercise for evaluation and promotion should be regularly conducted by the GPSC and Departmental Promotion Committee (DPC). The association has demanded implementation of the Tikoo Commission’s recommendations along with other resolutions adopted by the government. The Junior Doctors Association has extended support to their teachers.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/medical-teachers-stage-demonstration-threaten-strike/articleshow/82441484.cms||---
---||India||Deshmukh fails to get interim relief from HC in CBI’s graft case||MUMBAI: Granting former home minister Anil Deshmukh no immediate interim relief, the Bombay HC on Thursday adjourned a petition filed by the NCP politician that sought quashing of the FIR filed against him by the CBI under the Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) as the central agency said it needed time to file its reply. Moments after senior counsel Amit Desai, appearing for Deshmukh, began his submissions, additional solicitor general Anil Singh for CBI said the petition copy was served on Wednesday evening and he needed four weeks to file a reply to the quashing petition. He said that as far as interim relief was concerned, he would be ready to argue. Desai, citing urgency, said he would seek interim relief of "no coercive steps". A bench of Justice S S Shinde and Justice Manish Pitale observed that since the CBI had been served on Wednesday and had asked for time, it should be given reasonable time. The HC gave Deshmukh liberty to move the vacation bench in case of extreme urgency with 48-hour notice to the CBI. The bench passed an order stating that Singh had sought four weeks' time, which is "vehemently opposed by Desai". who submits "there is an urgency". The HC said it was inclined to grant the CBI reasonable time to file its reply but on Desai's request granted Deshmukh liberty to approach the court for any extremely urgent relief during the court vacation, but with prior notice to the CBI. Deshmukh's petition said the FIR followed a "biased, dubious" inquiry, "with ulterior motive at the behest of those having political or other vendetta" against him. Deshmukh said that prior sanction was necessary to register the FIR against him as he was a minister when the offence was alleged to have occurred.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/deshmukh-fails-to-get-interim-relief-from-hc-in-cbis-graft-case/articleshow/82447472.cms||Swati Deshpande

The number of cases is increasing every day and what is worrying is high death rates in Goa considering the size of our total population,” said Naik. AITUC has urged the government to set up healthcare facilities at industrial estates with adequate medical care and treatment facilities. AITUC has also demanded that the government should appoint a high-ranking officer to visit factories in all industrial estates to gather data of Covid infections and ensure that protocols are followed. “If required, the affected factories must be declared as micro containment areas to curb the spread of deadly coronavirus. Workers who test positive must be paid full wages while on leave,” said Naik. The accused were selling Remdesivir injections and oxygen cylinders in black. In all, 225 FIRs have been registered in the last few days after a helpline, 011-23469900, was launched to receive public complaints, along with cyber helpline 155260. “As many as 78 cases of black marketing and hoarding have been registered. In all, 144 culprits have been arrested so far, while teams are conducting raids to nab more,” Delhi Police PRO Chinmoy Biswal said, adding that cooperation of police forces from other states has been sought to nab organised gangs operating from Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Haryana, etc. Their links have been found in the technical analysis being done by the Cyber Cell and Crime Branch. “Teams are also working to bust these interstate gangs by freezing the suspected bank accounts and transaction gateways through National Payments Corporation of India,” Biswal added. Cops have also booked the corporate manager and security supervisor of a private hospital who were getting more cylinders filled than sought by the hospital. In Seelampur too, a man was arrested for selling Remdesivir in black.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/5-arrested-for-duping-people-with-fake-info-on-covid-help/articleshow/82443596.cms||---

---||Chandigarh||As 8 lions test positive in Hyderabad, Chhatbir zoo closed till May 31||MOHALI: After eight lions in Hyderabad tested positive for Covid-19, the Punjab government issued orders to close all the zoos of the state, including the one in Chhatbir, till May 31. Last year too, Chhatbir zoo was closed after lions in a US zoo tested positive. Chhatbir zoo field director Naresh Mahajan said, “As of now all the animals are safe and show no symptoms of coronavirus. All the animals are under observation and will be tested. The employees, whose samples have been taken, will be allowed to enter the enclosures only if their negative report is received.” Mahajan said the zoo management has installed CCTV cameras to monitor the animals. Earlier, the management was monitoring only newborn animals, but now every enclosure has been fitted with cameras, he added. The pandemic has not only affected the revenue generation at the zoo, but pushed it back by two years in becoming self-sustainable. 2020 was being cited as the year in which it was to become self-sustainable and the situation is not any different in 2021. The field director said the zoo had shown a revenue collection of Rs 6.5 crore in 2019-20 fiscal, and was heading smoothly towards becoming self-reliant, but Covid-19 has made it slip back by two years. He said, “Now we will have to start afresh as the lockdown period has already eaten up a major chunk of revenue. We have many continuous expenses, like feeding the animals and paying wages to caretakers. The animals consume meat, fodder, grains, fruits and vegetables of Rs 30 lakh a month. Though the Punjab government is giving the grant, collection made from visitors has become zero during lockdown.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/as-8-lions-test-ve-in-hyderabad-chhatbir-zoo-closed-till-may-31/articleshow/82441480.cms||---

---||Mumbai||ED chargesheet names GVK, MIAL for laundering Rs 500 crore||MUMBAI: Enforcement Directorate (ED) last week submitted its first chargesheet in the special court against GVK group of companies, Mumbai International Airport Ltd (MIAL) and its managing director Sanjay Reddy along with others for laundering Rs 500 crore through fictitious transactions to carry out further development of Mumbai’s international airport terminus (T-2). ED alleged that the group controlled-MIAL had awarded a fake contract of civil work to companies with forged documents. The contacts were never executed but MIAL released the agreed payment. ED alleged that the contractors then transferred the money to GVK group companies or firms associated with its promoters and they laundered the money. ED named over 21 accused in the case, including MIAL, GVK Airport Development Authority and GVK Energy along with other office-bearers of the firm involved in money-laundering. ED sources stated they will continue their investigation. GVK group declined to comment. Earlier, the government entity, Airport Authority of India (AAI) managed the city airport and entered into an agreement with the group, allowing them to operate, manage and develop Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (T-2). They formed a joint venture in 2006—MIAL--- in which the group-led consortium holds 74% shared and AAI 26%. According to the agreement, MIAL was told to manage T-2 operations and share 38.7 % earnings with AAI first, and keep the rest with the company for modernization-extension of the airport. AAI allegedly gave a 200-acre plot near the airport to MIAL for development and revenue generation. But MIAL allegedly entered into a bogus contract in 2017 with Aishwaryagiri Construction, Kotia Enterprises, SBK Trade & Infrastructure, Subhash Infra, Aqua Tech Solutions, MV Omni Projects, Richa Industries, Nice Projects and Aditi Infrabuild for real estate development. MIAL allegedly transferred over Rs 310 crore to these companies but the contracts were not executed. In another instance, it was alleged the accused forged a board meeting resolution of MIAL to use Rs 395 crore surplus funds in the company to create a fixed deposit in Bank of India’s Hyderabad branch. GVK group had allegedly raised loans against the FD for their group companies. Last July, ED had registered the money-laundering case against the accused and searched premises of GVK group companies, its promoters in Mumbai and Hyderabad. ED’s probe under PMLA (Prevention of Money Laundering Act) is based on an FIR registered by CBI on June 27 last year against 13 people.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-ed-chargesheet-names-gvk-mial-for-laundering-rs-500cr/articleshow/82443638.cms||Vijay V Singh
---||Jaipur||Rajasthan: Requests for sanitisation drives rise but limited resources hit execution||JAIPUR: The requests for sanitisation in wards have been rising since the last three weeks as the number of cases started soaring in the city. According to the chairman of fire committee of Jaipur Municipal Corporation-Greater Paras Jain, around 400–500 calls every day are being received from the councillors and the citizens for sanitisation and the limited resources are making it difficult to implement it. Hence, an application has been sent to JMC-Greater commissioner to provide at least two knapsack machines in every ward. Thousands of cases are being reported in the state and people are getting panicked. Hundreds of complaints are being received for sanitisation. Sometimes from people whose family member or a neighbour was found positive and sometimes from people who just want to sanitise for prevention. However, only 56 knapsack machines are available at JMC-Greater for manual sanitising and rest is done by fire department. Jain has written to commissioner Yagya Mitra Singh asking for knapsack machines in every ward. “I am getting continuous calls. There are some wards where sanitisation has been done two or three times and some places not even once. If one or two knapsack machines are provided, every councillor can use it. Fire tenders cannot go in every lane and sometimes, requests come at odd timings when vehicles are busy,” said Jain. A senior JMC-Greater official, on condition of anonymity, said that purchasing machines immediately is not possible and after the Covid is over, they will become useless. Hence, authorities are avoiding it. Rashmi Kankariya, health DC said, “We got the application from Paras Jain and have forwarded it to higher authorities. We are trying our best to take care of the all the requests we receive. I look into the knapsack machines and on JMC-Greater helpline, we are receiving 90 requests daily regarding that. Our priority is always to sanitise the areas where Covid patients are found, but sometimes we take into consideration the neighbours as well.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/requests-for-sanitisation-drives-rise-but-limited-resources-hit-execution/articleshow/82441490.cms||---

---||Ahmedabad||GST officials seize SUV; it’s pure dacoity, says Gujarat high court||AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Thursday likened the Goods & Service Tax (GST) officials’ seizure of a Rajkot businessman’s private vehicle to dacoity. Later, the state government agreed to release the vehicle. The bench of Chief Justice Vikram Nath and Justice R M Chhaya made oral observations about the functioning of the state GST flying squad. This was with regard to a petition filed by one Rakesh Sarasvadiya from Morbi, whose truck with goods was detained on February 16. He was summoned to GST office in Ahmedabad, where he was detained for two days. GST officials seized his SUV, seven mobile phones, and three diaries before raiding his premises in Rajkot and Morbi. Sarasvadiya approached the high court for release of his SUV and mobile phones. His truck was released after he paid the due amount levied by the department. When the judges came to know that the seizure was made by assistant commissioner, an officer below the rank of joint commissioner and who is not authorized by the GST Act to make seizure, they questioned the state government what the court should do with the officer. After a brief discussion, the CJ commented, “This is dacoity.” The judges kept their audio channel on while they were discussing the issue among themselves. Later the CJ told the government lawyer, “We want you to hear what we were talking. This is pure dacoity.” Justice Chhaya also passed some remarks about the seizure proceedings and said, “…My Lord is absolutely right in using this word dacoity.” The chief justice also criticized the seizure and questioned the procedure adopted in this case, “The question is who can make a raid and who can make a seizure? If somebody is not authorized to carry out the raid and seizure enters my house, then it is trespassing. That is robbery. It is dacoity, if more than five people are there or it is a robbery.” The state government said that it was ready to release the SUV. The HC asked it to do it within a week because the court was informed that the officer involved in the seizure is down with Covid-19. The court has sought reply from the department in two weeks and posted hearing after the summer vacation.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/gst-officials-seize-suv-its-pure-dacoity-says-hc/articleshow/82441519.cms||---

---||Chandigarh||Chandigarh asks Centre to hike oxygen quota from 20MT to 35MT||CHANDIGARH: The UT administration has written to the Centre, asking it to increase their quota of liquid oxygen from 20MT to 35MT. In the letter written to Rajesh Bhushan, secretary, health and family welfare, UT adviser Manoj Parida has submitted that the Centre has allotted 20MT of liquid oxygen, which they are already supplying to three government hospitals, including GMH-16, GMCH-32 and Sector 48 Covid hospital, and to many NGOs that have set up Covid care centres in Chandigarh. The administration has demanded that to meet the rising demand of oxygen in the city, the Centre should increase its quota to 35MT. UT suggested that the additional quota allocation could be made from the Inox plant in Barotiwala, Baddi. Meanwhile, on the request of the UT health department, the UT director general of police (DGP) has provided escort facility to tankers carrying medical oxygen from Inox plant to Chandigarh and deployed DSP Dalip Ratan as the nodal officer for it. On Wednesday, UT health secretary Arun Kumar Gupta had written to the DGP, stating that the nodal officer for oxygen supplies in UT, Yashpal Garg, had highlighted the need to provide police escort to tankers carrying liquid medical oxygen from the plant to various destinations in Chandigarh to reduce the travel time and avoid any untoward incident. The UT administration has already deployed two of its officials at the Baddi plant for better coordination. Besides, the UT administration has already roped in three vendors for refilling cylinders to be used by health institutions of the city. Garg said, “The ministry of health and family welfare has fixed the daily quota of 20MT of medical oxygen for UT from Inox. This medical oxygen is being utilised for GMH-16, GMCH-32 and the Covid hospital in Sector 48. Recently, three oxygen generation plants were also commissioned at these three hospitals.” However, there is an additional requirement at these three government hospitals. The private healthcare institutions also need medical oxygen and PGIMER’s requirement is met from a separate quota. After meeting the daily requirements of GMCH-32, GMH-16 and the Sector 48 Covid hospital, the remaining oxygen from the 20MT quota is provided to the private refilling vendors to cater to the needs of the other government and private hospitals of the city. Garg said they have been monitoring supply to private institutions too.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/ut-asks-centre-to-hike-o2-quota-from-20mt-to-35mt/articleshow/82441527.cms||Rajinder Nagarkoti

---||Chandigarh||MC gets Rs 127cr from admn, will have to spend it prudently||GRANT-IN-AIDChandigarh: The UT finance department has released the first installment of the grant-in-aid of Rs 127 crore to the municipal corporation for the current financial year of 2021-2022. This is the first quarter’s installment out of Rs 502 crore. Of the released Rs 127 crore, Rs 2 crore have been given to the Swachh Bharat Mission works and the remaining Rs 125 crore are for other expenditures of the civic body.It is up to the MC to divide the amount and spend it as per its requirements. Though the payments will be released to the departments by the accounts office of the MC, sources said this would be done after the approval of the senior officers. “Committed liabilities are the main segment of the expenditure for the civic body. Developmental works that were under way and in need of funds will also get an allocation. As road re-carpeting works are on full swing, the contractors are also asking for their payments. The money needs to be spent judiciously and on priority. Every single penny will be allocated after orders from the senior officers,” sources added.A senior officer said since this was grant of the first quarter of the fiscal, the MC would also have to keep in mind that the next installment would come after three months, so it should be used prudently.The MC general house had earlier this year prepared and passed a Rs 1,627-crore budget for the current financial year, but the UT had given Rs 502-crore grant-in-aid. The amount is Rs 77 crore more than the last financial year’s budget, when the MC was given Rs 425-crore financial aid.Key monthly expenditures Head--------------------------------------AmountSalary------------------------------------- Rs 18 croreWages------------------------------------- Rs 16 crorePower and water bills---------------- Rs 10 crorePetrol, oil and lubricant------------ Rs 1.5 crorePension------------------------------------ Rs 5 crore||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/mc-gets-rs-127cr-from-admn-will-have-to-spend-it-prudently/articleshow/82441497.cms||Deepak Yadav

---||Goa||Archivist Prakashchandra Shirodkar dies in Bengaluru||Panaji: Former director of archives, archaeology and museums, Dr Prakashchandra Pandurang Shirodkar, passed away in Bengaluru on May 6. Born in 1941, the octogenarian was ailing from age-related health issues for some time. Sources close to him said that it was not a Covid death. Shirodkar was the eldest son of Rashtraveer Pandurang Purushottam Shirodkar, a leading freedom fighter and the first elected Speaker of the Goa, Daman and Diu Legislative Assembly in 1963. When his father was incarcerated in Angola, Shirodkar completed his school and college education in Mumbai and worked for a decade at Free Press Journal Mumbai, last as its chief sub-editor. Shirodkar was instrumental in releasing several publications, the most notable being Purabhilekh-Puratatva, Journal of the Directorate of Archives, Archaeology and Museum, which was also edited by him. A researcher and scholar of international repute on Portuguese colonial history from Brazil to Africa to South East Asia, he also served at the Goa Gazeteer Department as its executive director and editor. He made several archaeological discoveries in Goa, including the largest laterite (Stone Age) carving of Mother Goddess rock art at Pansimal in the Pirla village of Sanguem taluka. This discovery has catapulted Goa on the rock art map of India and the site with unique carvings estimated to be 9,000 years old. He was associated with Goa University right from its inception in 1985. He was member of its Senate and Academic Council, Advisory Board of Latin American Centre for 22 years. He was also a recognised expert in Portuguese palaeography.Ailing for some time, Shirodkar had moved to Bengaluru a few years ago. He is survived by his wife Sulabha and son Priyadarshan in Bengaluru and daughter Pradnya who is in the USA.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/archivist-prakashchandra-shirodkar-dies-in-bengaluru/articleshow/82445683.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क
---||Goa||With market closed, traders offload fish on roadside||Margao: With a view to prevent crowding at the South Goa Planning and Development Authority’s (SGPDA) wholesale fish market, authorities had ordered closure of the market, following which it has remained shut for over a week. However, locals have now complained that fish vehicles coming to the market from other states offload their fish stocks outside the wholesale fish market, thereby resulting in a rush for buying of fish by both wholesale fish sellers and retail customers. Locals have complained that fishermen are occupying spaces along the sides of the Western bypass in the vicinity of the SGPDA market to sell their stock, resulting in people crowding on the road, leading to traffic congestion. “The very purpose of closing down the wholesale fish market is defeated if traders continue selling fish outside the wholesale fish market and along the roadsides. It’s puzzling why the police have failed to rein in these violators,” a resident from the locality said.
