---||Chandigarh||Bed shortage at Mohali civil hospital isolation ward||MOHALI: The Mohali civil hospital has run out of Covid beds under L2 category at the isolation ward. It has none in L3 category. The major hospitals of Mohali have 100% occupancy of Covid specialized beds and the district is left with just a handful of L2 beds at some of the government hospitals. Deputy commissioner Girish Dayalan said around 200 beds would be set up at Chandigarh University, subject to the availability of doctors and paramedics. Bed capacity at the civil hospital was increased from 60 to 120, and now the hospital has 124 patients in the isolation ward. Moreover, the Army is setting up a Covid specialty ward at the civil hospital on the third floor and will soon make 50 beds operational. Manpower shortage is staring the Mohali administration in the face at a time when the recovery rate is falling to the all-time low of the year at 79.5%. However, Dayalan said, “All the Covid beds in private hospitals are now occupied and we are relying on the Army to set up a 100-bed facility at the government hospital. We already have Chandigarh University with 200 beds’ capacity that can be upgraded to 1,000 as per requirement. We have enough facilities to cater to the increasing cases and recoveries are also leading to vacant beds. We have sufficient doctors, healthcare workers and paramedics and have asked the Punjab government to provide us with an ample stock of vaccine.” Recently, Mohali got five ventilators that are yet to be made functional at the civil hospital. Western Command, after accepting the appeal made by the Punjab chief minister for help, had agreed to set up 100 beds’ ward at the civil hospital.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/bed-shortage-at-mohali-civil-hosp-isolation-ward/articleshow/82441538.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: 46 held for procession to ‘eradicate Covid-19’||AHMEDABAD: Gandhinagar Police arrested 46 people for taking out a religious procession of Lord Baliyadev at a village in Gandhinagar district to “eradicate coronavirus,” an official said on Thursday. The incident of holding the religious procession took place in Dabhi Faliyu in Raipur village in Gandhinagar on Wednesday and the complaint was lodged late on Wednesday night after a video of the event went viral, said an officer of Gandhinagar police. Deputy superintendent of police, M K Rana, said that all Covid-19 prevention norms were allegedly violated during the latest procession taken out in Raipur village on Wednesday and a complaint was filed with Dabhoda police in the matter. In a video that went viral on social media platforms, around 100 men and women, most of them without masks, were seen participating in a procession in the village. While women were carrying water pots on their heads, several men were leading the procession while beating drums. “After being alerted about the incident, we have arrested 46 men involved in taking out the procession,” Rana said. A section of people from the village believed coronavirus could be eradicated by pouring water on the idol of their deity in a local temple, he said. All the 46 accused were booked for violating police notification regarding gatherings under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code and provisions of the Disaster Management Act and the Epidemic Diseases Act, Rana said. On May 3, a similar incident had taken place at Navapura village in Ahmedabad where a large number of women carrying water pots on their heads took out a procession to a local temple, believing that pouring water on the idol would eradicate Covid-19. Police booked as many as 23 persons including a village sarpanch for violating norms in four villages of Ahmedabad district. The Gujarat government has already imposed a ban on all kinds of gatherings in the state in the wake of a surge in coronavirus cases.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/46-held-for-procession-to-eradicate-covid-19/articleshow/82441563.cms||---

The locals have also alleged that the people who bring the bodies to the crematorium often dump their PPE kits in the area. The crematorium has a crop field around it and the farmers are not able to work there because of the burning of the bodies. The local administration had established a dedicated crematorium for Covid-19 patients to reduce the burden on existing facilities.  “We have written to senior officials including the Vikasnagar MLA but nothing has been done so far. Our village doesn’t have any Covid-positive patients yet but the current situation may result in an outbreak,” said Kishan Lala, a local resident. ---||Business||Biological E set for Covid vaccine rollout by August||Hyderabad: As the country grapples with the second wave of Covid-19, vaccine maker Biological E is gearing up to churn out 75 to 80 million doses per month of its recombinant protein vaccine candidate from August this year. The company also says it will be one of the most affordable vaccines in the country. Biological E’s managing director Mahima Datla indicated as much in an exclusive interview to TOI when she said: “I am not at liberty to share it (pricing) yet because we are still working on it, but I can assure you it will be among the most affordable Covid-19 vaccines that you can get a hold of.” She added that the company certainly won’t take advantage of the situation. “We’re third generation in this business,” she said. “Covid did not make us enter into this business and we pride ourselves on having made vaccines accessible in pre-pandemic times to countries that needed it the most.” Dr Maria Elena Bottazi, associate dean, National School of Tropical Medicine (NSTM) at Texas-based Baylor College of Medicine, which is collaborating with Biological E for the vaccine, has been quoted as saying that the subunit vaccine, which is modelled after the hepatitis B vaccine, uses traditional technology and is cheap to produce at only about $1.5 (Rs 110 approx) per dose. Datla’s assurance on affordable pricing comes at a time when vaccine pricing has become a political issue. After being criticised, the central government had to ask both Serum Institute of India (Covishield) and Bharat Biotech (Covaxin) to cut their prices for state governments. On being able to churn out 75-80 million doses per month right from the start, Datla said: “It’s a significant capacity and we have already scaled up. We have confidence in our manufacturing capabilities to be able to deliver that number from August onwards.” “We are well-resourced in terms of capacities, both for fill-finish and bulk antigen. We are focusing on hunkering down and getting our vaccines through to the finish line and making sure that we're able to deliver capacities...” she added. Bio E’s vaccine rollout could help substantially ease the vaccine crunch that is currently hampering the country’s vaccination drive. Apart from Covaxin and Covishield, Russian vaccine Sputnik V, which is priced at $10 globally, has received emergency use authorisation but India would initially have to rely on imports as local manufacturing of the vaccine is slated to begin only in the July-September quarter. Currently, Biological E is busy with preparations for phase III trials of the two-dose vaccine on 1,268 healthy volunteers in the 18-80 years age group at 15 centres across the country as part of a larger global study. Apart from the two-dose recombinant protein vaccine Bio E also has a tie-up with Johnson & Johnson for making 600 million doses of the latter’s single shot Covid-19 vaccine -- Ad26.COV2.S — in India. The company has been promised funding from the US International Development Finance Corporation to produce at least 1 billion doses of Covid-19 vaccines by the end of 2022 under the Quad initiative.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/biological-e-set-for-covid-vaccine-rollout-by-august/articleshow/82445644.cms||Swati Bharadwaj

He said that the teams of NDRF and SDRF have initiated a rescue operation but no success has been achieved. Meanwhile, Anil went close to the borewell while playing and tried to remove the cover,” Acharya said. In this attempt, he slipped into the borewell. AMC health officer Dr Neeta Padalkar said the state government has asked all the districts to utilise the available stock of Covaxin only for the 18-44 years age group till further orders. “We have received 6,000 doses of Covaxin, of which, 500 have been handed over to the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH). The civic administration is operating three vaccination centres where Covaxin is being administered to only one target group with prior online registration,” she said. Elaborating on the supply of Covaxin and its use, assistant director of health, Pune circle, Sanjay Deshmukh said the vaccines procured from the Centre are used for the 45+ age group while those which have been procured by the state government directly from the manufacturers will be strictly used only for the 18-44 age group. For those needing the second dose of Covaxin, Padalkar said the state-level health authorities were expected to come out with another set of directives soon. “Ideally, a gap of around four to six weeks is expected between the first and the second Covaxin doses. The state-level authorities are expected to make available sufficient supply of Covaxin for those needing the second dose,” she said. ---||Gurgaon||10 days after directive on 900 beds, Gurugram fails to add any||GURUGRAM: On April 26, chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar had outlined a plan to add around 900 oxygen beds for Covid patients in the city. These hospitals were to come up in vacant flats of an M3M condominium in Sector 67 condominium (400 beds) in collaboration with Medanta, at the HSVP auditorium in Sector 43 (100 beds) and SGT hospital (400 beds). In the ten days between then and Thursday, the city has averaged in excess of 3,000 new infections every day. But so far, none of those 900 beds has been activated for patients at a time when Covid beds in the city are full and people are travelling to other districts or even states for treatment. The main challenge, officials say, is medical oxygen. Adding oxygen beds will drive up demand and almost inevitably lead to a flurry of SOS calls from various hospitals. The oxygen supply lines have relatively stabilised this week after a tense fortnight for hospitals and the Gurugram administration that saw a daily scramble to deliver oxygen to hospitals on time. At two private hospitals – Kriti and Kathuria – 10 patients died, allegedly after the facilities ran out of oxygen. The other reason officials cite is an inadequate number of skilled professionals like nurses, ICU specialists and medical officers. The number of active Covid-19 cases in the city is now around 40,000 and the list of people waiting to get a hospital bed is getting longer. ICU and ventilator beds are not immediately available. All 2,459 beds allotted for Covid patients are full. According to a senior government official, 250 beds have been arranged at the Sector 67 condominium and more than 60 beds have been set up at the HSVP auditorium. But they haven’t been activated because there isn’t enough oxygen supply. Efforts are on to procure more oxygen cylinders and concentrators to get these facilities up and running. “We will start operations at these places only after all arrangements are made. When these beds become functional, more health workers and doctors will be needed too, but the health department and private hospitals are already facing a shortage of professionals,” the official added. SGT hospital’s capacity expansion to 500 beds is likely to take another fortnight, at least. The hospital does not have an oxygen storage tank, which needs to be built before it can accommodate more Covid patients. According to the health department, SGT hospital has only 50 oxygen beds now.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/gurgaon/10-days-after-directive-on-900-beds-gurgaon-fails-to-add-any/articleshow/82443699.cms||Shahnawaz Alam

Filed on behalf of the relatives of the deceased, the PIL also lists several other demands including basic Covid-19 medical facilities at the hospital. The PIL pointed out the shortage of beds, oxygen, and long waiting hours for 108 EMRI ambulances. The petition, however, did not elaborate much on the reason for seeking a postmortem examination.  The lawyer mentioned the petition before a bench headed by the chief justice on Thursday and sought hearing on the issue. The judges said the plea would be heard on May 11 along with the suo motu PIL on Covid-19. The PIL has also urged the HC to direct authorities to make ventilators, oxygen and beds available in adequate number for people who are suffering from Covid-19 in Jamnagar. ---||Mumbai||Mumbai scrap dealer, aide held for bid to sell 7kg uranium||Mumbai: The state ATS has arrested two men, including a Mankhurd scrap dealer, for illegally possessing and trying to sell 7.1kg radioactive uranium worth around Rs 21.3 crore. It is used in cancer treatment and in aeronautics, an official said. The case began in mid-February when the ATS received a tip-off that a Thane resident, Jigar Jayesh Pandya (27), was trying to sell pieces of a uranium substance. The ATS sent a dummy customer who bought some for over Rs 1 lakh and then sent it to Bhabha Atomic Research Centre in Trombay for analysis. Meanwhile, Pandya was detained and questioned. He said he got it from Abu Tahir Choudhary (31), who the ATS apprehended from the scrap market and seized from him 7.1kg uranium. “Choudhary said he wanted to sell it for Rs 5 crore,” said an ATS officer. On Wednesday, the BARC report confirmed it was uranium. “The report stated that the substance is natural uranium, highly radioactive and dangerous to human life,” said an ATS officer. Investigators are trying to find out where it was procured from. Following the report, Arjun Panda, regional director, Atomic Minerals Directorate of Exploration and Research at Nagpur, lodged an FIR and the duo was arrested. They were booked under sections of the Atomic Energy Act, 1962. An NIA court later remanded them in police custody till May 12.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/city-scrap-dealer-aide-held-for-bid-to-sell-7kg-uranium/articleshow/82445645.cms||Mateen Hafeez
---||Kolhapur||Steady rise in cases in Satara & Solapur: Health ministry||Kolhapur: Two districts of Maharashtra — Satara and Solapur — are among the 30 districts in the country, which have reported a consistent rise in Covid cases for the last two weeks, as per the information revealed by central government’s health ministry.Joint secretary of Union health ministry Lav Agarwal in the daily Covid briefing at New Delhi put out the information and said the consistent rise in the Covid cases in 30 districts is a cause of concern right now. Some of the districts are showing a sudden spike in cases over last the two weeks, but Satara and Solapur districts have reported a steady rise. Meanwhile, 11 districts from Maharashtra are reporting a consistent decline in Covid cases for the last two weeks.On Wednesday, Satara reported 2,372 Covid cases and 58 deaths. For the past few days, the cases are hovering above 2,000. The district has 21,000 active patients. Strict lockdown has been imposed for the last few days in Satara as the citizens were hardly following the Covid restrictions imposed by the state government.  Ramchandra Shinde, acting district collector of Satara, said, “Every day we conduct around 7,000 tests. Currently, the positivity rate is 35%. We are reporting nearly 2,500 cases daily and therefore to stop the spread, we have imposed strict lockdown.”In Solapur district, the rural parts are worst affected as they have recorded 1,830 cases and 34 deaths. Solapur rural has around 16,500 active cases. Pandharpur tehsil, a part of Pandharpur-Mangalwedha assembly constituency, which recently witnessed the bypoll, is also badly affected. Of the daily 1,800 cases, around 350 are from Pandharpur tehsil. Earlier, the officials had said the large number of cases is due to many people coming into contact while campaigning last month.Solapur city is currently reporting fewer cases (around 150) as compared to cases last week, which is mainly due to the strict lockdown enforced by civic chief P Siva Sankar. Meanwhile, Kolhapur guardian minister Satej Patil is furious after the Centre stopped the supply of 50 metric tonnes of liquid oxygen from Bellary based plant. He said a letter has been sent to the central government to restore the supply.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolhapur/steady-rise-in-cases-in-satara-solapur-health-ministry/articleshow/82438194.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat BJP protests against Mamata Banerjee, TMC||Ahmedabad: The Gujarat BJP on Thursday held protests against West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee and her party Trinamool Congress over alleged attacks on BJP workers in that state after assembly elections. In Ahmedabad, Rajya Sabha member Narhari Amin and state BJP general secretary Pradeepsinh Vaghela were among those who took part in demonstrations. Gujarat Municipal Finance Board chairman Dhansukh Bhanderi led a sit-in in Rajkot city while local mayor Hemali Boghawala joined the protest in Surat. Vaghela, who had campaigned in West Bengal, alleged that 11 BJP workers were killed there after the elections. "In Gujarat, the BJP has been in power for the last 25 years. But we never attacked anyone from opposition Congress," Vaghela told reporters. He also alleged that the TMC was getting support from "illegal Bangladeshi immigrants". Bhanderi said protests were held by following coronavirus guidelines and maintaining social distancing. pti||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/gujarat-bjp-protests-against-mamata-banerjee-tmc/articleshow/82441614.cms||---
---||Kochi||Could secure strongholds in adverse times: Indian Union Muslim League in Kerala||KOZHIKODE: The high-power committee of IUML, which met in Malappuram on Thursday to assess the performance of the party in assembly elections, said that the party was able to secure a win in its strongholds despite adverse conditions and the setbacks received by UDF. IUML state president Panakkad Syed Hyderali Shihab Thangal said after the meeting that the party will conduct a detailed review of the election results, go for an introspection and take steps for moving ahead and strengthening the UDF. Thangal said that a panel will be constituted to look into the defeat suffered by the party in some seats. The meeting, which was also attended by the newly-elected MLA designates, also elected IUML national general secretary P K Kunhalikutty as the parliamentary party leader and M K Muneer as the deputy leader. K P A Majeed is the parliamentary party secretary. IUML national organizing secretary, E T Mohammed Basheer said that some persons are making farfetched and unrealistic assessments that the party suffered defeat without seeing the reality. “The party put up a good performance in our strongholds. Our winning margins increased in seven constituencies in Malappuram and also in the two constituencies in Kasaragod. The party was also able to wrest Koduvally seat. The party has lost some seats by thin margins only,” he said. He said that the attempts to target some leaders on social media were part of a planned attempt by some to negate the gains made by the party. Basheer said that IUML was able to make significant contributions in closing the account of BJP in state; it ensured that the party didn’t win at Manjeswaram and Palakkad seats. Though the party was able to retain its 11 seats in Malappuram, the total seat count of the party has decreased from 18 in 2016 to 15 despite the party contesting in 27 seats (its highest). The party had lost its sitting seats of Azhikode, Kalamassery, Kozhikode South and Kuttiady though it managed to wrest Koduvally.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kochi/could-secure-strongholds-in-adverse-times-iuml/articleshow/82440389.cms||---
---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Senior IAS officers to join Covid operations at government hospitals||HYDERABAD: With Covid-19 cases rising exponentially in the state, especially in Greater Hyderabad, senior IAS officers will soon be roped in to monitor the situation and coordinate with health authorities at seven major state-run hospitals in the city. Though several bureaucrats are already included in various committees, the government might depute IAS officers to coordinate with the seven hospitals, managing the bulk of Covid- 19 cases. Apart from Covid nodal centre Gandhi Hospital, the officers would keep tabs on six other health facilities, including Nizam’s Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS), District Hospital, King Koti, Government Fever Hospital, Sarojini Devi Eye Hospital and Government TB & Chest Hospital. “The officers will coordinate with the hospital authorities for better management of the situation and attend to their needs,” a top government source told TOI. The directives might be released in a day or two. Also, collectors would monitor the situation at major district hospitals. Till now, the district collectors were working closely with civic and health department officials, but now they would directly interact with hospital authorities. Sources say at the district level, there were other changes in the offing. A coordination committee on Covid-19 would be constituted with district panchayat officer and others to manage the situation. In some districts, the government has already deployed district employment officers (DEOs) to look into vaccination stock and drive. Sources said there could be changes within the health department too after exit of Eatala Rajender. “The idea is to ease burden on officials and give them specific tasks so that there is more clarity in work” the sources said. CMO official P Rajsekhar Reddy was made nodal officer for Covid-19. IAS officer Jayesh Ranjan is looking into medicine and essential supplies . While Sandeep Sultania will monitor bed availability, IAS officer Rahul Bojja will look after call centres. Sarfarj Ahmed will monitor oxygen supply.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/sr-ias-officers-to-join-covid-ops-at-govt-hosps/articleshow/82445701.cms||Sribala Vadlapatla
---||Jaipur||Good Samaritans supply food to Covid-hit families||UDAIPUR: Amid the stories of black-marketing, stockpiling, there are tales showcasing acts of kindness to extend relief to thousands of families affected by the pandemic. While there are people who have started free food packets delivery services to households hit by the virus, there are also organisations that are providing help by distributing corona kits for those tested positive. Individual volunteers, too, are offering help by various means including blood and plasma donations. Looking at the increasing demand for oxygen, a youth Mukesh Sharma has been offering free refills of oxygen cylinders at doorsteps. Anyone calling on his number can avail help by giving the empty cylinder which Sharma would return completely filled. The Brahman Samaj in Udaipur is delivering food packets to home isolated Covid patients. Narendra Paliwal, president Vipra Foundation, said a team of 15 volunteers is working relentlessly to provide food packets to people at their homes and also to needy patients in hospitals. Sikh samaj has ordered for oxygen concentrator machines which are expected to arrive soon. “Once the Machines are available, needy persons can take them from Gurdwara,” said spokesperson Ravindra Pal Singh Kappu. Zahiruddin Sakka of Life Progressive Society said many people are unemployed due to the pandemic and to ensure that no one suffers or starves, ration kits are being supplied at calls. Narayan Seva Sansthan is providing a free kit to those who have tested positive. “Ours is a medicine kit which has pre-prescribed medicines. Individuals, companies, differently-abled, old/senior citizens can approach us through the helpline number 9649499999.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/good-samaritans-supply-food-to-covid-hit-families/articleshow/82441649.cms||---

---||Chandigarh||Panchkula hospital installs its own oxygen plant||PANCHKULA: Panchkula Sector 6 civil hospital has installed its own oxygen plant on the premises that will start functioning within a week. It will have the capacity to supply 24x7 oxygen to 30 beds. Panchkula chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Jasjeet Kaur said, “The plant has started generating oxygen. We have sent a sample of oxygen to a Gurugram laboratory. If the report matches the standards, we will start supplying 24x7 oxygen to 30 beds at the hospital. If it is a success, we will build another plant with three times its capacity.” Amit, a technical expert at the plant, said, “The plant can store 4,000 litre of oxygen at one time and produce 300 litre of oxygen per minute.” On how they are tackling the issue of oxygen shortage, the CMO said they were getting the supply from Roorkee and have cylinders in reserve as a backup. Two days ago, the civil hospital faced oxygen shortage at midnight and a tanker was called from Mohali for patients. Haryana food and drugs department on April 24 had directed Air Liquide, Roorkee, Uttar Pradesh, to provide Panchkula with 5.5 TPD (tonnes per day) of liquid medical oxygen. The DC was asked to make sure the oxygen quota was lifted from the filling station.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/pkl-hospital-installs-its-own-oxygen-plant/articleshow/82441611.cms||Arvind Bishnoi

His family members, including his father, too have been infected. He has isolated himself and is managing work from home. ---||Jaipur||Villages wear deserted look as people stay indoors||KOTA: Even as the number of curfew violators is considerably high in urban areas of the state, people in rural and semi-urban areas have preferred to confine themselves indoors leaving the areas deserted. During the second wave, the infection has hit the rural areas hard and several villages in Kota, Bundi, Jhalawar and Baran districts are under self-imposed zero mobility. In Shahabad area of Baran district, most villages with majority of tribal population are under zero mobility as there are many infected persons undergoing treatment in home isolation in the villages. Muhal, Dikwani, Shahabad, Kelwada, Samraniya, Gadreta, Devri, Kasbathana villages in Shahabad of Baran district are under zero mobility. The reports of daily Covid deaths in almost every village have forced the locals to stay indoors as they are now aware of the fact that hospitals have run out of medical facilities and if they fall prey of infection, nobody is going to take care of them, said an ASHA supervisor at a community health centre in Bundi. Panic and fear prevails everywhere here in the village after two brothers in a family died on Monday and Wednesday this week in Jawahar Nagar village of Amli panchyat samiti of Bundi while another person died Saturday last week, she said, adding that people suffering from cold and cough can be found in almost every house in the village. Covid medicine kits containing 6-7 drugs are being distributed to such people after the survey, she added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/villages-wear-deserted-look-as-people-stay-indoors/articleshow/82441615.cms||---

---||Kolhapur||Draft plan to tackle river pollution ready||Kolhapur: Developing sluice gates at barrages along the Panchaganga river, making sure service centres have in-house effluent treatment plant, setting up separate washing centres for clothes and cattle are some of the measures suggested by the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) in its draft report prepared on the directions of chief minister Uddhav Thackeray. The CM after taking cognizance of the complaints about fish deaths in the Panchaganga river had asked the board to come up with a concrete plan to tackle the pollution of the river. District guardian minister Satej Patil and several other public representatives from the district have approved the draft, which will be given to Thackeray soon. Currently, most of the sewage from Kolhapur city is treated while around 45 million litre from Ichalkaranji is discharged into the river without any treatment, which is the major source of pollution. The expert members associated with the drafting of the report said the major focus of the plan is to develop infrastructure such as treatment plants for Ichalkaranji and villages along the banks of the river. Uday Gaikwad, an environmentalist and expert member said, “We have suggested measures to be taken at the micro-level. For instance, we expect the effluent from the household textile units from Ichalkaranji to be diverted to a single point and then treat it effectively. We have proposed sluice gates for the barrages to flush out the solid waste and sediment waste from the river so that the river water remains diluted.” Kolhapur city was once a major polluter of the river. Currently, around 95% of the sewage generated in the city is treated. Gaikwad said they have suggested mandatory setting up of the effluent treatment plants by the servicing centres. “The servicing centres generate a huge amount of wastewater every day. Such units come under the industrial category and by law they should have their own effluent treatment plants,” said Gaikwad. The plan also includes the diversion of 91 million litre of treated wastewater from Kolhapur city for irrigation . He said the work requires over Rs 25 crore, however, the funds can be recovered by charging fees from farmers for using the treated wastewater. Patil has asked officials to estimate the funds required to implement the measures.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolhapur/draft-plan-to-tackle-river-pollution-ready/articleshow/82438247.cms||---
---||Jaipur||Rajasthan: 4 women allege rape by ‘godman’ in ashram||JAIPUR: Four women, three from the same family, have accused a self-proclaimed godman of raping them in his ashram in Jaipur, police said on Thursday. The women filed a complaint against Shailendra Mehta, accusing him of raping them when they used to visit Tapasvi Ashram to attend satsang and other activities, station house officer, Bhankrota police station, Mukesh Choudhary said. “The victims said they have been visiting the ashram along with their family members for years. The women used to stay at the ashram for a couple of days in the name of service and it was then when the accused used to rape them,” he said. While the three women from the same family registered a case on Tuesday, the fourth woman lodged an FIR on Wednesday. The matter came to light when one of the victims refused her husband to take their daughter to the ashram. "When she narrated her ordeal, the other two women from her family showed the courage and opened up about what had happened with them, following which the family decided to register a case,” the SHO said. The matter is under investigation and no arrest has been made yet, he added. (The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/4-women-allege-rape-by-godman-in-ashram/articleshow/82441658.cms||---
---||Udaipur||Rajasthan government imposes lockdown for 2 weeks from May 10 to 24||JAIPUR: Following the surging second Covid-19 wave, the state government on Thursday decided to impose a lockdown in the state from May 10 to 24 and suspended marriage functions till May 31. The lockdown will be effective from 5am on May 10 to 5am on 24th. As per the order issued by the home department, only register marriages attended by not more than 11 people will be allowed till May 31. Register marriages too have to be e-intimated on the portal, http://covidinfo.rajasthan.gov.in. The order banned marriage functions, DJs and marriage processions (baraat). Similarly, no permission will be given for bands, catering services and gathering of guests till May 31. Marriage gardens, halls and hotels will be closed for marriage functions. Marriage garden owners and caterers will have to return the advance amount paid by parties. Newspaper distribution will be allowed from 4am to 11am and journalists will be permitted to work and travel. No community feast will also be allowed during the lockdown period. Labourers working under NREGA have to follow social distancing norms. All places of worship will remain closed. People have been requested to conduct 'poojas' and religious rituals at home. It has also been decided to allow only one attendant in case of emergency with a Covid patient admitted to a hospital. The name, address and mobile number of the attendant has to be given to the department of medicine and health. Such attendants will need to be isolated from their families for 15 days. All public transport, including buses, tempos, tractors, jeeps, etc., will be off the roads. Only workers permitted will be allowed to load or unload inter-state or intra-state goods. Except for medical emergencies, no inter-district, inter-city, city to villages or villages to city travel will be allowed. Those who enter the state from other states will have to produce RT-PCR negative test reports conducted within 72 hours of commencing the journey. They will have to remain in quarantine for 15 days. All industrial and construction activities will be allowed to prevent the exodus of labourers. Concerned industrial units have to issue identity cards to such workers. They will be allowed to run special buses to transport workers. But shops selling construction materials will remain closed. However, they will be allowed to take orders through the electronic mode. District collectors will have powers to enforce more restrictions in containment zones other than the above based on local conditions.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/udaipur/raj-govt-imposes-lockdown-for-2-wks-from-may-10-to-24/articleshow/82453540.cms||Joychen Joseph

---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Many live with guilt of infecting, causing death of loved ones||HYDERABAD: A 27-year-old doctor who had contracted Covid-19 and had lost his sister to the infection, is now on medication for anxiety and depression. He feels he was responsible for her death. “I knew that my family was at risk and although I isolated myself when I reached home after work, I could have moved out of the house instead,” said Sayeed, who continues to experience sleep disturbances and nightmares even two months after the death because of the guilt. Live updates: CoronavirusKalyan P’s father died of Covid-19. “Initially, my wife and I tested positive for Covid-19. We immediately went into isolation, but, within three days my parents tested positive. My father’s oxygen level went down drastically, but we couldn’t even get a bed in hospital. We somehow managed to get an oxygen cylinder and started his treatment at home, but he died in the last week of April,” said Kalyan adding that it was because of him his father died as he kept on postponing getting them vaccinated due to office work. There are many such people who feel that their infection led to the death of a loved one. They are carrying this heavy burden on their shoulders despite having recovered from Covid-19. Unable to come out of the guilt, they have sought help from psychologists. Guilt, psychologists say, is part of grief. But when it continues for too long, it can become dangerous to the point where a patient contemplates suicide. Read AlsoAnxiety and agony adding to Covid woes in DelhiAmit Sengupta, a marketing professional, made a list of people two weeks ago. His friends and uncle had just tested positive for Covid-19, and he thought he would regularly call the listed infected people to keep their morale high. “The list has become longer in the last few days with many other“Grief starts with denial, then anger, then depression, then the brain starts reconstructing and finally the stage of acceptance. But not everyone can go through these stages successfully and that’s is when cognitive therapy is useful,” said Dr Virinchi Sharma, consultant psychiatrist and director of Manasa Hospital. One of the patients Dr Sharma is treating had contemplated suicide. “He worked in a pharmacy and was the sole breadwinner in the family. After he contracted the virus, almost everyone in his family was infected. His mother having multiple comorbidities did not survive and he clearly blamed himself for her death,” he added. Coronavirus: Complete coverageUsually in such cases, patients keep brooding over what happened in the countdown to the incident. “The first person who tested positive suffers from a higher level of guilt and keeps thinking that it was his or her mistake or negligence which led to the loss. The person feels one or two things done differently would have not led to death,” said Dr Anitha Are, clinical psychologist, who has seen over 10 such cases recently. She added that people with a spiritual bent were found to cope better. (Names of some of the respondents have been changed to protect their identity)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/many-live-with-guilt-of-infecting-causing-death-of-loved-ones/articleshow/82445748.cms||Amrita Didyala

Except for medical emergencies, no inter-district, inter-city, city to villages or villages to city travel will be allowed. Those who enter the state from other states will have to produce RT-PCR negative test reports conducted within 72 hours of commencing the journey. They will have to remain in quarantine for 15 days. All industrial and construction activities will be allowed to prevent the exodus of labourers. Concerned industrial units have to issue identity cards to such workers. They will be allowed to run special buses to transport workers. But shops selling construction materials will remain closed. However, they will be allowed to take orders through the electronic mode. District collectors will have powers to enforce more restrictions in containment zones other than the above based on local conditions.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ajmer/raj-govt-imposes-lockdown-for-2-wks-from-may-10-to-24/articleshow/82453541.cms||Joychen Joseph
---||Ahmedabad||Ahmedabad: Two fights over sale of tobacco products||AHMEDABAD: Two disputes that led to fights over sale-purchase of tobacco products were registered in the city on Wednesday. The government has prohibited sales of tobacco products to prevent gatherings at such shops and help curb the spread of Covid-19. The complaints were from Satellite and Chandlodia areas of the city. In his FIR with Satellite police on Wednesday, a paan shop owner, Mukesh Parmar, 41, said that three men who were his regular customers had come to his house and asked for paan masala. When Parmar expressed his inability, given the government mandate and the fact that he had kept his shop closed, the trio began to abuse him. The trio dragged him onto the road, when Parmar objected to their behaviour. Then one of them then began beating Parmar with a stick because he had dared to refuse to sell paan masala when they had asked. Satellite police registered a complaint against the trio under charges of causing hurt, uttering of abusive words and criminal intimidation. In another complaint filed with Sola police, a 26-year-old man from Chandlodia area of city, Parth Patel, said that he was beaten by a paan shop owner and his two aides after Patel objected to the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products from the shop. Patel said that he had on Wednesday warned the paan shop owner Naresh Marwadi not to sell cigarettes flouting Covid-19 rules. This did not sit well with Marwadi, who with his two aides Shiva and Prince Desai came to Patel’s house on Wednesday, and beat him severely.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/two-fights-over-sale-of-tobacco-products/articleshow/82441687.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||‘Maru Gaam, Corona Mukt Gaam’ key to check virus: CM Vijay Rupani||GANDHINAGAR: Chief minister Vijay Rupani on Thursday described the ‘Maru Gaam, Corona Mukt Gaam’ campaign, launched on Gujarat’s foundation day on May 1, as the key to check spread of coronavirus in villages. Addressing district development officers (DDOs) and chief district medical officers (CDMOs) through videoconferencing, he said all efforts are on to ensure primary healthcare medicines and facilities continue to reach villages at primary health centres, community health centres and sub-centres. The administration has been directed to provide adequate stock of medicines, drinking water in hygienic surrounding without delay. The administration has also been asked to provide equipment to measure blood pressure and oxygen levels and these facilities should be available up to the last village, Rupani said. A committee of ten prominent villagers is being formed at district and taluka levels to create awareness among people to wear masks, and avoid crowded places. At present, he said, there are few cases in the villages, but there is a need to convince village elders to send patients who have tested positive with mild symptoms like fever, common cold and cough to the 13,061 Community Covid Care Centres with 1.20-lakh beds in 33 districts.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/maru-gaam-corona-mukt-gaam-key-to-check-virus-cm/articleshow/82441663.cms||---
---||Jodhpur||Rajasthan government imposes lockdown for 2 weeks from May 10 to 24||JAIPUR: Following the surging second Covid-19 wave, the state government on Thursday decided to impose a lockdown in the state from May 10 to 24 and suspended marriage functions till May 31. The lockdown will be effective from 5am on May 10 to 5am on 24th. As per the order issued by the home department, only register marriages attended by not more than 11 people will be allowed till May 31. Register marriages too have to be e-intimated on the portal, http://covidinfo.rajasthan.gov.in. The order banned marriage functions, DJs and marriage processions (baraat). Similarly, no permission will be given for bands, catering services and gathering of guests till May 31. Marriage gardens, halls and hotels will be closed for marriage functions. Marriage garden owners and caterers will have to return the advance amount paid by parties. Newspaper distribution will be allowed from 4am to 11am and journalists will be permitted to work and travel. No community feast will also be allowed during the lockdown period. Labourers working under NREGA have to follow social distancing norms. All places of worship will remain closed. People have been requested to conduct 'poojas' and religious rituals at home. It has also been decided to allow only one attendant in case of emergency with a Covid patient admitted to a hospital. The name, address and mobile number of the attendant has to be given to the department of medicine and health. Such attendants will need to be isolated from their families for 15 days. All public transport, including buses, tempos, tractors, jeeps, etc., will be off the roads. Only workers permitted will be allowed to load or unload inter-state or intra-state goods. Except for medical emergencies, no inter-district, inter-city, city to villages or villages to city travel will be allowed. Those who enter the state from other states will have to produce RT-PCR negative test reports conducted within 72 hours of commencing the journey. They will have to remain in quarantine for 15 days. All industrial and construction activities will be allowed to prevent the exodus of labourers. Concerned industrial units have to issue identity cards to such workers. They will be allowed to run special buses to transport workers. But shops selling construction materials will remain closed. However, they will be allowed to take orders through the electronic mode. District collectors will have powers to enforce more restrictions in containment zones other than the above based on local conditions.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jodhpur/raj-govt-imposes-lockdown-for-2-wks-from-may-10-to-24/articleshow/82453538.cms||Joychen Joseph
---||Kozhikode||Kerala: 8 alumni, 2 former teachers of Farook College elected||KOZHIKODE: Farook College literally has a stranglehold over power as 10 of its alumni, including former teachers, made it to the state assembly and parliament after recent elections. While eight of its alumni and a former teacher made it to the state assembly, Abdussamad Samadani who is a former teacher of the college, won Malappuram parliamentary byelection, taking the total of victorious candidates from the institution to 10. While five of the college alumni were sitting MLAs in the previous assembly, the clout of the college increased after the recent election with three more alumni members –P A Mohammed Riyas from Beypore, Najeeb Kanthapuram from Perinthalmanna and U A Latheef from Manjeri – getting elected. Other alumni members, who were sitting MLAs, and won again include IUML leaders P K Kunhalikutty, K P A Majeed, Manjalamkuzhi Ali, Congress leader Shafi Parambil and LDF independent member P T A Rahim. Abid Hussain Thangal who had got elected from Kottakkal had served as a teacher at the college. “I don’t think there is any other college in state which has had as many as 10 alumni and teachers getting elected in a single election. We are fortunate to have so many of our former students as MLAs and MPs. The emergence of so many leaders cutting across political parties reflects the healthy atmosphere of student politics and academics on campus. All student organizations on campus have ensured that student politics did not adversely affect the academic atmosphere on campus,” said principal Dr K M Naseer. He also recollected that two former education ministers Nalakathu Soopi and P K Abdu Rabb were alumni. “Also former higher education minister K T Jaleel had worked in the college as a guest lecturer. All of them know about the needs of the college and we have received support in terms of sanctioning of new courses, etc,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kozhikode/8-alumni-2-former-teachers-of-farook-college-elected/articleshow/82448016.cms||---

Dr Mohite, who is currently six months pregnant, has been treating Covid patients over the past one year. She got infected by the virus on April 4 and after 19 days of recuperation, Dr Mohite has resumed duty at at the Badlapur civic Covid-19 hospital . She attends to around 80 to 90 patients. She will continue till she is able to go to the hospital before her delivery. Dr Mohite has a BAMS degree and has been working for a year. “When my family also got infected (her husband Mayur, in-laws and parents)along with me, I thought they may oppose my joining duty. ---||Goa||2 women die as Netravali ambulance out of order for 8 months||Poinguinim: The 108 ambulance service for the residents of Netravali in Sanguem taluka has been inoperational for the last eight months, thus putting them to inconvenience. The nearest hospital, that is primary health centre at Sanguem is 30km away,” Netravali deputy sarpanch Abhijit Desai told TOI. He said that since the ambulance has been out of order, the locals are facing difficulties. even though the ambulance driver is available in the village throughout. One woman from Nunem, in Netravali, was shifted from the village in a private car to Sanguem PHC, from there she was shifted to Hospicio, Margao, but she breathed her last along the way. Desai said that a patient gets first aid in an ambulance before reaching the hospital. This service has been missing for the residents of Netravali for the last eight months. The 108 ambulance service was of great service and assistance to the villagers, he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/2-women-die-as-netravali-ambulance-out-of-order-for-8-months/articleshow/82443734.cms||---

---||Mumbai||Mumbai: HC grants Bhave bail in Dabholkar murder case||Mumbai: The Bombay high court on Thursday granted bail to Vikram Bhave, an accused in the 2013 murder case of rationalist Narendra Dabholkar. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) had arrested Bhave (37) in 2019. Bhave had filed appeals before HC after the special court in Pune rejected his bail plea last year. A terror offence has been invoked in the case under the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act, apart from murder under the Indian Penal Code. Dabholkar was shot dead in Pune while on his morning walk. The HC bench of Justices S S Shinde and Manish Pitale said the material placed by the CBI “does not appear to show reasonable grounds to conclude that the accusations levelled against Bhave can be said to be prima facie true’’. Bhave was named by an alleged shooter during the probe. He is alleged to have shown the shooters the “way to escape on a motorcycle after committing the crime’’. His counsel Subhash Jha and Ghanshyam Upadhyay said the rejection of the bail was “erroneous’’ and the material brought on record by the CBI against him was “far-fetched’’. CBI counsel Sandesh Patil said Bhave had filed two successive bail pleas and both were rightly rejected by the Pune court as under UAPA, the court while deciding a bail plea cannot analyse the prosecution’s case in detail but only see if prima facie a case is made out. The HC said CBI may not be justified in wholly relying on the confession of the co-accused, Sharad Kalaskar, made under the Karnataka Control of Organised Crime Act in a case pending against him in Karnataka where Bhave is not an aaccused. Kalaskar’s confession in the Karnataka case “cannot be of significance’’ in the Dabholkar case. The HC also found some “obvious discrepancy’’ in the case records over reconstruction of the crime scene and Bhave’s role.  The HC directed Bhave’s release on bail on a personal bond of Rs 1 lakh and two sureties.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-hc-grants-bhave-bail-in-dabholkar-murder-case/articleshow/82441718.cms||---
---||Kochi||Kerala: New government likely to sworn in on May 20||KOCHI: The swearing-in ceremony of the second Pinarayi Vijayan-led government is likely to be held on May 20. The tentative date was decided at a CPM-CPI bilateral meeting held on Thursday. The CPM leadership has requested the CPI leaders to reduce the number of the party’s cabinet berths to three from the last time’s four. “But the CPI leaders were adamant on the stand that their party should get four ministers,” a CPM leader said. The CPM is holding one-to-one meetings with each constituent of the LDF to finalize the cabinet berths and other perks to be given to them. There is a plan for cutting down the number of CPM and CPI ministers in the next cabinet so that new entrants in the front and single-MLA parties can be accommodated in the cabinet. There had been 13 members, including the chief minister, for the CPM in the outgoing cabinet. While CPI had four ministers, Janata Dal (S), NCP and Congress (S) had one representative each in the cabinet. This time, Kerala Congress (M) and Loktantrik Janata Dal (LJD), the new constituents in the LDF, have also demanded cabinet berth. The CPM is mooting a plan that the single-MLA parties can be given a cabinet berth if they merge and become a single party. “In the coming days, discussions with the constituent parties will continue. It is expected that the discussions with the major constituents can be completed by May 12. After that, CPM will have to take a decision on whether the party is to forgo one or two cabinet berths for accommodating other constituents,” sources with CPM said. The CPM state secretariat which held a couple of days ago had decided to complete all the meetings and procedures for the formation of the government by May 18. The LDF meeting to be held on May 17 and the CPM state secretariat scheduled for May 18 will take a final decision on the date for the swearing-in ceremony.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kochi/new-govt-likely-to-sworn-in-on-may-20/articleshow/82440441.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: No bail for lab owner booked for fake RT-PCR reports||AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court on Thursday denied bail to Nilesh Vaghela, 33, who was arrested for allegedly issuing fake Covid-19 test reports to people from his laboratory, though it was not authorized to conduct RT-PCR tests for Covid-19. Vaghela was arrested and his Gayatri Laboratory in Vatva was sealed by police on April 13. He was booked under various provisions of the Indian Penal Code and the Medical Practitioner Act because he was issuing Covid reports even though he was not a qualified doctor. He was remanded in police custody for five days. When Vaghela filed a bail plea claiming innocence, public prosecutor Sudhir Brahmbhatt opposed it vehemently and argued that Vaghela issued reports in the name of Sterling Accurist Wellness Pvt Co Ltd. He allegedly illegally prepared a seal and forged letterhead of the company. He has been accused of forging the signature of Dr M D Patel. Action was taken after it was verified with this company that the RT-PCR test reports issued were fake. After hearing the arguments, additional sessions judge V V Parmar observed, “This court cannot lose sight of the fact that cases of Covid-19 are on a surge and the situation has become uncontrollable. This act of the applicant in the present situation cannot be viewed lightly and no leniency needs to be shown towards the present applicant.” The court also took into consideration the submissions made by the prosecution that the probe is under way and granting bail to the accused could have an impact on the investigation and that he may not be available for the trial in the future.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/no-bail-for-lab-owner-booked-for-fake-rt-pcr-reports/articleshow/82441712.cms||---
---||Jaipur||Corona treatment: 300% spike in medical waste over 3 weeks in Rajasthan||JAIPUR: There has been a significant rise in the generation of medical waste in the state in the last three weeks. Around 22 tonnes of medical waste were generated every week. Earlier, it used to be around eight tonnes per week which translates into a whopping 300% rise. There is, however, a demand for increasing the medical waste treatment facilities in the state as well. There are eight functioning facilities and seven more are being proposed, the requirement of which is being felt during Covid times. Currently, majority of the waste being generated from hospitals is related to Covid which his being collected by the vehicles and dumped at the facility established for the medical waste. The quantity of waste generated is lower than last year when more than 28 tonne of garbage was being generated every week. A senior official of State Pollution Control Board said that strict guidelines are being followed while disposing of the medical waste. “We have made the guidelines available to all the department and waste is being disposed of on that basis. We have already proposed seven medical waste disposal plants some are ready to be started and some are yet to be approved. With the pandemic, we are hopeful that we will get the permission sooner.” Medical waste is disposed of in an incinerator where waste is burnt out in a few minutes without eliminating pollutants in the environment. Either this or waste is buried deep in pits but medical incinerator is the standardize procedure with less pollution. With eight facilities, many districts are dumping their medical waste at one place. Like Jaipur gets medical waste of Duasa, Sikar, Churu. Whereas Alwar takes care of medical waste of Bharatpur, Sawai Madhopur, Karauli.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/corona-treatment-300-spike-in-med-waste-over-3-weeks/articleshow/82441713.cms||---

---||Nagpur||HC permits 29-year-old rape survivor to terminate pregnancy||Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court allowed a 29-year-old rape survivor to terminate her 16 weeks old fetus under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971. She knocked the judiciary’s doors after lodging a police complaint against boyfriend, who allegedly exploited her under the pretext of providing a job. He also allegedly spiked her drink when he called her at his home and took her obscene photographs and videos. He then also married her secretly at the Arya Samaj, but after realising that she was pregnant, he severed all relations with her. She later came to know that the boyfriend was already married and was having kids. The survivor then filed FIR for rape against the man at Ranapratap Nagar police station and then filed a plea in HC for pregnancy termination last week. A division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote asked the HC Legal Service Committee to provide her a lawyer to plead the case. Accordingly, Sweety Bhatia was appointed to plead her case, based on her vast experiences of successfully pleading many such similar cases of MTP Act. In first hearing on April 27, the bench directed the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) dean to constitute a medical board as per government resolution (GR) of August 14, 2017 to examine her. The board submitted its report on April 30. Union ministry for health and family welfare through counsel Mugdha Chandurkar and State Public Health Department through lawyer NR Patil were made respondents along with GMCH dean. “The report shows that there is a unanimous opinion of all members that it would be in the patient’s interest to undergo MTP with due informed risk and obtaining consent. She would also be taking optimum necessary precautions at the time of operation.” The judges added that they need to go by the experts’ opinion and permit the premature MTP in spite of the fact that it was 16 weeks and two days old. “Accordingly, we permit her MTP as per the conditions mentioned in the experts’ report.” The survivor however informed that she doesn’t want to undergo MTP at GMCH due to the threat of Covid-19 from hundreds of patients admitted there and she should be allowed to approach a private hospital. The bench then asked her to approach the District Level Committee (DCC) as per Section 4 of the MTP Act seeking necessary approval. “We partly allow the petition by granting permission to the petitioner, to undergo the MTP procedure at a place which would be approved by DCC. We grant liberty to her to file an application before the DCC which should be decided in accordance with the law,” the justices said before disposing of the plea.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/hc-permits-29-year-old-rape-survivor-to-terminate-pregnancy/articleshow/82441717.cms||Vaibhav Ganjapure

---||Jaipur||CMIE: Joblessness rate at record 28% in April||JAIPUR: Unemployment rate in Rajasthan shot up to 28% in April, the second highest among the states after Haryana, according to Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE). After a dip in March to 19.7% from 25% in February this year, the April figures reflect a trend of high unemployment witnessed in the state over the past two years. In fact, the CMIE data base shows that the double digit rates started from October 2018 and has been only increasing since then barring in couple of months when it fell to single digit. Explaining the reasons for high unemployment rates in Rajasthan, Alka Batra, promoter of an oldest recruiting agency, said, “In the past 3 years, very few new investments have come in the state. Existing companies are also not expanding. MSMEs, which generate bulk of the employment are not in the fine fettle.” Batra said that the bad situation became worse after the outbreak of the pandemic. “I think the situation is worse than the CMIE data projects. For this, the pandemic is reason. But in any way, we have not been able to attract enough investments to Rajasthan,” added Batra. When asked about the high unemployment rates in the state, labour secretary Neeraj K Pawan said that CMIE is a private agency and he does not know how it collects data. Since 2016, the unemployment rate remained below 10% till mid of 2018. Haryana is another state where the unemployment rate has remained higher for a longer time than Rajasthan. In the past two years, whatever new investments have come or been proposed are in the renewable energy sector which does not create enough jobs, as per experts. Suresh Agarwal, president of Federation of Rajasthan Trade and Industry, said, “MSMEs in the state are not in the pink of health. Somehow they are managing. They cannot expand capacity because in Rajasthan everything is expensive, be it price of land, electricity or water.” Agarwal said unless the state government changes strategy, entrepreneurs won’t put in money in Rajasthan. “Investments are key to generate employment. For investments, the state needs to reduce the cost of setting up a business,” added Agarwal.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/cmie-joblessness-rate-at-record-28-in-april/articleshow/82441686.cms||---
---||Dehradun||Uttarakhand government to give free wood for the cremation of Covid-19 patients||DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand government, which has been recording an average of 100 Covid-19 deaths per day for the past one week, has decided to provide free fuelwood from Uttarakhand Forest Development Corporation (UAFDC) for the cremation of the deceased patients. The state has witnessed 3,293 deaths due to Covid since the pandemic broke out last year in March. Almost 85% of cremations of Covid patients are taking place in the plain districts of Dehradun, Haridwar, US Nagar and Nainital. And the remaining 15% are being conducted in the hill districts. It is estimated that on an average more than 1,200 tons of wood is being used daily at various cremation grounds in Uttarakhand. “In such testing times, when the lockdown is in place and many loved ones of the deceased cannot even go for the last rites, this is the least that we can do for our people. The state government will pay for all the last rites done during Covid-19 in Uttarakhand under the CM Rrelief Fund,” said Harak Singh Rawat, state forest minister. He added that in many cases of Covid deaths, the last rites are being done by people who are not family members.“These are Good Samaritans, volunteers or the state-appointed workers. Such people are serving humanity, and we have to amplify their efforts,” said Rawat, adding that the order has been extended for the cremation of any unclaimed body found anywhere in the state. Meanwhile, newly-appointed managing director of UAFDC, D J K Sharma, said that the auction of fuelwood for cremation has been stopped till May 31and transportation of the wood from the Kumaon region to Garhwal has been prioritised to meet the rising demand. Uttarakhand has almost 24,303.04 sq km of forest cover, which makes up 45.44% of its geographical area, according to the Forest Survey of India. It has 12 major timber depots. Notably, a few neighbouring states had also approached the UAFDC to provide wood for cremation but the state is unable to facilitate the demand. “Right now, we have just enough wood for cremations for the next ten days. Therefore, we don’t want to supply wood to other states," said Rawat. He added that he has directed the officials to fell trees to meet requirements. “I have asked for dry as well as rotten trees to be felled so that they can be used for cremation by the needy,” added Rawat.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/dehradun/uttarakhand-government-to-give-free-wood-for-the-cremation-of-covid-19-patients/articleshow/82440447.cms||Shivani Azad
---||Mumbai||Maharashtra: Supplier detained and office sealed in swab stick case||Kalyan: A day after a video of slum-dwellers in Ulhasnagar inserting earbud-like long sticks into a plastic packet used for swab collection for RT-PCR tests in unhygienic conditions went viral, the police there detained local supplier Manish Keshwani on Thursday. The police said Keshwani had hired 10 residents from Sant Nyaneshwar Nagar to insert a lakh such sticks — two in each packet — for Rs 20 for 1,000 packets. The police got hold of Keshwani late at night and were investigating how and from where he had obtained the large stock of sticks and to whom he was supposed to supply the finished product.The FDA team that jointly investigated the case along with the police found that Keshwani was using the name ‘BioSwab’, a foreign company involved in manufacturing swab sticks, on the pack. The FDA and the Ulhasnagar Municipal Corporation instructed all labs and doctors not to use sticks in packets bearing the name of the company.The FDA found that on the packet there was no mention of the manufacturing date, expiry date and batch number, which is compulsory.The officials sealed Keshwani’s office in Khemani.“The police team and we will try to find out where Keshwani has hidden stocks which he picked up from residents after the video had gone viral and before our team reached the houses for raid,” an FDA official said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/maharashtra-supplier-detained-and-office-sealed-in-swab-stick-case/articleshow/82443786.cms||Pradeep Gupta
---||Hyderabad||Telangana turns to Karnataka, TN for test kits, abroad for oxygen equipment||Hyderabad: Facing demand for more antigen kits and need for uninterrupted supply of oxygen, the Telangana government has now turned its eyes towards two southern neighbours and abroad. Now, antigen kits will be sourced from Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, while Telangana will import all oxygen supply-related equipment from foreign countries, as local companies are supplying to large number of states facing similar crisis. “We are trying not to depend on one area for more supplies, and are looking at different states to get the kits. Now we are trying to source more from Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, as it is easy getting from there,” said Jayesh Ranjan, principal secretary (industries and commerce). “But we will not stop sourcing from the distributors around Delhi as well,” he added. The state at one point struggled to get kits as many of the antigen kit suppliers were based around Delhi, which is facing a huge outbreak of Covid-19 cases. “We procure anywhere around six to seven lakh kits every week but now the supply will be improved further,” Ranjan added. With the increasing demand all over the states for more kits, suppliers are giving limited kits everywhere. The Telangana government at one point of time even wrote to the Centre asking for more kits to boost oxygen supply. “We are trying to source oxygen-related equipment from other countries wherever possible as the medical cargo with flights is still permitted, despite commercial flight banned to India by some countries,” one official said. Officials denied that tests have been less due to shortage of kits. “We are only focusing on symptomatic people to break the virus spread chain and give them treatment immediately. Those who need testing are getting it done, and there is no concern in that area,” Jayesh Ranjan added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/telangana-turns-to-karnataka-tn-for-test-kits-abroad-for-oxygen-equipment/articleshow/82442799.cms||Sribala Vadlapatla
---||Jaipur||Storm forces flight from Ahmedabad to return||Jaisalmer: A flight from Ahmedabad scheduled to land here at 8am on Thursday was forced to return because of poor visibility due to a dust storm. Airports Authority of India’s Jaisalmer director BS Meena said visibility was very poor due to the strong dust storm and the plane could not land. At the time of landing, a minimum visibility of 1,300 metre is required, but it was only 500-600 metre, which was not enough, Meena said. The pilot waited for around 20-25 minutes expecting visibility to improve, but returned to Ahmedabad after the situation did not change. A strong dust storm was witnessed in many areas of western Rajasthan including Jaisalmer due to a western disturbance and a system above the Arabian Sea on Thursday.The 40kmph dust storm disrupted normal life and made it difficult for commuters to drive during the day as it had become so dark.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jaipur/storm-forces-flight-from-ahmedabad-to-return/articleshow/82441720.cms||---

Active cases, meanwhile, inched closer towards the two lakh figure and are now 1,98,010. Valmiki was the councillor of Ward No 97 of Jaipur-Heritage Municipal Corporation. Jaipur also saw 3,440 daily cases, which rose from previous days. The number of active cases in the city increased to 46,206. Hospitals in Jaipur are running to capacity. We have already intimated the government,” said a spokesman of a private hospital. Meanwhile, health minister Raghu Sharma intervened and promised oxygen supply to these hospitals. ---||Hyderabad||Hyderabad: Old City gold losing glitter as workers head home||HYDERABAD: Reeling under the second wave of Covid-19 infections, Hyderabad’s famous gold ornaments industry in Old City has been badly hit with thousands of goldsmiths leaving the city for their native places. The near Rs 1,000 crore business is down by almost half with most marriages and ceremonies postponed as a result of the pandemic. The workforce of goldsmiths, comprising largely of migrant workers from Bengal, Odisha, and Bihar, are now taking the first available train out of town. Mounting financial distress and a fear of contracting the virus has led to a halt in operations of around 500 big and mid-sized shops dotted across the by-lanes of Ghansi Bazaar, Gulzar Houz, and Chellapura. “I used to work at a leading jewellery store. I have seen several of my friends succumb to the virus and some did not even get oxygen supply. Under such conditions, I feel scared and hence I am leaving for home,” said Srimon Surdas, a goldsmith from Odisha. “From what I know, around 1,500 to 2,000 workers if not more, have already the city,” he says. Another goldsmith, Sumanthu Dhara, counted and said that 11 of his friends working at multi-storied jewellery factory have already returned home while the remaining were packing and preparing to leave on May 17. He said the business was down and there simply is no work left. “The dull business doesn’t allow us to bear expenses in Hyderabad. My wife and kids are calling me every day as they are worried about the situation,” said Dhara, who will soon leave for his hometown in West Bengal. A lack of medical facilities and the unavailability of vaccine in the city has exacerbated the woes of workers of the gold industry which is divided in to around 500 to 600 shops and several hundred production units which also serve as homes for those involved in the city’s gold business. A Razzaq Malik, a jewellery shop owner explained that his business took a sudden hit after showing small signs of recovery from the impact of the first wave of the pandemic last year. “I had around 23 boys with me, dealing in design and making attractive jewellery. All of sudden everything has changed and they have gone home as the market is seeing tough days,’’ Malik said. Suman Aura and Lucky Das, both goldsmiths, fear they will contract the virus if they stay in the city any longer. “Over 75 per cent of goldsmiths have left Old City. “The remaining waiting anxiously to get the vaccine and continue to work but they fear that if a lockdown was imposed, they will face a challenge to survive,” said a spokesman from the local jewellery association.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/old-city-gold-losing-glitter-as-workers-head-home/articleshow/82442976.cms||---

---||Mumbai||No Bombay HC relief for Deshmukh in graft case||Mumbai: Refusing to grant former home minister Anil Deshmukh immediate interim relief, the Bombay HC on Thursday adjourned his petition that sought quashing of the FIR filed against him by the CBI under the Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) as the central agency said it needed time to file its reply, reports Swati Deshpande. Moments after senior counsel for Deshmukh, Amit Desai, began his submissions, additional SG Anil Singh for the CBI said the petition copy was served on Wednesday and he needed four weeks. He said that as far as interim relief was concerned, he would be ready to argue. Desai, citing urgency, said he would seek interim relief of “no coercive steps”. A bench of Justice S S Shinde and Justice Manish Pitale observed that since the CBI had been served on Wednesday and had asked for time, it should be given reasonable time. The high court then gave Deshmukh liberty to move the vacation bench in case of extreme urgency with 48-hour notice to the CBI. The bench passed an order stating that Singh had sought four weeks, which is “vehemently opposed by Desai” who submits “there is an urgency”. The high court said it was inclined to grant the CBI reasonable time to file its reply, but on Desai’s request, granted Deshmukh liberty to approach the court for any extremely urgent relief during the court vacation, but with prior notice to the CBI. Deshmukh’s petition said the FIR followed a “biased, dubious” inquiry, “with ulterior motive at the behest of those having political or other vendetta” against him. Calling the first information report (FIR) against him “false”, Deshmukh said that prior sanction was necessary to register the FIR against him as he was a minister when the offence was alleged to have occurred. He said the FIR made “bald and vague allegations” and no case of allegations of “illegal gratification” under Section 7 of the PCA or criminal conspiracy under Section 120B of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The FIR is to have him “arrested, with an ulterior motive”, said the former minister. The petition said the high directed the CBI to conduct a preliminary inquiry and to take further steps “in accordance with law”. He said since the state had last year withdrawn its general consent to the CBI for investigation of offences occurring here, barring a direct order by the high court or the Supreme Court, which was lacking in the case, the agency could not lodge an FIR and investigate it.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/no-bombay-hc-relief-for-deshmukh-in-graft-case/articleshow/82445932.cms||Swati Deshpande

---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Hospitals, hotels join hands for isolation facilities, beds||AHMEDABAD: When availability of hospital beds in Ahmedabad is at a low, a few private hospitals have collaborated with hotels in the city to set up isolation facilities and oxygen beds for patients. For a charge, these hotels provide residents with isolation facilities, meals and medical attention from the hospital’s doctors. Many also have oxygen cylinders on standby, so patients’ medical needs can be addressed. “We have collaborated with Medilink and Shalby Hospital to help treat Covid patients. Some 45 rooms at the hotel have been dedicated to patients with mild to moderate Covid. They are provided meals and the supervision of doctors. The treatment is managed by the hospitals with daily visits by paramedics or doctors to monitor patients’ health,” said Atul Buddhraja, general manager, Ramada Hotel, which has reserved at least 50% of its room inventory for Covid care. The hotel also offers isolation facilities. Hotels are offering these services in collaboration with hospitals at prices ranging upwards of Rs 10,000 per day. Some have also made oxygen cylinders available. Pride Hotel in Ahmedabad is another such case. Koustuv Mukherjee, group head, Gujarat, Pride Group of Hotels, said, “Patients with oxygen saturation levels of more than 94% can get admitted to our hotel. We’ve earmarked two floors with 50 rooms which are available on single or double occupancy basis. The hotel provides patients meals and tea. If the patient needs to consult a doctor or oxygen support, these are available and will be charged accordingly.” A couple of other hotels on Ashram Road have also converted their properties into Covid care facilitys where patients who are asymptomatic or those with mild symptoms can be isolated.The Grand Bhagwati on SG Road has also dedicated eight rooms for doctors who deployed on 104 ambulances. Hoteliers say the initiative does not generate much revenue but provides a cushion at a time when the industry is reeling for a revenue shortage. “Hoteliers who have converted their properties into isolation centres are getting some revenue to meet their cost of operations. The hospitality sector has been going through a bad phase for a year and the lockdown-like restrictions have only worsened it,” said Narendra Somani, president, Hotels and Restaurants’ Association (HRA), Gujarat.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/hospitals-hotels-join-hands-for-isolation-facilities-beds/articleshow/82441740.cms||Niyati Parikh
---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Home care packages focus on hobbies to aid recovery||HYDERABAD: Doctors treating patients under home quarantine have stressed on the importance of motivation and engagement in order to aid recovery. Several corporate hospitals have started offering home isolation packages once again, after briefly halting them towards the end of the first wave of Covid-19 infections in the state. While most home care packages offer medical guidance and monitoring, medical experts explained that it is engagement in therapeutic hobbies such as singing and painting have shown good results in reducing panic among patients and helping them cope better during the course of their treatment. Virtual consultations with doctors, lung rehabilitation through tele-physios, nutrition, dietary advice, apart from engagement activities are increasingly becoming part of home care packages of hospitals. “Our motivation and engagement experts are working on various elements like body scan and mindfulness, mindful eating, brain games and puzzles, storytelling using props, hobby development such as poetry, mimicry , singing , dancing , painting and quarantine diaries. These sessions have diverted the mindsets of Covid-19 patients from fear to positivity and has certainly helped in rapid recovery of cases,” said Dr Mahesh Joshi, chief executive officer Apollo Home Healthcare Limited. As compared to 10,000 enrolments during the entire first wave, the home care package by Apollo Hospitals has seen 10,000 enrolments in the six weeks of the second wave alone, Dr Mahesh Joshi said. In the current wave of infections, many symptoms such as cough, running nose, fever, loss of taste and smell are similar to those in the first wave but it is the novel symptoms such as persistent high-grade fever with chills, and gastrointestinal issues which tend to make patients more anxious. “More than 70 per cent of patients with these symptoms who visited the hospital were advised home quarantine with proper instructions on how to monitor their health at home and when to come to the hospital. It is seen that anxiety unnecessarily worsens their situation, making them more sick,” according to director of home care services at Medicover Group of Hospitals, Dr Satheesh Kumar Kailasam.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/home-care-packages-focus-on-hobbies-to-aid-recovery/articleshow/82442881.cms||Amrita Didyala
