---||Business||Natco rolls out Baricitinib ahead of approval for patent waiver||HYDERABAD: Even as it has filed for a compulsory licence for Covid-19 drug Baricitinib in India, Natco Pharma has already begun rolling out its generic version of the rheumatoid arthritis drug under the Barinat brand. Natco launched its 4mg tablets at Rs 30 a piece on Thursday and stocks of the drug are already in the market, sources with know of the matter told TOI. The 4mg dosage tablet accounts for nearly 95% of the market for this drug for SARS-CoV-2 treatment, they added. Barinat is priced at less than 1% or nearly one-hundredth the price of the innovator drug Olumiant, which is pegged at around Rs 3,230 per tablet. According to analysts, by going ahead with a drug rollout without waiting for the CL, Natco runs the risk of being sued for infringement by the patent holder. While the patent for Olumiant is held by Incyte Holdings, the drug is marketed by giant Eli Lilly. But Eli Lilly, which also got restricted emergency use approval for Baricitinib 2mg and 4mg from the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) on Monday, said that it is “working with local Indian pharma companies to execute royalty-free voluntary licensing agreements to accelerate manufacturing and distribution of the medicine in India during the pandemic”. In a press communique issued earlier this week, Lilly also said it will be donating Baricitinib tablets to the Indian government, including an immediate initial donation of 4 lakh tablets for eligible hospitalised Covid-19 patients. The Barinat 1mg and 2mg tablets, to be priced at Rs 15 and Rs 20 a piece, respectively, will be rolled out shortly, sources added. The Barinat launch comes less than a week after Natco received emergency use approval from the CDSCO for the Covid-19 drug. Baricitinib, approved by USFDA for use with Remdesivir in November 2020, prevents a cytokine storm that Covid-19 triggers. In its CL application, filed under Section 92 of the Patents Act, Natco had cited unmet medical needs due to lack of supply and affordability in light of the grave and life-threatening national public health emergency as the main grounds for seeking the CL. Natco’s application said Olumiant is not manufactured in India and less than 9,000 tablets were imported in 2019 and 2020, which were enough to meet the needs of only around 600 patients.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/natco-rolls-out-baricitinib-ahead-of-approval-for-patent-waiver/articleshow/82442841.cms||Swati Bharadwaj
---||Hyderabad||Telangana: 3 held for peddling Remdesivir in Warangal||WARANGAL: Local police on Thursday seized 29 vials of Remdesivir and arrested three persons who were indulging in illegal sale of the drug in Warangal town. According to police commissioner Dr Taruna Joshi, the arrested persons included a pharmacist and two pharmacy assistants. The commissioner said the accused had formed a group and were hoarding Remdesivir vials which is being widely used for treating Covid-19 patients. Task force sleuths and Subedari police arrested Kumaraswamy, the pharmacist and two pharmacy assistants — Bagaji Manohar and Ayita Ashol. Police seized Rs 20,000 cash from the accused. During interrogation, the accused confessed while the pharmacist said the two assitants devised the plan seeing the spike in demand for Remdesivir injections. The two assistants, police said, work at a medical counter of a private hospital, had sketched out a plan to hoard the vials of Remdesivir and sell them outside at a higher price. As part of their plan, the duo raised an order for vials of Remdesivir with Hetero, the pharmaceutical manufacturing the drug under the name of their medical store. Upon receiving the shipment of the vials, the accused started selling the drug, charging anywhere between Rs 35,000 and Rs Rs 45,000 for each injection as against the company price of Rs 2,800. Pharmacies are allowed to sell the drug for Rs 3,490 per injection. In view of the current situation where many Covid-19 patients are being treated using Remdesivir, the accused had devised the plan to sell the drug through the black market. Acting on a tip-off, task force sleuths and Subedari police raided the pharmacy, seized vials of the drug along with Rs 20,000 in cash. The arrested have been sent in judicial remand.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/3-held-for-peddling-remdesivir-in-warangal/articleshow/82442925.cms||Shiva Kumar Pinna

---||Vadodara||Sans doctors, 8 ventilators lie idle in Lunawada hospital||Vadodara: At a time when most cities and hospitals are running out of ventilators as Covid-19 hospitalisation continues to rise, Lunawada in Mahisagar district has the luxury of having eight unused ventilators. Reason? There are no doctors at the Cottage Hospital in Lunawada to operate these. The ventilators have been procured during and after the first wave of Covid-19. Sources said that three of these ventilators were procured by the district administration while the remaining five were provided by the government. The difficulty, however, is that the hospital does not have a physician, anaesthetist, intensivist or pulmonologist. While there is a desperate need to put them to use, but there is none to put a patient on the machine and then monitor it. Mahisagar district collector R B Barad said that the hospital even did not have a physician and a private practitioner was roped in temporarily. “Ventilators need round-the-clock experts. We have raised a demand for a physician with the state government,” he said. Sources added that the re-elected representatives of the district had also raised the issue with the state government. Till a doctor is appointed at the hospital, the precious equipment may not be of much use.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vadodara/sans-doctors-8-ventilators-lie-idle-in-lunawada-hospital/articleshow/82439310.cms||Sachin Sharma
---||Goa||Even after multiple fines, Margao municipality continues to burn waste||Margao: Prashant Maurya has written to the Goa State Pollution Control Board (GSPCB) over the failure of authorities in eliminating the hazards posed by roadside burning of waste. Over the last 10 years, Maurya has innumerable letters to the Margao Municipal Council (MMC) and the GSPCB urging them to take steps to end the menace of roadside burning of waste which poses environmental and health hazards. Acting on his letters, the board fined the MMC Rs 25,000 each time for violation of pollution control laws. However, the punitive action hasn’t translated into any change in the ground situation so far. “The roadside waste is still being burnt with impunity. The Margao municipality has still not mended its ways. The fact remains that the real issue has still not been addressed. Neither MMC has stopped doing it, nor has it taken any steps to influence shopkeepers and general public to curb this malpractice,” Maurya told TOI. Painting a sordid picture of how MMC garbage collection workers resort to burning of waste, Maurya in his letter to the pollution control board said, “Every second day, women in green sarees can still be seen burning the piles. They have been given a bamboo basket, just to accumulate waste of few places at one point and then set it on fire. Just about 70m from Victor hospital, there is a MMC waste storage station, which is a permanent burning centre, in fact. Any time of night and day there are instances of burning piles. Just imagine what the patients are being subjected to there.” Pointing out that burning plastic, thermocol and other packaging material adds to the toxicity of the air, Maurya wrote to the board, “This has caused numerous respiratory diseases to citizens, reducing their immunity, causing cancer and other chronic diseases and higher mortality rate due to Covid-19.?”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/even-after-multiple-fines-margao-municipality-continues-to-burn-waste/articleshow/82443879.cms||---
---||Delhi||Not just Covid hosps, other facilities reeling under O2 shortage too||New Delhi: It is not just the Covid hospitals that are reeling due to the oxygen scarcity, other medical facilities too are in a predicament. Care Newborn and Child Hospital in Vivek Vihar, a non-Covid hospital, was in a spot on Wednesday evening with oxygen enough for only around two hours. While the authorities gave the hospital the oxygen to survive a few hours more, a bigger crisis looms: the supplier has halted replenishments because the hospital’s name has been removed from the list of allottees. Orchid Hospital in Janakpuri, also a non-Covid facility, similarly languishes with inadequate supplies. Care Newborn and Child Hospital has so far averted a disaster and managed its daily operations. Speaking to TOI, Dr Navin Khichi, owner, said, “We sent an SOS on Wednesday evening, but managed cylinder through our various centres and through the help of some do-gooders. At Vivek Vihar, we had four babies on ventilators. We are avoiding taking in any infants requiring ventilator support and high flow of oxygen. After we approached the authorities on Thursday, our supplier was directed to refill 20 cylinders for us, but we got only 10.” Care Newborn’s three other centres Janakpuri, Rajouri Garden and Gurgaon have around 20 babies admitted in each. Recently, the hospital had to refuse a newborn who required a ventilator because the administration wasn’t assured of consistent oxygen supply. The Vivek Vihar facility requires at least 20 cylinders every day for a smooth existence. Janakpuri’s 45-bedded Orchid Hospital, a non-Covid facility, has been managing oxygen on a day-to-day basis. The hospital authorities revealed that earlier the vendor would send stocks to the institution, but now the hospital had to send its vehicles to the supplier every day. “Sometimes it takes seven hours or more to get the cylinders refilled,” claimed Dr Hari Om Gupta, owner of the hospital. “The administrators are trying their best and are even working overtime to make sure there are no glitches. We are admitting patients who are critical. Pregnant women in labour are also coming to us for deliveries.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/not-just-covid-hosps-other-facilities-reeling-under-o2-shortage-too/articleshow/82443798.cms||---

On Thursday, Akola district collector Jitendra Papalkar indicated that strict lockdown like restrictions will soon be imposed in the district. In Wardha, essential shops will remain closed even between 7am and 11 am from May 8. Only home delivery will be allowed. Similar decisions are likely to be taken in Amravati, Chandrapur and Buldhana in the next two-three days. Amravati reported 1,189 new cases and 20 deaths on Thursday and now 9,673 patients are under treatment, which is highest-ever for the district. Akola reported 11 deaths, Wardha 25, Chandrapur 15 and Yavatmal 16 on Thursday. Each of these districts is having more than 5,000 patients under treatment. Overall, 7.82 lakh patients have recovered so far. Chandrapur recorded its highest-ever recoveries of 2,126 patients in a day on Thursday. With fewer new cases and more recoveries, the recovery rate of Vidarbha has reached 83.5%. The number of patients under treatment has come down under 1.40 lakh. One of them, Dushyant Tyagi (52) from Rajha village, died on the day of the results on Tuesday without even knowing that he had won the polls. He was undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Moradabad after his condition deteriorated. The other candidate, Amrish Kumar (45) from Mathna village, died in hospital a day after being elected on Wednesday. Sources said both candidates were involved in intense campaigning in villages during the polls. Tyagi’s family members said he was taken ill a few days before declaration of the results. He was admitted to a private hospital in Moradabad, where he was tested positive for Covid-19. Then, his condition began to deteriorate, and he succumbed on Tuesday evening. Tyagi never lived to learn that he had won by 45 votes and was elected as the pradhan of Rajha of Asmoli block in Sambhal. Amrish Kumar, who contested from Mathna village, was admitted to a private hospital 10 days before voting after he complained of difficulty in breathing. He, too, tested positive later and succumbed to the infection on Wednesday afternoon, a day after the election results were declared. He won by 86 votes.According to health department officials in Sambhal, as many as 7,780 people have tested positive for Covid-19 in the district since the second wave of the pandemic hit the state in March-end. ---||Delhi||Delhi hospitals breathe easier, but erratic supply still a headache||NEW DELHI: Finally, after a fortnight of living desperately, Delhi’s hospitals breathed just a wee bit easily on Thursday, though most of the medical centres still felt the oxygen situation remained unpredictable. “We can’t say the crisis is over,” said Dr P K Bhardwaj, chief executive director and head of surgery, Saroj Hospital. “The uncertainty about supplies and reduced quotas are matters of concern. It is an ongoing fight.” Refilling of empty oxygen cylinders is a time-consuming exercise and keeps ambulances and manpower needlessly preoccupied. Like many other small medical facilities, Saroj Hospital also faces a shortage of medicines such as antiviral drug Remdesivir and Tocilizumab and is cautious about admitting new patients. At Indian Spinal Injuries Centre in Vasant Kunj, which has been living dangerously these past few days, Dr K Preetham, medical superintendent, said, “We still have to send our vehicles to different locations to get our cylinders refilled. We are indeed getting the liquid oxygen supplies, but only around 2 metric tonnes of the 5 the hospital requires every day.” After managing to get some oxygen cylinders refilled, the hospital was optimistic of “surviving till Friday morning”. Aakash Healthcare in Dwarka has been in a better state in the past 36 hours, but is monitoring the situation every 12 hours. Dr Aashish Chaudhry, managing director, said, “There is always a reason to worry about at least once in a day. But, over all there is a slight improvement in the oxygen situation for our hospital. We require around 6 MT, but have been getting only 3 MT. Our vendor is only supplying half of what we were getting earlier due to changes made in the allotment by the government. We have been trying to manage by getting our own cylinders and refilling them, but that is a problem too in terms of time and hospital resources involved. We hope the situation gets better now.” Most hospital authorities also complained that the amount of oxygen filled in the cylinders appeared to be less than what the vessels could hold. “We have been noticing for some days that some of the refilled cylinders last for 20 minutes or half an hour while others get depleted in just 15 minutes — which is a clear indication that a cylinder hasn’t been filled to its full capacity,” said a doctor in an outer Delhi hospital. “Also, we realise that government hospitals are given priority over private hospitals.” Bhardwaj of Saroj Hospital highlighted the shortage of critical drugs, such as Remdesivir and Tocilizumab. “Some patients require it and we haven’t been able to source the drug from our supplier for two days apparently because it’s out of stock,” he said. On Wednesday, Shanti Mukund Hospital had similarly alleged a scarcity of Remdesivir and Tocilizumab.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/hospitals-breathe-easier-but-erratic-supply-still-a-headache/articleshow/82443854.cms||---
---||Kolkata||9 out of 10 patients in Kolkata hospitals are on oxygen support||KOLKATA: With almost nine out of 10 patients in hospitals now requiring oxygen support, the demand for medical oxygen has more than doubled in the past few weeks. While hospitals had to refill their oxygen tanks once in two days earlier, some of them are now requiring a refill two times a day. “Our daily oxygen consumption has doubled from about 3,000kl to 6,000kl. Out of the 270 Covid patients admitted at RN Tagore Hospital, around 80% require oxygen support. Luckily, our LMO tank can hold 11,000kl. But now we are getting it refilled every day so that we are prepared,” said R Venkatesh zonal director (East), Narayana Health. At Ruby General Hospital, the LMO tank with a capacity of 3,000 litres is being refilled twice daily. More than half of the 170 Covid patients in ICU and HDU need high oxygen flow support while many in the wards also require oxygen therapy. “Even till March-end, we would require refilling only on alternate days. Now the consumption has hit the roof. Most patients coming to the hospital now require oxygen support,” said Subhasish Datta, general manager, operations at Ruby General Hospitals. On Thursday, the city recorded 3,887 fresh cases, taking the active cases count to 26,269. Many are waiting at home till they find a hospital bed. By the time they reach a hospital, some of them already have dangerously low oxygen saturation that makes them require to be put on devices like HNFC consuming 50 to 60 litres of oxygen per minute. “We have 220 Covid patients and almost everyone is needing some level of oxygen or the other. While we are getting our LMO tank refilled everyday we have also kept 110 cylinders as back up. But we cant rely on these cylinders for the patients who require high oxygen therapy,” said Simmardeep Gill, COO, CK Birla Hospitals CMRI. During the first wave Bengal never faced any oxygen crisis while many other states complained of its shortage. “Under normal condition the oxygen consumption would be around 1,500 cubic meters a day. Now with 170 Covid patients, the consumption has doubled up. So far the supply is uninterrupted, despite the rising demand,” said Sudipta Mitra CEO Peerless Hospital.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/9-out-of-10-patients-in-kolkata-hosps-are-on-oxygen-support/articleshow/82441825.cms||Sumati Yengkhom

---||Nashik||Fuel prices go up in Nashik for third consecutive day||Nashik: Fuel prices in Nashik city continued to increase for the third consecutive day with petrol and diesel being sold at Rs 97.84 and Rs 87.63 respectively on Thursday.Prices of petrol and diesel were stable since April 15, but has started increasing marginally from Tuesday. While price of petrol increased by 66 paise, diesel got dearer by 81 paise in the last three days. The price of premium petrol has also increased by 68 paise to Rs 100.69 in the last three days. There has been continuous rise in fuel prices since November and the prices have increased several times. Vijay Thakre, vice-president of Federation of All Maharashtra Petrol Dealers’ Association (FAMPEDA), said main reason for rise in price of petrol and diesel depends on price of international crude oil, dollar exchange rates, various taxes of state and central government and adoption of daily rate change method adopted by the central government.According to office-bearers of petrol dealers association in Nashik, the state and central government should reduce taxes to bring down fuel prices.According to farmers, agricultural activities, undertaken with the help of tractors, have become costlier. “Farming activities are carried through tractor-mounted equipment. The charges for ploughing and other activities have increased by 30-35% during eight months due to continuous rise in fuel prices,” Nivrutti Nyaharkar, an onion farmer, said.“This will increase the cost of production for farmers, but farmers are getting less returns compared to the cost of production. The government should provide diesel to farmers at subsidized rates,” he added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nashik/fuel-prices-go-up-in-nashik-for-third-consecutive-day/articleshow/82438542.cms||Tushar Pawar
---||Kolkata||35-minute oxygen tension at ID Hosp||Kolkata: It was a nail-biting 35 minutes for doctors and other healthcare workers at Infectious Diseases and Beliaghata General (ID&BG) Hospital on Wednesday as the centralised supply of oxygen from the LMO (liquid medical oxygen) tank had to be shut and they had to switch over to oxygen cylinders for critical patients. More than 300 patients are currently undergoing treatment at the state’s nodal hospital for Covid-19. A single mistake could have led to anything untoward, especially for those patients on high oxygen need. “We did two things to repair the existing vaporiser and install a new one to share the load, during which the centralised pipe had to be shut,” said Asis Manna, medical superintendent and vice principal at ID&BG. A vaporiser converts the LMO from the tank to gas before it is supplied to patients through the pipeline. While the team of engineers operated from the site of the LMO tank the medical team led by doctors Sayantan Banerjee, Yogiraj Ray and Debojyoti Majumder were in the hospital ward for the switchover. The synchronisation was done over conference call. The health department had deputed additional doctors and nurses from other hospitals to tackle the situation in case anything went wrong. The supply from the LMO tank resumed after about 35 minutes.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/35-minute-oxygen-tension-at-id-hosp/articleshow/82441884.cms||Sumati Yengkhom

---||Chandigarh||HC seeks report from Bathinda, Mohali SSPs on ASI sfter his family complains on email||Chandigarh: The Punjab and Haryana high court has sought a report from the SSPs of Bathinda and Mohali regarding an assistant sub-inspector (ASI), who was posted with the special task force (STF) in Ferozepur and allegedly picked up by Bathinda police just a day before his superannuation. The HC has ordered that in case the cop has been picked up without his involvement in any criminal case, he should be immediately released. Justice H S Madaan passed these orders while taking suo motu cognisance of an email received on April 30 from a person claiming to be the son of ASI. Treating the email as habeas corpus petition, the HC has sought response from the officials of the Punjab Police regarding the alleged incident. The email stated: “My father Devi Lal Asi has been forcibly taken away from outside the office of DIG by police of Cantonment police station today at 5 pm. We have apprehension of his false implication in any case as he was going to retire tomorrow.” Another email was received claiming, “Police have taken my father to Bathinda for implicating him in some case as proclaimed by police.” The third stated: “My father Devi Lal ASI who was working with STF Ferozepur had been forcefully apprehended by STF Bathinda before retirement and has been falsely roped in some cases by STF Bathinda and booked at STF Mohali police station. They have raided our residential house and proclaimed that my father Devi Lal will be implicated in other cases as they have directions from senior police officials and as such apprehend false implication of my father in other cases. Our entire family is in fear that they can also harm us. Kindly intervene into this matter.” After receiving the mail, the HC administration placed the matter on the judicial side for action. After hearing the matter, Justice Madaan on Thursday ordered, “The senior superintendent of police, Bathinda and senior superintendent of police, Mohali, are directed to give a written response to such emails by the next date of hearing. They are directed to ensure that the alleged detenue is set at liberty unless his involvement in some criminal case registered at police stations within their jurisdiction is there”. The matter would now come up for hearing on May 11.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/hc-seeks-report-from-bathinda-mohali-ssps-on-asi-sfter-his-family-complains-on-email/articleshow/82441891.cms||---

We cannot just increase the fares when there is no (good) service,” he added. The fares were last revised in 2014, following which, rising fuel prices forced the department to propose a revision of existing fares. The Goa consumer action network (Goacan) had recently written to Satardekar asking an extension of time by ten days for the feedback, saying that the May 6 deadline was too short to offer suggestions. “The proposed revision of existing taxi fare rates is a very important subject that requires to reach not only the taxi operators and commuters but also other stakeholders in the tourism sector as well as the elected representatives from the Goa legislative assembly, zilla panchayats, municipal councils and village panchayats,” Goacan coordinator, Roland Martins had said. In addition to this the transport department will be taking up the implementation of digital meters in taxis in the next 15 days, Satardekar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/deadline-for-taxi-fare-hike-feedback-extended-till-may-16/articleshow/82443968.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Interim relief on evictions to stay till June 30 in Mumbai: HC||Mumbai: A full bench of the Bombay high court on Thursday unconditionally extended till June 30, the validity of all interim orders passed by the high court and lower courts earlier, unless specifically dealt with by any order to the contrary. The current situation, has “marginally improved” since April 16, but is “still not conducive for access to justice” to all concerned, said the HC bench. The HC bench added that any order for eviction or dispossession or demolition which may have been passed by any court/tribunal/authority and were in abeyance till May 7, will remain so till June 30 unless directed otherwise. ---||Kolkata||Shortage of drugs for Covid treatment hits Kolkata pharmacies||KOLKATA: Even as the supply of a few medicines and supplements has improved in Kolkata, there is still a shortage of some antibiotics like doxycycline that is being prescribed by doctors for Covid-19 treatment. The shortage of antiviral drugs like favipiravir has also hit the city pharmacies. Doxycycline started witnessing the shortage since last month. Drug manufacturers have already voiced their concerns to the central government over the increase in prices of active pharmaceutical ingredients or raw materials of certain key Covid drugs. They had also apprehended a shortage of certain drugs including doxycycline in the next few months. “We are seeing a sudden spike in demand for doxycycline and it is going off the shelf overnight,” said Sajal Ganguly, general secretary of the Bengal Chemist and Druggists’ Association (BCDA). “Our members are not getting adequate supply of certain drugs including doxycycline,” he added.  “Many of the doctors are prescribing doxycycline for Covid-19 patients in the home isolation,” said Subir Sen, north Kolkata district secretary of the BCDA. Sanjay Mukim a wholesaler at the Mehta Building said that shortage of doxycycline is continuing over the past few weeks. Meanwhile, the shortage is witnessed in certain other drugs like favipiravir that have lesser usage in Covid management. The antiviral medicine, approved by the Drugs Controller General of India for treating mild to moderate Covid-19 patients, however, is not being prescribed much as compared to last year. The trouble with the multivitamin, vitamin C and zinc tablets started after people began stocking up medicines again.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/shortage-of-drugs-for-cov-treatment-hits-pharmacies/articleshow/82441919.cms||Rohit Khanna

---||Chandigarh||Huge spike in Punjab stubble burning cases after wheat harvest||Bathinda: With the surge in the Covid-19 cases, stubble burning too has picked up pace in Punjab. The crop residue burning cases in the ongoing wheat harvest season have registered a sharp increase compared to the last two years. Even though stubble after wheat harvesting is not as high as compared to crop residue burning after paddy harvest yet the cases have seen a sharp rise this year. A total of 203 stubble burning cases were reported on May 6, taking the total cases in the ongoing season to 3,267. Against it, only 243 crop residue burning cases were reported till May 6 in 2020. In 2019, 888 stubble burning cases were recorded till May 6. Earlier, 733 stubble burning cases were recorded on May 5, the highest so far in the ongoing season, as per data collected from Punjab Remote Sensing Centre. Before that, 594 cases were recorded four days ago on May 2. The first stubble burning cases were reported on April 17 when two cases had come to the fore. Sangrur district witnessed the most stubble burning cases so far at 552, followed by 293 in Patiala, 283 in Bathinda, 247 Ferozepur, 237 Barnala, 231 Moga, and 227 in Mansa. These Punjab districts have recorded over 200 stubble burning cases so far. Compared to these, SBS Nagar and Roopnagar districts still figure in single digits, as SBS Nagar has reported only three and Roopnagar only registered nine crop residue burning cases so far. Stubble Burning Cases Till May 6 Sangrur 552 Patiala 293 Bathinda 283 Ferozepur 247 Barnala 237 Moga 231 Mansa 227 Roopnagar 9 SBS Nagar 3 Year-Wise Burning Cases 2016 10,732 2017 14,436 2018 10,907 2019 11,701 2020 13,420 2021 (till May 6) 3,267||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/huge-spike-in-punjab-stubble-burning-cases-after-wheat-harvest/articleshow/82441945.cms||Neel Kamal
---||Ghaziabad||Two govt hospitals in Gzb to get own O2 plants soon||Ghaziabad: Two government hospitals in the district will have their own oxygen plants in the next couple of weeks, officials have said.While Bharat Electronics Limited (BEL) has decided to install a plant for the District Combined Hospital as part of its corporate social responsibility, state health minister Atul Garg has donated Rs 50 lakh to set up a plant and procure oxygen concentrators at MMG District Hospital, a non-Covid facility. The two plants will together be able to provide continuous oxygen supply to 70-80 beds, officials said. On Wednesday, a team from BEL visited the District Combined Hospital, a 100-bed L2 facility, to earmark the place for the plant. The chief medical superintendent at the hospital, Dr Sanjay Teotia, said: “The company representatives have assured us that the plant will be up and running in the next 10 days. According to them, the plant will be capable of supplying oxygen to about 30 beds continuously. Once ready, it will reduce our dependence on oxygen cylinders from outside. Currently, 35-40 patients are on oxygen support on a daily basis.”An oxygen plant had been installed at the hospital five-six years ago by a Lucknow-based company. It worked for about three years and has been lying defunct since then.For the past few months, Teotia said, they have been trying to revive the facility and the firm from Lucknow had recently sent its representatives for an inspection. But it was found that the plant cannot be revived now.Dr Teotia said the new plant will cost around Rs 30 lakh and it would be installed right next to the defunct facility.MMG District Hospital, the largest government facility in Ghaziabad with over 150 beds, is a non-Covid unit. The hospital caters to patients with emergencies and critical ailments. According to officials, with the Rs 50 lakhs donated by the minister, several oxygen concentrators would be bought soon. The oxygen plant that would be installed in the next few weeks will provide oxygen supply to around 50 beds, said an official.Apart from the District Combined Hospital and MMG District Hospital, the other prominent government facility in the district is the District Womens’ Hospital.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ghaziabad/two-govt-hospitals-in-gzb-to-get-own-o2-plants-soon/articleshow/82445931.cms||Aditya Dev
---||Ghaziabad||Ghaziabad: 414 oxygen cylinders land up for refill in 2 days||GHAZIABAD: Two days after the district authorities started an initiative to refill oxygen cylinders used by patients in home isolation, officials said, they have received 414 empty cylinders from residents. They have also refilled and handed over 238 cylinders that came in on the first day. According to officials, the cylinders were refilled within 24 hours, although the time limit had been fixed between 36 and 48 hours. With several residents desperately looking for oxygen, the district administration, on Wednesday, launched the initiative and set up collection points where people could drop off empty cylinders so that they could be refilled and returned for use. Collection points have been set up at each of the five municipal zones across the city. Ghaziabad Municipal Corporation (GMC) is executing the plan and GMC commissioner Mahendra Singh Tanwar has been appointed as the nodal officer for overseeing the oxygen supply process. On Wednesday, 238 residents had registered and received coupons and on Thursday, 176 people applied for refilling. The maximum number of registration was done in Vasundhara zone (171 residents). It was followed by City zone (88) and Mohan Nagar zone (71), respectively. Coupons were given to people after checking documents, like a patient’s Covid report and doctor’s prescription. Sandeep Tyagi, a resident of Saddik Nagar, who got a refilled cylinder within 24 hours, said the process was smooth. “We were facing a lot of problems while getting cylinders for my 35-year-old sister-in-law whose oxygen level dropped to 70. Earlier, we wasted an entire day waiting at a refilling agency in Lal Kuan,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ghaziabad/414-o2-cylinders-land-up-for-refill-in-2-days/articleshow/82445940.cms||Aditya Dev
---||Mumbai||How Mumbai got breather: Year before 2nd wave, BMC set up oxygen team||By: P VelrasuMuch interest has been generated on the ‘Mumbai Model’ of oxygen management after recent observations by the Supreme Court. I wonder what could make a management method unique and get its own name when the ingredients at hand seem to be common among cities. The success of the Mumbai Model can be attributed to centralization of certain aspects and decentralization of the services aspect. Understanding the requirements for Mumbai and micro-planning was essential for successful oxygen management in this mega city. Efficiently doing so in a pandemic involves many aspects, including resource and inventory mapping, generating storage capacities, and proper supply chain management. The BMC started with resource mapping and inventory accounting in May 2020 following oxygen difficulties in one of our hospitals within three months of the Covid outbreak in Mumbai. Our ‘Oxygen Team’ was asked to visit every hospital and compile data on storage capacity, supply method, suppliers’ names and supply periodicity. We accounted for much increased oxygen demand during the pandemic and expected the number of ICU and oxygenated beds to go up. The next step was to increase storage capacities by installing additional cryogenic tankers in civic hospitals. The work was completed within 40 days. Underutilized during the first Covid wave, the tanks took the load during the second Covid wave very effectively. Adequate supply of liquid medical oxygen is of paramount importance. I think this is where Delhi has faced problems. The basic supply quantity has to be sufficient even if everything else is in place. On three consecutive days Mumbai too witnessed lots of SOS calls. We shifted many patients to bigger hospitals without any casualty. Excellent teamwork was put forth by the BMC. Fortunately for Mumbai, there is an oxygen team at work round the clock in Mantralaya too. There are at least five IAS officers who work round the clock to secure increased supplies of liquid medical oxygen from new sources. Once our supply inadequacy was flagged at that level, Mumbai was allotted 30 metric tonnes from a steel plant in Raigad. Also, later supplies were augmented with tankers from Jamnagar. Had these additional supplies not been ensured in time, Mumbai too would have had problems. No amount of good management can compensate for supply inadequacies — simple and straight. Again, proper supply chain management is critical to avoid any supply disruptions. Because new difficulties can emerge any time: oxygen filling stations at manufacturing plants are lined with tankers and waiting times have become longer because now the plants are supplying real-time. When in an emergency, contacting a plant and requesting for an out-of-turn filling also helps, an option we have exercised sometimes! A point to remember is that optimising the turnover time is crucial since the number of cryotankers is limited. Currently, the oxygen team is working on future-proofing Mumbai from the shocks and exigencies of oxygen supply. We will be installing self-generating oxygen plants in all BMC hospitals as augmentation measures. The new plants will be able to cater to 100% of patients in normal times and during extreme situations too. This supply system will work well without stress even during disruptions. (The author is additional municipal commissioner — projects — BMC. As told to Chaitanya Marpakwar)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/how-city-got-breather-yr-before-2nd-wave-bmc-set-up-o2-team-in-mumbai/articleshow/82444047.cms||---
---||India||Foreign aid allocation 100% transparent, no delays: Kant||NEW DELHI: The Centre is following a transparent system for allocating all foreign aid being received to combat the surge in Covid-19 cases and all items received up to May 5 have been allocated and dispatched, Niti Aayog CEO Amitabh Kant said on Thursday. So far, the government has received 3,682 oxygen concentrators and cylinders, 13 oxygen generation plants, 2,403 ventilators, BiPap units and more than 2.8 lakh Remdesivir vials from various countries. All items received up to May 5 have been allocated and dispatched to states and institutions following the health ministry's standard operating procedures which are initially aimed to aid states and institutions with high caseloads. According to government data, so far, 38 institutions in 31 states and Union Territories have received the items. "We are following 100% transparency on all foreign aid. There is not a minute's delay in allocating the relief material and moving them to their destinations," Kant told TOI, rebutting criticism about delays in getting the foreign aid to states and UTs grappling with the deadly surge in Covid-19 cases. Several countries from around the world have mounted a massive relief operation to provide critical equipment and drugs to help India in its fight against the deadly virus which has claimed over 2 lakh lives. Kant said the goods were being moved through flights and container trains and were swiftly dispatched to their destinations. Control rooms have been set up by the health ministry and the Niti Aayog to track the movement. Niti Aayog has set up a portal (http://covaid.niti.gov.in) to enable private sector donors to track the movement up to the end beneficiaries. "This will help individuals and organisations to do end-to-end tracking till the ultimate beneficiary," Kant said, adding that the control room was functional 24x7 to facilitate the movement of aid material from the private sector. Several agencies such as the Indian Red Cross Society are working round the clock in coordination with the health ministry to ensure swift movement of foreign aid. Cargo clearance and deliveries are facilitated without delay in coordination with various agencies. Kant also said a press statement would be issued daily giving details about the items received and allocated to states, a measure which will add to the transparency over the entire process. On May 5, the Centre received 1,056 ventilators, BiPaP/CPAP units, 43 oxygen cylinders from Australia, 40,300 RDK, 1.56 lakh vials of Remdesivir, PPE kits and other items from the US and two liquid oxygen containers from Bahrain. The empowered group headed by Kant met on Thursday to discuss logistical issues and ensure faster distribution of the material received from foreign countries. There was a suggestion that the relief material be sent directly to southern and western states and the material could land at Mumbai, Hyderabad and Chennai airports. The health ministry said the distribution plans were already in place by the time it landed in India, according to an official statement.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/foreign-aid-allocation-100-transparent-no-delays-kant/articleshow/82447703.cms||Surojit Gupta
---||Mumbai||Let private hospitals have own oxygen plants like in Sangli: Bombay HC||MUMBAI: Bombay HC on Thursday, in light of the expected third Covid wave, batted for private hospitals in the state to have their own oxygen manufacturing plants. “Private hospitals must have their own oxygen manufacturing plant now that the third wave is likely. If it can be done at Sangli, why not it be replicated in private hospitals?” a bench asked while hearing a clutch of PILs on remdesivir injections, beds, oxygen and testing facilities. TOI had on Thursday reported on Sangli’s Bharati Vidyapeeth Hospital investing in oxygen resources. The judges also exhorted all civic bodies in the state to replicate Mumbai’s success in lowering Covid cases. “Bombay model must be replicated not only by the entire country, but also by other municipal corporations and councils in the state,” said the CJ. The bench of of Chief Justice Dipankar Datta and Justice Girish Kulkarni said, “This is the time to reach out to people in need. If Mumbai has tided over the crisis, should we not help others now?” Advocate general Ashutosh Kumbhakoni said as active cases had decreased by 50,000 to 6.4 lakh from 6.9 lakh in Maharashtra, there was reduced burden of beds with oxygen facilities. He informed the court that jumbo Covid centres are being built near oxygen-generating industries “where oxygen can be transferred and not transported” to patients. The AG said an oxygen consumption audit is done to prevent wastage, leakage and pilferage. “There should not be a single death for want of oxygen. Your authorities have to regulate oxygen in such a manner that we don’t have casualties for want of oxygen,” said the CJ. The judges then said it is “high time” private hospitals meet their own oxygen demand. They sought from the state the logistics of setting up oxygen plants for hospitals with more than 50 beds. The judges took note of the “alarming situation” in Pune, which has the highest number of cases and double that of Mumbai. “If this is the situation in Pune, why not consider a total lockdown?” asked the CJ, adding “drastic steps” are required in places where the caseload is high, including imposing a total lockdown, so that it does not have a cascading effect on peripheral centres. Advocate Rajesh Inamdar said apart from remdesivir, there is shortage of tocilizumab injections and tamiflu pills. He said dexamethasone, recommended by WHO as more effective than remdesivir, costs only Rs 10 per vial whereas doctors recommend remdesivir which costs Rs 1,000-5,000 per vial. “Why should we go for remdesivir?’’ asked the CJ. Inamdar said tocilizumab costs starts from Rs 40,000 per vial. The judges pointed out that tocilizumab is manufactured by Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche and marketed by Cipla. “If there is a low price medicine, which can be used like a sanjeevani which saved Lakshman, why go for foreign medicine?” the CJ asked. Additional solicitor general Anil Singh said the Centre had told the Supreme Court three drugs are better than remdesivir. The judges questioned why no advisory was put out for cheaper alternatives to tocilizumab and remdesivir injections. “It is for you, the Central government and the state government, to put your foot down. India is not a place for multinational companies to exploit Covid-19 in a situation like this,” said the CJ. Senior advocate Anil Sakhare for the BMC said there is a lot of improvement in Mumbai in terms of remdesivir, oxygen and beds. The judges said if there is a shortage in nearby areas, there must be connectivity with the BMC so that what is available with the civic body can be utilised by neighbouring districts. “We do not disrespect any municipal commissioner. Let them not be bogged down by ego. If one has done good work, let it be replicated,’’ said the CJ.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/let-pvt-hospitals-have-own-o2-plants-like-in-sangli-bombay-hc/articleshow/82446039.cms||Rosy Sequeira

---||Nagpur||All industries must spend CSR funds for Covid patients: HC||Nagpur: Asking all industries to respond to “clarion call of Covid-19 patients struggling to get beds, medicines and oxygen”, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court directed them to provide corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds to fight the pandemic. “We are of opinion that, at this hour of crisis, those companies under a duty to spend CSR funds because of their earning net profit, respond to clarion call of Covid patients and make CSR funds available to the best of their ability,” a division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote said, before adjourning the hearing till Friday. Quoting Section 135 of the Companies Act, the Companies (CSR Policy) Rules, 2014, and Union Ministry of Corporate Affairs’ (MCA) March 23, 2020 notification, the bench noted that all these sufficiently show that an onerous responsibility has been placed upon the industries to contribute their share towards social cause, including the Covid pandemic. “We find that not only is there an authorization of law for the companies to use their CSR funds for Covid cause, but also an encouragement for them to do so.” While hearing a suo motu PIL based on TOI report where Shreerang Bhandarkar was amicus curiae assisted by Nidhi Dayani, the judges said sub-sections (5) and (7) of Section 135 indicate that in every financial year, the company must ensure to spend at least 2% of the average net profits during three immediate preceding financial years. “If a company defaulted, it would be liable to pay two times penalty to the fund specified in Schedule VII or the unspent CSR account or Rs1 crore, whichever is less.” Explaining the Schedule VII, the bench said it speaks of disaster management including relief, rehabilitation and construction activities for which CSR fund should be spent. “It also speaks of such social causes as eradication of hunger, poverty, malnutrition, promoting healthcare, including preventive, sanitation and disaster management. The MCA notification clarifies that funds may be spent for various activities related to Covid-19 for promotion of healthcare.” The judges said if there is any difficulty for any of the companies to spend CSR funds in a particular area, when their headquarters or registered offices are located elsewhere, such issues stand more than removed by proviso to sub-section (5) of Section 135. “It prescribes that the company shall give preference to the local areas where it operates for spending the amount earmarked under CSR funds.” Approach cos: HC to Ngp, Amt collectors The bench directed Nagpur and Amravati collectors to explore the possibility of mobilizing funds for Covid cause from CSR heads of companies in Vidarbha. The move came after intervener’s counsel M Anil Kumar submitted a list of 59 companies and Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA) lawyer Jatin Kumar filed another list of firms that had spent their CSR funds in 2020-21. “We would request VIA to submit all details such as their head offices’ locations, local areas of operation, percentage of the amounts shown in relation to the net profits and other relevant details. It’s also not known whether these amounts which are shown to have been spent are by the companies under CSR or by individuals.” The judges pointed out that VIA hasn’t so far placed on record any details about the number of oxygen cylinders, liquid oxygen storage tanks and other infrastructural facilities with all its members for generation, storage and transportation.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/all-industries-must-spend-csr-funds-for-covid-patients-hc/articleshow/82442011.cms||Vaibhav Ganjapure
---||Chennai||Tamil Nadu: After poll rout, Makkal Needhi Maiam vice-presidents and general secretaries quit||CHENNAI: Kamal Haasan’s party Makkal Needhi Maiam (MNM) received a major post-election jolt on Thursday as its two vice-presidents – R Mahendran and V Ponraj – quit their posts. Rebutting Mahendran’s charges, Kamal Haasan said he was a “traitor” and added that there was a clarion call from the cadres to weed out traitors. Mahendran’s name was first on the list, he said. Kamal said Mahendran was standing in the way of the growth of several hard-working cadres. “Everyone knows the doors of the party always remain open for incompetent and dishonest persons to leave. He (Mahendran) is trying to blame others for his incompetence, dishonesty, and failure to seek sympathy,” Kamal said. He said Mahendran had quit knowing well that he would be removed from the party. “We ignore cowards, who run away on seeing failures,” he added. Four general secretaries of the party - A G Mourya, Umadevi, C K Kumaravel and M Muruganandam – have also resigned their posts. In an eight-page letter addressed to Kamal, Mahendran lashed out at the party’s consultant and a key advisor of the actor for the pathetic show of the party in the assembly elections. He said the consultant and advisor had misguided Kamal and despite repeated warnings, the actor did not go for course correction. Iyer heads Sankhya Consultancy, which had handled election strategies of the MNM after Prashant Kishor’s IPAC’s contract ended. Mahendran said the consultancy firm and Kamal’s advisor had sidelined many hardworking functionaries and cadres in the party. Mahendran said none of the key members of the party was consulted on any decision when the party was preparing for the assembly polls. Even on alliance formation, none of the office bearers were consulted, he said. MNM spokesperson Murali Abbas, in a statement, said the party leader would decide on the resignations. The MNM’s vote share dipped from 3.6% in 2019 LS polls to 2.8% in the 2021 assembly polls. Kamal lost the polls to Vanathi Srinivasan of BJP in Coimbatore south and Mahendran lost in Singanallur segment. Mahendran told TOI that he had submitted a letter to Kamal citing reasons for his exit and added that if the actor chose to act upon the issues raised in the letter, it would be good for the party. However, his decision to quit the party was final, he said. Mahendran said the party core committee members wanted Kamal to contest from Velachery in Chennai as many senior leaders were also contesting in the city. Kamal’s presence in the city would have helped them, he said. But Kamal, going by the consultant’s opinion, chose to contest from Coimbatore south. “Today, I’m sad to say, there is a decline in your tenacity of purpose, which lies buried under a style of operation that reeks of a non-democratic manner of running a political party,” said Mahendran and added after three years, the situation warranted him to step down from the party posting and the primary membership of the party. In another letter to the party functionaries, Mahendran said, “Even after the massive defeat of the party and his (Kamal) own defeat (in Coimbatore South), I am not seeing any change in the leader’s approach and I am not confident that he will change,”. It may be recalled that party founder member Kameela Nazar had resigned earlier.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/after-poll-rout-mnm-vps-and-gen-secys-quit/articleshow/82444035.cms||---

---||Chandigarh||NCC to be elective subject in colleges||CHANDIGARH: The National Cadet Corps (NCC) would now be considered a General Elective Credit Course (GECC) among the graduation courses being run in educational institutes or colleges in Haryana. A decision has been taken in this regard in response to the proposal mooted by the Directorate General National Cadet Corps, New Delhi. NCC Syllabus for ‘B’ and ‘C’ cert is designed as per choice based credit system of National Education Policy 2020, which grants 24 credit points, covering six semesters, out of which a student can accrue four credit points, covering first two semesters and 10 credits in the third and fourth semesters and 10 credits in the fifth and sixth semesters. The move is in consonance with the National Education Policy 2020, where students can select their choice of subjects rather than being confined to only those being offered by the institutions. This makes learning holistic and skill-oriented. On successful completion of the course, students are awarded points which will enable them to qualify for their respective degrees. Brig A S Berar, Group Commander, NCC Group Ambala has recommended early implementation of NCC as an elective subject in educational institutions in Haryana. The UGC has already issued an advisory to the vice-chancellors (VCs) of all universities to include NCC training as General Elective Credit Course. An NCC spokesman said the proposed implementation, which is planned from the forthcoming academic session, has evoked a positive response from the state government and is being viewed as a visionary step. “It will undoubtedly add to the appeal of the largest uniformed youth force which has contributed immensely to the role of nation building. The Rashtriya Uchha Siksha Abhiyaan (RUSH) state offices are encouraged to work with respective state governments and facilitate the implementation of NCC as elective subject”, said Brig A S Berar.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chandigarh/ncc-to-be-elective-subject-in-colleges/articleshow/82442031.cms||---

---||Nagpur||Kin of Nagzira fire victims still await full govt compensation||Nagpur: Nearly a month after three van majoors were charred while fighting forest fires inside Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary in the Gondia district, the families of the victims are waiting for ex-gratia announced by the chief minister. Two NGOs have released Rs 9.75 lakh to them. Wildlife Conservation Trust (WCT), Mumbai, released Rs 1.50 lakh for each of the deceased and Rs 50,000 for each of two injured to the Nagzira Tiger Conservation Foundation. Wildlife Trust of India (WTI), Delhi, released Rs 1 lakh each to the next of kin of the deceased and Rs 25,000 each to the injured. “We deposited the money directly in the bank account of the victims’ kin,” said Prafulla Bhamburkar, WTI adviser, Maharashtra. On April 9, three forest labourers - Rakesh Madavi (25), Thadezari, Rekhchand Rane (45), Dhanori, and Sachin Shrirange (22), Kosamtondi— died after fire-blowers they were carrying exploded. The injured, Vijay Maraskolhe (40), Thadezari, and Raju Sayam (30), Bolunda, are still undergoing treatment at a private hospital in the city. The chief minister, Uddhav Thackeray on April 10 had announced Rs 5 lakh compensation for next of kin of deceased from Chief Minister’s Relief Fund. Till now only Rs 1 lakh each has been released. Gondia resident deputy collector Jairam Deshpande said, “We have still not received post-mortem and police report and detailed report from the forest department. Once these papers are received, we will release the money as soon as possible.” Another reason for the delay is that the administration is busy tackling Covid spread. Besides, funds crunch is also an issue, Deshpande said. NNTR field director M Ramanujam said, “We will submit papers to the district administration soon. Due to Covid, our office is working with restricted staff strength.” He confirmed NGOs WCT and WTI have released the money as promised. However, the kin of the three victims were promised a package of Rs 10 lakh each. This included Rs 5 lakh from CM Relief Fund and another Rs 5 lakh was to come from the contribution by NGOs, local MLA, and forest unions and associations. Till now only Rs 3.50 lakh each has been mopped up. The two injured van majoors are undergoing treatment in Nagpur and the NNTR foundation has spent Rs 15 lakh on them. The cost of treatment will be borne by the state government and the money will be later refunded to the foundation.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/kin-of-nagzira-fire-victims-still-await-full-govt-compensation/articleshow/82442091.cms||Vijay Pinjarkar
---||Goa||Let app-based taxis operate in state: Hotels body to govt||Panaji: The Hotel and Restaurant Association of Western India (HRAWI) has submitted a representation to chief minister Pramod Sawant and tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar requesting the government to allow the app-based taxi service aggregators to operate in the interest of tourists and the hotel industry. The association said that app-based taxis provide good services at cheaper rates as against that of the existing taxi operators. “The industry is of the opinion that lopsided trade practices are detrimental to progress and discourage tourism in the state,” the HRAWI stated, adding that the local taxi operators’ demands are “unreasonable and uncompetitive when viable and transparent app-based options are available”. They pointed out that app-based cab operators including Ola, Uber, and GoaMiles, among others offer tourists the choice of their ride. “These operators provide decent services at reasonable fares to the local commuters as well as tourists, and hence should be allowed to operate. App-based cab operators are operating in almost every state in the country except Goa which is a huge inconvenience for both the domestic as well as international tourists.” they wrote. Welcoming the state government’s decision to install digital meters, the association president Sherry Bhatia said that it “will bring transparency, and offer convenient and reliable taxi services” in Goa. “We therefore request the state government to ensure that GoaMiles continue its operations along with other app-based taxi services that could also be allowed to operate in the state,” said committee member of HRAWI Menino Proenca. “The government’s intervention on this matter will go a long way in aiding and enabling tourism in the state as the local transport system is known to be the key driving factor in the promotion of tourism.” he added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/let-app-based-taxis-operate-in-state-hotels-body-to-govt/articleshow/82444121.cms||---

---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat high court notice over consumer court members’ demand||AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Thursday issued notice to the Centre, state government and registrar of the Gujarat State Consumer Dispute Redressal Commission after two non-judicial members of the commission filed a petition demanding pay parity with its judicial members. Two members — Jyoti Jani and Jolly Shukla — have filed a petition in the HC stating that they are advocates and have given up their practice of law and working as full-time members of the consumer commission. They have been paid salary of Rs 20,000, whereas a judicial member, who is a retired judge, is paid Rs 1.8 lakh on basis of pay minus pension formula. These two petitioners have cited a 2018 Supreme Court order issuing directions to the Uttar Pradesh administration to rationalize the salary structure of members of consumer courts. They have argued that they sit on the same bench with the judicial members, they put in equal efforts to resolve disputes of complainants, but there is a vast difference in salary structure. In their petition, they have demanded pay revision in line with the payment being made to a judicial member and also sought the difference in payment since 2013. They has also urged the HC to direct the state government to frame rules for the salary structure on basis of the model rules framed by the central government. After hearing the case, Justice Biren Vaishnav , issued notice to concerned authorities and posted further hearing on June 14.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/pay-parity-hc-notice-over-consumer-court-members-demand/articleshow/82442134.cms||---
---||Bareilly||UP cop rescues woman who jumped into Ganga canal||Muzaffarnagar: Constable Rakesh Kumar of the UP Police dived into the Ganga canal here on Thursday, moments after a woman who had allegedly jumped into the water to end her life and rescued her. A video of the rescue has gone viral, earning accolades for the policeman who risked his life to save the woman. According to police sources, constable Kumar and another policeman posted on PVR duty were stationed on the banks of the canal in Sikhera police station area. A passerby informed Kumar that a woman sitting on the banks did not seem to be normal. As Kumar walked towards her, she suddenly jumped into the canal. Acting on the spur of the moment, Kumar rushed to the police vehicle, brought out a rope, tied himself with it and jumped in after the woman. He managed to reach her before she could drown and rescued her. The woman was shifted to hospital and was handed over to her family after medical examination. Subhash Chand Gautam, SHO of Sikhera police station, said, “Further action in the matter is being taken.” He has sent a report about the incident to the police headquarters, recommending a reward for constable Kumar.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/bareilly/up-cop-rescues-woman-who-jumped-into-ganga-canal/articleshow/82440706.cms||Mohd Dilshad
---||Nagpur||Over 80 teak trees felled in Ghodazari sanctuary?||Nagpur: Taking advantage of lockdown, teak smugglers with the involvement of forest staff have struck it rich by felling over 80 big teak trees in and around Ghodazari wildlife sanctuary, 105km from here, in Nagbhid forest range under the Bramhapuri division. Chandrapur honorary district wildlife warden Vivek Karambelkar, who visited the sanctuary on Wednesday along with members of NGO Nature Environment & Wildlife (NEW) and villagers, said, “We recorded at least 80 stumps inside the sanctuary but according to the villagers, the number of trees maybe even more and the smuggling racket must be going on for long with the involvement of the forest staff.” Bramhapuri deputy conservator of forests (DyCF) Dipesh Malhotra, denied felling inside the sanctuary. “In separate raids in the area, we have seized 22 logs of teakwood valued at Rs77,000. The stumps of these trees fall in the territorial forest in Mangrul and not in the sanctuary as being alleged.” However, Mangrul villagers, who released pictures of stumps of trees felled in Huma and Mangrul forest area, on May 4, submitted a memorandum to the deputy conservator demanding action against forest staff and teak smugglers who are hand in glove otherwise such felling inside a sanctuary is not possible. Mangrul sarpanch Vaibhav Nikhure said, “We have demanded action against the forest staff and those involved. It is possible that the forest fires last month must have been ignited to destroy evidence of tree felling in and around Ghodazari sanctuary.” The villagers have also demanded a probe into fake financial claims of crop damage from the forest department, especially when there is no crop in the agriculture fields. The role of forest staff in the illicit felling cannot be ruled out. Malhotra said, “Acting on a tip-off about illicit tree felling, we conducted the first raid on April 26, on a farm owned by Madhukar Satpaise, a resident of Mangrul, and seized seven big logs of teak hidden under haystacks.” “We are verifying call details records (CDRs) and have registered five preliminary offence reports (PORs) against unidentified persons. After forest staff being named, an in-charge lady beat guard has been shifted. Further investigation is going on and action will be taken if more staff is found involved,” said Malhotra.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/over-80-teak-trees-felled-in-ghodazari-sanctuary/articleshow/82442145.cms||Vijay Pinjarkar

---||Nagpur||Elephant Gajraj kills forester in Tadoba||Chandrapur: Gajraj, the problem elephant of Tadoba, killed an officer with Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) while one other had a close shave deep in the Botezari forest in core area on Thursday evening. “Residents of Kolsa and Rantalodhi villages in Tadoba core have been alerted and asked to stay indoors till the time the elephant is captured,” said CCF and field director, Jitendra Ramgaonkar. This is the third human kill by Gajraj. The pachyderm had earlier fled from its camp and killed a woman and injured one other in Yavatmal district in October 2018 when it was involved in capture of problem tigress Avni. On November 15, 2019, the elephant had turned aggressive under musth and killed its caretaker at Moharli gate when he was trying to feed the jumbo. Musth is a periodic condition in bull (male) elephants characterized by highly aggressive behaviour due to rise in testosterones (reproductive hormones) level.  The elephant was moved into deep forest in Botezari in Kolsa range of TATR after the incident. On Thursday evening, Ramgaonkar said, Gajraj turned aggressive and caretakers tried to rein it in. “ACF Ravindra Kulkarni and chief accountant of field director office of TATR, Pramod Gaurkar, were patrolling in the same area. At around 6pm, their vehicle got stuck in the mud. Suddenly, Gajraj charged at the duo sitting in the vehicle,” said Ramgaonkar. “Both the officers left their vehicle and ran for the safety but the elephant attacked the duo. Gaurkar was killed on the spot, while ACF Kulkarni had a close shave,” he said. Ramgaonkar maintained that the elephant was not in ‘musth’. “Its musth was over recently. It turned aggressive for uncertain reasons,” he said. The field director informed that rapid response teams from Tadoba and Chandrapur along with a veterinary doctor and the commandos of Special Tiger Protection Force have been called for rescue operation. Efforts to tranquilise and capture Gajraj were underway till filing of this report. Ramgaonkar claimed that rescue workers are facing problem in tranquilizing the animal due to darkness, but was confident of capturing the jumbo by morning.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/elephant-gajraj-kills-forester-in-tadoba/articleshow/82442173.cms||Mazhar Ali
---||Meerut||Six injured as Haryana, Uttar Pradesh farmers clash over land||MEERUT: Less than a month after a clash between Haryana and UP farmers over claim to agricultural land left one dead and several injured in Baghpat, another violent clash on Wednesday evening in the border village of Tanda in Baraut tehsil of Baghpat left six, including a woman, injured. Sources in Baghpat claimed that Haryana’s Panipat-based farmers attacked the UP farmers with sharp-edged weapons and even mowed down a farmer with a tractor. His condition is stated to be serious. Additional DM Amit Kumar said, “An investigation is underway and efforts are on to establish contact with authorities on the other side of the border also. We will resolve this matter soon.” This is not the first time that such a clash has taken place in the region. Every year, mainly due to the changing course of the river Yamuna, post-monsoon, territorial disputes emerge among farmers often leading to heated arguments and clashes. In April this year, a clash near Nagla Behlolpur village in Baghpat claimed the life of a farmer in UP and left several injured. In November, a fierce clash occurred over claim to agricultural fields of Niwada village on the UP-Haryana border. In October last year, 14 residents of Tanda village had staged a protest at the DM’s office demanding action against farmers of Haryana who had allegedly destroyed sugarcane plantations in the area. Also, farmers in Sonepat district of Haryana were attacked, allegedly by UP farmers, in which almost 12 farmers of Jajal village were hurt. Six districts of western Uttar Pradesh – Shamli, Saharanpur, Baghpat, Gautam Buddh Nagar, Bulandshahr and Aligarh – witness frequent clashes between farmers of the two states over ownership of farm fields at the inter-state border. At present, 132 villages of five districts of UP and 102 villages of six districts of Haryana are located on the border and witness frequent clashes over land disputes. In the backdrop of these clashes, the two state governments had agreed to cooperate in resolving half a century old issue and on January 8 last year, a meeting was held under the chairpersonship of then divisional commissioner of Meerut, Anita Meshram, but things went on the backburner due to the Covid pandemic.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/meerut/six-injured-as-haryana-up-farmers-clash-over-land/articleshow/82440754.cms||Sandeep Rai
---||Rajkot||Bain Circuit saves 50 lives in Rajkot civil hospital||Rajkot: Amid massive influx of Covid-19 patients requiring oxygen support and shortage of ventilator beds, doctors at Rajkot Civil Hospital have been able to save about 50 lives in the last one month using Bain Circuit technique that delays immediate requirement of life support system.Experts say the technique has immensely helped patients and doctors buy some crucial hours till the ventilators are arranged.Dr. Chetna Jadeja, nodal officer, anaesthesia department of civil hospital told TOI: “Bain Circuit is used when a patient is being shifted from ventilator to room air . We did this on an experimental basis when there was a shortage of oxygen. It could provide oxygen to a patient from five hours to two days depending on the patient’s lung condition but it helps buy time to arrange a ventilator.” According to doctors, requires 50 litre oxygen per minute while this Bain Circuit requires nearly 12-15 litres. However, a patient can’t be left alone when this Bain circuit is used and it requires an expert to handle this equipment. Doctors in Ahmedabad, Surat and Bhavnagar also experimented with Bain Circuits during the ventilator shortage.Dr Rahesh Mishra, an intensive care specialist in Ahmedabad, said, “Using Bain Circuit can help save many lives, but it requires trained people to handle the equipment, lest it leads to catastrophic cardiac arrest.” The technique is being regularly used in Ahmedabad-based SVP Hospital too, sources confirmed to TOI.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/rajkot/bain-circuit-saves-50-lives-in-rajkot-civil-hospital/articleshow/82440803.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: In pandemic year, SEZs see 19% dip in exports||AHMEDABAD: There has been a 19% decline in exports from operational special economic zones in Gujarat during 2020-21, due to disruptions in demand and supply caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The cumulative exports — both merchandise and services — from functional SEZs in Gujarat plummeted from Rs 1.57 crore in 2019-20 to Rs 1.27 lakh crore in fiscal 2020-21. This shows a dip of about Rs 30,000 crore during the year as per the data compiled by the Export Promotion Council for EoUs & SEZs (EPCES), a council set up by the union ministry of commerce and industry to service the promotional needs of export-oriented units (EoUs) and SEZs in the country. According to zone-wise data collected by EPCES, Gujarat zone saw export of manufacturing-related products decrease from Rs 1.56 lakh crore in fiscal 2020 to Rs 1.25 lakh crore in fiscal 2021. The exports from services and trading stood at Rs 2,121 crore as against Rs 1,404 crore, the data further shows. All the 21 operational SEZs in Gujarat fall under the jurisdiction of Kandla Special Economic Zone (KASEZ) development commissioner. The overall decline in SEZ exports from Gujarat is largely attributed to the fall in export of petroleum products. Reduction in price of petroleum products, mainly crude oil, impacted SEZ exports of petroleum products in 2020, said people in the know. The export of petroleum products in terms of value dipped to Rs 77,374 crore during the financial year 2020-21 as compared to Rs 1,14,192 crore in 2019-20, according to EPCES data. Petroleum products exports account for about 70% of the total SEZ exports from Gujarat. Export from most SEZs in the state was hit during the initial months of lockdown imposed last year, causing subsequent disruption in demand and supply. However, many SEZs saw recovery later on. “SEZs in Kandla, Dahej, and Surat have seen growth in exports in fiscal 2021 despite the challenges posed by the pandemic,” said sources.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/in-pandemic-year-sezs-see-19-dip-in-exports/articleshow/82442192.cms||Kalpesh Damor

The survivor was among the convict’s 11 children from three wives. Born to his second wife, the girl has been putting up with her father’s sexual assault since 2017 when she was 15 years old. He continuously raped her by threatening to kill her mother if she revealed it to anyone. However, the woman came to know about it in 2019 and threatened him with dire consequences. He decided to get rid of her after she started preventing his further advances towards the girl. He murdered the woman in December 2019 at an isolated place. Police arrested him and it was during inquiry that they came to know about his sexual assault on his own daughter. Judge R Sathya convicted the man under four sections of the Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) (amendment) Act, 2019. Besides death sentence, she also awarded him a life sentence, nine years of rigorous imprisonment and fines adding up to Rs 3 lakh. This is the third case of rape of a minor in the past six months in which the judge has awarded death sentence. In December 2020, a 25-year-old man who murdered a seven-year-old girl after raping her in June that year was awarded death sentence, rigorous life imprisonment and fine. In February this year, the judge awarded triple death sentence to a 34-year-old native of Gujarat for sodomising a 17-year-old boy with learning disabilities who later died in hospital due to internal injuries.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/daughter-17-raped-and-wife-murdered-tn-man-gets-death/articleshow/82444149.cms||Sampath Kumar

---||Mumbai||Maharashtra No. 1 by fully vaccinating 28.7L, but coverage only 3.2%||MUMBAI: Maharashtra has raced ahead of Gujarat to boast of the highest number of fully vaccinated people in the country. As on Thursday morning, the state has finished complete vaccination of 28.7lakh people, while Gujarat has given both doses to 28.5lakh. West Bengal with 27.4lakh complete vaccinations is in the third position. In terms of coverage though, this achievement is a drop in the ocean — only 3.2% of the 9crore adult population has been covered. About 15% (1.7crore) have received one dose. Nearly four months after the vaccination drive started on January 16, 90% healthcare workers in the state have taken the first dose, and 65% both doses. Among 13lakh-odd frontline workers, complete vaccination has been achieved for a little over 61% after they were included in the drive from February 13. In the 18-44 years group, 1.5lakh have got the vaccine since May 1. This third phase is moving at a snail’s pace due to vaccine shortage. Mumbai, for instance, is merely vaccinating 1,000-1,200 daily in the five public and two private centres. Principal health secretary Dr Pradeep Vyas said not only was Maharashtra leading with the highest doses administered, and also had a wastage rate of less than 1%. Dr Dilip Patil, the state’s immunisation officer, said it was important that at least 29% of the 3.9crore 45-plus people have received at least one dose. That age group remains the most vulnerable, accounting for over 70% of Covid deaths. A closer look reveals deep disparity between districts, both in the rate of vaccination and coverage. For instance, Kolhapur is at the top having administered at least one shot to 60% of the population above 45 years, while Hingoli is at the bottom with merely 11% having got one dose. The coverage in at least 23 districts is less than the state average. As many as 11 districts, including health minister Rajesh Tope’s home district Jalna, have achieved less than 20% coverage. In absolute numbers, Mumbai has vaccinated the highest (25.9lakh) followed by Pune (23.7lakh) and Thane (13.4lakh). In the Mumbai Metropolitan Region, Palghar district is among the slow performers with a first dose coverage of 14%. A local senior official said just when awareness was being created, the district began to face a shortage of vaccine. A health official from Chandrapur, where coverage has been around 25%, blamed the erratic supply and even questioned the distribution formula. “We often don’t get the quantities we need. Yet, our neighbouring districts are allocated more stocks. Gadchiroli and Bhandara have stocks for 15 and 32 days, respectively, while we have nothing,” the official said. Immunisation in-charge Patil said the state has devised a distribution policy to help underperforming districts. “We have given additional doses to at least nine districts to boost their drives. These districts include Hingoli, Jalna, Yavatmal, Washim and Beed, among others,” he said. Earlier, districts were allocated doses solely based on their coverage and active cases.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/maharashtra-no-1-by-fully-vaccinating-28-7l-but-coverage-only-3-2/articleshow/82444275.cms||Sumitra Debroy
