---||Chennai||Maratha quota judgment puts focus on Tamil Nadu’s laws||By Justice K ChandruThe Supreme Court decision annulling the Maharashtra law for fixing exclusive quota to the Maratha community has once again reopened the debate on crucial issues relating to reservation, such as the ceiling on reservation and the exclusive power of the Centre to include communities in the list of backward classes. The decision has not only refused to accept exclusive caste-based quota for reservation and also emphasise the need to have an overall ceiling of 50% of all types of reservation as mandated by its earlier judgment on the Mandal commission. The decision on Maratha quota has also turned its light on reservations in states like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka as these two states have reservation percentage of above 50% cap fixed by the Supreme Court in Indra Sawhney’s case (1992). The challenge to the increased percentage of reservation in Tamil Nadu is pending before the Supreme Court. Tamil Nadu has been the torchbearer in the matter of reservation. Before Independence, the Madras government had introduced communal reservation based on castes and communities, wherein seats will be reserved for brahmins, nonbrahmins, Christians, Muslims and scheduled castes. The introduction of the Constitution of India (1950) and particularly the equality clause under Article 14 and nondiscrimination based on religion and caste under Article 15(1) and 16(1) posed a challenge to the archaic law that was in existence for three decades. The Madras high court and the Supreme Court struck down the communal order as unconstitutional (Champakam Dorairajan, 1950). This led to an agitation which made the Centre bring the first constitutional amendment introducing an enabling provision in Article 15, wherein the power to make special provision for advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes (SEBC) of citizens as well as scheduled castes and scheduled tribes was introduced. But various states prepared a list of SEBCs and also included different castes into the list of OBCs, many with vote banks in mind. When the Mandal commission was implemented by the V P Singh government and for the first time a reservation for OBCs in central services was facilitated that the order was put to judicial review. A larger bench of nine judges in Indra Sawhney’s case (1992) upheld the introduction of reservation for OBCs, but nevertheless put a cap of total reservation at 50%. Knowing that some advanced communities within the backward class may corner the benefit of reservation, it also introduced the concept of "creamy layer", by which the affluent among the OBCs should be denied the benefit of reservation. The indiscriminate inclusion of any communities into the SEBC list also had another problem — several communities which are most backward within the list of SEBCs were seeking for internal reservation, so that a few communities which are politically dominant were able to corner all the benefits of reservation. Therefore, TN while fixing the reservation for backward communities at 50% created a niche for Most Backward Communities (MBCs) with a separate reservation 20%. This resulted in a total reservation 69%. But the Mandal judgment was a red herring and to get over the same, it was decided to bring in a special legislation and also get it included in the IXth Schedule of the Constitution to ward off any challenge based on fundamental rights. Thus the 1994 Act providing for 69% reservation in public employment and educational institutions was passed. The law was challenged before the Supreme Court and it has been pending for 27 years. Increased lobbying and succumbing to vote bank politics, the state also started introducing internal reservation within the BC and MBC reservations. The beneficiary in TN were the backward Muslims who work 3.5% within the 30% BC reservation. Within the scheduled castes, Arunthathiyinar were given 3.5% internal reservation within the 18%. This is also a subject matter of challenge and is pending consideration by the courts since the past two decades. In 2004, the Supreme Court in a matter relating to provision for internal reservation for scheduled castes held that it is not open to the state to make internal reservation among the scheduled castes. If they found that any community within the reserved list corners all the benefits due to their historical dominance, then the only way is to exclude them from the list of scheduled castes by a constitutional amendment to the President’s list (Chinnaiah, 2004). This decision has once again opened the decisions of various states. Ahead of the recent state assembly election, the AIADMK government had introduced an internal reservation of 10.5% for the vanniyar community (which is largely represented by the PMK and 7% for the thevar community and the balance of 2.5% to be shared by as many as 49 communities. This law is yet to be implemented. It is also stated that the population census will be taken to identify the strength of each caste and the percentage in this new law will be altered accordingly. If any such decision has to be made in terms of law, it not only requires a constitutional amendment, but also will have a different perspective on the issue of reservation. Adding to the confusion, the BJP government had brought in the exclusive quota of 10% for the economically weaker sections by amending the Constitution with its 102nd amendment (2018). This had increased the total number of percentages of vertical reservation in each state. In TN it has increased the vertical reservation to 79%. With small reservations for several categories, the total reservation stands at 80%. This will only mock the equality clause provided under Article 14 and also will be in utter breach of Indra Sawhney’s case. Against this backdrop and with elections in mind, the quota for the Maratha community was introduced. The Supreme Court judgment indicates the 50% cap cannot be violated under any circumstances and by virtue of Article 342A, the states cannot make any inclusion/exclusion from the list of OBCs and it shall be the exclusive responsibility of the Centre. The decision may be opposed by the states on the ground of erosion of federal principles and may pressure the Centre to remove the cap. However, the Supreme Court should immediately undertake judicial review of all the cases relating to reservation cases pending before it and finally decide the issue of fixing a cap on reservation, the legality of the reservation for economically weaker sections, the legality of internal reservation within the list of SEBCs/ SCs and also the power of preparing a list of OBCs. Otherwise decisions by smaller benches may tend to be ignored and at times by the law’s delay the settled principles may be violated by different states. (The writer is a retired judge of the Madras high court)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/maratha-quota-judgment-puts-focus-on-tns-laws/articleshow/82442204.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Mumbai:Rs 900cr MLA hostel redevpt proposal ‘to raise eyebrows’||Mumbai: The state public works department has invited pre-qualification bids for redevelopment of MLA hostel Manora at Nariman Point at an estimated cost of Rs 900 crore. The redevelopment is likely to raise eyebrows at a time when the state is facing a financial crunch and all its resources are geared towards tackling the pandemic, according to political sources. PWD sources told TOI the cost is expected to escalate further. The electrical work alone is estimated to cost Rs 250 crore. Earlier, the government had signed a memorandum of understanding with the National Building Construction Corporation to build the towers. Due to the delay, though, it has now issued a new tender, said officials. On Thursday, BJP MLA Atul Bhatkalkar tweeted: “Rs 900 crore tender has been issued by the Thackeray government for the MLA hostel. This seems to have slipped the eyes of those advising the Prime Minister to focus on vaccination rather than the construction of the Parliament Complex. Tell the chief minister to focus on the corona pandemic. He will get his percentage there as well.” The BJP has been targeting the Maha Vikas Aghadi government ever since former Mumbai police commissioner Parambir Singh, in a letter to the chief minister, had alleged the former home minister Anil Deshmukh had ordered assistant police inspector Sachin Waze to collect Rs 100 crore from bars and restaurants every month. The MLA hostel comprising two towers is expected to be completed in three years. It will comprise one 42-storey tower and another 28-storey tower. The total number of flats to be constructed are 675. Each flat will be spread over 1,000 square feet, of which 600 sq ft will be for the use of the elected representative while 400 sq ft will be for party workers who come to Mumbai for various works, said officials. Other facilities include gymnasiums on the terrace, meeting and conference halls, waiting halls for MLA visitors, a canteen, a grocery, a salon, shops, a dispensary and a theatre. The old Manora towers have been demolished and for the past 18 months the government has been paying Rs 1 lakh to each MLA per month so that they can find alternate accommodation in the same vicinity. This money is paid only to MLAs outside Mumbai and Thane districts.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbairs-900cr-mla-hostel-redevpt-proposal-to-raise-eyebrows/articleshow/82442223.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Rs 7,400 crore investment proposals in April||GANDHINAGAR: Although the second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic wreaked havoc with the lives of thousands of citizens, there is good news on the economic front for the state government. The Gujarat government cleared investment proposals worth over Rs 7,400 crore in April, and allocated a sizable 642 acres of land to industries to set up their units. In all, 75 investment proposals have been cleared and the government claims the investments will generate employment of over 19,000 in 12 to 18 months. Manoj Das, additional chief secretary (ACS) in chief minister’s office (CMO) and in-charge ACS industry & mines department said that despite the major impact of Covid-19 in April, the industries sector has shown encouraging progress. “The Gujarat government has allotted land to leading companies in GIDC estates of Dahej and Halol. More than 75 companies have been allotted land with a total area of 642 acres. Some of the prominent companies in these estates include Jindal Specialty Chemicals, Merino Industries, Avgol Nonwovens, Troikaa Pharmaceuticals, Coromandel International, DCM Shriram, Bharat Rasayan, Aarti Specialty Chemicals, Transpek Silox,Sumitomo Chemical among others,” the official said. “These projects have committed investments of over Rs 6,900 crore which will provide employment opportunity to over 19,000 people directly and indirectly. Besides, the state government has also approved the project by a renowned company to set up a plant for manufacturing ‘High Grade Steel Bars’ in Kutch with a total proposed investment of Rs 500 crore, providing employment to 1,000 people in the region,” Das said. The official said that 42 projects are such, where the investment by each company is in the range of Rs 10 crore to Rs 50 crore. The pledged investment by these companies is Rs 945 crore. An investment of Rs 4,366 crore has been pledged by industries who will invest more than Rs 50 crore.“As many as 11 projects have pledged an investment of over Rs 100 crore. Land has already been allocated at Dahej, Halol and Saykha (Bharuch) estates and production is expected to begin in 12 to 18 months,” Das said. “Before the end of the current month, a formal MOU (memorandum of understanding) is expected to be signed for two more projects worth around Rs 9,000 crore. The government has also directed all the district collectors to conduct monthly review meetings to resolve all kinds of issues of investors,” the official added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/rs-7-4k-cr-investment-proposals-in-april/articleshow/82442243.cms||Kapil Dave
---||Trichy||Students can send answers via email||Trichy: Bharathidasan University has asked students to submit a soft copy of their answer scripts through email if they are unable to submit them in-person at their respective colleges during the ongoing online semester examination. A few days back, BDU controller of examination S Srinivasaragavan had said teachers can collect the answer scripts at any location instead of asking students to come to college. However, on Wednesday he instructed colleges to collect the soft copies through email to prevent students from venturing out of home to submit answer scripts. He said the respective colleges can create separate email ids for different programmes and years to receive the answer scripts. He added that the evaluation, which used to be centralised before the Covid-19 outbreak, has been decentralised as colleges have been asked to carry out the evaluation to ensure results are published at the earliest. It is the responsibility of the colleges and the principals to ensure that students complete the exam on time and submit the answer scripts in-person or through email. Close to 1.2 lakh students from 130 affiliated college are appearing for the online semester examination.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/trichy/students-can-send-answers-via-email/articleshow/82447828.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क
---||Trichy||‘Don’t force teachers to come to college’||Trichy: Regional joint director of collegiate education (RJDCE), Trichy, has instructed all the private colleges of education and arts and science colleges to not force teachers to come to college. The directive has come in the wake of complaints from a few colleges where teachers were asked to come to college if they want a full salary.A Mekala, RJDCE, Trichy, said that she has been receiving complaints on erring colleges and has asked them to follow the directions issued by the state government. “There is no point in risking the lives of teachers when the Covid-19 spread is high,” said Mekala adding that she will take necessary steps against erring colleges after conducting an enquiry. The Tamil Nadu Teachers Education University asked colleges in March to switch over to online classes. Further, the state government also asked teachers in schools and colleges to work from home by the end of last month. However, a teacher from Jenney’s College of Education in Trichy said that relatives of some of the staff were tested positive for Covid-19, but they are coming to the college in the fear of losing salary. When asked, S Rama Prabha, principal of Jenney’s College of Education, Trichy, refused to comment on it. tnn||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/trichy/dont-force-teachers-to-come-to-college/articleshow/82447830.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क
---||Bareilly||Graveyards in UP running low on space, some facing shortage of diggers||MEERUT/AGRA/BAREILLY: Negotiating a maze of marked and unmarked graves, a group of mourners approached Babar Alam with a body. He hurriedly led them towards the extreme north of the graveyard, off the beaten path, where a row of freshly dug graves were waiting. Alam asked them to choose anyone of them, and they did. A little while later, as the body was being lowered and one of the mourners was sobbing helplessly, an earthmover was busy digging more pits, nearby. As secretary of Agra’s Panchkuian Kabristan, Alam says that he has never seen such a rush of bodies. It had prompted him to ask for an earthmover from the civic body. “The number of bodies has significantly increased in the last three weeks. On an average, we used to get six bodies earlier. Now the number has increased to 20. We are digging graves in advance with an excavator provided by the municipal corporation to avoid inconvenience to the relatives of the deceased,” Alam said. He said that there are around 20 graveyards in the district. “The number of bodies reaching for burial has increased everywhere,” says Alam, who believes that the month of Ramzan saved many lives. “Most people are fasting, staying at home and praying. Had it not been the holy month, many more would have died,” he said. The situation at Agra’s another prominent graveyard is no different. Caretaker of the city's Noorjahan Karbala kabristaan, Chaudhary Aleemuddin says, “The number of bodies reaching for burial have doubled.” And about 250 km away in Meerut, caretakers of graveyards were grappling with somewhat similar situations. And they didn’t have an earthmover to help them. At the city’s largest graveyard, Mohammad Alam was busy digging graves with his team of workers. “Earlier we used to dig six to seven graves a day. Now the number has increased five times. Our problem has compounded because we have to dig six feet now due to protocol. We cannot bury a Covid-19 infected body in a four feet grave,” says Alam, the caretaker of Meerut’s Bale Miya kabristaan. The graveyard’s in-charge, Mufti Mohd Ashraf, had his share of concerns. “So many of our workers have fallen sick, but bodies are continuously coming. We will soon run out of space. We desperately need mitti (soil) which should be at least 3-foot-high to accommodate the new arrivals,” Ashraf said. At another burial ground in Meerut’s Mohanpuri area, popular as Shah Vilayat graveyard, secretary Mohammad Rashid claimed that at least 50 to 60 people are dying daily. “We cater to the Lal Kurti area and don’t get many bodies here. But, according to my estimate, the daily deaths -- among Muslims-- is nothing less than 50-60 in the entire city. But these are highly conservative estimates. Number could be higher as well.” Last week, an MLA in Meerut released Rs 25lakh to purchase extra soil for the graveyards. Meerut city MLA Rafiq Ansari had said, “The situation is really bad. There is no oxygen, no hospital beds. People are dying and graveyards are running out of space. Our religion does not allow us to burn the bodies, and they cannot be left on roads too.” But space is not the only problem at the graveyards. Like cremation, the cost of burial has gone up too. “For burials, we need three things, kafan (a sheet of white cloth), wooden planks and gravediggers. Earlier, a cloth would cost Rs 1,100 while wooden planks came at Rs 1,200. The labourers charged about Rs 700. Now, the traders do not give the cloth anything less than Rs 2,000. The wooden planks are also in high demand as they are needed in cremation too. So the cost has gone up considerably,” says Mufti Ashraf. Muzaffarnagar’s Gore Ghariba Kabristan was also getting at least 11 bodies daily, mostly of Covid-19 patients. While in Bareilly, the graveyards were facing the shortage of workers. In Prayagraj, several graveyards had hired earthmovers to cope with the work.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/bareilly/graveyards-in-up-running-low-on-space-some-facing-shortage-of-diggers/articleshow/82452069.cms||Sandeep Rai
---||Dehradun||Police arrest two men for black-marketing of oxygen flowmeters||Dehradun: Two men were held from the Patel Nagar area of Dehradun on Thursday for allegedly hoarding oxygen cylinder flowmeters and selling them at inflated prices. Police recovered six flowmeters, equipment used to regulate the flow of oxygen from the cylinder, from their possession. The accused have been identified as Prince Kamboj, 35, resident of Saharanpur district of Uttar Pradesh, and Shivam Kumar, 23, resident of Tyagi Road in Dehradun. They were selling the flowmeters, which cost around Rs 1000, at 15 times the price. On May 5, the police team received inputs that two persons are indulging in black-marketing of oxygen flowmeters and the informer also shared the mobile number to contact the accused persons. "Posing as a relative of a Covid patient, one of the members of the police team called on the number and spoke to Prince Kamboj. He quoted Rs 15,000 as the price of the flowmeter. After negotiations, he agreed to sell it at Rs 12,500," said sub-inspector Vivek Bhandari. The accused have been booked under sections 420 (cheating), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and 270 (whoever malignantly does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/dehradun/police-arrest-two-men-for-black-marketing-of-oxygen-flowmeters/articleshow/82440889.cms||Gaurav Talwar
---||Chennai||Tamil Nadu: CM M K Stalin’s 33-minister DMK cabinet is a mix of old & new||CHENNAI: DMK president M K Stalin will take oath as chief minister on Friday morning at a low-key affair on the lawns of the Raj Bhavan in Guindy. A total of 33 ministers will form part of his cabinet. First-time MLA and Stalin’s son Udhayanidhi does not figure on the list. While Duraimurugan is among 18 former ministers to be inducted into the cabinet, Palanivel Thiagarajan, son of late party heavyweight P T R Palanivel Rajan and a former investment banker with Lehman Brothers, has been allocated finance portfolio. Former Chennai Mayor Ma Subramanian is among the 15 who would be first-time ministers. Governor Banwarilal Purohit approved the recommendations of Stalin on appointing the ministers and allocating the portfolios. “M K Stalin, the chief minister-designate has sent a list of persons to be appointed as ministers of the state of Tamil Nadu along with their portfolios on Thursday,” a Raj Bhavan release said. On Wednesday, Stalin staked claim to form the government after being unanimously elected as legislature party leader by 133 MLAs, including eight MLAs who were elected on DMK’s rising sun symbol. Stalin said that he was proud to have risen through the ranks with hardwork as an asset to the decorated seat of former chief ministers CN Annadurai and M Karunanidhi. “May 7 will be etched in golden letters in the history of Tamil Nadu politics. The DMK is going to assume charge for the sixth time. The DMK’s return to power realization of the dream of Kalaignar brings happiness, but there is sadness too,” Stalin said, reminding the low-key swearing in ceremony due to Covid pandemic. Pointing to his inability to take charge in front of cadres who strove hard for the party’s victory, Stalin appealed to partymen to view the ceremony on television from home.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/cm-stalins-33-minister-dmk-cabinet-is-a-mix-of-old-new/articleshow/82444225.cms||---
---||Meerut||RLD chief Ajit Singh dies of Covid-19 at 82||MEERUT: Rashtriya Lok Dal chief and former Union minister Ajit Singh, 82, passed away at a private hospital in Gurgaon on Thursday morning, his son Jayant Chaudhary confirmed. Son of former prime minister Chaudhary Charan Singh, Ajit Singh had contracted Covid-19 last month. “Chaudhary Ajit Singh Ji was diagnosed Covid positive on April 20. He battled his condition till the very end and breathed his last today morning, the 6th of May, 2021,” Jayant tweeted. Senior party members claimed the cremation, due to the raging pandemic, was a low-key affair with only close family members in attendance. “As the nation confronts the horrific pandemic, it is our humble request to all those who wish to pay their respects, to please stay at home as far as possible. We must observe all safety protocols to keep ourselves and everyone around us healthy and safe. This would be the best way to honour Chaudhary Sahib as well as those Covid warriors who are working night and day to protect us,” Jayant said in a tweet. Born in Meerut, Singh began his political career as a Rajya Sabha MP in 1986. An IIT alumnus, he pursued his post-graduation from the Illinois Institute in Chicago and then joined IBM. He spent 16 years in the US before he reluctantly came back to India in the 80s and formally joined politics. Ajit Singh was inducted as Union minister of industry in the VP Singh government in 1989 and also served as food minister in the P V Narasimha Rao government. Seven-time member of the Lok Sabha, Singh formed Rashtriya Lok Dal and joined the Atal Bihari Vajpayee government as the agriculture minister in 2001. Known to his critics as a fair weather man, Singh switched sides on multiple occasions to stay with the party in power. He also served as civil aviation minister in Manmohan Singh’s cabinet in 2011. A stalwart from the sugarcane belt, Ajit Singh represented the family borough Baghpat with his party's stronghold spread across several districts in western Uttar Pradesh. Towards the fag end, he tasted successive defeats – first in the 2014 Lok Sabha elections and later in the 2019 LS polls in Muzaffarnagar where he lost by a thin margin to BJP’s Sanjiv Balyan. Senior leaders across party lines condoled Singh’s demise. “Extremely sad at the demise of former Union minister Chaudhary Ajit Singh Ji. He was always devoted to the interests of the farmers. He efficiently discharged the responsibilities of several departments at the Centre. My condolences to his family and supporters in this hour of mourning. Om Shanti!" Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in a tweet. “Saddened by the demise of Rashtriya Lok Dal chief and former Union minister Chaudhary Ajit Singh. He always raised his voice in the interest of farmers. As a public representative and a minister, he left a different mark on the politics of the country. My condolences to his family and well-wishers,” President Ram Nath Kovind tweeted in Hindi. “The news of the untimely demise of Rashtriya Lok Dal chief Ajit Singh is sad. My condolences to his family and loved ones,” Rahul Gandhi said. Congress general secretary in-charge Uttar Pradesh Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, said, “Got the sad news of the demise of popular leader, former Union minister and farmer-friendly leader Chaudhary Ajit Singh Ji. Chaudhary Sahab’s demise is an irreparable loss for society and politics.” She offered her deepest condolences to Ajit Singh’s son, Jayant Chaudhary. Defence minister Rajnath Singh said, “The news of Chaudhary Ajit Singh’s demise is very painful. In his long public life, he was always connected with the public and the land. At the same time, he also struggled for the interests of farmers, labourers and other weaker sections. My condolences to his family and supporters.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/meerut/rld-chief-ajit-singh-dies-of-covid-19-at-82/articleshow/82440853.cms||---
---||Agra||Graveyards in UP running low on space, some facing shortage of diggers||MEERUT/AGRA/BAREILLY: Negotiating a maze of marked and unmarked graves, a group of mourners approached Babar Alam with a body. He hurriedly led them towards the extreme north of the graveyard, off the beaten path, where a row of freshly dug graves were waiting. Alam asked them to choose anyone of them, and they did. A little while later, as the body was being lowered and one of the mourners was sobbing helplessly, an earthmover was busy digging more pits, nearby. As secretary of Agra’s Panchkuian Kabristan, Alam says that he has never seen such a rush of bodies. It had prompted him to ask for an earthmover from the civic body. “The number of bodies has significantly increased in the last three weeks. On an average, we used to get six bodies earlier. Now the number has increased to 20. We are digging graves in advance with an excavator provided by the municipal corporation to avoid inconvenience to the relatives of the deceased,” Alam said. He said that there are around 20 graveyards in the district. “The number of bodies reaching for burial has increased everywhere,” says Alam, who believes that the month of Ramzan saved many lives. “Most people are fasting, staying at home and praying. Had it not been the holy month, many more would have died,” he said. The situation at Agra’s another prominent graveyard is no different. Caretaker of the city's Noorjahan Karbala kabristaan, Chaudhary Aleemuddin says, “The number of bodies reaching for burial have doubled.” And about 250 km away in Meerut, caretakers of graveyards were grappling with somewhat similar situations. And they didn’t have an earthmover to help them. At the city’s largest graveyard, Mohammad Alam was busy digging graves with his team of workers. “Earlier we used to dig six to seven graves a day. Now the number has increased five times. Our problem has compounded because we have to dig six feet now due to protocol. We cannot bury a Covid-19 infected body in a four feet grave,” says Alam, the caretaker of Meerut’s Bale Miya kabristaan. The graveyard’s in-charge, Mufti Mohd Ashraf, had his share of concerns. “So many of our workers have fallen sick, but bodies are continuously coming. We will soon run out of space. We desperately need mitti (soil) which should be at least 3-foot-high to accommodate the new arrivals,” Ashraf said. At another burial ground in Meerut’s Mohanpuri area, popular as Shah Vilayat graveyard, secretary Mohammad Rashid claimed that at least 50 to 60 people are dying daily. “We cater to the Lal Kurti area and don’t get many bodies here. But, according to my estimate, the daily deaths -- among Muslims-- is nothing less than 50-60 in the entire city. But these are highly conservative estimates. Number could be higher as well.” Last week, an MLA in Meerut released Rs 25lakh to purchase extra soil for the graveyards. Meerut city MLA Rafiq Ansari had said, “The situation is really bad. There is no oxygen, no hospital beds. People are dying and graveyards are running out of space. Our religion does not allow us to burn the bodies, and they cannot be left on roads too.” But space is not the only problem at the graveyards. Like cremation, the cost of burial has gone up too. “For burials, we need three things, kafan (a sheet of white cloth), wooden planks and gravediggers. Earlier, a cloth would cost Rs 1,100 while wooden planks came at Rs 1,200. The labourers charged about Rs 700. Now, the traders do not give the cloth anything less than Rs 2,000. The wooden planks are also in high demand as they are needed in cremation too. So the cost has gone up considerably,” says Mufti Ashraf. Muzaffarnagar’s Gore Ghariba Kabristan was also getting at least 11 bodies daily, mostly of Covid-19 patients. While in Bareilly, the graveyards were facing the shortage of workers. In Prayagraj, several graveyards had hired earthmovers to cope with the work.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/agra/graveyards-in-up-running-low-on-space-some-facing-shortage-of-diggers/articleshow/82452068.cms||Sandeep Rai
---||Meerut||Graveyards in UP running low on space, some facing shortage of diggers||MEERUT/AGRA/BAREILLY: Negotiating a maze of marked and unmarked graves, a group of mourners approached Babar Alam with a body. He hurriedly led them towards the extreme north of the graveyard, off the beaten path, where a row of freshly dug graves were waiting. Alam asked them to choose anyone of them, and they did. A little while later, as the body was being lowered and one of the mourners was sobbing helplessly, an earthmover was busy digging more pits, nearby. As secretary of Agra’s Panchkuian Kabristan, Alam says that he has never seen such a rush of bodies. It had prompted him to ask for an earthmover from the civic body. “The number of bodies has significantly increased in the last three weeks. On an average, we used to get six bodies earlier. Now the number has increased to 20. We are digging graves in advance with an excavator provided by the municipal corporation to avoid inconvenience to the relatives of the deceased,” Alam said. He said that there are around 20 graveyards in the district. “The number of bodies reaching for burial has increased everywhere,” says Alam, who believes that the month of Ramzan saved many lives. “Most people are fasting, staying at home and praying. Had it not been the holy month, many more would have died,” he said. The situation at Agra’s another prominent graveyard is no different. Caretaker of the city's Noorjahan Karbala kabristaan, Chaudhary Aleemuddin says, “The number of bodies reaching for burial have doubled.” And about 250 km away in Meerut, caretakers of graveyards were grappling with somewhat similar situations. And they didn’t have an earthmover to help them. At the city’s largest graveyard, Mohammad Alam was busy digging graves with his team of workers. “Earlier we used to dig six to seven graves a day. Now the number has increased five times. Our problem has compounded because we have to dig six feet now due to protocol. We cannot bury a Covid-19 infected body in a four feet grave,” says Alam, the caretaker of Meerut’s Bale Miya kabristaan. The graveyard’s in-charge, Mufti Mohd Ashraf, had his share of concerns. “So many of our workers have fallen sick, but bodies are continuously coming. We will soon run out of space. We desperately need mitti (soil) which should be at least 3-foot-high to accommodate the new arrivals,” Ashraf said. At another burial ground in Meerut’s Mohanpuri area, popular as Shah Vilayat graveyard, secretary Mohammad Rashid claimed that at least 50 to 60 people are dying daily. “We cater to the Lal Kurti area and don’t get many bodies here. But, according to my estimate, the daily deaths -- among Muslims-- is nothing less than 50-60 in the entire city. But these are highly conservative estimates. Number could be higher as well.” Last week, an MLA in Meerut released Rs 25lakh to purchase extra soil for the graveyards. Meerut city MLA Rafiq Ansari had said, “The situation is really bad. There is no oxygen, no hospital beds. People are dying and graveyards are running out of space. Our religion does not allow us to burn the bodies, and they cannot be left on roads too.” But space is not the only problem at the graveyards. Like cremation, the cost of burial has gone up too. “For burials, we need three things, kafan (a sheet of white cloth), wooden planks and gravediggers. Earlier, a cloth would cost Rs 1,100 while wooden planks came at Rs 1,200. The labourers charged about Rs 700. Now, the traders do not give the cloth anything less than Rs 2,000. The wooden planks are also in high demand as they are needed in cremation too. So the cost has gone up considerably,” says Mufti Ashraf. Muzaffarnagar’s Gore Ghariba Kabristan was also getting at least 11 bodies daily, mostly of Covid-19 patients. While in Bareilly, the graveyards were facing the shortage of workers. In Prayagraj, several graveyards had hired earthmovers to cope with the work.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/meerut/graveyards-in-up-running-low-on-space-some-facing-shortage-of-diggers/articleshow/82440869.cms||Sandeep Rai
---||Trichy||‘Last-minute’ rush, busy roads till noon in Trichy||Trichy: Commercial streets in Trichy city wore a deserted look on Thursday, the first day one of intensified restrictions to curtail public movement. However, last-minute purchases by residents saw crowding on the arterial roads. Trichy corporation officials and police personnel by around 12pm, used loudspeakers urging the shops to stop their sales.Grocery shops and vegetable shops commenced their businesses by around 6am. Similarly, tea stalls and meat stalls adhered to the restrictions by downing their shutters around 12pm. Traders said that owing to the limited hours of operation, they restricted the quantity of raw materials they usually procure when the shops were functioning till night. Tasmac shops which were opened from 8am witnessed a surge only in the closing hours. Social distancing was completely flouted in Thennur, Gandhi market and Bhima Nagar localities. A senior corporation official in Trichy said that the shops were told that a minimum penalty of Rs 5,000 will be levied if there are any deviations in the standard operating procedures. In Central bus stand, the footfall of passengers witnessed a fall by 10%. “Peak hours in the evening attracted the usual crowd but the day time saw only a few people boarding, far less than the 50% capacity allowed in buses,” a TNSTC official said. Trichy city police said that the movement of vehicles was high between 8am and 12pm. “Roads in the afternoon were deserted, only those who had genuine reasons stepped out. We are penalising the offenders,” a police officer near MGMGH said. tnn||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/trichy/last-minute-rush-busy-roads-till-noon-in-trichy/articleshow/82447832.cms||---
---||Trichy||Traders oppose plan to shift Gandhi market to G Corner||Trichy: Citing the surge in fresh Covid-19 infections in Trichy city, the district administration and Trichy Corporation have planned to temporarily shift the Gandhi market to G Corner ground on the Trichy-Chennai national highway. However, as traders have firmly opposed the relocation, the authorities are yet to take a final call on the proposal.“We have started preparing the G Corner ground to accommodate both retail and wholesale vegetable traders. Retail traders can use the helipad facility,” a source with the corporation said. Soon after information about shifting the market was shared with the traders on Thursday, a section of vendors resorted to a protest against the proposal. “We shall abide by the Covid-19 restriction measures by functioning within the Gandhi market, officials can penalise if we commit violations but we cannot move out. If forced, we may suspend the vegetable sales,” H Ramachandran, a retail vegetable vendor said. Following the backlash from the traders, corporation had softened its stand. “We convened a meeting to shift the Gandhi market but the traders wanted to do business only here. We will take a call on Friday,” corporation commissioner S Sivasubramanian said. tnn||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/trichy/traders-oppose-plan-to-shift-gandhi-market-to-g-corner/articleshow/82447833.cms||---
---||Nagpur||Tipeshwar tigress released in wild after treatment for snare injury||Nagpur: The four-year-old Tipeshwar tigress, which had suffered deep wire snare injury in her front leg, was successfully released into the wild after 12 days of treatment inside the wildlife sanctuary. The tigress was rescued by wildlife veterinarian Dr Chetan Patond on April 21 and released on May 2. T2-C1 was first sighted in injured condition inside the sanctuary by the patrolling staff on April 18. TOI had on April 21 reported tigress T2-C1, which was one of the offspring of the second litter of park’s dominating tigress T2, was seen limping by the patrolling staff on April 18. “A wire snare was observed in her leg. The snare was not of metal but a strong rope generally used for rappelling and climbing purposes,” said DFO Subhash Puranik. Puranik said, “The rope was so tightly stuck that had it not been removed the forelimb would have to be amputated. There is a wound and swelling on the leg and the tigress was unable to stand on four legs. It was released after the wound healed. Immediately after the tigress was released it approached a waterhole and relaxed.” This is the second incident in the last two years where a tiger was entangled in a wire snare and successfully released in the wild. In May 2019, a male tiger cub was rescued and its snare was removed. The 148 sq km Tipeshwar sanctuary, 180km from Nagpur, near Pandharkawda, has an old history of snares being laid by local poachers to kill herbivores like deer, wild boar, and chitals for bushmeat. Tigers come into contact with these snares leaving them injured. There are 14 villages bordering the sanctuary. This is the fourth recorded case from Tipeshwar where a tiger was entangled in wire snares.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/tipeshwar-tigress-released-in-wild-after-treatment-for-snare-injury/articleshow/82442251.cms||Vijay Pinjarkar
---||Hyderabad||Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao speaks to PM on vaccine and Remdesivir shortage, says no to lockdown||HYDERABAD: Following a severe shortage of vaccines, Remdesivir injections and oxygen for treating Covid-19 patients in the state, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi to immediately increase the allocations to Telangana. The CM also ruled out imposing lockdown in the state. The chief minister, who spoke to the PM over phone on Thursday evening, said the state had received only 50 lakh doses of vaccines and needs two lakh to 2.5 lakh vaccines every day. He said the state was getting only 4,900 Remdesivir vials a day, while the requirement is at least 25,000 vials a day and urged him to provide the injections immediately. He said only 440 MTs of oxygen was being supplied to the state, which should be increased to 500 MTs. He also brought to the notice of the PM that oxygen supplies allocated from Sriperumbudur in Tamil Nadu and Ballari in Karnataka were not transported to Telangana. “People from neighbouring states like Maharashtra, Karnataka, Chhattisgarh and AP are coming down to Hyderabad for coronavirus treatment and this is putting additional burden on Telangana’s resources,” KCR told the PM. Later, following the directions of the PM, Union minister Piyush Goyal spoke to KCR and assured that the Centre would take steps to supply vaccines and medicines to Telangana. Goyal said apart from Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, oxygen supplies from north-eastern states would be sent to Telangana. The CM, who held a review meeting with senior health officials, reiterated that the state government had no intention to impose lockdown in the state as it would not only destroy the livelihoods of people but also slow down the economy and hit the revenues badly. KCR said the lockdown will leave a severe impact on migrant workers, farming sector, industries and livelihood of the people. “Instead of imposing a lockdown, micro-level containment zones will be declared where the number of positive cases is more and preventive steps will be taken,” he said. The officials told the CM that of the 1.56 lakh positive cases in government and private hospitals, 1.30 lakh (85 per cent) had recovered from the infection. KCR directed the health officials to hold a press conference every day and inform the people about the Covid-19 situation in the state. Since there is a shortage of vaccines in the state, he instructed the health department to give priority to administer second doses. He also spoke with manufacturers of Remdesivir . Since the state government has decided to provide medicine kits to people testing positive for Covid-19 with mild symptoms, the CM said the kits should be provided at the doorsteps of the patients by Asha workers and ANMs. He said various reports have suggested that the second wave severity could come down after May 15. “People will have to wear masks, maintain social distancing and avoid social gatherings,” he said||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/cm-speaks-to-pm-on-vax-remdesivir-shortage/articleshow/82442274.cms||Koride Mahesh
---||Dehradun||Parents allege private schools charging extra fees for running online classes||DEHRADUN: Several parents have alleged that private schools are charging extra fees in the name of application services being provided to the students during their online classes. The parents told TOI that schools have been ordered by the state government to charge only the tuition fees, but they have found out ways of charging extra money by introducing apps in the online classes. They further said that the subscription charges of the apps are quite high, but don’t offer any special service, and the quality of online classes remains the same. “We have received several complaints, especially against mid-level private schools. We have even informed the state education department about it,” said Arif Khan, president of the parents’ body. Meanwhile, the district education department has said that an enquiry will be conducted soon, once the administrative offices reopen.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/dehradun/parents-allege-private-schools-charging-extra-fees-for-running-online-classes/articleshow/82440903.cms||Mohammad Anab
---||Chennai||To be a legislator, it is acumen not education that’s key||Much like the past, the state cabinet would be having ministers with a mix of educational backgrounds this time too. In the list of minister-designates are the names of doctorate holders P T R Palanivel Thiagarajan and K Ponmudy. Alongside are the names of P Moorthy and Anitha Radhakrishnan, both school dropouts, who are set to take charge as ministers for commercial taxes and fisheries.Not just the cabinet, the state assembly too would have a grand mix of legislators of varied educational backgrounds — from those who have just done their Class V to those with PhD suffixed to their names. As far as educational qualifications are concerned there seems to be very little difference between the two Dravidian parties. If the DMK has Ponmudy, the AIADMK has a doctorate MLA in Pollachi V Jayaraman. At the other end of the spectrum, the AIADMK has MLAs like former chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and former minister P Thangamani who took the political plunge with only a school education.According to the Association for Democratic Reforms (ADR) which analysed the educational qualifications of 224 MLAs, who won the recent election, seven had completed Class V, while 18 MLAs passed Class VIII.Politicians feel it is unfair to take into account educational qualification because the Constitution does not lay down any such criteria and what matters is dedication and the urge to serve people. They cite examples ranging from K Kamaraj to the more recent Edappadi K Palaniswami who was appreciated by the Centre for his handling of Covid.In 2016, there were even more MLAs with just schooling as their educational qualification when it analysed affidavits of 204 MLAs. "At least 89 (44%) MLAs have declared their educational qualifications to be between Class V pass and Class XII pass, while 110 (54%) MLAs have declared having an educational qualification of graduate or above," the 2016 report said.Of late there is a trend among political parties to look at educational qualification of candidates too, said ADR state coordinator Joseph Victor Raj. "But it does not seem to be a key criteria. Parties are unlikely to drop someone because of his or her education,’’ he said. It’s the candidates popularity in the constituency, money and muscle power and the "winnability" that are taken into consideration.Some time ago, the Rajasthan government set a minimum educational qualification for those contesting civic polls. But that was rolled back by the next government after the rule faced stiff opposition. "I have never felt that lack of a formal higher education as an impediment. In my political career I could serve people as efficiently and even better than many MLAs,’’ says P Karthikeyan, two-time MLA of Vellore who is a school dropout.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/to-be-a-legislator-it-is-acumen-not-education-thats-key/articleshow/82442250.cms||Mayilvaganan
---||Navi-mumbai||Covid-19: Total caseload in Maharashtra close to 5 million, Mumbai tally plateaus||MUMBAI: After a four-day respite, Maharashtra was back to adding over 60,000 cases on Thursday. If daily detections stay the course, total caseload in the state is likely to touch 50 lakh before the weekend. The state added 62,194 cases and 853 deaths on Thursday, taking the caseload to 49.42lakh. And with the addition of 853 deaths, total toll rose to 73,515. Covid tally and related deaths from Mumbai appear to have stabilised though. BMC’s update said 3,028 cases and 69 deaths were registered in the last 24-hour period. Since March 2020, the city's tally has climbed to 6.68 lakh cases and toll to 13,580 deaths. “Covid situation in the city is improving. Our daily test positivity rate is dropping,'' said additional municipal commissioner Suresh Kakani. The update said 30,942 tests were carried out on Wednesday as against 35,377 on Tuesday. “Due to the restrictions, people are not stepping out. There are no crowds that can be tested at malls, eateries, public places as we used to do previously,” said Kakani. The focus now is on preparations for the third wave. “We are in the process of procuring ventilators for public hospitals,” added Kakani. At the state level, some districts–Nandurbar, Hingoli, Sindhudurg and Nanded–had a high death rate of between 2.3-2.9%, far higher than the state's average of 0.9%. “The high deaths are still a concern. Many smaller cities are reporting deaths within 24-48 hours of the patient getting admitted. Many patients are still clearly coming late to the hospitals,” said an official. Meanwhile, daily caseload and toll are stabilising across the Mumbai administrative circle comprising several civic corporations. On Thursday, 8,525 cases were registered in the region, almost half the tally (15,623) on April 19; deaths have increased from 103 on April 19 to 124 on Thursday. Dharavi in Mumbai reported 13 cases on Thursday, one of the lowest figures reported since the second wave started. On April 8, Dharavi had 99 cases on a single day which was the highest. The total cases reported from Dharavi so far have been 6,574 off which 900 are active cases. Both Nashik and Pune administrative blocks, however, show an increasing trend. On Thursday, Nashik circle registered 13,982 cases and 124 deaths, up from 8,230 cases and 103 fatalities on April 19. In Pune circle too, tally and toll on April 19 stood at 11,673 and 27 respectively and increased to 14,453 and 154 on Thursday. Five districts in the state—Pune, Nagpur, Mumbai, Nashik and Thane—contribute to 50% of total cases in the state. On a positive note, discharges in the state and the city were higher than daily detections. A total of 63,842 people were sent home on Thursday taking total discharges to 42.2 lakh.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/navi-mumbai/total-caseload-in-maharashtra-close-to-5-million-mum-tally-plateaus/articleshow/82447885.cms||Bhavika Jain

---||Vadodara||Woman thwarts mobile snatcher’s attempts, catches him||Vadodara: A 28-year-old woman and her friend caught hold of a man who tried to snatch her mobile phone on New VIP Road on Wednesday night and handed him over to the cops. The police are now trying to establish his identity. According to the police, Monika Singh was out for a walk near her house when the accused approached her on a motorbike and tried to snatch her mobile phone. When she resisted, he punched her and fled. However, the woman called her friend for help as he was hanging out nearby and both followed the accused in their car for some distance. “He lost control of his motorbike and fell down following which Singh and her friend caught hold of him,” the police said. During questioning the accused admitted that he tried snatching gold chain of another woman in the same area on Wednesday evening.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vadodara/woman-thwarts-mobile-snatchers-attempts-catches-him/articleshow/82440972.cms||---

---||Dehradun||Badrinath as ‘Smart Spiritual Town’: Centre, state ink Rs 100 crore MoU||DEHRADUN: The Centre and state have inked a Rs 100 crore MoU for developing Badrinath dham as 'Smart Spiritual Town'. The MoU was signed in the presence of chief minister Tirath Singh Rawat on Thursday by the PSUs of Petroleum and Natural Gas and Shri Kedarnath Utthan Charitable Trust. Keeping in mind the needs and requirements for the next 100 years, the development plan would be executed in a phased manner on a total of 85 hectare land. The MoU was signed by secretary Tannu Kapoor on behalf of ministry of petroleum and Uttarakhand tourism secretary Dilip Jawalkar. Union petroleum minister Dharmendra Pradhan was also present. CM Rawat said that the “reconstruction work at Kedarnath after the 2013 natural calamity under the guidance of Prime Minister Narendra Modi are in the final stages". “The PM has decided on a large scale development work at Badrinath dham. Taking into consideration the needs and requirements for the next 100 years, the Badrinath dham area of 85 hectares would be developed in a phase-wise manner.” The CM added that special efforts were being made to provide the best possible facilities to the pilgrims coming to Badrinath dham. The government would simultaneously start the redevelopment of Vyas Cave, Ganesh Cave and Charan Paduka. Rawat said that the contribution of oil companies in the development of Badrinath dham is "commendable" and the state's focus is on promoting homestays for pilgrims. He added the government is committed for development of Badrinath dham in the next three years. Union minister Pradhan said that the four dhams of Uttarakhand have special significance. He added that like Badrinath and Kedarnath shrines, some works will be planned for Gangotri and Yamunotri shrines in Uttarkashi in the future. In addition to embankment works of Alaknanda River, the plan is to beautify and reconstruct the entire area. The elaborate plan includes construction of plazas, toilets, draining and sewage system and setting up of lights and CCTV cameras. Bridges, too, would be constructed for better connectivity. State tourism minister Satpal Maharaj said that Badrinath dham has religious and economic significance. “Thousands of people get employment here. During the reconstruction work, we have to take care that the environment is not harmed. In the first phase, the expansion of the hospital is also proposed. Apart from this, riverfront development, strengthening of embankments, land narrowing, holding areas in case of congestion, retrofitting of bridges are to be done,” the minister added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/dehradun/badrinath-as-smart-spiritual-town-centre-state-ink-rs-100-crore-mou/articleshow/82440928.cms||Kautilya Singh
---||Goa||Bicholim locals demand repair of KTC bus stand road||Bicholim: The condition of the internal road of the Kadamba Transport Corporation’s (KTC) bus stand in Bicholim, is in a dilapidated state. The locals have therefore demanded with the authorities to undertake repairs before the onset of monsoon. “If asphalt is not laid in this place before the rains arrive, its condition will get worse,” a local said. Bicholim MLA and speaker of the legislative assembly Rajesh Patnekar said that the proposal for repairing the road has been approved but it is being delayed due to the pandemic. “We are following up on the work of the KTC bus stand and we hope that it will start by June,” Patnekar said. The chairperson of Bicholim Municipal Council Kundan Falari has also demanded that the repairs be taken up before the rains.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/bicholim-locals-demand-repair-of-ktc-bus-stand-road/articleshow/82444308.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Mumbai: 26-yr-old Taloja jail undertrial dies of Covid||Navi Mumbai: A 26-year-old undertrial of Taloja jail succumbed to Covid during treatment at Saint George hospital in Mumbai on Wednesday. The deceased was lodged at Taloja prison since 2018 after being arrested by the Bhiwandi police for allegedly raping a minor girl. He was booked under section 376 and Pocso Act, informed Taloja jail superintendent Kaustubh Kurlekar. “He was suffering from asthama and hypertension and on May 1, he fell sick. On May 2, he was sent to JJ hospital for treatment where they did his RT-PCR test and the report was Covid positive. He was shifted to Saint George hospital’s Covid ward, where he succumbed on Wednesday morning.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-26-yr-old-taloja-jail-undertrial-dies-of-covid/articleshow/82444318.cms||---
---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: Nirma Group’s Nuvoco Vistas files for Rs 5,000 crore IPO||AHMEDABAD: In what could mark billionaire Karsanbhai Patel-founded Nirma Group’s return to the domestic capital markets, the home-grown group’s cement arm Nuvoco Vistas Corporation Ltd has filed a draft red herring prospectus (DRHP) with the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) to raise Rs 5,000 crore through an initial public offering (IPO). Nirma Limited delisted its shares from the stock exchanges nine years ago. The initial public offer of Nuvoco Vistas will comprise of a fresh issue of equity shares aggregating up to Rs 1,500 crore and an offer for sale up to Rs 3,500 crore by its promoter selling shareholder Niyogi Enterprise Private Ltd, which holds 86.56% in the company, states the DRHP filed by Nuvoco Vistas. The company intends to utilize the proceeds of the public issue for repayment of certain borrowings availed by it. Hiren Patel, the younger son of the Nirma founder Karsanbhai, is currently the chairman of Nuvoco Vistas, which has acquired cement assets of Lafarge India and Emami Group. Nuvoco Vistas is the fifth largest cement company in the country in terms of manufacturing capacity and the largest cement company in East India. It has also grown from being a cement focused entity into a building materials company offering more than 50 products across cement, ready mix concrete and modern building materials.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/nirma-groups-nuvoco-vistas-files-for-rs-5000-cr-ipo/articleshow/82442323.cms||---
---||Dehradun||Beacons of hope: Individuals, schools, volunteer groups lend a helping hand||Mussoorie: From arranging ambulances, hospital beds, free food, oxygen cylinders, plasma and oximeters to chipping in to provide counselling to Covid patients and taking care of the children whose parents are infected, the Good Samaritans from Mussoorie and Dehradun are pooling in their own resources to help. For Covid affected families in need of food, Rajat Aggarwal along with several others are providing free meals to such families in Mussoorie. This group is delivering lunch and dinner packets, along with medicines, oxygen cylinders and other essentials. “We are making a door-to-door supply of meals, oxygen cylinders and other essentials. And arranging ambulance and hospital beds for those in need,” Aggarwal said. He added that Satish Juneja, Nagendra Uniyal and Jagjeet Kukreja and other members of his team were reaching out to the affected families for supplies. Smriti Hari and her group of women volunteers are also providing free meals, oxygen cylinders and other support to Mussoorie residents. In Dehradun, St Joseph's Academy Alumni Association, led by Ajay Goyal, president of Old Boys' Association and a team of 400 ex-students, is aiding the citizens with oxygen support, arranging hospital beds, medicines and free meals. “We have made a WhatsApp group of old boys and all of us are pooling in their resources and contacts to help as many residents as possible,” Ambuj Oberoi, one of the members, said. Similarly, Geeta Kumai, Arjun Vacchani and Rohit Kamboj have taken up the herculean task of arranging plasma for critical patients. “We get several requests for plasma from Mussoorie as well as Dehradun and Haridwar and we try to find plasma donors. Over the past 10 days we have arranged plasma for a number of patients,” Kumai said. Another recent initiative is that by Dr Nitin Pandey of Saheli Trust who is offering free hostel facilities for children whose parents are hospitalised and who have no one to look after them at home. Considering the anxiety, distress and mental health concerns arising during and after Covid, Binu Thomas, a counsellor with Woodstock School in Mussoorie, has offered to extend support. She is providing free counselling support through telephone and online.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/dehradun/beacons-of-hope-individuals-schools-volunteer-groups-lend-a-helping-hand/articleshow/82440937.cms||Anmol Jain
---||Hyderabad||Hyderabad: Volunteers resort to crowdfunding to help Covid positive patients||HYDERABAD: With hospitals facing shortage of beds, volunteer groups had now started crowdfunding to establish isolation centres for Covid-19 patients with mild symptoms. As hospitals are charging astronomical amounts for Covid-19, these groups have taken it upon themselves to set up isolation centres that are not only free but are also accessible to a larger part of the society. The Covid-19 Surge Impact Alliance has started an online crowdfunding campaign, wherein they have sought funds to start free isolation centres for patients in Hyderabad with a capacity of 30-50 beds. The centre will provide basic care under the observation of paramedical staff to people not needing hospitalisation and reduce the burden on hospitals. “Primary beneficiaries would be people who don’t need critical care. The facility will be for people from the weaker sections of the society. We intend to have 20 percent of the total capacity as oxygen beds,” said Raj Janagam, spokesperson of Covid-19 Surge Impact Alliance, which has also associated with corporates to raise funds for their initiative. The alliance has been able to raise Rs 5.51 lakh in the last few days and has a target of Rs one crore. Similarly, Feed the Needy, has started an online crowdfunding campaign to set up additional beds at Government Area Hospital, Kondapur. “We are aiming to raise $50,000 to provide the hospital with oxygen concentrators. These concentrators will help countless poor souls and their families from grave distress with the current hapless conditions. Any surplus funds that we collect will be used to help families in need,” said Pradeep Gadicherla of Feed the Needy, who initiated the campaign. They have raised about $15,000 (Rs 11.06 lakh) so far. These groups are being supported by the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation, resident welfare associations and corporates to establish Covid-19 isolation centres in several areas.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/volunteers-resort-to-crowdfunding-to-help-ve-patients/articleshow/82442347.cms||Preeti Biswas
---||Chennai||Tamil Nadu dips into its emergency reserves to stave off Oxygen crisis||CHENNAI: Two weeks after Tamil Nadu started asking the Centre to enhance oxygen allocation to the state to 500 metric tonnes from 280 metric tonnes under a revised allocation plan, consumption level of oxygen at hospitals in the state crossed 450 tonnes on Thursday, forcing health authorities to send emergency message across hospitals. The state got 280 metric tonnes when the active cases count was around 70,000. Over the last three weeks, active cases soared from around 50,000 to 1.28 lakh. Almost all oxygen beds and ICUs in most hospitals are full. The state health department has been drawing oxygen from its reserves, diverting industrial oxygen from MSMEs and tapping into all possible sources to keep the gas flowing in hospitals. While senior health officials, including health secretary J Radhakrishnan, presented the crisis before the Madras high court, political leaders had sent letters to Union health minister Harsh Vardhan seeking immediate action. “We have done everything we can to keep things safe and smooth,” said a senior official. For instance, a week ago, as a contingency measure, the state diverted industrial oxygen from a private steel plant in Gummidipoondi. In the last two days, nearly 1,378 cylinders from this plant was allotted to government and private hospitals in the city. “It was meant to be a reserve; it is now an important source,” the official said. With this the requirement for medical oxygen in Tamil Nadu touched 500 metric tonnes a day – this includes oxygen requirement in ambulances and at people’s homes. But the allotment from the centre was not enhanced. While all hospitals have set up committees to ensure judicious use of oxygen, several non-government organisations are working to set up oxygen generation plants or sourcing oxygen cylinders. “None of these measures are adequate. For the number of patients to have the allocation from the centre should double,” the official added. The oxygen allocation to the state is done by the Union health ministry based on recommendations from the Centre’s empowered group of secretaries (EG-II) which coordinates medical logistics, including oxygen. On May 5, the ministry revised allotments for 13 states, Tamil Nadu was left out. States with fewer active cases have been given higher allocations. For instance, Telangan which has around 77,000 active cases is allotted 360 metric tonnes. On May 5, allocation for Madhya Pradesh, which has 89,000 active cases, increased to 643 metric tonnes. For Andhra Pradesh it was increased to 500metric tonnes from 360 metric tonnes. The state has 1.70 active cases. On April 15, based on the supply plan suggested by the EG II, Tamil Nadu was allotted 220MT of oxygen by the Union health ministry. The plan suggested that allocation would be increased to 320MT by April 25 and 465MT by April 30. On April 18, however, a revised order increased allotment to Maharashtra, UP, Delhi, Rajasthan and added fresh allocations for Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Uttarakhand. The ministry allotment of 280MT to Tamil Nadu will not be altered. While Congress leader and former finance minister P Chidambaram questioned the rationale behind the allocation on Twitter, CPM MP from Madurai S Venkatesan wrote to Harsh Vardhan saying 13 patients died at the state-run medical College hospital in Chengalpet on Tuesday due to lack of oxygen. “Out of 447 admissions there for Covid, 309 required oxygen support. It is not an isolated example, and this is the situation in many parts of Tamil Nadu,” he said. “In this situation the supply plan has not done justice and ignored the state of Tamil Nadu even after repeated appeals by the government of TN for increased allocation,” he said. “I regret to state that the Government of India has to answer the people of Tamil Nadu if lives are lost due to inadequate allocation of oxygen supply. This is an urgent appeal and your intervention is sought without loss of time,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/state-dips-into-its-emergency-reserves-to-stave-off-o2-crisis/articleshow/82444376.cms||---

---||Lucknow||Vaccination drive for 18-44 age group in 11 more Uttar Pradesh districts||LUCKNOW: The Uttar Pradesh government has decided to scale up the Covid-19 vaccination programme for the 18-44 age group. “The vaccination for people above 18 years of age will now be conducted in all the 17 nagar nigams as well as Gautam Budh Nagar from next week,” said Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath here on Thursday. The campaign began in seven districts on May 1. The criteria of selection included districts having more than 9,000 active cases namely -- Lucknow, Kanpur, Prayagraj, Varanasi, Gorakhpur, Meerut, and Bareilly. The new additions will be Aligarh, Agra, Ghaziabad, Jhansi, Moradabad, Saharanpur, Firozabad, Mathura, Ayodhya, Shahjahanpur and Gautam Budh Nagar. At a meeting to review the progress of the vaccination programme in the state convened by the CM, health officials revealed that vaccine wastage had been brought to 0.5% which is negligible in a way. Insiders revealed that the wastage was in fact incidental while flaws in planning and micro-planning had been eliminated. The officials also said that so far, 68, 536 persons in the age group of 18-44 have been vaccinated. Later, health officials urged people to come forward to take Covid-19 vaccine as it was the other important pillar of Covid-19 containment besides prevention. UP to get 1cr doses of vaccine next week: Health officials claimed that to ensure the availability of adequate doses of the vaccine in Uttar Pradesh, the state government has ordered to procure 50-50 lakh doses of Covishield and Covaxin each, from the manufacturing companies. Stating that the consignment was expected for delivery next week, officials assured that there was no dearth of the stocks even today. Earlier, the Yogi government had floated a short term global tender for 40 million doses of vaccines.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/vaccination-drive-for-18-44-age-group-in-11-more-up-dists/articleshow/82444371.cms||---
---||Hyderabad||Hyderabad: Private engineering colleges witness jump in campus placements||HYDERABAD: A raging pandemic nothwithstanding, top private engineering colleges in the city have witnessed a 30 percent jump in campus placements, long-term internships and average salaries for the academic year 2020-21. From a slow start to the job drive and a shift in remote hiring, many companies are now coming forward with offers in emerging technologies as they augment projects in areas of artificial intelligence, data sciences, blockchain and internet of things. Digitization of operations by companies has led to an increase in campus recruitments, especially by IT services and product companies. “Since there is a rise in digital banking, e-retailing and e-commerce, more service based companies have come forward to recruit freshers in newer projects. During the first wave, we were skeptical that companies may reduce their intake and delay placements. But this time, the second wave has instead boosted the placements,” said K Kishore, director, training and placements at Vasavi College of Engineering. There is a rise in demand for trained and certified students as colleges have observed an uptick in the number of offers from product-based companies and start-ups. “There is a huge demand for students who are trained and certified in resources such as Full Stack, JAVA, Salesforce, front-end engineering etc. Due to rise in good offers, the average salary in our institution has increased from Rs 4.90 lakh to Rs 6 lakh this year,” said Vijaya Mair, head campus and corporate relations of CVR College of Engineering, adding that core civil and mechanical companies are offering more number of designing roles. There is also a marked rise in the number of high-paying offers in few institutions. “This year, we have had offers from various companies to the tune of Rs 12-33 lakhs. Companies are keen for an early on-boarding of the freshers, thereby, indicating an encouraging start to the placement season this year,” said K Butchi Raju, dean, placements, Gokaraju Rangaraju Institute of Engineering and Technology.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/private-engg-colleges-witness-jump-in-campus-placements/articleshow/82442385.cms||Preeti Biswas

Unfortunately, he did not get that opportunity, Choran’s niece, Premlata Maurya, told TOI. Choran was initially in the general ward when his iPhone went “missing.” “There was no other way to communicate as relatives are prohibited from entering the facility. So the day he was moved in an ambulance from the general ward to the ICU, we gave him another handset. We spoke with him over video call around midnight on April 26. He did not mention any other belongings going missing,” said Maurya. Around 5am on April 27, the family was informed that Choran’s oxygen level had dropped and he had passed away. After his body was taken away for cremation, the family was told his belongings were not there. “We were asked to come back after two days. We waited for several hours to meet the dean but in vain,” said Mourya. Two days later, the family was given Choran’s wallet with just Rs 800 in cash inside. Both his phones, his diary, his medical file and the rest of his cash had vanished. The family then approached Vanrai police where an FIR was lodged. “We will check CCTVs at the centre and make inquiries with staff,” a police officer said. Such homely atmosphere at the isolation centre helped him to recover within a week,” said Vijay Sampathraj Gadiya, who is a businessman. Similarly, Hamir Singh, a resident of Bolarum was admitted at Central Court Hotel, a makeshift isolation centre at Hyderabad. “I have spent five days at the isolation centre. Never in that period I felt I was at the isolation centre. It was so good,” said Hamir Singh. Like them, about 300 Covid-19 patients, who took treatment at all the five isolation centres _ including Tourist Hotel at Koti, Hotel Lemon Tree at Banjara Hills, Central Park at Hyderguda and MetroPolis at Secunderabad, and Platinum Hotel, at Himayathnagar _ recovered quite well. All these isolation centres were set up by the Jain Relief Foundation (JRF). “Shortage of beds, oxygen cylinders and rising Covid-related deaths inspired us to do something to help people in these desperate times,” said Prashant Kocheta, one of the directors of the JRF. “First we started with the isolation centre at Platinum Hotel. Subsequently, we opened centres at four other hotels. These facilities have 250 beds, medical infrastructure, including oxygen cylinders, ventilators and a team of expert doctors,” added Prashant. Interestingly, not even one death was reported at these isolation centre and everyone recovered. “Round the clock surveillance by a team of doctors and para medical staff. Providing proper diet and medication helped the patients recover fast. Almighty had given our community this opportunity to serve the needy,” Prashant said. ---||Hyderabad||Telangana: Cops, NGOs supply food, groceries to Covid-19 affected||HYDERABAD: Telangana police in association with NGOs, food and grocery delivery companies has launched a free lunch delivery facility for Covid-19 patients who are in home isolation. According to an official release from the Director General of Police (DGP)‘s office, Covid-19 positive patients, who are in home isolation, can order free lunch by sending their name, contact number, location and Covid-19 test details through a whatsapp message to (+91 7799616163). The service is expected to cater the needs of 1000 to 2000 Covid-19 affected people every day in the city and police are taking support from Sri Satya Sai Seva Organizations, Leadlife Foundation, Swiggy, Big Basket & Hope Organization to deliver the food. “Requests should be placed everyday before 6 am and any request after that shall be considered as a next day’s order. One can order for a maximum of five persons for five days from a registered mobile number,” the official release mentioned.
