---||Lucknow||Uttar Pradesh: Grocery shops shut despite exemption, consumers hit||LUCKNOW: The supply of grocery and other essential commodities has been hit in the city as despite exemption from curfew, grocers are either keeping their shops closed or opening only for a brief period in the morning or evening. Doorstep delivery is also taking 3-4 days which is adding to the people’s problems. In some areas, police is asking the owners to shut shops after finding that they are not following Covid-19 safety protocols. Residents of several localities complain about the crisis of essential commodities at home, barring milk and bread which are readily available. As the curfew period was initially of three days, many people did not keep adequate stock but since it has been extended till May 10, they are facing shortage. Vaishnavi Raj of Sector L, Aliganj, said: “We didn’t go for bulk purchase of essential items as there was no government order that grocers will also shut shops. However, no grocery store in my locality has opened for the last five days.” Prateek Srivastava of Daliganj, who had to go all the way to Gomtinagar to buy grocery, said: “I buy the stock in the first week of every month, but due to curfew since May 1, shops are closed in my area.” He said some small grocery shops were open but the items were of poor quality. “Around 11 am, cops asked the owners of these small shops to pull down shutters as they were not following Covid protocol,” he added. Similar situation prevailed in Mahanagar, Niralanagar, Nishatganj, Hazratganj and Shringarnagar where only a few shops were open. “A few shops opened in the evening but only for a few hours. By the time our turn came, we only got half the items we were looking for,” said Isha Shukla of Sringarnagar. “Online stores have put a cap of orders of minimum Rs 500 for home delivery. As a result, we have to purchase some other goods which we don’t require immediately,” said Pawan Kukreja of Niralanagar. Shailesh Kumar of Krishnanagar said if such a situation prevailed, there would be overcrowding as soon as the curfew gets over. Some shopkeepers said they closed voluntarily as many items were out of stock and they were not getting adequate supplies from wholesalers. Joint commissioner of police, law and order, Piyush Mordia said, “Only those shops which are not following Covid protocol are being asked to close down as per the directions of the state government. If any shopkeeper is forced by cops to shut without any reason, he/she may approach senior officers,” he added. TIMES VIEW If grocery stores are exempted from curfew, it’s the responsibility of traders to ensure that people get what they need and all safety protocols are followed. People too need to share responsibility with grocers in implementing preventive measures. At the same time, cops will have to see that essentials are easily accessible to people and if they find violation at any place, they should persuade them to cooperate. The city is going through a crisis, which requires each and every individual to show a sense of responsibility.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/grocery-shops-shut-despite-exemption-consumers-hit/articleshow/82444433.cms||Aditi Singh
---||Goa||Up to Rs 19.2k/day under DDSSY for Covid care in pvt hospitals||Panaji: The state government on Thursday issued a notification allowing reimbursement of the cost of Covid-19 treatment at private hospitals to citizens, under the state insurance scheme Deen Dayal Swastha Seva Yojana (DDSSY). An amount of up to Rs 8,000 per day will be reimbursed for treatment in a general ward for Covid, and up to Rs 19,200 per day can be claimed for ICU bed with ventilator. Chief minister Pramod Sawant said that for those who have not renewed their DDSSY cards, the state government has decided to grant auto-renewal free of cost. “We have decided today to grant auto-renewal to DDSSY cards free of cost. Even those who have not renewed their cards last year will get benefit of auto-renewal of their cards. In the case of those, who do not have cards yet, they should get one from the primary health centre or our online portal, so that they can also get benefit under DDSSY for Covid treatment,” Sawant said. “The claim shall be restricted to a maximum of ten days from the date of admission. The per day charges shall be calculated on the basis of 24 hours from the date of admission, any time less than six hours shall be ignored,” reads the notification issued by additional secretary (health), Vikas S N Gaunekar. The scheme for Covid treatment will be applicable only to those DDSSY empaneled hospitals which have ICU facilities, states the order. “The beneficiaries utilising the twin sharing or special room, such claims shall be restricted to general ward charges and the difference amount shall be paid by the beneficiary,” the notification states. The costs to be reimbursed will include admission charges, primary and specialist consultant charges, bed charges, nursing, resident doctor, diet, PPE kits for staff, X-ray, ECG, creatinine and liver function tests. Charges for cardiac monitor, infusion pump, catherterization and 2D echo will also be eligible for reimbursement under DDSSY. The amount spent on routine medicines will also be eligible for reimbursement like cost of multivitamin, vitamin C, zinc, vitamin D, paracetamol, antacid, anti-allergic, doxycycline, ivermectin and dietary charges. “The above package does not include diagnostic interventions, special drugs, use of special equipment, other special procedures/surgeries etc, extra oxygen flow other than ICU,” the notification states.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/up-to-rs-19-2k/day-under-ddssy-for-covid-care-in-pvt-hospitals/articleshow/82444509.cms||---

---||Lucknow||Lucknow: Dip in Covid cases springs hope but it’s still dark tunnel for patients||LUCKNOW: Even though the daily Covid-19 infections dropped on Thursday, the people’s problems continued as many had to struggle for basic things from oxygen refill to a critical care bed, testing and lifesaving drugs. Of the 72 covid facilities, 66 had uploaded their bed status by 10pm on Thursday. Akhilesh Bansal, a businessman from Daliganj, desperately searched for an oxygen supported bed for his 55-year-old sister-in-law. “I called five private hospitals between 1-3 pm and all said that they had no beds though the dashboard stated that they had some. Finally, I got a bed allotted through Integrated Covid Command Centre on the intervention of a senior district administrative officer,” he said. Special officer in-charge Covid relief in Lucknow, Roshan Jacob, found that laxity in the functioning of Rapid Response Teams (RRT). The Covid centre called 242 home quarantined patients to inquire about their well-being of whom 42 said that neither any RRT contacted them, nor they were given any medicines. She directed officers to issue show-cause notices to medical officers in-charge under whom these RRTs were working. Long queues were also seen outside most oxygen refilling stations since early morning.  “I have been standing here for six hours without food and water, but the station staff is saying that distribution to individuals will start only after supply to the hospital is over,” said Samarth Sen, a private executive, who wanted the refill for his critical ill friend. “Since all the other family members of the friend are also down with mild Covid-19 symptoms, they are not in a condition to stand in line, hence I volunteered to bail them out,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/dip-in-cases-springs-hope-but-its-still-dark-tunnel-for-patients/articleshow/82444473.cms||---

---||Mumbai||Students bound for foreign universities join scramble for vaccines||MUMBAI: With the vaccination drive opened for those above 18, thousands of teens aspiring to fly abroad for an education are rushing to get both jabs before boarding the flight. Universities in the UK have recommended that international students come vaccinated, but those in the US and Canada have been silent. So parents of most students with confirmed admissions, whether in the US, UK or Canada, are worked up about their wards getting both shots before leaving, especially in view of the vaccine shortage. Amid this scramble, at least one city school, the Dhirubhai Ambani international school, has reached out to its students. “Our school has emailed us to ask about our interest in getting our ward vaccinated. But we are wondering if we should take the Pfizer shot once we reach the US as our university has assured that if candidates reach without being vaccinated, they can take it on campus,” said the mother of a student. “We are asking our students to take the vaccine. The situation is evolving and we are not sure if airlines will insist on vaccination by the time it is August,” said counsellor Pratibha Jain. Students who will join universities in the fall of 2021 should ideally take the first dose in May and the second in July before leaving by early- or mid-August. “We have recommended that students and parents must take their vaccine before travelling, it will make their journey safer. If they are unable to access the vaccine in India, they must do so as soon as they land abroad. Some countries may require Covid vaccine passport, and some also may permit students to take vaccines on their campus,” said Karan Gupta, another counsellor. In US, universities have been implementing vaccination policies since late March, when Rutgers University, New Jersey, became one of the first to announce that having all returning students vaccinated will allow for an “expedited return to pre-pandemic normal”, making more in-person classes possible, as also on-campus events. Since then, Cornell, Brown, the University of Notre Dame, Syracuse University, Northeastern, and Ithaca, New York, have made similar announcements. Those who are not able to be vaccinated prior to their arrival would be required to do so after they land. The US has opened vaccination for people over 16. However, even if candidates travel vaccinated, most countries have mandated a negative SARS-CoV-2 test result and some countries have insisted that students undergo quarantine in a government designated facility.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-students-bound-for-foreign-univs-join-scramble-for-vaccines/articleshow/82444513.cms||Hemali Chhapia

Almora has not imposed a lockdown or curfew, but the markets will remain closed on Sunday whereas on weekdays, shops will be allowed to open till 2pm. The district magistrates have been given permission to impose curfew in either the entire district or specific places while taking into account the scenario in their respective areas.” Uniyal added that if similar situations continue for the next few days, the vegetable markets – which are located in narrow streets – would be shifted to the main road. An order in regard was passed by chief secretary Om Prakash on Wednesday. Meanwhile, there shall be no restriction on inter-state and intra-state movement of people and goods. ---||Nagpur||Vaccine is best available protection, don’t believe myths, say doctors||NAGPUR: Two vaccines available in India are at present the best protection against Covid-19, and one should not believe any social media rumours and myths about the vaccines, said expert doctors in Nagpur. With vaccination for all above 18 years gaining pace now, new series of fake news about vaccine efficacy and Covid-19 are buzzing in social media. “Vaccination is the only way forward to tackle the pandemic effectively. Don’t hesitate. Get your shots when your turn comes,” appealed infectious disease specialist Dr Ashwini Tayade. “Rather I would say this should be a priority for everyone. Paid or free vaccine, whichever is available, will definitely be cheaper than succumbing to disease,” she added. Some rarest of the rare incidents in which fully vaccinated citizens died during Covid-19 treatment are being highlighted in social media these days, with an intention to discourage youths from vaccination. Moreover, some platforms are flooded with information about new mutants and strains of Covid-19 and claims that vaccines don’t have any impact on these strains. “As per recent reports, no variant can escape vaccine immunity,” confirmed Dr Nitin Shinde, infectious disease specialist. “The L452R mutation is shared by both B.1.429 and B.1.617 (India) variants. These are about 20% more infectious, with higher viral loads. There are chances of some immune evasions, but cannot reduce vaccine efficacy,” he added. It’s now well known and proven fact that people who got vaccinated can also get infected, but their infection turns serious in very rare cases. Even after two weeks of complete vaccination, there are chances of infection in some people. “There’s nothing like 100% in any of the vaccines across the world. For that matter, Covid-19 vaccine has been developed on a war footing and further research will bring better vaccines for us in future. But, till then, we have no better option than getting a jab as quickly as possible,” said epidemiologist Dr Anand Thatte. Some youths are concerned about the fact that vaccines are not available. “Soon, we will have more options of vaccines and by the end of May, the present crisis of vaccines will be almost over,” said a senior member of Covid Task Force of the state government. MYTH BUSTERSVaccines cause autism: This myth originated from a 1997 study, whose author has since lost his medical license Healthy youths don’t need it: Unvaccinated youths, without protection from the virus, can easily get infected and spread it to senior citizens There are long term side-effects: Covid-19 vaccines in India are based on proven platforms with no long term side effects Vaccinated people also get Covid-19: This is known, called as breakthrough infections, and officially 0.0000097% people have it, which is negligible We will soon have herd immunity: India, with its huge population, cannot think about herd immunity for next many years||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/vaccine-is-best-available-protection-dont-believe-myths-say-doctors/articleshow/82441038.cms||Chaitanya Deshpande

The committee has been directed to make its recommendation on the release of the prisoners within two weeks of the meeting. The bench of Chief Justice R S Chauhan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma said that “since the coronavirus pandemic is likely to be there for the next few months amidst predictions of a third wave, the HPC should hold a meeting every month and deal with the issue accordingly.” The government meanwhile has been directed to ensure inoculation of prisoners aged above 18 years and to conduct RT-PCR test of any inmate who is released on bail or parole. The IG (Prison) was directed to ensure that sufficient hardware and software is available in the jails so as to permit the prisoners to converse with their counsel through the ‘E-Mulakaat portal. The directions came while the court was hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by a Roorkee-based resident seeking the release of under-trial and under-investigation prisoners. The petition also sought release of juveniles lodged in correction homes. The petitioner argued that the Covid numbers are setting new records each day and all evidence shows that the second wave is more deadly. Since the medical infrastructure of the state is already under severe strain and if the virus spreads to jails, which are even by the government’s own admission running at over 200% occupancy, the consequences will be devastating, the petition said, requesting the court to step in and direct the release of prisoners who pose no threat to society. ---||Goa||15-day lockdown needed as corrective measure: GCCI||Panaji: As Goa’s Covid-19 caseload continues to spiral, the Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI) has urged the state government to impose a 15-day complete lockdown as a corrective measure to break the transmission chain. GCCI, which till a fortnight resisted the idea of a complete lockdown, said that partial lockdowns are not showing any results. GCCI has recommended that the pharmaceutical industry and agro-based food processing industries must be allowed to continue operations if a statewide lockdown is imposed. In a letter to chief minister Pramod Sawant and chief secretary Parimal Rai, GCCI said that the focus on economic revival rather than human survival is “unfortunate” as the rapid spread of the novel coronavirus has put Goa’s entire health infrastructure under tremendous pressure. “Goa is currently facing the biggest health emergency in its history. It appears that measures like partial lockdowns are not showing the desired results,” president of GCCI Manoj Caculo said. Caculo said that the experience of the first Covid wave and the countrywide lockdown proved that the best way to control the pandemic is a total lockdown. He appreciated the government’s attempts to keep the economy going while tackling the pandemic, but said that it is time for “severe corrective measures to be adopted” to prevent Goa’s healthcare system from collapsing. “We have so far been reluctant to use the tried and tested method and seem to be concentrating more on the economic revival rather than survival of the citizens,” said Caculo. With the pandemic making deeper inroads, Goa has broken all its previous records and this has put the entire health infrastructure in the state under tremendous pressure. The state faces a shortage of hospital beds, medical equipment, oxygen, vaccination doses, ventilators. Medical staff are also stretched thin and stressed out. Many village panchayats and municipalities have declared their own lockdowns, which contradict the partial lockdowns imposed by the state. “The healthcare infrastructure is already on the brink of being overwhelmed, and there is urgent need to take the extreme measure of total lockdown for at least 15 days with a view to arrest the increasing number of positive cases and fatalities and give a much-required breather to revive the healthcare systems and the health workers to rejuvenate and ramp up capacities and capabilities,” Caculo said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/15-day-lockdown-needed-as-corrective-measure-gcci/articleshow/82444667.cms||---
---||Nagpur||Unregulated antibiotics use in Covid raising risk of resistant bacteria: Experts||NAGPUR: An array of the highest level of antibiotics are being used as a precaution in Covid patients, to prevent ‘hospital acquired’ or ‘secondary’ infections. However, this can lead to a greater problem through development of resistant bacteria in the community, against whom these drugs may prove impotent in future. Though antibiotics have no role to play, some doctors are heavily relying upon them to save Covid patients from secondary infections after the steroid therapy is kicked-started or immunosuppressant drugs like Tocilizumab or Itolizumab are administered. It’s also learnt that many doctors also believe using antibiotics from the initial days of admission to save Covid patients from ‘hospital acquired’ fungal or bacterial infections, without blood investigations or other evidentiary indications. Dr Meraj Shaikh, critical care physician at Care Hospital, said some are administering Meropenem right from the first day of hospitalization after coming from the community. “If highest antibiotic Meropenem is used indiscriminately on the first day, without any clinical reason, then we will not be able to use this drug later on. It would only add to the chances of the ‘opportunistic infections’ to grow and thrive later,” said Shaikh. “We are not sure whether such random use of higher antibiotic is being done for clinical requirement or economic reasons, as there is a major cost factor involved. Also, these higher antibiotics will kill friendly bacteria too along with the harmful ones, leading to many life-threatening conditions,” he said. The immediate commercial gain from such drug misuse seems to be shrouding the danger of antibiotic resistant bacteria later. Sources said a handful in the medical fraternity are spurred to prescribe these antibiotics as there is a profit margin of 300-400% or even more. Citing an example, an insider said the most commonly used antibiotic Meropenem injection is available from stockists and distributors for Rs 450-Rs 500 but is sold at maximum retail price of Rs 3,500, or with a little ‘discount’. Dr Nikhil Balankhe, intensivist at Viveka Superspecialty Hospital, said antibiotics have some role to play only after there is positive indications in the PCT (procalcitonin) test, which is a marker for bacterial infections or such other investigations, indicating its requirement. “The misuse of antibiotics likely to propagate resistant bacteria, which would be difficult to treat. This new strain would not have an antibiotic working against it,” he said. “One must use mild antibiotics under strict expert supervision,” he said. Dr Balankhe also pointed out there are antibiotics like Cefoperazone and Ceftriaxone which are in the range of Rs200-Rs 500, which can be used instead of Meropenem, which costs around Rs10,000 for a one-day dose, or Colistin, which costs Rs12,000. Dr Kamal Bhutada, director of ICU, Care Hospital, also said India is already home to resistant bacteria and doctors should not administer highest antibiotics to treat a viral disease like Covid. “Using steroids in Covid reduces immunity but only a handful pick up infections from the hospitals. Many do not even require antibiotics,” he said. “Using antibiotics so rampantly may lead to multidrug resistant bacteria, which may even kill the carrier,” he said. Jay Tekchandani, leading pharmacist, said there had been a 10 fold spike in sales of antibiotics now.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/unregulated-antibiotics-use-in-covid-raising-risk-of-resistant-bacteria-experts/articleshow/82441055.cms||Soumitra Bose

On checking the QR code, the police figured out it was a fake one. They summoned the applicant, Vaibhav Dabhekar, who had applied for it. After questioning, the police learnt that Dabhekar and his associate, Babu Mane, helped people procure e-passes. But if applications were rejected, they made fake passes. They charged Rs 500 Rs 1,000 for a person, depending on urgency or a pass. Mane is yet to be traced. Police said the accused used software to modify expired e-passes to make them appear genuine. ---||Delhi||Drive-in vax centres at parking lots in Delhi?||NEW DELHI: Encouraged by the success of a drive-through vaccination centre opened in Mumbai, North Delhi Municipal Corporation is also planning to set up drive-through vaccination centres in its multilevel parking sites. North corporation mayor Jai Prakash said that a meeting was held recently to discuss the blueprint for setting up such centres. “We have written to the Delhi government to allow us to start drive-through vaccination centres where people can get vaccinated while sitting in their cars. Our multilevel parking sites and other such locations can be used for this purpose,” he added. Jai Prakash said that “Delhi has a very high vehicle density and it should adopt all good models across the country to increase the vaccination coverage.” “The feasible sites are being shortlisted. Since multilevel parkings have enough space as well as multiple floors with defined vehicle flow directions, several such units can be opened in these sites.” The mayor further said that Delhi would have to use different strategies in urban areas, villages and unauthorised areas to encourage people to come out for vaccination. Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) had recently started a drive-in vaccination centre at the multi-level Dadar Kohinoor parking site, which has received a good response so far. BMC has now decided to start one such vaccination centre in every civic ward. The first drive-through vaccination centre opened by BMC allows senior citizens and differently abled citizens of the city to get jabs while remaining seated in their parked vehicles. People are also allowed to spend the 30-minute mandatory observation period after getting the vaccine shot in their own vehicles. The north Delhi mayor, however, said that they were planning to open the drive-through vaccination centres for people of all categories. A senior civic official said that such vaccination centres would also help people who are delaying their visit to vaccination centres because of apprehensions about crowding and the risk of catching infection. Delhi has several multilevel parking lots in places like Hauz Khas, Munirka, New Friends Colony, Model Town, Jangpura among others. Officials state larger open parking lots can also be used for this purpose.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/drive-in-vax-centres-at-parking-lots/articleshow/82442656.cms||Paras Singh
---||Chennai||Have just one day’s oxygen stock left, TN govt tells HC||Chennai: Tamil Nadu is left with just a day’s stock of liquid medical oxygen, and the issue has reached a critical point, officials told the Madras high court on Thursday. Top brass of the state’s health department told judges that while 25 tonnes of oxygen is being diverted from Sriperumbudur to Andhra Pradesh or Telangana, the 40MT it was supposed to get in return from Palakkad in Kerala has not come. “Officials say it is a critical situation and the reserves have been used up to the extent that there may be a further day’s reserve, but there may not be oxygen supply in adequate quantity on Saturday,” said the first bench, recording the state’s precarious oxygen situation. “The Union government and the empowered committee should take immediate steps in such regard to ensure adequate supply of oxygen to the State of Tamil Nadu to meet the needs. This must be ensured by tomorrow (Friday), so that the emergency that the officials speak of of the reserves supply running out by Saturdaydoes not happen. It is critical and it requires the attention of the highest offices so that lives are not lost for want of oxygen. The Sterlite unit at Thoothukudi is unlikely to produce oxygen till next week,” the bench of Chief Justice Sanjib Banerjee and Justice Senthilkumar Ramamoorthy said on Thursday. During hearing, health department officials said a meeting was held on May 2, 2021, involving officials from Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Tamil Nadu, central government representatives, manufacturers and others, at which a consensus was arrived at to ensure that 475MT of oxygen would be released to Tamil Nadu daily. The officials complained that notwithstanding the meeting, no allocation order had been issued for Tamil Nadu till date. They said that an allocation order was issued on May 5, but it did not include Tamil Nadu. As a result, as against the daily requirement of about 450MT per day, the Central allocation remained 280MT since last week. Pointing out that the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) has installed oxygen generating machines in some hospitals elsewhere at extremely short notice and at costs which are affordable, the judges said: “The state and the Union should facilitate the setting up of such units, if feasible, in this State, particularly in larger cities, including Chennai, Coimbatore and Madurai.” As for availability of Remdesivir in the state, officials told the cour that at the behest of the DMK government set to assume charge on Friday, Remdesivir centres are being set up in other major cities, including Madurai and Coimbatore, for release of the drug directly to private hospitals or patients. Till April, Tamil Nadu had been allocated 1.35 lakh units of Remdesivir against the order placed of 2.5 lakh units, they said, adding that about 24,000 units had been distributed from the Kilpauk Medical College centre upon appropriate documents being produced. On the hospital beds front, the court said Tamil Nadu appeared to be doing well, though 95% of the beds having oxygen supply had been occupied. According to the officials, roughly 70% of the overall bed capacity has been occupied, but a large proportion of the available beds do not have oxygen supply. The officials have, however, indicated that measures have been initiated to augment bed capacity, including oxygenated bed capacity and that such augmented bed capacity would be available shortly. The court then directed the Centre to ensure prompt supply of vaccines so that preventive measures could be taken at the earliest to stop proliferation of cases and the possible third wave. It then adjourned further hearing on the matter to May 12.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/have-just-one-days-oxygen-stock-left-tn-govt-tells-hc/articleshow/82444581.cms||Srikkanth D
---||Madurai||HC seeks details on BHEL O2 plant, vax complex in TN||Madurai: The central government, which supported reopening of Sterlite plant campus for oxygen product, must explain steps it has taken to reopen oxygen plants at BHEL in Trichy, said Madras high court on Friday. A division bench of Justices M S Ramesh and B Pugalendhi raised these issues when a public interest writ petition filed by A Veronica Mary came up for hearing on Thursday. The Centre has been given time till May 19 to respond to the queries. The PIL sought production of oxygen at the BHEL in Trichy and urged the union ministry of health and family welfare to grant approval for Covid-19 vaccine production at the Integrated Vaccine Complex -- HLL Biotech Ltd -- at Chengalpet, near Chennai. The PIL said BHEL had three plants to produce 140 metric cube of oxygen per hour. Noting that the plants are lying shut down since 2003, he said the units could be revived to meet the current demand in the state. Referring to counsel’s submission that Trichy Siva MP had sent a representation to the Centre seeking to resumption of oxygen plants at BHEL, the judges asked whether BHEL had the facility as claimed by the petitioner. “If so, what are the steps taken by the Centre pursuant to the representation sent by the MP?” With regard to the vaccines, the judges observed that India is one of the pioneers of vaccine production and world's largest exporter of vaccines. “This court is not finding fault with the government's action in procuring the vaccines from private enterprises or the deliberations with regard to price. But our anguish is that when the government itself is having vaccine-manufacturing institutes, such institutes may be revived and they may be put into effective use,” observed the judges. They then sought response from the Centre and state on these following queries: Details on the number of government-owned vaccines manufacturing institutes in the country along with its period of commencement of operation, production capacity and its present status. Why vaccines are developed only at a private institute, instead of utilizing the government institutes. The case was adjourned to May 19 for further hearing.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/madurai/hc-seeks-details-on-bhel-o2-plant-vax-complex-in-tn/articleshow/82441090.cms||Kaushik Kannan

Singh, who is single, is not only suffering from Covid-19 but is also grappling with financial constraints. Pragya, who is herself pregnant but is fighting for the survival of her maternal uncle, told TOI that she exhausted all her financial resources but her uncle’s condition did not improve. “He tested Covid-19 positive on April 12 but his condition did not improve. We have to shift him to a hospital in Chowk on April 22,” she said. “Two days passed but his condition remained the same. Doctors too did not pay any heed to our concerns. I contacted his friends in the hockey association and with their help, my uncle was admitted to TS Mishra hospital on April 24,” Pragya said. “However, his condition kept worsening so we decided to admit to him to another hospital in Niralanagar on April 26. Finally, he tested negative and sent to a non-Covid ward. As I was left with no money, I took to social media and requested Indian government and sports fraternity for financial help. We approached the president of Indian Olympic Association (IOA) Narinder Batra who extended financial support to us,” she said. Pragya added that inspector general of police, Lucknow range, Laxmi Singh also contributed Rs 2 lakh for Singh. “He had a chronic spinal injury due to which it had become hard for him to play on turf. Finally, the injury forced him to quit. Later, he joined SBI from where he took premature retirement. My mamaji is single, and has an elder sister, Saraswati Devi, and an elder brother, Rajendra Pal Singh,” Pragya said. ---||Nagpur||Oxygen tankers headed for city ‘traced’ to Aurangabad, Gondia||Nagpur: District collector office had back-to-back scares on two days after four tankers, scheduled to reach Nagpur, were found in Aurangabad and Gondia under mysterious circumstances leaving the Oxygen management team reeling under tension.The four tankers, that had substantial liquid oxygen from Bhilai’s Praxair India private limited for Nagpur, were to be provided police escort for the rest of their journeys. The tankers, that were traced at Aurangabad, had delivery receipts meant for a location at Chakan in Pune. These tankers were requisitioned by Nagpur district collector Ravindra Thakare.It’s learnt district oxygen management team was left on toes on Wednesday after two oxygen tankers were untraceable after having left Bhilai with liquid medical oxygen. The tanker drivers were not responding to repeated calls.Collector office had alerted the police and RTO offices. Oxygen co-ordinator Pyare Khan’s team too were engaged in tracing the vehicles. Much to the relief of the collector’s team, RTO and police had traced the two vehicles at Deoli check naka in Gondia from where they were escorted back to city.In the latest incident on Thursday, another two oxygen vehicle too had gone missing after updating their status as ‘breakdown’. As Khan’s maintenance team reached the Bhilai’s plant to repair the tankers, they were found missing. Following an alert by Khan’s team, district collector team contacted the Bhilai’s plant management. The management helped collector team with the location of the tankers near Kasarwadi in Aurangabad district where they were made to be intercepted by police who are bringing back the tankers to city.The district collector office, which has now roped in RTO officials to track tankers’ movement, is now set to take slew of measures like alerting the toll and check nakas regarding the tankers meant for Nagpur.In the other development, it’s learnt the Indian Airforce (IAF) transport aircraft was supposed to reach city from Vijaynagar to lift four tankers for Bhuwaneshwar but they were yet to land at the time of going to press. ---||Surat||Glaring violation of fire safety at Covid hospitals||Surat: During inspection of Covid-designated hospitals in the city, Surat Municipal Corporation’s fire department has come across glaring lapses that pose as potential threats for major mishaps in the future. The department has issued notices to 33 hospitals in the last two days to rectify the issues. Among the major irregularities in the hospitals, fire officials came across electrical cables and oxygen lines running parallel to each other. In a few hospitals, the oxygen lines were even fitted under exposed electrical cables. The department has also suggested the hospitals to remove as many inflammable materials, which are not needed, as possible. “ICUs use curtains to divide patients, which catch fire very quickly. We have asked them to start rectifying the electrical fittings and removing the curtains,” said in-charge chief fire official B K Pareek. Taking a cue from the fire at Covid hospital in Virar, they have also asked to reduce the number of sanitizer bottles in the ICU. Surat fire officials have also found accumulation of evaporated sanitizer contents on the ceiling and in the air. “Hospitals have been asked to reduce sanitizer bottles by 50% and keep proper air ventilation in the ICUs. If windows are kept open partially, sanitizer vapours will not remain suspended in the air,” Pareek added. Installation of residual current circuit breaker (RCCB) and molded case circuit breaker (MCCB) in ICUs have also been suggested. “The air-conditioners in all hospitals are on for almost a year so we have asked them to get all these appliances serviced,” he said. Teams of firemen also found that oxygen cylinders were not chained properly due to which these may fall and cause a blast.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/surat/glaring-violation-of-fire-safety-at-covid-hospitals/articleshow/82439412.cms||---
---||Chennai||Lessons from a Gandhian’s life||Chennai: On May 4, V Kalyanam, best known as the man who served as Mahatma Gandhi’s personal secretary between 1944 and 1948, passed away in the city at 99.It was exactly 77 years ago, on another sweltering May afternoon that Kalyanam had met ‘Bapu’ for the first time in Bombay. The latter had just been released from prison and was undergoing a treatment of naturopathy in the city. But Kalyanam had soaked in the Gandhian ideology before that by working at the Sevagram Ashram for about a year and serving eight months in jail for participating in the Quit India Movement. "He was caught by the police in Delhi slipping pamphlets under doors of homes. He was fresh out of college and was doing his bit," says Kalyanam’s biographer Kumari S Neelakandan.Neelakandan spent close to three years with Kalyanam, visiting him and often staying back at his then residence in Teynampet around a decade ago, to research for his book on the nonagenarian freedom fighter titled ‘August 15’. "When Gandhi met him for the first time, Kalyanam was working in the ministry of defence as a budget assistant, a job that earned him `250 a month," says Neelakandan. On learning this, Gandhiji told him he wouldn’t be able to pay him anything more than `60 to work with him -- a proposition Kalyanam accepted without a thought.Over the next four years until Gandhi’s assassination in 1948, Kalyanam compiled letters Bapu received from across the world. He typed out letters for Gandhi, and accompanied him extensively in his travels on foot and by train. "Until very recently, he sat on his antique Remington typewriter to write letters to friends, and complaints to the corporation and the CM. He used the back of pamphlets that came with newspapers to write these letters — a frugality ritual he had picked up while working with Gandhiji," says Neelakandan.Kalyanam was among those who was by Gandhi’s side the day he was assassinated, and went on to state in several interviews thereafter that he never heard him utter the famous words, "Hey Ram", during those last moments. In Madras where he moved to in the mid-1950s, Kalyanam worked as the regional commissioner of the SC/ST commission and had a stint with Rajaji’s Swatantra Party. He donated abundantly to the Voluntary Health Services, government relief funds and medical aid for the poor. "It gave him purpose to help those in need," says Kalyanam’s daughter Nalini with whom he lived in Padur until his passing.Most of those who knew Kalyanam also reminisce about his sense of independence. "He was great with all kinds of manual work – something he picked up at the ashram. "Until the age of 97, he cooked his own meals. He also liked making tea for his visitors, and ensured they always went back with a memorable conversation," says Nalini.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/chennai/lessons-from-a-gandhians-life/articleshow/82432518.cms||---

Police sources said that Paramasami, a 1997-batch police constable, responded well to the treatment when he was infected the first time. At least five police personnel from Madurai district died during the first wave. Paramasami subsequently took first dose of vaccine in the month of March. He developed fever before he could take the second dose of the vaccination in April. Even after recovering from fever, he could not get vaccinated due to shortage in vaccines. Meanwhile, he got infected again with Covid-19 around 10 days ago. After undergoing medication at home for initial days, he got himself admitted to a private hospital in Thirumangalam. He died without responding to treatment on Wednesday. He is the first police staff to die in the second wave in Madurai city. He is survived by his wife and two sons. They were providing on-spot vaccination till few days back and suddenly turned to online booking from Thursday without any intimation,” said Bhalerao Kimmatkar, an elderly person who was denied the jab for not scheduling his dose online. Insufficient supply of vaccines and lack of planning marred the process. People were losing patience and crowding up inside the centres despite risk of infection,” he said. While only 100 vaccine were given at every centre, more than 200 persons gathered there. “Elderly people were seen leaving disheartened after waiting for several hours in the sun,” said Deshmukh. Preference was given to those who registered online and walk-ins were allowed only in cases of spare doses as per the directives of administration. ---||Nagpur||43% posts vacant, state FDA working with added burden||Nagpur: The Maharashtra Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) is playing a key role in the state’s Covid management but with 43% posts vacant, its functioning has been crippled. Recruitments have not happened for several years while selection and related processes were clouded with controversies and litigations. Amid the second wave of Covid, FDA drug wing’s manpower shortage problem was exposed with the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court pulling it up for alleged mismanagement. It’s learnt, a team of only seven officials, including a temporary joint commissioner flown in from Mumbai a fortnight ago, are managing the production and distribution of oxygen and availability of drugs like Remdesivir and Tocilizumab in the five the districts of Vidarbha, including Nagpur. One of the senior drug inspectors, not promoted for 26 years due to technical reasons and whose post is almost like that of a district head, is functioning as assistant commissioner in Nagpur. Wardha, Chandrapur, Bhandara and Gondia do not have a similar district head or assistant commissioner (drugs). FDA has 66 posts of assistant commissioners (drugs) in the state but 35 are vacant. Except Konkan, no other division has full-time joint commissioner (drugs). Like Nagpur, they are managed by officials having additional charge for brief periods. In Nagpur, it’s been almost two years since the division had a joint commissioner in the drug wing. For the same period, there has been no regular assistant commissioner (drugs) too for Nagpur district. Apart from official posts, there is acute shortage of ministerial staff too for administrative work. “We also do not have a law officer to assist us in legal work,” said an FDA source. Of the 1,361 posts in the state, around 585 are vacant in FDA’s both drugs and food sections. Sources in Mumbai stated that the last recruitment for FDA’s drug inspectors had taken place in 2008 but they could join only in 2012 as there were tedious litigations and objections. “The recruitment is done through Maharashtra Public Service Commission. The selection criteria is tough as one should have at least three years experience in testing and manufacturing. The last full-fledged recruitment had taken place in 1996-97,” said the source. According to a source at a senior position, a list of 23 officials was put up for promotion to the post of assistant commissioners but government could not take decision due to reservation issues. “Some assistant drug inspectors were also recruited on contract basis but the process is now stuck,” said the source.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/43-posts-vacant-state-fda-working-with-added-burden/articleshow/82441122.cms||Soumitra Bose
---||Pune||2 pose as women, blackmail 100 men from Pune since Jan||Pune: The cybercrime department of the Pune police has identified two men from Rajasthan, who posed as women and blackmailed at least 100 men from the city since January this year. The men have been arrested by the Rajasthan police and the city police plan to seek custody soon. The two accused would share their phone numbers after befriending the men and request them to pose nude on video calls. The duo recorded these video calls and later blackmailed the victims. A team, headed by deputy commissioner of police (cyber) Bhagyashri Navatake, has expedited the investigation of these cases on priority. “We will seek their custody after the investigation of the Rajasthan police is completed. They are in the custody of Khoh police station near Deeg in Rajasthan,” said senior police inspector DS Hake of the cybercrime police station. Hake further added, “We have received as many as 100 complaint applications from different parts of the city since January.” The police team tracked down the IP addresses of the electronic devices used by the suspects as well as the bank account details of suspects. “Our team visited Rajasthan last week and found out that the men had been arrested by the Rajasthan police in relation to similar cases registered there,” Hake said. According to the officer, the duo has extorted a sum ranging from Rs 3,000 to Rs 25,000 from the complainants. “All the victims, who approached the police, were fed up with the extortion and threat calls. The victims are aged between 25 and 55 years,” he said. The police officer said that, at first, the victims received a friend request on their social networking site. “The duo has prepared fake profiles on the social media site using the names of women and the victims accepted these requests. The duo then starts chatting with the victim via the messenger app. The dialogue would generally be limited to sexual topics. After chatting for a few days, the men exchanged their phone numbers and the duo called them using sound modulating software,” the officer explained. “The two men would later make video calls claiming they would pose nude, but they actually played videos of women on the calls. After this, the duo ‘compelled’ their victims to pose nude on the video calls. The accused would record the video call using a screen video recorder software,” said Hake.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/2-pose-as-women-blackmail-100-men-from-pune-since-jan/articleshow/82441093.cms||---

When school libraries, electricity, internet, sports facilities and other infrastructure is not being used and parents have to shell extra to make education facilities available at home, why shouldn’t the school fee be reduced,” asked Rahul Srivastava, a parent. “We are thankful to the SC that it has paid attention to the issue. Private schools are charging hefty fee just for online classes of few hours,” he added. “Schools are not reducing fees, not paying salaries to their staff and have sacked employees in the name of Covid. They are saving and making money in every way. The government should direct all private schools to waive 50% of school fee,” another parent, Rishabh Tiwari, said. He said the schools had reduced the hours of teaching and parents were sitting with children for online classes then then there was no point in charging hefty fee. “Not a single classs was held for the entire month of April and the academic session is beginning from mid-May. Why are schools charging the fee for one and a half months when nothing is being done,” a parent, Jyotsna Singh, asked. She added that the fee shold be reduced and parents like her who had already submitted the fee should be refunded the amount. On the contrary, schools have given concessions to the parents who were unable to pay the fees during pandemic.” He said if the government could promise the waiver of fixed electricity charges, sewage charges and water tax and was ready to bear the cost of insurance of school buses, fitness of school vehicles and salaries of drivers, the schools would reduce the fees. “Due to inflation, the maintenance cost of school buildings is going up every day. The salaries of all the employees has to be given,” said Sarvesh Goel, chairman of GD Goenka Public School. “Many schools are giving scholarships and fee concession. Schools which have cut down these expenses can reduce their fees but it is not possible for others,” he added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/parents-hail-supreme-court-view-on-fee-cut-for-online-only-classes/articleshow/82444634.cms||---
---||Delhi||Delhi can add 9,500 oxygen beds if supply is adequate: CM Arvind Kejriwal||NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Thursday that Delhi government could create 9,500 more oxygen-equipped hospital beds provided the central government ensured sufficient oxygen supply.  He also said that Delhi, for the first time, received 730 metric tonnes of oxygen on Wednesday and would require such a volume every day until the current Covid-19 wave subsided. The chief minister thanked the Centre, Supreme Court and Delhi High Court because of whose efforts the city was able to get 730 MT of oxygen. Kejriwal also sent a letter of thanks to PM Narendra Modi and requested him to ensure that Delhi did not suffer a reduction in daily supplies. Kejriwal has appealed to hospitals that were forced to reduce their bed capacities for want of oxygen to reinstate the earlier beds. “Due to the scattered oxygen supply that Delhi was getting, several hospitals reported shortages. They sent SOS message after message. We were facing a lot of difficulties. But yesterday, for the first time Delhi got its share of 730MT of oxygen from the central government,” Kejriwal said. He, however, added, “Getting 730 MT of the gas for one day will not work. Until the second wave of infections doesn’t diminish, we need 700 MT oxygen daily. Getting 700 MT one day and 300-400 MT another day will create a turmoil among the hospitals again.” Kejriwal said that many patients had died due to lack of oxygen in hospitals and some healthcare centres had, therefore, reduced the beds available. “A major hospital with 300 beds reduced the capacity to 100 beds,” the CM noted. “This led to people not getting beds, whereas our efforts should have been to increase the number of oxygen and ICU beds. If big hospitals are forced to cut down the number of beds, there will be complete mayhem. It is my request to all hospitals to reinstate their earlier beds.” Full occupation of hospital beds with oxygen had led to frantic searches for bed even as several patients died awaiting hospital admission. Many Delhiites were compelled to take their kin to hospitals in the neighbouring states. “If we receive 700 MT of oxygen every day, we can create new oxygen-equipped beds in Delhi. If we have enough oxygen, we can create 5,000 beds at Radha Soami Satsang, 2,500 beds in two sites in Burari, 1,000 beds in Commonwealth Games Village, and 1,000 in Yamuna Sports Complex. If we get 700 MT daily, I guarantee you that no person will have to die because of oxygen shortage,” asserted Kejriwal. The CM said there was great enthusiasm for vaccination after the exercise was opened to people aged above 18 years. Till now 35,74,000 vaccine doses have been administered. Saying that those who have taken the first shot number 28 lakh, and 7,76,000 people have received both the doses, Kejriwal appealed to all eligible individuals to get vaccinated.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/delhi-can-add-9-5k-o2-beds-if-supply-is-adequate-cm/articleshow/82444671.cms||AlokKNMishra
---||Pune||Fraudster claims to be bank official, wipes out worker’s entire savings||Pune: A cybercrook siphoned Rs2.2 lakh — the entire savings — from the account of a worker in a cushion-making workshop by posing as an employee of a public sector bank. Santosh Kumar Tiwari (35) of Wakad had gone to an ATM kiosk on March 8 to withdraw Rs20,000 to send to his ailing father in Bihar. He could not withdrawn the cash, but the amount was debited from his account. When he supposedly found the customer care number on the internet, he contacted it and the cybercrook returned the call via another number. He took Tiwari’s bank details and siphoned the amount. Tiwari has filed an FIR with the Hinjewadi police. “Initially when I contacted the number, there was no response. After sometime a person contacted me via another cellphone number and introduced himself as an executive of the bank. He asked for my account number and told me that the money would be credited to me within half-an-hour,” Tiwari said. “The person then told me to share the OTP. Believing him to be a bank official, I shared three OTPs with him. I lost Rs2 lakh in the first transaction, Rs10,000 in the second and Rs7,000 in the third,” he said. Tiwari then tried to contact that person but his number was not reachable. “I went to the bank immediately. The bank officials could at least save Rs17,0000. I was told that Rs2 lakh was transferred to a bank account in Bihar,” he said. ---||Nagpur||Atmanirbhar: Over 7k send self-meter readings||Nagpur: In about last 15-20 days, over 7,000 people in the city carried out self-meter readings of their electricity consumption. Following challenges faced in peak summers during last lockdown, this initiative was taken by Mahavitaran to ensure that citizens are not overburdened with collective bills of a few months.Across the state, over two lakh consumers have sent their meter reading through website, mobile application and SMS. Pune got the highest readings at 49,950 followed by Kalyan with 28,916.State energy minister Nitin Raut had directed Mahavitaran to facilitate its consumers with the self-meter reading facility. “Taking into account the positive response from the consumers, Mahavitaran decided to continue this facility and also increased the number of valid time period to send the reading to four days. Also, a special facility of sending meter readings through SMS is also made available for the consumers during this pandemic,” stated a press release by the company.It added that in the last month, 1.35 lakh consumers sent their self-meter reading. “In April, there was a rise of 67,481,” the release stated.Apart from Nagpur, Akola recorded 7,180 self-meter readings, Amravati 5,662, Chandrapur 3,188 and Gondia 3,464. “Many localities are under containment zone and thus it is not possible for us to go and take readings. Last year, citizens complained as they had to pay collective electricity bills for a few months. To avoid this economic burden on the pockets of common man, self-meter readings works best,” said officials.As per the release, every month there is a fixed date for taking the photo meter reading between 1st and 25th of the month. “Every month, one day prior to this meter reading date, Mahavitaran appeals its consumers through a SMS to send their self-meter reading.Self-meter reading will help the consumers to have a regular check on the meter and its reading. Accordingly, the consumer can control their consumption. “The consumers can make immediate complain about faulty meter. If the reading rises suddenly, the consumer can find out the reason behind it,” it added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/nagpur/atmanirbhar-over-7k-send-self-meter-readings/articleshow/82441135.cms||Manka Behl
---||Madurai||35 dead in south TN, 20 in central||Madurai/Trichy: A total of 4,565 fresh Covid-19 cases and 35 deaths were recorded in the ten southern districts on Thursday while the central region registered 2,072 new cases and 20 deaths, according to the health department. Madurai with 996 fresh cases recorded its highest in a day followed by Tuticorin with 796 cases, Tirunelveli (688), Theni (456), Kanyakumari (445), Dindigul (307), Tenkasi (280), Virudhunagar (269), Ramanathapuram (180) and Sivaganga (148). After recording more than 4,000 active cases over the last eight days, Tirunelveli’s active cases dropped to 3,792. Kanyakumari (2,335) and Theni (2,290) are the other districts with more than 2,000 active cases. In central TN, Thanjavur recorded the highest death toll of six followed by Trichy (5), Karur (4) and two each in Pudukottai and Nagapattinnam. ---||Lucknow||Devise Covid plan keeping in mind present, future: CM Yogi Adityanath to health panel||LUCKNOW: In his first meeting with the advisory panel of health experts, set up to provide guidance and suggestions to Team-9 on Covid management and prevention, chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Thursday said a strategy should be prepared for the state, keeping in mind the current situation of pandemic and the challenges that may come up in future. The CM asked the panel to meet every day and convey its suggestions to the health or medical education department and also send a report to him. He also asked the committee to inform the medical institutes and hospitals about Covid treatment protocols and give necessary suggestions. “This is not the time for negative discourse. We have to come together in this fight and boost the morale of front line workers involved in the fight against Covid-19. Positive stories about victory on coronavirus should be publicised prominently in print, electronic and social media,” he said. “UP has a population of 24 crore people. As compared to other states, UP should not lack in anything. Prevention is extremely important in Covid-19. As soon as symptoms appear, one should get tested. Doctors should advise patients on who needs oxygen, medicines and hospitalisation. Telemedicine facility should be used to help patients at home,” Yogi told the panel. Chairperson of the advisory panel, SGPGI director Dr RK Dhiman, said health specialists should give information about Covid treatment to people through media. “Prevention is more crucial than cure in Covid-19 and infection can be controlled through Covid-appropriate behaviour like wearing masks, gloves, sanitisation and vaccination,” he said. The panel also made a presentation before the CM on various aspects of Covid-19 prevention.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/devise-covid-plan-keeping-in-mind-present-future-cm-to-health-panel/articleshow/82444702.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Of 44,000 who applied for e-passes to travel out of Mumbai city till Wed, 25% allowed||The Mumbai Police till Wednesday issued 11,300 e-travel passes for people to travel from Mumbai to various districts across the state and other parts of the country. Sources said that the e passes were issued only to those travelling on extreme emergencies. Deputy commissioner of police (PRO) S Chaitanya said that they have so far received 44,158 applications for e-passes of which only 11,300 — roughly 25% — were permitted to travel. It is mandatory for citizens to obtain e-passes for travel outside Mumbai for emergency and essential services.  The authority of approval or rejection of e-passes lies exclusively with the zonal deputy commissioner of police. Sources said many applications were from relatives wanting to see their elderly parents, medical reasons, many whose wives were expecting a child and others who had to attend funerals of their loved ones.TNN||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/of-44000-who-applied-for-e-passes-to-travel-out-of-mumbai-city-till-wed-25-allowed/articleshow/82444739.cms||---
---||Agra||Graveyards in UP running low on space, some facing shortage of diggers||Meerut/Agra/Bareilly: Negotiating a maze of marked and unmarked graves, a group of mourners approached Babar Alam with a body. He hurriedly led them towards the extreme north of the graveyard, off the beaten path, where a row of freshly dug graves were waiting. Alam asked them to choose anyone of them, and they did. A little while later, as the body was being lowered and one of the mourners was sobbing helplessly, an earthmover was busy digging more pits, nearby. As secretary of Agra’s Panchkuian Kabristan, Alam says that he has never seen such a rush of bodies. It had prompted him to ask for an earthmover from the civic body. “The number of bodies has significantly increased in the last three weeks. On an average, we used to get six bodies earlier. Now the number has increased to 20." " We are digging graves in advance with an excavator provided by the municipal corporation to avoid inconvenience to the relatives of the deceased,” Alam said. He said that there are around 20 graveyards in the district. “The number of bodies reaching for burial has increased everywhere,” says Alam, who believes that the month of Ramzan saved many lives. “Most people are fasting, staying at home and praying. Had it not been the holy month, many more would have died,” he said. The situation at Agra’s another prominent graveyard is no different. Caretaker of the city's Noorjahan Karbala kabristaan, Chaudhary Aleemuddin says, “The number of bodies reaching for burial have doubled.” And about 250 km away in Meerut, caretakers of graveyards were grappling with somewhat similar situations. And they didn’t have an earthmover to help them. At the city’s largest graveyard, Mohammad Alam was busy digging graves with his team of workers. “Earlier we used to dig six to seven graves a day. Now the number has increased five times. Our problem has compounded because we have to dig six feet now due to protocol. We cannot bury a Covid-19 infected body in a four feet grave,” says Alam, the caretaker of Meerut’s Bale Miya kabristaan. The graveyard’s in-charge, Mufti Mohd Ashraf, had his share of concerns. “So many of our workers have fallen sick, but bodies are continuously coming. We will soon run out of space. We desperately need mitti (soil) which should be at least 3-foot-high to accommodate the new arrivals,” Ashraf said. At another burial ground in Meerut’s Mohanpuri area, popular as Shah Vilayat graveyard, secretary Mohammad Rashid claimed that at least 50 to 60 people are dying daily. “We cater to the Lal Kurti area and don’t get many bodies here. But, according to my estimate, the daily deaths -- among Muslims-- is nothing less than 50-60 in the entire city. But these are highly conservative estimates. Number could be higher as well.” Last week, an MLA in Meerut released Rs 25lakh to purchase extra soil for the graveyards. Meerut city MLA Rafiq Ansari had said, “The situation is really bad. There is no oxygen, no hospital beds. People are dying and graveyards are running out of space. Our religion does not allow us to burn the bodies, and they cannot be left on roads too.” But space is not the only problem at the graveyards. Like cremation, the cost of burial has gone up too. “For burials, we need three things, kafan (a sheet of white cloth), wooden planks and gravediggers. Earlier, a cloth would cost Rs 1,100 while wooden planks came at Rs 1,200. The labourers charged about Rs 700. Now, the traders do not give the cloth anything less than Rs 2,000. The wooden planks are also in high demand as they are needed in cremation too. So the cost has gone up considerably,” says Mufti Ashraf. Muzaffarnagar’s Gore Ghariba Kabristan was also getting at least 11 bodies daily, mostly of Covid-19 patients. While in Bareilly, the graveyards were facing the shortage of workers. In Prayagraj, several graveyards had hired earthmovers to cope with the work.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/agra/graveyards-in-up-running-low-on-space-some-facing-shortage-of-diggers/articleshow/82439367.cms||Sandeep Rai
---||Goa||Special loans for MSMEs to mfg O2, oximeters||Panaji: In an attempt to encourage micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) to address the demand for critical goods and services required to tackle the second wave of Covid-19, Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) is offering low-cost funding to units that manufacture oxygen cylinders, oxygen concentrators, oximeters and essential drugs. Understanding the urgency of the situation, SIDBI has offered to sanction credit within 48 hours to such firms which can help Goa and the nation augment capabilities to fight the pandemic. SIDBI is offering 100% funding up to an amount of Rs 2 crore to a MSME unit at attractive interest rate of 4.5-6% per annum if the firms meet all the criteria. The schemes are devised under the guidance from the Centre and will provide funding for production and services related to the supply of oxygen cylinders, oxygen concentrators, oximeters and essential drugs such as Zincovit, Limcee, Ivermectin, Paracip, Azax, Betadine, Azithromycin, Fabiflu, Remdesivir and others. While Goa has four medical and industrial oxygen suppliers, it has to depend on neighbouring states for oxygen cylinders, oxygen concentrators, oximeters and other essential equipment. SIDBI, the principal financial institution for financing and development of MSMEs, has launched the SHWAS and AROG quick credit schemes and hopes that the term loans and working capital funds will help MSMEs speed up the production of oxygen cylinders, oxygen concentrators, oximeters and essential drugs. The two loan products, said a SIDBI official, are being offered at a concessional rate for ramping up supply of products used in fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. In the second wave of Covid-19, the virus has shown an massive resurgence and has crippled Goa’s health care infrastructure. Hospitals and patients who have opted for home isolation are struggling for oxygen supplies.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/goa/special-loans-for-msmes-to-mfg-o2-oximeters/articleshow/82444869.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क

---||Pune||Recovery rate fights April dip, rises to 89% in PMC, PCMC||Pune: The Covid-19 recovery rate in the Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad municipal corporation limits is on the rise since the past month and has touched 89%. Around March 20, both municipal corporations had recorded a 90% recovery rate which, however, dropped to 82% in the second week of April. The past four weeks have been witnessing a steady rise in daily recoveries in urban pockets on most days. Health officials said the daily caseload has dropped to 3,500-4000 this week in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) limits and to around 2,000 in the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) areas. On two occasions last week, the daily cases in the PMC limits had dropped below 3,000 and the tally went below 2,000 once in the PCMC areas. A PMC official said they were continuing with the contact tracing and testing of people despite the drop in daily cases and increase in recoveries. “We have noticed a steady rise in discharges in the past four weeks in the city. The recovery rate has gone up again. During this one month, the city has not reported any significant drop in recoveries. We expect the recovery rate to stay on the higher side,” an official said. On May 6, the progressive positive caseload in the PMC limits had reached up to 4.36 lakh, of which 3.89 lakh patients recovered. Out of 2.21 lakh positive cases in Pimpri Chinchwad, 1.97 lakh people have recovered. Sanjeev Wavre, assistant health chief at PMC, said, “The recovery rate in the PMC limits was over 90% in early March. If the existing trend continues for a few more days, it will go beyond 90%. We have not closed any swab collection centres, though the cases have dropped. The citizens have been appealed to get tested if they develop any symptom of Covid-19 and start treatment at the earliest to prevent complications.” The recovery rate in the district’s rural areas has, however, been low as compared to the urban pockets. On May 6, the rural areas reported an overall recovery rate of 82%. The new cases per day in the rural pockets have been on the rise as compared to the daily discharges.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/recovery-rate-fights-april-dip-rises-to-89-in-pmc-pcmc/articleshow/82442750.cms||Sarang Dastane

It has to be a quick disposal of information to the intended group so that help can be provided on time and at the proper place. Thus, we motivate them to follow precautions as thoroughly as they can,” said a party functionary. President of the party Sanjay Nishad holds live sessions on Facebook to keep workers motivated and interact with them every day. ---||Agra||Ventilators sent by Centre gather dust at Agra district hospital||AGRA: With active Covid-19 cases touching an all-time high and growing number of critical patients battling for life amid shortage of beds, medical equipment, medicines and oxygen, it has come to the fore that two ventilators sent by the central government using PM care funds are gathering dust at the Agra district hospital. The hospital management claims that the machines are not being used as it does it have a specialized doctor and technician to operate the machines to provide ventilator support for patients in critical condition. There are 78 beds in Covid-19 ward at the district hospital. Last year, the hospital was provided with two fully digital ventilators by the central government using PM care funds. The state-of-the-art ventilators can be used as Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) and high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) for treatment of patients in critical condition. A senior doctor at the district hospital said, “Since past several months, the two ventilators are gathering dust. There is no chest physician or technician to operate these machines. We are not able to provide adequate treatment to Covid patients suffering from difficulty in breathing. Oxygen supply to the hospital is also not sufficient. Patients in need of high flow oxygen are transferred to other centres. Doctors and supporting staff are trying their best to serve the patients with the limited facilities available with us.” Superintendent in-charge of the district hospital Satish Verma said, “We had received two ventilators arranged from PM care funds. Following lack of human resources, we are not able to operate them. The oxygen supply to the hospital has improved in the past few days. We do not have an ‘in-house only’ supply infrastructure. Oxygen cylinders are used for patients having difficulty in breathing. Critical patients are referred to the SN Medical College”. District magistrate Prabhu N Singh said, “The ventilators are vital machines in treatment of critical patients of Covid-19. I was not aware that the district hospital has two ventilators gathering dust. I will ensure they are suitably utilized. We can transfer them to some other Covid care centre if required staff is not available to operate them at the district hospital.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/agra/2-hi-tech-ventilators-sent-by-centre-gathering-dust-at-agra-district-hospital/articleshow/82439417.cms||Deepak Lavania
