---||Lucknow||RSS cadres pitch in to help patients||Lucknow: Extending a helping hand to families of Covid-19 patients, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) has issued detailed guidelines for volunteers to reach out to the people in distress. Be it setting up of counselling centres to arranging beds, providing food to infected families, helping people in vaccination and even helping in performing last rites of Covid victims, the RSS volunteers are helping people in keeping with the 13-point strategy. To support the families which have lost their dear ones to Covid-19, RSS volunteers have put out messages on social media which read, “Yadi aapke aas paas mein koi aise vyakti ki mrityu hoti hai jisko kandha dene ya unki antyehsti karne ke liye koi log nahin hain toh humein bataye hamare paas paanch sadasya ki team taiyar hai. Yadi koi bilkul nirdhan vyakti hai toh uski antyeshti ka kharcha bhi hamari team vahan karegi (If there has been a death around you and there is no one available to carry the body for cremation, let us know. We will also bear the expense of cremation for the poor)”. “In every mandal (organizational unit of RSS at every nyay panchayat level), our volunteers and office-bearers are connecting with people through WhatsApp and Zoom to keep a watch on the situation at local level. These groups have messages like whom to contact when in need,” said Awadh Prant Karyawah of RSS, Prashant Shukla. Helpline numbers have also been released where people may call and seek help. Other points of the guidelines include distribution of kaadha (concoction), encouraging people to donate blood and plasma, setting up counselling centres, providing stay to relatives of Covid-19 patients, helping people to get vaccinated and setting up isolation centres and Covid care centres. “Our people are coordinating with government and administration to help those in need of hospital beds. We have contact numbers of doctors and arrange consultation for patients. We are also arranging medicines for patients,” Shukla said. At many places, RSS volunteers are even drawing help from people who are not associated with the saffron brigade.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/rss-cadres-pitch-in-to-help-patients/articleshow/82444764.cms||Neha Shukla
---||Pune||Credai seeks four months’ extension for property registration, fine waiver||Pune: Credai Maharashtra has sought four months’ extension from the state government for registration of property documents executed in December. The state developers’ body has written to the Inspector General of Registration and Stamps regarding the same. As per section 24 of the Registration Act of 1908, all documents need to be registered within four months of the date of the signing of the agreement, failing which a fine, not exceeding 10 times the registration fee, is to be levied each month in different slabs. The developers’ body has approached the state government to be considerate towards property buyers and not charge a fine in view of the pandemic. State Credai president Sunil Furde said that while the state government has given a stamp duty waiver of 3%, which helped boost the realty sector and saw many documents being executed on or before December 31, the current Covid situation, travel restrictions and overall health scare were preventing property registrations. “The Inspector General Of Registration and Stamps (IGR) of the state is conferred the powers under section 70 of the Registration Act to remit wholly or in part the difference between any fine levied under section 25 of section 34. We request you extend it for a further period of four months,” the letter written by Credai Maharashtra stated. State IGR officials have confirmed receipt of the letter. They said it has been forwarded to the state government for consideration. Shantilal Kataria, national vice-president, Credai, said with Maharashtra reeling under the second wave of Covid, it had not been possible for many home buyers to meet the four-month deadline.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/pune/credai-seeks-four-months-extension-for-property-registration-fine-waiver/articleshow/82441171.cms||Nisha Nambiar
---||Madurai||Jasmine price dips to Rs 100/kg||Madurai: The price of Madurai jasmine flowers has dipped to Rs 100 a kg after its demand fell despite good production. Madurai flower market has been receiving 30 tonne of the flower daily. With temples being shut and Covid restrictions limiting the numbers of guests at weddings, demand for flowers has come down drastically. On Thursday, a kilogram of jasmine was sold for Rs 100 in the morning, Rs 80 in the evening while chendu malli and sampangi sold for Rs 10 a kg each, arali for Rs 30 and all other flowers did not find buyers even for Rs 10 a kg. This year, steps were taken to allow the market to function on its own market premises where the 400 shops had to regulate crowds and adhere to Covid SoPs. But, with the government imposing stricter restrictions, traders and farmers have been affected. S Palanisamy, a farmer from Usilamapatti, said this was the festive and marriage season. “This year the flower production has been good, but as temples are closed and marriages have been asked to limit crowds, the demand has come down and we are only able to sell a kilogram of very good buds for Rs 50,” he said. Coordinator of Madurai Flower Market Associations, S Ramachandran, said the time specified for markets from 6am to 12pm is also affecting them because farmers were not able to bring the flowers by 6am to the market and there were problems in transport as a result of which the prices are falling. “It would help if we could keep the market open till at least 3pm,” he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/madurai/jasmine-price-dips-to-rs-100/kg/articleshow/82441176.cms||---
---||Mumbai||Mumbai: CBI in court for Shukla’s phone tap records||Mumbai: The CBI has filed an application before the Esplanade court, seeking a pen drive from the Mumbai police with digital records related to the phone taps made by former police commissioner of state intelligence Rashmi Shukla. The application, invoking section 91 of the CrPC, is likely to be heard on Friday by an additional metropolitan magistrate. The provision deals with “summons to produce documents or other thing” that may be necessary for an investigation, inquiry or trial. The state is expected to be represented by special public prosecutor Ajay Misar. The Mumbai Cyber Cell, BKC, had registered an FIR on March 26 against unknown persons over “leaking’’ of Shukla’s confidential report dated August 20, 2020, on the alleged politician-police nexus on transfers and “powerful” postings. She has said her report is based on phone tap permissions granted by the official concerned from July 17, 2020, to July 29, 2020. While conducting a preliminary enquiry into allegations of corruption against former home minister Anil Deshmukh by former Mumbai police chief Param Bir Singh, CBI recorded Shukla’s statement on April 16 in Hyderabad, where she is now posted with the CRPF.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/mumbai-cbi-in-court-for-shuklas-phone-tap-records/articleshow/82444811.cms||---
---||Madurai||Madurai to get major portion of O2 from Sterlite plant, says collector||Madurai: The Madurai district administration has been assured that a major portion of the oxygen to be produced in the Sterlite plant in Tuticorin would be given to hospitals in Madurai and steps are being taken to meet the rising demand, district collector T Anbazhagan has said. As on May 6, about 400 patients on oxygen support in Madurai hail from other districts. Speaking to reporters after a review meeting with doctors and members of the Indian Medical Association (IMA) in Madurai on Thursday, the collector said that the demand and supply of medical oxygen for both government and private hospitals in Madurai, were revisited during the meeting. Compared to the first wave, the consumption of oxygen had increased by 300% as 20 to 30% of the patients required oxygen in the second wave. The two local industries that were manufacturing oxygen were producing 110% of their original capacity and working round-the-clock. These companies had been asked to regulate their distribution to the hospitals with which they had tied up to ensure that other hospitals could get some cylinders when there was a need, he added. The Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) has 1,100 beds with oxygen of which 1,000 were filled up as on Thursday. The collector said that the numbers were changing by the hour with new admissions and simultaneous discharges. He said that the oxygen storage facility at the GRH had a 26kl capacity of which 20kl was being used everyday. The facility was also adequately filled as per demand. The oxygen control room under the joint director of health and Inspector of factories would monitor the movement of supply in the district and ensure that the maximum number of patients were helped, he said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/madurai/madurai-to-get-major-portion-of-o2-from-sterlite-plant-says-collector/articleshow/82441178.cms||---
---||Coimbatore||As curbs kick in, city turns into ghost town||Coimbatore: On the first day of the new Covid-19 containment restrictions came into force on Thursday, the busy Cross Cut Road, 100 Feet Road, Big Bazaar Road, Oppanakkara Street and other commercial areas in the city wore a deserted look with almost all shops closed by noon.As many as 756 police personnel were deployed in the city to enforce the new restrictions.Tasmac outlets were teeming with customers from early morning as they could remain open only from 8am to noon.Though buses could operate with 50% passengers, most buses plied with less than 50% of passengers.Only 50% of government employees came for work.Ukkadam fish market secretary Jaffar Ali said that the fish market shops were following the Covid-19 norms strictly.“We are cooperating with the state government to control the spread of Covid-19. Our business started around 10am and we closed it at noon. We were not able to earn enough in the two hours business and we were struggling to provide salary to our staff. We are requesting the state government to increase the timing,” Jaffar Ali said.“We did not register any case as all the shops were closed by noon,” said G Stalin, Deputy Commissioner of Police (law&order), Coimbatore city.City corporation commissioner Kumaravel Pandian inspected a vegetable market at Ramar Kovil street at Ukkadam. He also visited grocery shops, rice shops, bakeries on Range Gowder Street, Big Bazaar Street, TK Market, Raja Street and Karuppagounder Street.He imposed a fine of Rs 200 each for 11 people for not wearing face masks and imposed Rs 500 each to two shopkeepers for failing to maintain social distancing among their customers.Grocery, fish and meat shops were opened from 6am to noon. Hotels saw brisk business in take-away (parcel) service.Petrol bunks and medical shops functioned as usual while milk supply went off smoothly in the city.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/coimbatore/as-curbs-kick-in-city-turns-into-ghost-town/articleshow/82442824.cms||---
---||Lucknow||Only 5% found positive in 69,000 tests in rural areas of Uttar Pradesh||LUCKNOW: Out of the 69,474 people, who underwent rapid antigen test in rural Uttar Pradesh, 3,551 or a little over 5% were found positive. The five-day testing campaign, being carried out across the state’s 97,000 revenue villages, is taking place in the aftermath of the panchayat polls and amid reports of rising Covid-19 cases in villages. Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that teams would visit every single home and check people for symptoms, isolating those who test positive and ensure that they are given medicines. “To prevent the spread of novel coronavirus spread in rural UP, a mass testing drive has been launched in villages. Teams are going to all houses to provide treatment and counsel patients. Door-to-door screening and testing is being done by monitoring committees,” said a government spokesperson. The teams have been asked to arrange tele-consultation for patients with doctors. If required, the government said, the teams would provide proper medical facilities to patients. “Members of the monitoring committee and rapid response teams are starting work from early morning itself. The five-day campaign aims at identifying people with Covid symptoms in villages and getting them hospitalized. For this, members of the monitoring committees and RRTs have been provided medical kits and antigen test kits. During the campaign, the teams will be checking the oxygen level of people using a pulse oximeter and conducting other tests to know the health status of villagers,” said the spokesperson.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/lucknow/only-5-found-positive-in-69k-tests-in-rural-areas/articleshow/82444772.cms||---
---||Delhi||Weather Takes Mercy As Covid Shows None||New Delhi: The capital saw light rain on Thursday with parts recording a brief, but intense spell of rain, accompanied by gusty winds touching 50 km/hr in places. Overcast skies were seen post the afternoon, leading to eventual showers at some locations. Safdarjung, Delhi’s base station recorded 0.4mm rainfall till 5.30pm, while Najafgarh, at 2.5mm, received the most rain during the day, a Met official said. IMD has forecast clear skies for Friday, with another rain spell only to return on May 10. “With western disturbance bringing rain to the northern plains on Thursday, clear skies are expected to return. In the next three days, Delhi will record no rain and the mercury may again touch 40-41 degrees Celsius, before light rain returns on May 11,” said the official. Delhi recorded a maximum of 39.8 degrees Celsius on Thursday — one degree above normal. The warmest location in the city was Najafgarh, with a high of 40.3 degrees Celsius. While Aya Nagar received 0.6mm rainfall till 5.30pm, Lodhi Road and Palam saw 0.2 and 0.7mm rainfall, respectively, during the same period. Narela received 2mm rainfall. With a maximum temperature of 38 degrees Celsius, IMD officials said the cooling effect from these showers would be limited, but was likely to be seen on Friday. “The maximum and minimum will both fall by around 1-2 degrees Celsius compared with Thursday. However, clear skies will push mercury back up again,” said the Met official. Delhi’s air quality, meanwhile, was in the “moderate” category with an overall Air Quality Index (AQI) of 156 on Thursday. SAFAR, a forecasting body under Union ministry of earth sciences, said further improvement on account of rain and ventilation was likely on Friday. “Surface winds are moderate and easterly in direction. SAFAR’s model forecasts moderately faster wind speed for the next 24 hours. Isolated thunderstorms are likely for the next two days, hence, the AQI is likely to stay in the ‘moderate’ category on Friday,” said SAFAR.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/weather-takes-mercy-as-covid-shows-none/articleshow/82442852.cms||टाइम्स न्यूज़ नेटवर्क
---||Coimbatore||2,068 fresh Covid cases take tally to 88,342||Coimbatore: The district recorded 2,068 fresh Covid-19 cases on Thursday, taking the total number of cases to 88,342. This is the second day in a row that the district is recording more than 2,000 cases. Though 1,551 people were discharged, the number of active cases inched close to 10,000-mark at 9,845. The district recorded four deaths due to the virus, taking the toll to 740. The deaths included a 77-year-old man, who died 10 days after hospitalization and a 42-year-old man, who died eight days after hospitalization. Both did not have comorbidities. The other two victims were a 46-year-old man with heart problems and a 50-year-old hypertensive man, who died due to bilateral bronchopneumonia.The district began facing an acute shortage of oxygen, especially in private hospitals, which depend on gaseous oxygen from cylinders.Ganga Hospital, which planned to increase allotment of beds to Covid-19 patients, told the district administration that while they can give more beds with oxygen facilities, oxygen is in shortage. “They have asked us for our requirement and told us they’ll arrange for supplies,” said chairman of the hospital’s orthopedic and spine surgery ward, Dr S Rajasekaran. In GH, two nasal cannula are being connected to one high-flow oxygen source to split it for two patients, so more people can get oxygen, sources said.The TNEGA website showed that 23 ICU beds were available on Thursday. However, ICU beds in major hospitals, including Coimbatore Medical College Hospital, ESI Medical College and Hospital and all private hospitals were full. The only locations where ICU beds were available were in suburban GHs including Madukkarai, Sulur, Annur, Mettupalayam and Pollachi district headquarters hospital.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/coimbatore/2068-fresh-covid-cases-take-tally-to-88342/articleshow/82442838.cms||---

---||Vadodara||Smaller govt hospitals get oxygen plants||Vadodara: While the Centre and state wasted its breath trading barbs over oxygen plant approvals, there were some who acted with urgency ensuring they had such plants in time and were able to breathe easy. They will soon be almost self-reliant when it comes to oxygen requirement for hospitals. Hospitals saw a major surge in the demand and, as a consequence, shortage of oxygen since last month. While many plants were approved last year and a fresh lot of plants got approved for the states only recently, hospitals started to panic in search of uninterrupted oxygen supply. As things became difficult, some, however, found a way out by making their own arrangements albeit with help from elected representatives. Like, the Cottage Hospital or the general hospital in Lunawada in Mahisagar district which has a capacity of 45 oxygen support beds of which, most are occupied. Work on the plant is nearly over and is expected to start operations anytime soon. Mahisagar district collector RB Barad said that there were no suppliers or plant of oxygen in the district. “Given this situation, we decided to have a small plant of our own. We placed an order for the plant on April 10,” said Barad. The project became possible due to funds under the Member of Parliament Local Area Development (MPLAD) grants. According to Barad, the plant will produce 140 litres of oxygen per minute. “This is sufficient for the 25 to 30 patients at the hospital. We also have a backup of 70 to 80 large cylinders to ensure that there is sufficient oxygen if needed,” he said. The plant came up at a cost of Rs 25 lakh. A similar plant has been proposed in Godhra in Panchmahal district at the Godhra Civil Hospital. Like most places even this town was facing difficulties in arranging oxygen despite Panchmahal district having plants manufacturing oxygen. The plants, however, have to cater to other districts. Godhra MLA C K Raulji has proposed that a plant should come up in the civil hospital. He added that a funding of Rs 22 lakh should be made from his development grants for the project. Raulji has sought that the nod for the project should be given at the earliest. A vendor has quoted Rs 25.96 lakh for the project. Officials said that those who acted in time like the Mahisagar district administration were at an advantage as their plants were commissioned in time. Others may have to wait a longer time and the plants may also cost higher.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vadodara/smaller-govt-hospitals-get-oxygen-plants/articleshow/82439357.cms||Sachin Sharma
---||Ranchi||50k disabled suffer as govt stops pension amid curbs||Ranchi: Thirty-two-year-old Ormanjhi village resident Rajesh Kumar, who has a disabled leg, is finding it difficult to make his ends meet owing to a lack of job and non-disbursal of the government disability pension last few months. His wife, who worked as a maid, has also lost her job making it difficult for them to sustain their family of four. Kumar is not alone. Thousands of disabled persons like him are facing several financial crises during the lockdown in the state after the government stopped their monthly pension of Rs. 1,000 for the past several months. To mitigate the crisis soon, the Jharkhand Viklang Manch (JVM), an umbrella group for disabled people, headquartered in Jamshedpur, had written a letter to chief minister Hemant Soren appealing him to release the monthly pensions. The government has assured to release the pension soon. Talking to TOI, JVM president Arun Kumar Singh said, “While everyone is talking about migrants, poor people and other marginalised groups, there is none to raise the problems faced by the disabled in Jharkhand at a time when they are also reeling under the pandemic. Since September-October last year, the state government has stopped the monthly disabled pension to beneficiaries. We urge the state government to release the pension immediately.” The Centre and the state government run two disabled pension schemes simultaneously but a beneficiary is entitled to avail only one of the two schemes under which he or she will get Rs 1,000 per month. According to Singh, there are about two-lakh beneficiaries of the schemes in the state. Though the total number of persons, who are unable to get the pension couldn’t be ascertained, Singh said roughly put the number to over 50,000 people. He said the pension was stopped suddenly by the government, citing various reasons like lack of funds, delay in document verification and non-release of funds by the Centre among others. Singh added, "We appeal to the state government to release the pension immediately irrespective of the hurdles, which can be sorted out later on like the announcement of ration for those without ration cards. The disabled people must too get their pensions whether the document verification is pending or not.” The women and child development and social security minister, Joba Manjhi, who is the JMM MLA from West Singbhum, assured that funds will be released soon. “The department is aware of the problem and funds will be released very soon now,” she told TOI.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ranchi/50k-disabled-suffer-as-govt-stops-pension-amid-curbs/articleshow/82441056.cms||ASRP Mukesh
---||Ranchi||Ranchi: Rims sets up 327 oxygen beds at multi-level parking lot||RANCHI: In a first in Jharkhand, Ranchi’s Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (Rims) made operational a Covid-19 ward with 327 oxygen supported beds at its newly built multi-level parking facility on the campus. Another ward with of 128 oxygen beds was inaugurated at the Rims’ old building and a 73-bed Covid ICU facility was commissioned at the hospital’s oncology wing. The three new facilities became functional on Thursday. “I had an opportunity to visit these facilities while they were being built. The Rims management and the agencies concerned have done a great job. To set up such facilities within 12-15 days is no mean feat,” chief minister Hemant Soren said after virtually inaugurating the facilities from his home in Kanke Road. The parking lot was inaugurated in late 2019, but was lying unused. With the new facilities, the total bed capacity at Rims for Covid 19 patients increased to 1,191. “The number of beds is much higher than what we had during the first wave last year. We are hopeful to add another 108 oxygen beds with the help of NTPC (National Thermal Power Corporation) very soon. Our endeavor is to see that no patient is turned back because shortage of beds,” Rims director Dr Kameshwar Prasad said. Notably, Rims had 260 Covid beds during the first wave of the pandemic last year. On April 19, the number was increased to 663. “After Thursday’s inauguration, we will have around 850 oxygen beds and 250 beds equipped with ventilators,” Prasad added. Health minister Banna Gupta said the parking lot was zeroed for setting up a Covid facility as it was lying unused since its inauguration. The facility will be provided oxygen cylinders while the other two facilities will receive oxygen from the hospital’s central supply line. Jharkhand had a little over 10,000 Covid beds in the beginning of May statewide. Of them, nearly 6,000 are oxygen supported. While 220 oxygen supported beds were inaugurated by Soren in Koderma on Wednesday, another 500-bed facility at Itki Sanitorium is in the pipeline. On Wednesday, Jharkhand high court asked the state to to set up 300 oxygen supported beds at Ranchi Sadar hospital within 10 days. “We will increase beds in keeping with the growing demands,” Soren said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ranchi/rims-sets-up-327-oxygen-beds-at-multi-level-parking-lot/articleshow/82441035.cms||Dhritiman Ray

---||Ranchi||Jharkhand: MLAs demand free Covid treatment for all||RANCHI: At least two lawmakers from Jharkhand — Jamtara MLA Irfan Ansari and Silli MLA Sudesh Mahto — on Thursday demanded free treatment for Covid-19 patients in both government and private hospitals. Notably, the Andhra Pradesh government recently decided to provide free treatment to all Covid patients in government and affiliated hospitals and also capped the rates in private hospitals. Last year, the Jharkhand government, too, had capped rates for treatment at private hospitals. However, allegations of over pricing and violations of rate-cap surfaced from time to time. While the state is currently rattled by a four-digit spike in fresh infections on a daily basis coupled with 100-plus deaths per day since the last one week, several patients across different districts continue to struggle for timely admission into hospitals due to paucity of beds or other medical resources. In Ranchi and other parts of the state, reports of ‘medical loot’— be it for Covid testing, availing ambulance and beds, among others — are also surfacing unabated through social media despite state government’s efforts to curb them. To prevent the poor and commoners from getting fleeced while seeking treatment, both the lawmakers have separately appealed to chief minister Hemant Soren to consider implementing the Andhra model for Covid treatment. Talking to TOI, Irfan, who is also a co-working president of the state Congress unit, said that he has also written a letter to Soren in the morning and have spoken to chief secretary Sukhdev Singh and health secretary Arun Kumar Singh to place his demand. “Being an MLA of the ruling coalition government, I demand that free treatment for Covid-19 be provided to all. These are unprecedented times and the government must walk an extra mile to save lives like Andhra Pradesh,” said Ansari speaking over the phone. He added that he will soon speak to the CM personally on the issue. Notably, the state government has been raising the issue of funds crunch since assuming charge in December 2019. The outbreak of Covid-19 coupled with the lockdown further dented the state’s resources due to halt in economic activities. Even as the state could steer the wheels of economic activities, the second wave of the pandemic has unleashed mayhem since March this year. Ansari’s party president and state’s finance minister Rameshwar Oraon on Wednesday said that the state’s revenues have fallen short by more than 50% in the current fiscal. Ansari, however, said that money shouldn’t be an issue to save lives of the people. He added, “Those who are influential and have money are able to get treatment in big private hospitals and command all the resources but it is the poor and commoners who are facing all kinds of problems. The state government is trying hard to increase beds and other facilities, but even the poor have the right to get treatment in private hospitals but they can’t afford it due to exorbitant rates.” Former deputy CM and Ajsu Party chief Sudesh Mahto said that the second wave of Covid-19 has become so virulent that it was infecting family members at one go, unlike the case during the first wave. “A family can think of affording treatment if one person is infected, but the way the virus has spread its wings this time in Jharkhand, entire families are getting affected. Can a poor or a middle-class person afford treatment for all at one go? The situation is such that due to the pandemic and resultant joblessness, it has become difficult for people to run their homes, forget affording treatment. Therefore, the government must announce free treatment both at private and government hospitals like it has been done in Andhra Pradesh,” said Mahto, who shot a letter separately to Soren.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ranchi/mlas-demand-free-cov-treatment-for-all/articleshow/82440927.cms||ASRP Mukesh
---||Ranchi||Jharkhand: Banquets’ coffers empty as many cancel weddings||RANCHI: With scores of families postponing marriage ceremonies due to Covid-19 pandemic, banquet owners have suffered heavy losses this season. Notably, there was heavy booking of banquet halls at the beginning of the year when Covid pandemic had slowed down. The banquet hall owners were hoping for a profit after a gap of almost a year. However, as cases shot up in the wake of second wave, many have started postponing their marriage functions. Vishwajit Paul of Hotel Palk Street said, “After the hotel business, the banquet hall trade has been badly hit due to Covid-19. All bookings of my banquet hall have been postponed. People have cancelled their bookings for various reasons. Some cited Covid as the cause while other said that they would like their function to be a grand occasion which is not possible under the current restrictions imposed by the government. Several families were facing travelling bottlenecks.” Asked about the future of the trade, Paul said that everything depends on the Covid situation. He added that, at present, the most important factor was to save oneself and one’s family members.  Notably, several other hotels including Royal Retreat also reported near total cancellation of the booking for marriages. Sudhir Chopra of Yuvraj Palace said that 80% of bookings at his banquet hall was cancelled due to Covid since April. He added that even though the government has fixed an upper limit of 50 guests for weddings, the actual number of guests being invited to marriages was even less. Chopra said, “The banquet business is in a very bad shape for the past one year not only in Ranchi but also all over the country.”||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ranchi/banquets-coffers-empty-as-many-cancel-weddings/articleshow/82440850.cms||---

---||Ranchi||Jharkhand: Dalma sanctuary sets up nursery to provide livelihood to locals||JAMSHEDPUR: Foresters at the Dalma Wildlife Sanctuary (DWS) have launched a drive to develop a nursery of 50,000 saplings to rejuvenate the green cover and to provide an earning opportunity to dwellers living in the foothill villages amid the Covid-19 pandemic that has rendered many daily wagers jobless. DFO Abhishek Kumar said, "We will employ from the local villagers in the nursery and are expecting to generate 250 man-days. At least 150 families will get the opportunity to earn from the nursery." According to Kumar, a worker could earn Rs 300 per day from the nursery which will have 50,000 saplings of various trees like sal, arjun, karanj, teak, fruits and bamboo. He said, "Plantation in and around the sanctuary with the saplings from the nursery would commence from June when the monsoon starts. Therefore, the nursery has to be ready before June." "The plantation would commence in June with the onset of the monsoon and by then we have to make the nursery ready," Kumar said. Kumar added that pockets like Hansada, Saherbera, Somadih, Dangdum, Lailam, Koira and Dangardih among others which form part of the 192 sqkm forest area of the sanctuary will be covered under the plantation drive. According to foresters, the addition of bamboo saplings in the drive is to check incidents of wild elephants entering into human habitation. They said the drive would be conducted during the pandemic when no visitors would arrive at the sanctuary. Over and above the workers at the nursery, the work of 70 forest watchers who were employed on a daily basis since last year would be extended. "During this period when many people were losing their jobs, we decided to extend the service of the forest watchers so that they have a source of livelihood," Kumar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ranchi/dalma-sanctuary-sets-up-nursery-to-provide-livelihood-to-locals/articleshow/82441113.cms||B Sridhar

---||Jamshedpur||Jharkhand: Dalma sanctuary sets up nursery to provide livelihood to locals||JAMSHEDPUR: Foresters at the Dalma Wildlife Sanctuary (DWS) have launched a drive to develop a nursery of 50,000 saplings to rejuvenate the green cover and to provide an earning opportunity to dwellers living in the foothill villages amid the Covid-19 pandemic that has rendered many daily wagers jobless. DFO Abhishek Kumar said, "We will employ from the local villagers in the nursery and are expecting to generate 250 man-days. At least 150 families will get the opportunity to earn from the nursery." According to Kumar, a worker could earn Rs 300 per day from the nursery which will have 50,000 saplings of various trees like sal, arjun, karanj, teak, fruits and bamboo. He said, "Plantation in and around the sanctuary with the saplings from the nursery would commence from June when the monsoon starts. Therefore, the nursery has to be ready before June." "The plantation would commence in June with the onset of the monsoon and by then we have to make the nursery ready," Kumar said. Kumar added that pockets like Hansada, Saherbera, Somadih, Dangdum, Lailam, Koira and Dangardih among others which form part of the 192 sqkm forest area of the sanctuary will be covered under the plantation drive. According to foresters, the addition of bamboo saplings in the drive is to check incidents of wild elephants entering into human habitation. They said the drive would be conducted during the pandemic when no visitors would arrive at the sanctuary. Over and above the workers at the nursery, the work of 70 forest watchers who were employed on a daily basis since last year would be extended. "During this period when many people were losing their jobs, we decided to extend the service of the forest watchers so that they have a source of livelihood," Kumar said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/jamshedpur/dalma-sanctuary-sets-up-nursery-to-provide-livelihood-to-locals/articleshow/82452422.cms||B Sridhar

---||India||Govt moves SC against Karnataka HC order on Oxygen||NEW DELHI: A day after the Karnataka high court directed the Centre to increase the daily liquid medical oxygen (LMO) allocation for the state to 1,200 MT from the present 962 MT per day, government rushed to the Supreme Court on Thursday against the HC order. A bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and M R Shah will take up Centre's plea on Friday. The government in its appeal contended that it is trying its best to meet the needs of various states and order passed by the HC would hamper its effort to ensure supply of oxygen to other states as per their requirements which would lead to complete collapse of the system. "It is most important to note that the entire nation is feeling the effects of the ongoing second wave of Covid-19 Coronavirus and in such a situation it is imperative that the limited resources available at the disposal of the entire nation (in this case, oxygen supply), be put to its most judicious use, keeping in mind the overall situation in the country. Thereby, passing directions in the nature and manner the HC has done, would ultimately lead to mismanagement of resources and create a further chaotic environment in an already overburdened system," the petition said. "The HC failed to consider the rationale behind allocation of certain amounts of oxygen to each state and purely on the basis of purported shortage in the city of Bangalore, passed directions which, if fulfilled, will have a cascading effect and result in the total collapse of the system in its fight against the ongoing second wave of Covid-19," the Centre said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/govt-moves-sc-against-karnataka-hc-order-on-oxygen/articleshow/82447845.cms||---
---||Vijayawada||APSRTC says no to transportation of sanitizers||TIRUPATI: At a time when Covid-19 cases are on the rise across the country and several states are opening up green channels to ensure hassle-free supply of vaccines, oxygen, medication, hand sanitizers and masks, APSRTC shocked distributors of hand sanitizers by refusing to book the cargo. The staff of the logistics point at the central RTC bus stand here said that they received an advisory from their superiors not to book any liquids as they were leaking during transit and causing damage to other products. Essential oils, cooking oils etc were also denied a booking by the counter staff on Tuesday. B Raghu, representative of a popular hand sanitizers brand, told TOI that the counter staff were unmindful of the fact that the hand sanitizers are an essential part of the fight against Covid-19. “The second wave is very serious. We are risking our lives and striving our best to supply hand sanitizers to even the remotest part of the district through APSRTC only as no other private transporter has such a connectivity. Now if APSRTC refuses to stop transportation of hand sanitizers, there will be a huge shortage of supply of sanitizers to medical shops in rural areas of Chittoor district which may lead to a spike in Covid-19 cases,” lamented the medical representative. When APSRTC Tirupati regional manager was contacted, he said he will speak to his superiors and take a policy decision. However, RP Thakur, vice-chairman and managing director of APSRTC, said that the APSRTC had not issued any such restrictions on supply of hand sanitizers or other liquid materials and that it was committed to the supply of every single legitimate product to the rural areas across the districts of Andhra Pradesh and other states at affordable prices.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vijayawada/apsrtc-says-no-to-transportation-of-sanitizers/articleshow/82441242.cms||Sandeep Raghavan

---||Vadodara||Parents’ masks delay babies’ smiling, cooing skills||Vadodara/Surat: New dad Nitin Parikh (name changed) started worrying when his six-month-old baby boy wasn’t responding to gestures and smile. He called up a paediatrician and the diagnosis left him stumped. The doctor told him that the Covid pandemic is having a totally different level of effect on babies, particularly those below two years of age. Masks are indeed a saviour from Covid-19 infection but the constant screen of parents’ and grandparents’ faces at home is adversely affecting the development of babies’ social milestones like smiling and cooing. Paediatricians across the state are unanimous about the adverse effect of face masks on the newborns’ social skills in the new normal. “The sensory stimulation among many kids below two years of age is missing. They are not able to understand the facial gestures quickly and their social milestones are also getting delayed by an average 2-3 months,” said Dr Tushar Shah, executive board member, Academy of Paediatrics Gujarat. “Since they were born and began to understand the world around, babies below two years are seeing everyone wearing face masks. They can’t see facial gestures like anger, laughter or joy when they meet anyone. Except at home, these kids see their parents too in face masks,” Shah told TOI. “Usually babies start smiling, cooing and responding to gestures after they turn three months old. But now these skills are getting delayed by a few months. I have been getting calls from worried parents over the last several months,” Shah, former secretary of Indian Medical Association (IMA) Vadodara, said. Experts said that lack of social interaction and strict home confinement is affecting their ability to integrate with the society. Doctors in Surat too have been getting calls from anxious parents having kids aged between six months and 18 months. “Every fifth day, we are getting a case wherein parents notice that their child’s interaction is problematic. Some babies are actually behaving like autistic kids,” said Dr Sanjeev Rao, a senior paediatrician in Surat. Parents noticed the delayed development of responses in their kids, said Rao, adding that masks are screening children from developing their skills in understanding or grasping facial gestures and emotions. Dr Shah further added that spending most of their time at home and hardly any interaction with outsiders have affected kids’ social and learning skills.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vadodara/parents-masks-delay-babies-smiling-cooing-skills/articleshow/82439469.cms||Tushar Tere

Many feel that they cannot take the vaccine because they have comorbidities when, infact, they should be the ones first in line to receive it,” a senior doctor said. But in villages people are still reluctant to take the vaccine. They believe the information they find on Whatsapp,” the officer said. ---||India||Ajit Singh: An IITian who was the face of Jat politics in UP||The best and the worst about Ajit Singh, veteran politician and scion of late Charan Singh, was that he was happy in his skin. He did not crave, or value, approvals or validation. It was a quality that made him his own man, a politician who managed to keep his hold for long over the "jatland" of west UP even as he was chided as a “political chameleon”. Singh (82),who passed away owing to Covid complications in the capital on Thursday, practically retired from politics after losing two consecutive elections in 2014 and 2019 in his erstwhile patch. At one time a constant in national and UP politics, Singh was a bundle of contradictions – an IIT computer engineer of 1960s who plunged into the rough and tumble of politics, a suave Jat who presided over a rugged region and its aggressive and empowered populace, a gentleman who just could not resist being “practical”. For a man who was a Lok Sabha MP from 1989 to 2014 with just one defeat in 1998 polls, and who held elite central ministries like Commerce and Industry, Agriculture, Food Processing and Civil Aviation under prime ministers as ideologically diverse as V P Singh, Narasimha Rao, Atal Bihari Vajpayee and Manmohan Singh, the CV is a testimony to political suppleness as well as a grassroots legacy. But the long career spanning is also largely a story of a legacy lost. A supporter in Baghpat once described him as “the man who shrank his mighty father Charan Singh’s legacy from six states to six districts”. Fissures in his loyal base had begun to surface over time, with fast changing age profile, aspirations and national political churn. The advent of Narendra Modi, his hard Hindutva and native appeal cleaved Singh’s longstanding Jat-Muslim combine, planting BJP in the region and sweeping aside Rashtriya Lok Dal. The post-2014 barren phase put to complete shade the farmer-OBCs politics that struck roots six decades ago. Now, Singh’s son Jayant, who has been leading the protests against the controversial farm laws over last months, faces a daunting challenge of reviving that faded appeal in an altered context. Some of the impermnance in Singh’s politics owed to the phase he was blooded in, with Lok Dal and its tendency to split. With time, he rubbed shoulders and crossed swords with satraps of the day, from Mulayam Singh Yadav to Devi Lal to R K Hegde to Deve Gowda to V P Singh. He stayed in parties, or formed them, like Lok Dal (A), JP, BKKP, RLD. Singh was a survivor, one who could on occasion acknowledge the cynicism of political choices, even as he knew that a shriveled base was good enough to make him important for any aspiring government -- until Modi ended that with a single party majority. But the slip was visible, as he gradually reduced to being a Jat leader. To stay relevant, he continued dabble in new projects to mobilise his base – like Harit Pradesh, farmers’s unity, Jat reservation. Singh goofed up in the wake of Muzaffarpur riots in 2013. With the Jats and Muslims clashing, some confidants urged him to visit the scarred region like the patron guardian. For some reason, Singh procrastinated, leaving the field open for the rising Modi campaign led by Amit Shah who was then party incharge of UP. The much delayed efforts to repair the alliance were perfunctory and, expectedly, fruitless. He never recovered from it. He lost in 2014 and 2019 polls. For some, it was to Singh’s credit that he voted against the Narasimha Rao government after the Babri mosque demolition. He, though, joined the government later. In the chequered career, a constant was with his bitter rivalry with Mulayam Singh Yadav. A rising star in the increasingly “Mandalising” political firmament of late 1980s, Yadav saw himself as Charan Singh’s political legatee but son Ajit Singh threw his hat in the ring but could never match the SP chief. Over the years, Yadav, in fits and starts, courted Singh and they managed a civil interaction that confounded observers. The heir apparents Akhilesh Yadav and Jayant Chaudhary revived the partnership by allying along with BSP, for 2019 LS polls, but to little gain.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/ajit-singh-an-iitian-who-was-the-face-of-jat-politics-in-up/articleshow/82447915.cms||Subodh Ghildiyal
---||Vijayawada||AP: Deaths in Covid wards put recovering patients on edge||AMARAVATI: A 30-year old, K Maheswari, resident of a remote village in Guntur district, was admitted to Government General Hospital (GGH), Guntur for Covid-19 treatment with acute respiratory trouble. Doctors struggled for ten days to treat her. Now, Maheswari keeps fainting and cries often. Perturbed at her condition, doctors initiated several rounds of discussions among each other and patients. They found that seeing people dying next to her has had a traumatic effect on the young woman. Doctors have started counselling her and are trying to discharge her at the earliest as she keeps pleading that she wants to go home and can’t bear to see any more deaths. Maheswari’s troubles are not hers alone. Many patients are slipping into trauma while recovering from the virus attack. “Doctors are advising full rest to recover early. It is very difficult to take rest while getting treated in a common ward as people keep complaining about one issue or the other,” said C K Murthy, a young IT professional recovering in a private hospital. The environment in Covid-19 hospitals is fast becoming traumatic for the survivors as they are forced to witness death almost every day. Patients are facing acute mental stress due to the increasing number of deaths in their wards. Although familes are not allowed in Covid-19 wards, many go inside to collect bodies while shouting and crying aloud. “Even the packing and shifting of the bodies from the neighbourhood is a frightening experience,” said Dr Anil Kumar, a physician in a Covid-19 hospital. Dr G Vijayasaradhi, a psychologist, said the government should take help from psychologists to handle the situation. He said ignoring the issue might pose more troubles in recovery of patients.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vijayawada/deaths-in-covid-wards-put-recovering-patients-on-edge/articleshow/82440852.cms||Samdani MN
---||Bhopal||Madhya Pradesh: Industries gasp for Oxygen, 50% units closed in Mandideep||BHOPAL: Barely five months ago, the industries had started operating normally like pre-Covid era, following months of lockdown- related restrictions. But following the Oxygen scarcity during the current pandemic surge, with O  diverted for medical use, industries are again in doldrums. With Covid lockdown clamped in most parts of the state, industrial areas are severely affected although industrial estates have been exempted from the lockdowns. “The production has been affected badly; 50 per cent industries have already shut down and remaining half have already reduced production to half,” said Rajeev Agrawal, president of All Industry Association of Mandideep Industrial area. He said, “Many industries have also shut down because the retail market is closed down and there is no point, dumping the production”. However, he went on to add that industrial sector stands firmly behind the society in these trying times. Amarjeet Singh, president of the Govindpura Industrial Area (GIA) also lamented, “More than10 per cent industries in Govindpura have shut down while hardly any production is taking place in the remaining units.” He said that food processing, pharma units and packaging industries are doing well. From December to mid -March ,the industries operated almost at normal level till the second wave struck. Many industries had started hiring mid -level and senior executives when the crisis started. again. During the current crisis, the production has been affected, but no company has so far retrenched any one, said industrialists. President of Federation of MP Chambers of Commerce and Industry Goswami said, “At this moment, we are not thinking in terms of profit, it is time to support the society.” </div><br/></div><div ---||Ahmedabad||Gujarat: They make the toughest calls informing death due to Covid||AHMEDABAD: Dr Gunjan Trivedi (name changed), a CMO at 1,200-bed hospital on Wednesday braced herself up yet again, as she dialled the number. She remained composed while starting her conversation with “I have a bad news for you. Be brave. Your father is no more. We tried our best to revive him, but as you know, he was critical”. “We are used to long pauses – most often, people take a long time to process the information. Then comes denial, despair and pain,” says Dr Trivedi, who is one of the four doctors who make the ‘most difficult call’ to the patients’ relatives. “The response often starts with, ‘He was well when we last talked to him’, but we have to appraise them of the health condition and listen to their side.” Hospital authorities too understand its psychological implications. A senior official told TOI that no person is given duty for more than two days at a stretch. “It’s not at all a mechanical process – they take some time between calls to regain their composure. Initial few days are most difficult as the caller experiences the entire spectrum of emotions – from complete denial and pleas to check again to resignation to fate,” said a senior official. Ahmedabad city is recording average deaths of 20 to 25 Covid patients daily for the past one month. On Thursday, the number dropped to16. Civil Hospital officials said that an SOP is already in place for the callers to avoid any medico-legal issues later. All have different mechanisms to beat the blues, said the doctors. The shifts change fast at A0 ward where the dead body management team works closely with other parts of the Covid care system. Civil Hospital officials said that an SOP is already in place for the callers to avoid any medico-legal issues later The authorities refused to divulge the number of deaths in a day, but accepted that the volume has increased compared to January-February. “I have lost two members of my extended family. I can understand the pain one feels – but kin don't deserve any delay. The initial calls were the most difficult calls I made in my life,” said another junior doctor associated with the process. Doctors on call duty say they practice some sort of yoga or wellness regime to keep themselves physically and mentally upbeat. “We also unwind by viewing comedy or dance shows. It also turns some into more extroverted persons, trying to connect with other family members more often than pre-Covid times.” The team members said that they turn more sympathetic towards the families and try to expedite the process to reduce their trauma. “In the first wave, there were a few instances where none came to claim the body out of stigma or all members of the family getting infected. But this time around, the stigma is less. We have not reported any unclaimed body so far,” said a doctor. Dr Neelam Kapadia, CMO of the Covid control room, said she has made regular calls to her family members who test Corona positive. "We make calls connecting with hundreds on a daily basis for their requirements ranging from oxygen to food. We have also seen how a video call with a family member completely lights up a patient. This taught me to connect more with my ailing relatives," said Dr Kapadia, adding that he got recuperated from the infection.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/ahmedabad/gujarat-they-make-the-toughest-calls-informing-death-due-to-covid/articleshow/82447930.cms||Parth Shastri
---||India||Haven't got O2 as per pact, just one day's stock left: TN in HC||CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu has just one day's liquid medical oxygen stock left, and the issue has reached a critical point in the state, officials told Madras high court on Thursday. The state's health department brass told the court that while 25MT of oxygen is being diverted from Sriperumbudur to Andhra Pradesh or Telangana, the 40MT it was supposed to get in return from Palakkad in Kerala has not come. "Officials say it is a critical situation and the reserves have been used up to the extent that there may be a further day's reserve," said the first bench, recording the state's precarious oxygen situation. "The Union and the empowered committee should take immediate steps in such regard to ensure adequate supply of oxygen to Tamil Nadu to meet the needs. This must be ensured by tomorrow. The Sterlite unit is unlikely to produce oxygen till next week," the bench of Chief Justice Sanjib Banerjee and Justice Senthilkumar Ramamoorthy said on Thursday. During hearing, health department officials said a meeting was held on May 2 involving officials from Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Tamil Nadu, central government representatives and manufacturers, at which a consensus was arrived that 475MT of oxygen would be released to Tamil Nadu daily. The officials complained that notwithstanding the meeting, no allocation order had been issued for Tamil Nadu till date. As against the daily requirement of about 450MT per day, the Central allocation remained 280MT since last week. As for availability of Remdesivir, officials told the court that at the behest of the DMK government set to assume charge on Friday, Remdesivir centres are being set up in other major cities, including Madurai and Coimbatore, for release of the drug directly to private hospitals or patients. Till April, Tamil Nadu had been allocated 1.35 lakh units of Remdesivir against the order placed of 2.5 lakh units, they said, adding that about 24,000 units had been distributed from the Kilpauk Medical College centre upon documents being produced.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/havent-got-o2-as-per-pact-just-one-days-stock-left-tn-in-hc/articleshow/82447929.cms||Srikkanth D
---||Amaravati||AP: Criminal cases against 6 hospitals for irregularities in Covid treatment||AMARAVATI: The vigilance and enforcement department booked criminal cases against six hospitals for irregularities in handling Covid-19 treatment to patients in the state. The department also recommended cancellation of permission to one hospital for providing treatment to Covid-19 patients. KV Rajendranath Reddy, director general (vigilance and enforcement), on Thursday said flying squads set up for monitoring irregularities in treatment of Covid-19 patients continued inspection of hospitals in the last two days and found several irregularities in six hospitals. He said the teams have inspected 30 hospitals so far and booked the managements of six hospitals. “Certain hospitals among those inspected are found to be indulging in charging patients excessively beyond approved limits, denying/discouraging treatment under Arogya Sri for eligible patients and misappropriating Remdesivir injections allotted,” said Rajendrantha Reddy. He said the teams found violations in pharmacies attached to the hospitals including not maintaining prescribed registers, sale bills and invoices. He said criminal cases were registered against the management of five hospitals under relevant sections of IPC, Disaster Management Act and Drugs and Cosmetics Act and action is initiated against one hospital for revoking permission granted to treat Covid-19 patients. Permission granted to the City Care hospital in Kadapa to provide treatment to Covid-19 patients has been suspended for not issuing bills to the patients for payments made by them. Managements of Palnadu Hospital and Anjireddy Hospital in Piduguralla were booked under section 188, 420 of IPC and Section 51(a) of Disaster Management Act for charging excessively than the prescribed rates. Subhashini Hospital in Chittoor was booked under section 420 of IPC and Section 51(a) of Disaster Management Act for discouraging treatment under Arogyasri. Similarly, Vedanta Hospital in Vijayawada was booked under section 188, 420, 269 of IPC and Section 51(a) of Disaster Management Act for admitting Covid patients without permission and making patients to procure Remdesivir vials on their own. Criminal cases were booked against Suryamukhi Hospital of Srikakulam after noticing misappropriation of Remdesivir.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/amaravati/criminal-cases-against-6-hospitals-for-irregularities-in-covid-treatment/articleshow/82440996.cms||Samdani MN

---||Bhopal||Nothing positive in it: When worst fears came true in testing times||BHOPAL: It was April 17, Saturday (my day off from office), when my worst fear appeared to have come true — I had light fever. In the last one year, on several occasions I had felt as if I had contracted the deadly virus—due to sore throat, coughing, feeling feverish or loose motions— but the feeling or fear was not so credible as this time round. The horrible pictures of what was happening to Covid-19 patients in hospitals due to lack of requisite facilities like Oxygen cylinders or ventilators and the manner in which dead among them were being cremated or buried in hordes as seen and read in media and social media platforms started coming to my mind even as I thought what to do next. Testing was the obvious answer. Meanwhile, one of my friends, whom I had asked to find out about private facilities carrying out RT PCR tests called up to say that Bansal hospital would have been the best place but they have also stopped testing from today itself. By this time, prescription of medicines had arrived from my friend in administration. Apart from medicines like Azithromycin, Sumo 300, vitamin C and multivitamin tablets, he was recommended by his doctor friend to take Prednisolone (a steroid), 39 mg for the first three days and then 20 mg and then 10 mg in the following six days to keep the lungs intact. He wrote take Sumo when you have fever and Prednisolone, when you are coughing a lot. However, I took Azithromycin and Sumo that night besides a host of Ayurvedic and herbal preparations. Next day, in the afternoon, I called one of my friend, an officer in Mantralaya, who had contracted infection along with his wife and son and asked him to send someone for test. He said “I know someone. But, he only does Rapid Antigen test and will charge Rs 800 for that.” I said let him charge Rs1000 but ask him to come to my place. After a while someone called up on my mobile and said, “I am sending someone to do the test but we shall not be able to give you the report or receipt of the test. He will show you the result there itself.” I asked him to send over his man. Within 10 minutes, a young boy on his bike arrived, took my swab sample, did something outside even as my wife and I prayed that the test report were negative. But, it was not to be. He came inside after a few minutes and said “You are positive, sir.” He took me outside to explain how had he deduced that I was positive but I was hardly listening to him. I only knew I was “positive”.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/bhopal/nothing-positive-in-it-when-worst-fears-came-true-in-testing-times/articleshow/82447933.cms||---

---||Vijayawada||Increase Covid bed strength in hospitals: Jagan tells officials||Vijayawada: Chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy has asked officials to increase Covid beds in both government and private hospitals across the state. Jagan, who reviewed the pandemic situation at his Tadepalli camp office on Thursday, told officials to ensure that every patient is admitted for treatment even if there are no beds. Stating that the state has created a new record in conducting Covid-19 tests, the chief minister said 50% of beds should be allotted to Arogyasri patients in temporary empanelled hospitals and non-empanelled hospitals notified by district collectors. He directed officials to empanel the notified hospitals temporarily and allot beds. “Treatment should be provided free of cost in all hospitals empanelled for Covid treatment under Arogyasri scheme,” the CM said. Explaining the process of functioning of 104 toll-free call centre, he said when a call is made, the message should be immediately sent to the district, depending on the location of the patient. “The collector and district administration should respond immediately and admit patients in the respective hospitals. Medical services should be provided completely free of cost to Covid patients,” he reiterated. Jagan said food quality, sanitation, oxygen, medical care and availability of doctors are important in Covid hospitals and instructed officials to recruit doctors on temporary basis if necessary. He also wanted them to ensure supply and storage of oxygen in all hospitals. “Teaching hospitals should have 10 kilo litres storage capacity and other hospitals should have 1kl storage capacity of oxygen,” he said. Principal secretary (health) Anil Kumar Singhal said the government is exploring all options to increase the production of oxygen. “As of now, six plants are producing around 25 tonnes of oxygen in the state. Six more plants will soon start production. All plants together can produce around 76 tonnes of gaseous oxygen in the state in the next few days,” he said. The government has been transporting around 472 metric tonnes of liquid oxygen daily, he said. “We have decided to purchase 25 cryogenic tankers to boost the transport of liquid oxygen. We are also in the process to procure 10 oxygen concentrators,” Singhal informed.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vijayawada/increase-covid-bed-strength-in-hospitals-jagan-tells-officials/articleshow/82441043.cms||Gopi Dara

---||Visakhapatnam||Over 20,000 Covid-19 cases in Andhra Pradesh three days in a row||VISAKHAPATNAM: Andhra Pradesh reported 21,954 new Covid-19 cases on Thursday, taking the cumulative caseload to 12,28,186. This is the third day in a row that the state has recorded over 20,000 daily cases. The death toll increased to 8,446 as 72 more people succumbed to the disease. As many as 11 patients died in Visakhapatnam, nine patients each died in East Godavari and Vizianagaram districts, eight in Anantapur, six in Prakasam, five each in Chittoor, West Godavari and Guntur districts, four each in Krishna, Kurnool and Srikakulam districts and two in Nellore district. East Godavari reported 3,531 new infections (highest in the state on Thursday), followed by Chittoor (2,354), Visakhapatnam (2,107), Srikakulam (1,939), Kurnool (1,920), Anantapur (1,871), Prakasam (1,666), Guntur (1,348), Nellore (1,292), Vizianagaram (1,160), YSR Kadapa (1,130), West Godavari (1,088) and Krishna (548). As many as 10,141 patients were declared cured on Thursday. There are currently 1,82, 329 active Covid-19 cases with 10,37,411 cumulative recoveries and 8,446 fatalities. The recovery rate has dropped to 84.46 per cent from the peak of over 99 per cent in February. Andhra Pradesh conducted 1,10,147 Covid-19 samples and detected 21,954 new cases, translating to a positivity rate of 19.93 per cent. ---||Vijayawada||HC suspends PCB’s closure order to battery plant in Chittoor district||Vijayawada: The high court on Thursday suspended the closure orders given by AP state pollution control board to Amararaja batteries limited (ABL), terming it arbitrary in nature as the said order was passed without adverting to the reply given by the company to rectify any irregularities found. The APSPCB had given closure orders to the battery manufacturing plant situated near Karakambadi village, under Renigunta mandal in Chittoor district, after it found the environmental pollution caused by the plant to be in excess of prescribed limits. Power supply to the company was also withdrawn following the order. ABL then moved the high court challenging the closure order through its authorised signatory Nugula Gopinatha Rao, DGM in the environmental engineering division of the company. Arguing on behalf of ABL, senior counsel B Adinarayana Rao told the bench comprising Justice Joy Malya Bagchi and Justice M Ganga Rao that the plant has been following international standards as per as environmental protection is concerned. “There has been a dispute over the manner in which APSPCB arrived at the conclusion that ambient air quality is polluted. There are certain procedures to calculate ambient air quality as prescribed by the Union government which is followed by ABL,” he said, contending the method in which APSPCB conducted inspections to decide that ambient air is polluted beyond permissible limits. When it comes to workplace air quality, there are no set guidelines in India but ABL has been following American standards, Rao said, adding that ambient air quality is different from workplace air quality. He further said the closure order was given without even asking them an explanation or giving them the reports of pollution control board’s findings. Arguing on behalf of APSPCB, senior counsel C V Mohan Reddy said the inspections were conducted twice and the reports were alarming. They found lead in adjacent water bodies, in wastewater effluents and even in the blood samples collected from employees and people living in nearby villages. He further said that concentration of lead in blood stream can cause serious health problems to humans as well as animals. After hearing both sides, the HC bench said the APSPCB findings are significant and need to be addressed. “At the same time, the company’s operations should also continue as people take enormous risks in setting up industries which are the driving force of our economy. As the ABL has been running its operations for a considerable period of time, there is no justification on the part of the APSPCB to give a closure order without giving it an opportunity to rectify the deficiencies raised in the show-cause notice,” said Justice Bagchi. Stating that a balance has to be achieved between environmental protection and running of industries without compromising each other, the high court suspended the closure order with the condition that ABL shall take steps to rectify the deficiencies by June 15 and the APSPCB shall conduct another inspection by duly giving prior notice. The inspection report should be submitted to the court before the next date of hearing on June 28, the bench said, and also directed the electricity department to restore power supply to the plant. APSPCB had given closure orders to the battery manufacturing plant after it found the environmental pollution caused by the plant to be in excess of prescribed limits||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/vijayawada/hc-suspends-pcbs-closure-order-to-battery-plant-in-chittoor-district/articleshow/82441174.cms||Srikanth Aluri
---||Kolkata||Accept mandate, let us do Covid work: Bengal CM to Centre||KOLKATA: Learn how to accept people’s mandate with humility, Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee appealed to the Centre and the BJP on Thursday, requesting them to let the new state government work on Covid containment measures and alleging that central ministers were coming to Bengal to engineer communal riots. “We were sworn in at 10.45 am on Wednesday, the first stern letter from the Centre reached us at 7 pm the same evening and a central team arrived on Thursday morning. Did central teams ever come to ask about oxygen and vaccine shortage? We wish the Centre was similarly proactive when Hathras (gang-rape) happened and riots took place in Delhi or UP,” she added. Banerjee announced Rs 2 lakh as compensation for the next of kin of 16 people who died in post-poll violence, “most of them before May 3, when the model poll code of conduct was in force and law-and-order was under the Election Commission”. “I know money cannot bring back those who have died but this will provide some relief to the bereaved families,” she said. One of the dead was a Sanjukta Morcha supporter and the rest were from the BJP and the Trinamool Congress. “All next of kin, irrespective of religion, caste, community and political party, will be compensated,” she added. Banerjee then appealed to the Centre and the BJP: “Accept people’s mandate. Allow us to work on Covid now. We do not want to quarrel with you now.” “Let good sense prevail. A lot of fake videos are in circulation. Stop instigating people. A fake video was sent to me on Wednesday night showing a woman being assaulted. Later, it turned out to be a dispute over tree-felling,” she said. “All BJP CMs have been asked to speak against me,” she said in response to Assam BJP leaders’ contention that BJP workers from Bengal were taking shelter in Assam. “Coochbehar borders Assam. People from Assam come to Bengal when there are disturbances there. It is significant that the BJP has won most seats in Coochbehar,” she said. Banerjee has said most of the violence is happening in areas where the BJP has won. The CM cited the attack on senior Coochbehar leader Udayan Guha, whose hand was broken. Guha lost to BJP MP Nisith Pramanik by 57 votes, the lowest margin in the recently concluded polls. “We have mapped the black spots. There was also inefficiency (in the administration). You know the EC changed all superintendents of police and even the state director-general of police,” she said. The Bengal government replaced Coochbehar SP Debasish Dhar, who was appointed by the EC, on Wednesday itself. “Some sporadic incidents take place after every poll. This happens every time. So, immediately after our poll win, I appealed for peace, stopped all celebrations and urged party workers not to be provoked,” Banerjee added. The Bengal CM questioned the presence of central ministers in Bengal, who “were going to villages and instigating communal riots”. “Anyone coming to Bengal now must have a negative RT-PCR report or else must stay in quarantine for 14 days at their own cost. This will be applicable for people arriving by all special flights, including chartered flights. Even their safety is our concern,” she said, adding that the Bengal government had also banned political gatherings with more than 50 people.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/accept-mandate-let-us-do-covid-work-cm-to-centre/articleshow/82444708.cms||---

---||Kolkata||Rs 12,000 festival advance to Bengal govt staffers||KOLKATA: The Bengal government has decided to give interest-free festival advance of Rs 12,000 to employees whose monthly revised emoluments are within Rs 45,000 a month. The advance will be recovered from their salary in not more than 10 monthly instalments. The recovery is to be completed by August 2022. All employees retiring after November 2021 will be entitled to get the salary advance. This will also be available to teachers of aided schools and staff of urban local bodies and panchayats. Normally, the state government issues salary advance on the eve of Eid-Ul-Fitr and also before Pujas. Muslim employees get the advance before their festival and for other employees, it is paid between September 21 and October 5 if they apply for the same, the finance department notification said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/rs-12k-festival-advance-to-bengal-govt-staffers/articleshow/82443447.cms||---
---||Kolkata||CID SIT to fast-track Sitalkuchi probe||KOLKATA: The CID on Thursday formed a Special Investigation Team (SIT), led by its deputy inspector general Kalyan Mukherjee, to fast-track investigation into the April 10 poll-day firing in Sitalkuchi that had left four dead. Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday said she had sought a detailed CID report “on what happened that day” and would not like to comment before the probe was over. Prima facie, “some mischief was there”, she added. The Cooch Behar police superintendent was replaced by the Bengal government on Wednesday. Speaking to reporters in Nabanna, CM Banerjee said: “I will wait for the (CID) report first.” She added that “strong action” would be taken against mischief-makers. Earlier, the initial post-mortem report had indicated that in all four deaths in CISF firing that day, the victims had gunshot injuries in their upper body. The report had prompted Banerjee to refer to this incident earlier as “genocide” and “cold blooded murder”. CISF – and district police – had said they had fired in “self-defence” when a “mob tried to snatch their firearms”. The Calcutta High Court too has sought a CID report as several petitions are being heard that have demanded a judicial inquiry; one PIL has even urged an inquiry by a sitting HC judge. The HC is likely to take up the matter again after summer recess. On Thursday, SIT questioned case investigating officer (of Cooch Behar) Moloy Bose. He was summoned to Bhawani Bhawan and his statement recorded. Inspector-in-charge Biswasroy Sarkar of Mathabhanga police station, under which Sitalkuchi falls, is likely to be summoned on Monday to Bhawani Bhawan, the DIG said. The CID team has so far spoken to family members of victims and several witnesses. CID sources said polling officers will record their statements too. The state CID will then ask CISF personnel to join investigations. “It will be a time-bound probe,” Mukherjee said. CID has also spoken to independent witness Ali Rahman, who has described in detail his version of events. CID officers have told TOI that they have asked locals to share everything they know, including videos, still photographs and even shared WhatsApp images. Two FIRs have been lodged in the case, one by a victim’s relative and another by CISF. The CM said all five persons killed in Sitalkuchi that day, including four in the firing, had been given Rs 5 lakh compensation by the government earlier. Their next of kin would be given job of a home guard, she added.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/cid-sit-to-fast-track-sitalkuchi-probe/articleshow/82443557.cms||Dwaipayan Ghosh
---||Kolkata||Bengal CM writes to PM Narendra Modi, seeks central benefits to 9.8 lakh verified farmers||KOLKATA: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday wrote to Prime Minister Narendra Modi urging him to release PM-Kisan benefits to the 9.8 lakh famers whose names have been verified by the state and details uploaded on the Public Finance Management System (PFMS). These farmers are among the first lot of 14.9 lakh who had applied for PM-Kisan. Stressing immediate disbursement, Banerjee reminded Modi of his pre-poll statement in which he had asked “state officers to be ready to prepare a list of beneficiaries for the PM Kisan Nidhi programme”. PM-Kisan has been a contentious issue between the Centre and Bengal, resulting in back and forth of several letters. Bengal had said PM-Kisan aped its Krishak Bandhu scheme launched in December 2018 and the Central scheme had a long exclusion list of bargadars, sharecroppers, persons giving self-declarations, serving and retired employees, and income-tax payers. The Centre had written to Bengal that despite its opposition, 21.7 lakh people had logged on to the central portal and questioned why they should be denied their due. Referring to the 21.7 lakh applicants, the CM wrote to the PM on Thursday that among them 14.9 lakh had been uploaded and 9.8 lakh were checked and cleared as per norms. She further wrote: “I would like to impress that during your recent visit to the state, you gave repeated assurances on releasing the arrear amount of Rs 18,000 to each farmer, but till date, no fund has been received.” Urging the PM to release the amount, the CM also urged him to ask the Union agriculture ministry to share data of all 21.7 lakh applicants for verification. Banerjee also highlighted that while the Central payment was awaited, Bengal had already paid Rs 3,454 crore to all eligible under the state’s Krishak Bandhu scheme from January 2019. She further said 20,678 families, under this scheme, had also received death benefits of Rs 413.5 crore. She added that her pre-poll promise to hike Krishak Bandhu scheme benefits to Rs 10,000 would be rolled out once the Covid situation was brought under control.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/didi-writes-to-pm-seeks-central-benefits-to-9-8l-verified-farmers/articleshow/82443459.cms||---
---||Kolkata||Post-poll violence in Bengal: MHA team meets officials, BJP leaders||KOLKATA: A four-member Uni-on home ministry team reached Bengal on Thursday to assess the situation amid allegations of post-poll violence. The visit came three days after a home ministry letter to the state government, enquiring about the law-and-order situation, failed to elicit any response. The team called on state chief secretary Alapan Bandyopadhyay at Nabanna to know about steps taken to control the “violence”. It then visited the Jagaddal residence of Shova Rani Mandal, who died four days ago, trying to protect her son, BJP supporter Gopal Mandal, from goons who attacked their home after the poll results. A BJP delegation, led by state unit çhief Dilip Ghosh and Nandigram MLA Suvendu Adhikari, later met the MHA team to present its account of the situation in Bengal. BJP leaders complained that there was no let-up in the violence, particul-arly in East Burdwan’s Ketug-ram and Birbhum’s Rampurhat, even on Thursday. Jadavp-ur BJP candidate Rinku Nask-ar’s house was ransacked on Wednesday evening, they added. Bengal officials contend that the MHA has “limited jurisdiction” over day-to-day law-and-order issues that are primarily the state government’s responsibility. “The MHA can issue advisories to the state government as it has done on earlier occasions, call for reports and persuade state governments to take steps,” a senior Bengal government official said. The MHA team’s visit on Thursday was the first after a central team’s visit to Kolkata in 2020 to “aid and advise” the state government on Covid surveillance and management during the first wave of the pandemic. The team had then complained about not getting “cooperation” from the state government.
