---||Kolkata||MLAs’ launch showcases Bengal’s diversity||KOLKATA: Underscoring Bengal’s linguistic and cultural diversity, newly elected legislators took their oath in the assembly on Thursday in different languages, including Bengali, Hindi, Urdu, Santhali and English. They were sworn in by pro tem speaker Subrata Mukherjee. On her way to Nabanna, chief minister Mamata Banerjee briefly attended the swearing-in, which is being held in batches in strict adherence to the Covid protocol. As many as 150 MLAs — most of them elected from seats in Kolkata, North and South 24 Parganas, East and West Midnapore, Howrah, Hooghly, Jhargram and Purulia — took oath on the first day. The ceremony ended with the swearing-in of BJP’s Nandigram MLA Suvendu Adhikari. The assembly witnessed two firsts on Thursday — a couple and a father-daughter duo simultaneously taking oath as MLAs. Becharam Manna bagged Singur defeating his once mentor Rabindranath Bhattacharya while his doctor wife Karabi Manna won from Haripal, a seat incidentally vacated by Manna. A reticent Karabi said, “I have to learn. I will try to honour the faith CM Mamata Banerjee and the people of Haripal have shown in me.” Dulal Das, the new MLA of Maheshtala, watched proudly as daughter Ratna Chatterjee, who won from Behala East, joined the assembly for the first time. Ratna said: “I will do my very best to serve the chief minister, my party and the people who have given me such responsibility. I pledge to work for the people of Behala.” Speaking in public for the first time since his nail-biting victory, Adhikari said: “We will play our role as expected by the people who have elected 77 MLAs from BJP. Our role will be constructive as far as Covid-19 is concerned. Let the assembly first function in a full-fledged manner.” Referring to an alleged attack on junior external affairs minister V Muraleedharan’s convoy in West Midnapore, he added: “No one is safe in this state. The attack is on the people of a particular community by a particular community.” Ironically, journalists interviewing Adhikari were allegedly manhandled by central forces and the MLA reportedly made only a “mild attempt” to restrain the security personnel. Mediapersons, including women, accused CAPF of hitting them with gun butts and ripping off camera wires. The journalists filed a written complaint with the pro tem speaker and sought a ban on CAPF personnel on assembly premises. Earlier in the day, Birbaha Hansda — elected from Jhargram — stole the show in her ethnic attire as she took her oath in Santhali. She honoured Mukherjee with an uttariya (a traditional scarf) after being sworn in. The ceremony was star-studded with the presence of newly elected members from Tollywood, singers and sportspersons. ---||Kolkata||West Bengal violence: Ex-Trinamool MLA suffers fractures, BJP team attacked||MIDNAPORE/JALPAIGURI: A Union minister’s vehicle came under attack in Midnapore and a senior Trinamool Congress leader had his arm fractured in an assault in Cooch Behar as post-poll clashes continued to surface in Bengal on Thursday. Minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan’s vehicle was attacked at Paanchkuri in West Midnapore and the rear glass of his MUV smashed, prompting police to arrest eight persons and show-cause three district police officers who were responsible for the Union minister’s security. Trinamool Congress denied any involvement in the incident. In Dinhata, former Trinamool MLA Udyan Guha, who lost by a mere 57 votes to BJP’s Nisith Pramanik from Dinhata in the just-concluded assembly polls, was dragged out of his car and assaulted allegedly by BJP men. Guha was left with multiple fractures in his arm while his two security personnel and driver were seriously injured; one of them receiving multiple head injuries. Guha named 11 BJP workers in his FIR, seven of whom he claimed to have identified himself. Read AlsoBengal post-poll violence: MHA team meets Guv, to seek reportA four-member team of the Union home ministry, tasked with looking into reasons for the post- poll violence in West Bengal, met Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar at the Raj Bhawan on Friday.​Soon after the Midnapore incident, Union minister Muraleedharan sent out three Twitter posts, one with a 58-second video on the attack on his vehicle. “TMC goons attacked my convoy in West Midnapore, broken windows, attacked personal staff. Cutting short my trip,” he wrote. “We could not visit the house of Bengal BJP karyakarta Biswajit Mahesh, who was killed in the post-poll violence at his village Markundachak. Police advised us not to go after the attack on my convoy at Paanchkuri,” another post said. Mahesh was found murdered in Sabang (West Midnapore) on Tuesday night. His family in an FIR said the murder was a fallout of a land dispute. West Midnapore SP Dinesh Kumar later confirmed that eight persons had been arrested and three police officers show-caused. “Enquiry is on, departmental action will follow,” Kumar said. BJP West Midnapore president Soumen Tiwari alleged the police were mute spectators during the attack. Trinamool’s district president, Ajit Maiti claimed the “central minister had instigated the villagers, our party has nothing to do with it”. In Dinhata, Guha’s SUV was intercepted at Boys’ Club More. Guha was dragged out and beaten up; an X-ray later revealed he had multiple fractures in his right hand. His two personnel security officers and driver were injured trying to shield him. According to locals, the Boys’ Club was vandalized on Wednesday night. One of the club’s executive members is Ajoy Roy, a former Trinamool leader who defected to BJP just before the polls. Roy claimed Guha had slapped him first, leading to the attack. “We were standing in front of our club when Guha was passing by. On seeing me he came out of his vehicle and slapped me unprovoked. This angered the locals and Guha was assaulted. By the time people gathered, we had left the place,” Roy claimed. But Malati Rava Roy, BJP’s Cooch Behar president, claimed the assault on Guha was the result of “TMC’s internal feud and we have nothing to do with it”. Elsewhere, a 28-year-old BJP Kisan Morcha Mandal leader, Kishore Mandi, was found dead in Jhargram’s Jamboni prompting BJP to allege he was killed in political violence. The family, however, had not lodged any FIR or made any police complaint till reports last came in. Balaram Majhi, a BJP worker at Ketugram, succumbed to his injuries on Wednesday night. He was attacked by some men a few days back and was battling for his life at a hospital. Clashes between Trinamool and BJP workers also broke out in Tilai, Rampurhat. Police reached the spot and arrested four persons. The residence of BJP’s Jadavpur candidate, Rinku Naskar, was also ransacked. Naskar had defected to BJP from CPM just before the elections. ---||Kolkata||Next 15 days will be critical in Covid fight: Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee||KOLKATA: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday announced a host of steps — including employing more doctors and nurses and stabilising oxygen supplies at all Covid facilities — to fight the raging second wave of the pandemic while urging everyone to be careful in the next 15 days, saying the number of cases was expected to rise in that period. “I am not trying to scare, but alerting everyone,” Banerjee said. “In the next 15 days, the number of cases can spike. I appeal everyone with my hands folded, please take care of yourselves.” The CM announced that the state would provide special incentives to MBBS pass-outs, including all postgraduate trainees and interns, to join the Covid battle, aiming to employ an additional 1,188 doctors and 3,428 nurses for the 93 state-run Covid hospitals across Bengal. Also, 1.7 lakh alternative medicine practitioners would be trained by the state health department to act as “first responders” to Covid patients in rural Bengal. “They will be called Sathya Surakha Karmi,” Banerjee said. The measures announced on Thursday were in addition to a 14-day hiatus on local train services, a mandatory negative RT-PCR report for each inbound traveller to Bengal, and a 50-person limit on gatherings — subject to prior approval — announced by her on Wednesday. Banerjee also announced a one-time approval for all private health facilities, both nursing homes and hospitals, to scale up their Covid bed capacities by a further 40%. This would be in addition to the existing sanctioned bed strength. “This is expected to add 2,000 beds in private hospitals alone,” she said. This approval was also granted to all 105 Covid facilities in the state — both state-run and private — to set up their own Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) medical oxygen generation plants. In order to save time, the hospitals will need no additional approval. “They will generate medical oxygen from ambient air. This has been done to cut time. They need not wait for any approval. The Diamond Harbour and Cooch Behar hospitals have already made their own plants,” she said. On the recruitment of more doctors and nurses, an order from the health department on Thursday specified that 530 medical officers would be employed for general wards, 183 in HDU/CCUs and 475 specialist doctors in general medicine, anaesthesia and respiratory medicine. Anima Haldar, principal of the Beliaghata ID Hospital, welcomed the move. “Because of the surge in the number of patients, there is always a need for additional manpower,” she said. While the medical officers will be paid a consolidated amount of Rs 40,000 per month, the specialist doctors will be paid Rs 50,000. The remuneration for nurses would be Rs 17,220 per month. Banerjee made it clear that everyone was a stakeholder in the battle against Covid. She urged industry chambers to come forth and take responsibility of one market each. She urged industrialists based in the districts to take charge of one district market. “The markets need to be sanitised and there should be a provision for adequate masks. They had helped us before, they will again,” she said. She also reminded NGOs, clubs, social organisations, Durga Puja committees and even religious bodies that they should ensure Covid protocols were maintained. “This time, across India, Covid is turning out to be fatal for people in the 30-45 age-group. The second strain is impacting more youngsters,” she said. The CM is scheduled to meet all religious heads at 3pm on Monday to urge them to join in Covid battle by encouraging people to worship from home. Banerjee also appealed to imams to help her in the Covid battle, like last year. She urged them that any gathering at any point should be less than 50 people, maintaining distancing norms.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/mamata-next-15-days-will-be-critical-in-covid-fight/articleshow/82444550.cms||Sumati Yengkhom
---||Kolkata||Kolkata cops register 2 FIRs as fake ‘poll violence’ posts go viral||KOLKATA: Kolkata Police and state CID have initiated multiple probes, registered at least two FIRs, and shared a helpline number and an email ID after complaints from citizens that fake news portraying them as “victims of post-poll violence in Bengal” was being posted on social media. One such person is Abhro Banerjee, who’s in his twenties and works with one of India’s leading media groups in Delhi. After he’d been declared a “martyr” on the “West Bengal BJP” Facebook page and had started receiving frantic calls from family, friends and colleagues, he was compelled to go on Twitter to say: “I am Abhro Banerjee, living and hale and hearty and around 1,300 km away from Sitalkuchi. BJP IT Cell is now claiming I am Manik Moitra and died in Sitalkuchi. Please don’t believe these fake posts and please don’t worry. I repeat: I am (still) alive.” His tweet was accompanied by a screenshot of the post that presented him as a “martyr” from Sitalkuchi in Cooch Behar. When contacted, Banerjee told TOI that he had nothing to add to his tweet. His friends said they were worried. “This factory of lies is very dangerous,” one of them said. The 5.28-minute clip that said he was dead was later taken down from the “West Bengal BJP” Facebook page but it was live on the “@BJP4India” Twitter handle till much later. This tweet too was deleted later but, before that, had been shared thousands of times. TOI spoke to BJP Bengal unit spokesperson Samik Bhattacharya on Thursday morning. “I will enquire and get back to you. Let me check the details first,” Bhattacharya said. The “BJPBengal” Twitter handle later clarified that Banerjee’s image was “erroneously included in the video”. “Mamik Moitro succumbed to his injuries in Sitalkuchi following violence by Trinamool members,” the tweet claimed. “Our cyber cell is probing the complaints we have received and we have already registered two FIRs. Complaints include fake news, false representations, threats issued over the internet and use of old clips from unrelated incidents to foment trouble,” joint commissioner of police (crime) Murlidhar Sharma said. Another senior official said charges against the alleged offenders included publishing or circulating statements or reports containing rumours or alarming news with the intent to create or promote feelings of enmity and hatred on grounds of caste and community, sedition and violation of Information Technology Act regulations. The fake posts include a video apparently tweeted by a senior BJP women’s wing social media cell functionary. The video shows a group of people dancing with their arms raised in the air, some of them holding daggers, knives and guns to the “Khela hobe” background track. “A separate FIR has been drawn up against this,” an official said. Some other posts have also been flagged as fake by websites that specialize in fact-checking. The CID’s cyber cell is in touch with both Twitter and Facebook to try and delete misinformation. “We have uploaded and cautioned people against two such fake videos in the past 24 hours,” a senior CID officer said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/kolkata/cops-register-2-firs-as-fake-poll-violence-posts-go-viral/articleshow/82444863.cms||Dwaipayan Ghosh
---||Hyderabad||Hyderabad's Biological E set for Covid vaccine rollout by August||HYDERABAD: As the country grapples with the second wave of Covid-19, vaccine maker Biological E is gearing up to churn out 75 to 80 million doses per month of its recombinant protein vaccine candidate from August this year. The company also says it will be one of the most affordable vaccines in the country. Biological E’s managing director Mahima Datla indicated as much in an exclusive interview to TOI when she said: “I am not at liberty to share it (pricing) yet because we are still working on it, but I can assure you it will be among the most affordable Covid-19 vaccines that you can get a hold of.” She added that the company certainly won’t take advantage of the situation. “We’re third generation in this business,” she said. “Covid did not make us enter into this business and we pride ourselves on having made vaccines accessible in pre-pandemic times to countries that needed it the most.” Dr Maria Elena Bottazi, associate dean, National School of Tropical Medicine (NSTM) at Texas-based Baylor College of Medicine, which is collaborating with Biological E for the vaccine, has been quoted as saying that the subunit vaccine, which is modelled after the hepatitis B vaccine, uses traditional technology and is cheap to produce at only about $1.5 (Rs 110 approx) per dose. Datla’s assurance on affordable pricing comes at a time when vaccine pricing has become a political issue. After being criticised, the central government had to ask both Serum Institute of India (Covishield) and Bharat Biotech (Covaxin) to cut their prices for state governments. On being able to churn out 75-80 million doses per month right from the start, Datla said: “It’s a significant capacity and we have already scaled up. We have confidence in our manufacturing capabilities to be able to deliver that number from August onwards.” “We are well-resourced in terms of capacities, both for fill-finish and bulk antigen. We are focusing on hunkering down and getting our vaccines through to the finish line and making sure that we're able to deliver capacities...” she added. Bio E’s vaccine rollout could help substantially ease the vaccine crunch that is currently hampering the country’s vaccination drive. Apart from Covaxin and Covishield, Russian vaccine Sputnik V, which is priced at $10 globally, has received emergency use authorisation but India would initially have to rely on imports as local manufacturing of the vaccine is slated to begin only in the July-September quarter. Currently, Biological E is busy with preparations for phase III trials of the two-dose vaccine on 1,268 healthy volunteers in the 18-80 years age group at 15 centres across the country as part of a larger global study. Apart from the two-dose recombinant protein vaccine Bio E also has a tie-up with Johnson & Johnson for making 600 million doses of the latter’s single shot Covid-19 vaccine — Ad26.COV2.S — in India.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/hyderabad/telangana-biological-e-set-for-covid-vaccine-rollout-by-august/articleshow/82447958.cms||Swati Bharadwaj
---||India||EC versus HC: EC member wanted to resign, be punished for ‘murder’ if observations not withdrawn||NEW DELHI : Election commissioner Rajiv Kumar had insisted on a more forceful and personal submission in the Madras High Court while seeking withdrawal of its observation that EC officials be "put up for murder" for the Covid surge, and offered to take individual responsibility, resign and face punishment in case the HC refused the prayer. In a separate draft affidavit, whose contents he had wanted to be incorporated in the EC affidavit and, alternatively, have the affidavit filed in his individual capacity as election commissioner, Kumar said the HC observations had demoralised 11 lakh people involved in conduct of polls under Covid cloud. Stating that when “murderers, the description used by the Hon’ble court, head or remain part of ECI, voters in general and contesting candidates/political parties….cannot trust free, fair, transparent elections,” Kumar said: “I, as election commissioner, cannot escape individual responsibility and leave it to the judgement of Hon’ble court to punish in the manner the Hon’ble court is pleased to so decide. The institution (ECI), however, needs to be absolved of the doubts cast on it”. Kumar’s separate affidavit was never filed as the senior counsel arguing the matter opined that an affidavit could only be submitted on behalf of ECI or CEC who were made respondents in such cases. “The submissions in a court of law on behalf of ECI have to be within a legal framework and must be vetted by the senior counsel,” a senior functionary told TOI. “At the EC meeting, all the senior officials as well as legal counsel were unanimous that it is for EC to approach courts unitedly and not for an election commissioner to place submissions in his individual capacity. There is no such precedent,” an officer said adding that at the stage of filing the SLP in the Supreme Court, many paragraphs from Kumar’s affidavit were incorporated and the prayer for restraining media from reporting oral observations of the court, excluded. “The EC affidavit in Madras HC and later the SLP in Supreme Court were filed only after the election commissioner’s approval, and it was made amply clear to him that he could not make submissions in his individual capacity,” an EC functionary told TOI. Kumar had in his draft affidavit argued that EC was far ahead of the Covid curve and took nearly 30 actions for safe polls, including considering deferring of polls and merging the last few phases. However, deferring of polls would temporarily disenfranchise voters, leading to implications of elections not being completed on time and necessitating an extended term or President’s rule. This, he said, would attract sharper objections of favouring one and acting against another. Kumar’s draft affidavit said the HC’s ‘murder’ observation had caused loss of faith in EC as an institution, making it additionally difficult for it to conduct elections in the future. He also objected to EC singularly being blamed for the Covid surge when Disaster Management Act placed this responsibility on the local administration that must act as per directions of NDMA and SDMA. He also pointed out that between announcement of polls on February 26and the filing of the affidavit, no inputs were received by EC about a possible surge in Covid cases and precautions to be taken. In fact, it was only on April 25 that the Union health secretary wrote to the states and UTs suggesting intensive local containment focused on restraining intermingling of people for a period of 14 days.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/ec-versus-hc-ec-member-wanted-to-resign-be-prosecuted-for-murder-if-observations-not-withdrawn/articleshow/82447950.cms||Bharti Jain
---||Delhi||Oxygen concentrator racket busted in Delhi, businessman on run||NEW DELHI: In a massive crackdown against hoarders selling oxygen concentrators in the blackmarket, Delhi Police seized over 450 oxygen concentrators in multiple raids across the city, the biggest being at south Delhi's Lodhi Colony which alone led to recovery of 419 machines. The Lodhi Colony operation has led to the largest seizure during this pandemic. Delhi | Four people from a restaurant-cum-bar in Lodhi Colony have been arrested in connection with black marketing… https://t.co/zMUumYZMSt— The Times Of India (@timesofindia) 1620279032000Four people have been arrested while a manhunt has been initiated for a businessman named Navneet Kalra who cops said was absconding. Most of the men arrested in the busts are also businessmen. BIGGEST HAUL | 419 #OxygenConcentrators seized by @DCPSouthDelhi #DelhiPolice PS Lodhi cly team from restaurant &… https://t.co/WYNNQ601rc— #DilKiPolice Delhi Police (@DelhiPolice) 1620311486000450 O 2 machines seized, cops to approach court over distributionMany of the men arrested for black marketing of concentrators are businessmen who dealt in other goods before the pandemic but resorted to selling concentrators for profit in recent days. The cops will approach the court to have the seized machines distributed to hospitals and medical facilities during the oxygen crisis. According to DCP (south) Atul Thakur, the recoveries started from Nege & Ju bar, owned by Kalra. Kalra is a well-known businessman associated with Dayal Opticals and Khan Chacha, police said. Two other restaurateurs are also under the scanner with initial probe suggesting they were involved in funding the procurement through a firm which dealt in sim cards, a senior officer said. The cops got the first tipoff from a WhatsApp message allegedly sent by Kalra to his acquaintance detailing his account details in lieu of a concentrator. Following this, cops mounted watch at Kalra's bar in central market, Lodhi Colony. “During area patrolling, suspicious activity was noted at the outlet which was found open. When enquired, a person was found working on a laptop and handling orders of oxygen concentrator by ‘Xpect Everything online portal’. During search of the premises, 32 boxes of concentrators having capacity of 9 and 5 litres were seized,” DCP Thakur said. An FIR was registered and the bar manager Hitesh and three others — Gaurav, Satish and Vikrant — were arrested. They led the cops to Khullar Farm, Mandi Village from where 387 more units were seized. In the second operation, the west district police seized 18 concentrators and arrested two suspects, DCP Urvija Goel said. The suspects have been identified as Hemant Mehta and Hari. Inspector Narender’s team had received a tip-off that the duo was selling the machines for Rs 1.3 lakh each and conducted a raid. Mehta had imported these from China. The north Delhi Police seized nine concentrators and arrested two people in separate operations. “Five machines were seized by cops from Wazirabad police station who arrested a man named Amit Bajaj while four concentrators and nine cylinders were seized from a suspect named Harshit Gupta by the anti-auto theft squad,” DCP Anto Alphonse said. In southeast Delhi, DCP R P Meena’s team seized six concentrators and arrested a man named Avinash Gupta. SHO Lajpat Nagar Dharam Dev had received a tip-off about the suspect selling concentrators in black and sent a decoy customer. The suspect arrived with the machines and was arrested. In Govindpuri, a home care service provider was arrested for overcharging Covid-19 patients for providing oxygen concentrators. The suspect, Deep Kumar, was charging Rs 3 lakh for a single oxygen concentrator. He accepted Rs 2.1 lakh in advance in his account but the buyer complained to cops after getting to know that she was being overcharged.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/delhi/oxygen-concentrator-racket-busted-in-delhi-businessman-on-run/articleshow/82447962.cms||Raj Shekhar
---||Udaipur||Rajasthan: Over 39,000 in 18+ category vaccinated, tally now 2 lakh||JAIPUR: Covid vaccination drive for the 18-44 age bracket saw a drop in numbers on Thursday as only 39,198 beneficiaries got their first dose. On most of the previous days, the number hovered around the 50,000 mark. Though it was the sixth day since vaccination started in the state, many people are still clueless on slot booking. Many who had already registered are not been able to get a time slot and the vaccination site for themselves and their families. In the last six days of inoculation, a total of 2,22,063 have been vaccinated so far. The number could have gone higher but due to problems in the Co-Win and Aarogya Setu apps, many who had registered did not get slots. Many people who were roaming near the vaccination centres were told that without slot booking they can’t be entertained. “We have a slot of 100 vaccines per site in Jaipur. As soon as slots are opened, youngsters get their slots booked. This problem will improve when we will increase the vaccines and that is possible only after getting adequate supply of doses,” said Dr Raghuraj Singh, nodal officer, vaccination. He added that vaccines have arrived for frontline and health workers and those above 45 years in the evening. “We have got 3 lakh vials for this category and hopefully this will enable us to administer the second dose to beneficiaries in this category,” he added. Out of the 39,198 shots, 8,196 got their first jab in Jaipur followed by Bharatpur (5,888), Kota (4,059), Udaipur(3,701), Jodhpur (3,096), Ajmer (2,816), Bikaner (2,788), Bhilwara (2,277), Pali (2,025), Dholpur (1,583), Sikar(1,545) and Alwar (1,215).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/udaipur/rajasthan-over-39000-in-18-category-vaccinated-tally-now-2-lakh/articleshow/82447963.cms||---

---||India||'Incoming garbage' got BJP tickets in Bengal: Tathagata||KOLKATA: Former Meghalaya governor Tathagata Roy led a blistering attack against the "foursome" Kailash-Dilip-Shiv-Arvind (KDSA) - Bengal BJP minder Kailash Vijayvargiya, Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh, party leaders Shiv Prakash and Arvind Menon - the day he was summoned to Delhi for his controversial "nogorer noti" remarks against the party's Tollywood celeb candidates. These candidates had gone on a boat trip with their political adversary, Trinamool Congress leader Madan Mitra, in the run-up to polls. Roy, who is down with Covid, is upset over BJP's performance in the Bengal assembly polls and has blamed "KDSA" directly for the poll debacle. "They have dragged the names of our respected PM and home minister through mud and have sullied the name of the biggest political party in the world," the BJP leader posted on his Twitter handle on Thursday. Roy, who describes himself as a swayamsevak, said the four distributed tickets to "incoming garbage" from Trinamool and added that BJP would now face an exodus of the "garbage" and also old party karyakartas let down by Bengal BJP brass. "These people have heaped the worst possible insults on ideologically driven BJP workers and devout swayamsevaks who had been relentlessly working for the party since 1980s. Now those very people are suffering the worst persecution from Trinamoolis. But KDSA won't go to their rescue, they won't even exhort them to fight back," Roy said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//india/incoming-garbage-got-bjp-tickets-in-bengal-tathagata/articleshow/82448004.cms||---
---||Thiruvananthapuram||Covid management: Thiruvananthapuram corporation starts building fleet of vehicles||THIRUVANANTHAPURAM : The city corporation has started rolling out an elaborate transportation plan as part of Covid management in the city. The health wing started preparing a database of available school buses in government schools. Besides plans are underway to make use of school buses owned by private educational institutions. Transportation plan and maintaining a fleet of vehicles are being done as part of various Covid-related activities undertaken by the control room being run by city corporation. The maintenance of school buses in government schools has emerged as the biggest challenge for the civic body. “We made a list of 14 schools and identified buses which could be taken over. However, when we inspected those vehicles, we found that the buses need mechanical repair and works of other kinds. All these buses have not been used for more than a year. We can’t afford time either. Our priority now is to get a few vehicles functional very soon so that they will be ready for operation,” said a health official. With a major percentage of people remaining in home care and availability of vehicles becoming a cause of concern with rise in cases, corporation plans to deploy a fleet of vehicles in each ward and the demand can be communicated via the control room. As per the order issued by local self-government department (LSGD), corporations have been directed to look for taxis with double chamber and to enter into contract with private ambulances. The officials said that there are practical difficulties in implementing the order. “Private vehicle owners are already facing the brunt of economic breakdown. Besides there is always the risk of infection as many of the drivers are below 45 years of age and are not vaccinated unlike the frontline health workers. It is not often possible to get them into a contract based on rates being pitched by civic bodies,” said a health official. LSGD has put forward options like making use of private vehicles which are not used frequently or availing vehicles from those who own more than one car. The local bodies have been directed to meet the driver and fuel expenses or explore options to sponsor fuel. The corporation officials said that they really have to work hard to explore such options and convince people into giving away their private vehicles which are not in use at present. The vehicles are mostly required for transport of patients from homes to firstline or domiciliary treatment centres and Covid hospitals. As per the directive, corporation has also been asked to ensure that drivers of taxis wear PPE kits and corporation purchase that PPE kit for them.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/thiruvananthapuram/covid-management-thiruvananthapuram-corporation-starts-building-fleet-of-vehicles/articleshow/82448035.cms||Aswin J Kumar
---||Business||Govt in no rush to grant 'compulsory licences'||NEW DELHI: The government may not rush ahead and grant a series of compulsory licences to access cheaper drugs in the wake of Natco Pharma seeking patent waiver for rheumatoid arthritis drug Baricitinib that is being administered to Covid patients. While it is still early days for Natco's application, sources indicated that a blanket use of compulsory licence - a provision available in WTO's TRIPS agreement - may not be a good idea. Amid suggestions to use the tool for Remdisivir and Tocilizumab, two drugs that are being used, government sources said that it made little sense to invoke compulsory licensing provisions, given that the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) is not available in the country. "It will not solve any purpose as you will need the basic chemicals too," said a government source. Under India's Patent Act, relaxations can be given under half-a-dozen situations. Natco has used among the more controversial section 92, which allows the Centre to invoke compulsory licensing provisions in case of due to a national emergency, circumstances of extreme urgency or in case of public non-commercial use. The use of the provision to waive Bayer's rights over a cancer drug almost a decade ago had generated considerable controversy with the US expressing its displeasure. Over the years, the commerce and industry ministry has resisted pressure from the health ministry to use the clause, arguing that it's to be used in the rarest of rare cases. Officials said that this is time consuming as well. Former PM Manmohan Singh had recently pointed to possible use of compulsory licence and other flexibility under the Patents Act to boost vaccine output. There are other provisions too, which are simpler. For instance, section 47 allows the government to import patented drugs for its use or for use in hospitals and dispensaries, which is seen as a non-controversial use. Similarly, under section 100 it has powers to use certain inventions either before a patent has been granted or even after the rights have been given to the inventor. Sources indicated that while the government has powers to use compulsory licence as a tool, especially when WTO members such as the European Union have supported its use, it will prefer the TRIPS waiver window, for which negotiations are expected to begin shortly.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/govt-in-no-rush-to-grant-compulsory-licences/articleshow/82448058.cms||Sidhartha
---||Business||Nabard gives Rs 9,162 cr fin aid to state in FY20||Kolkata: The National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (Nabard) has given financial support of Rs 9,162 crore to the state during the last financial year for the development of agriculture and allied sectors amid Covid-19 pandemic. The financial supports included Rs 1269.2crore loan to the state government for various rural infrastructure development, Rs 3842.3 crore long-term refinance assistance to Rural Financial Institutions (RFIs) for financing investment activities in agriculture and allied sectors and MSME sector, and Rs 3757.5 crore short-term refinance to RFIs for supporting production and marketing activities of farmers and rural artisans, Nabard said in a release on Thursday. For 2021-22, it has estimated a credit potential of Rs 2.2 lakh crore for West Bengal to be disbursed by various banks for the priority sector activities. “During 2020-21, Nabard sanctioned 2,284 new rural infrastructure projects consisting of rural roads, rural bridges, medium and minor irrigation projects, flood protection projects, solar power plants and Anganwadi Centres with RIDF loan support of Rs 1659.6 crore to the Government of West Bengal. On implementation, these projects will lead to creation of 857 km length of rural roads and 129-meter long rural bridges, benefitting 949 villages and favorably impacting about 70 lakh people in the rural areas,” the bank said.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//business/india-business/nabard-gives-rs-9162-cr-fin-aid-to-state-in-fy20/articleshow/82442383.cms||---
---||Trichy||Daughter, 17, raped and wife murdered: Tamil Nadu man gets death||TRICHY: A mahila court in Pudukottai on Thursday sentenced a 52-year-old man to death for raping his 17-year-old daughter and killing his wife for questioning the exploitation. The survivor was among the convict’s 11 children from three wives. Born to his second wife, the girl has been putting up with her father’s sexual assault since 2017 when she was 15 years old.  He continuously raped her by threatening to kill her mother if she revealed it to anyone. However, the woman came to know about it in 2019 and threatened him with dire consequences.  He decided to get rid of her after she started preventing his further advances towards the girl. He murdered the woman in December 2019 at an isolated place. Police arrested him and it was during inquiry that they came to know about his sexual assault on his own daughter. Third rape case ending with death sentence in 6 months Judge R Sathya convicted the man under four sections of the Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) (amendment) Act, 2019. Besides death sentence, she also awarded him a life sentence, nine years of rigorous imprisonment and fines adding up to ₹3 lakh. This is the third case of rape of a minor in the past six months in which the judge has awarded death sentence. In December 2020, a 25-year-old man who murdered a seven-year-old girl after raping her in June that year was awarded death sentence, rigorous life imprisonment and fine. In February this year, the judge awarded triple death sentence to a 34-year-old native of Gujarat for sodomising a 17-year-old boy with learning disabilities who later died in hospital due to internal injuries. (The victims' identities have not been revealed to protect their privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/trichy/daughter-17-raped-and-wife-murdered-tamil-nadu-man-gets-death/articleshow/82448108.cms||K Sambath Kumar
---||Mumbai||No walk-ins for vaccination in Mumbai except for Covaxin 2nd shot||MUMBAI: In a bid to control overcrowding at vaccination centres, BMC on Thursday decided that all potential recipients will have to mandatorily book an appointment on the CoWin app and that no walkins would be entertained. Some exceptions have been made. Citizens above 45 years who are due for a second dose of Covaxin can enter without an appointment provided they carry the certificate of the first dose in either soft or hard copy. Healthcare and frontline workers due for a first or second dose of Covaxin or Covishield are also exempted but will need a certificate from their employer. “The above orders will come into force with immediate effect,” said BMC commissioner Iqbal Singh Chahal. The directive has come in the wake of crowding and the absence of Covid-appropriate behaviour at vaccination points; a stampede-like situation broke out at the Bandra Kurla Complex centre on Wednesday. Those in charge of all centres—there are 147 in the cityhave been directed to ensure verification of online appointments before allowing entry into the premises. The news triggered concerns among those who struggle to book appointments or find online appointments being overlooked.Many said BMC should have arranged for assistance for senior citizens to go online. BMC may enlist NGOs to help sr citizens; more Covaxin sites set upA Mulund resident said, “I had an appointment for 12pm on Wednesday but when I reached, there were 500 people ahead of me. The centre refused to consider the appointment and asked me to wait in line… they had only 200 vaccines left,” he said. A teacher from Dahisar said getting a slot on CoWin was not easy. “Unless they have a perfectly efficient app, it will be unfair to stop walk-ins,” she said, adding that she has been trying in vain to book an appointment for the past one week. BMC’s additional municipal commissioner Suresh Kakani said, “Those without an appointment will have to go back unless they are in a category that’s exempted…we had no control over the crowd at the centres. People refused to listen and 90% came in through walk-ins,” he said. For assistance, he said people would be given support at ward offices. “In addition, we will look at tie-ups with NGOs willing to help senior citizens,” Kakani said. The system is permanent for now, though there could be some modifications to the rule. On Thursday, vaccination numbers picked up with 60,153 people taking the shot. Daily vaccinations were languishing in the range of 25,000-40,000 the past few weeks due to erratic supply of doses. Kakani said the city received 70,000 doses on Thursday, so vaccines will be available for the next few days. For the agegroup of 18-44, he said more centres will be added next week. Currently, only five are vaccinating this group. The state has received 5lakh Covaxin doses that will be used for this age group. Among private centres, HN Reliance vaccinated 983 while Nanavati gave doses to 470 on Thursday. Congress MLA for Bandra (East) constituency Zeeshan Siddique said with vaccine stocks being limited, it is better to take only those who have registered. “Once vaccines arrive in large numbers, walk-in should once again be allowed with adequate security arrangements,” he said. Three new centres have been added to the existing five Covaxin centres for those between 18-44 years. The new centres to start from Friday will be PWD Community Hall (Bandra East), MCGM Parking World Tower (Lower Parel) and Maasaheb Meenatai Thackeray Maternity Home (Chunabhatti).||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//city/mumbai/no-walk-ins-for-vaccination-in-mumbai-except-for-covaxin-2nd-shot/articleshow/82448117.cms||Richa Pinto

---||World||Young desi doctors in US help get aid for India||NEW DELHI: Often between shifts at St Vincent hospital in Wisconsin, critical care surgeon Dr Mamta Swaroop logs on to Clubhouse and Instagram to help out with India's ongoing Covid-19 crisis. Alarmed by the unprecedented surge in cases, the 43-year-old is among 1,000-odd young desi doctors in America who are doing their bit by bringing donors from the US in contact with beneficiaries in India. Ever since the second wave hit India, these doctors have responded by floating not-for-profit organisations, creating bank accounts where donations can be deposited, and tying up with cargo and shipping companies to organise charitable efforts to send oxygen tanks, ventilators, oxygen meters, regulators, concentrators to India. "After I return home, I stay awake till 1am or 2am co-ordinating relief efforts in India," said Swaroop, founder-president, Unite4India and Sadanah, an international charity NGO. "We raised US$ 250,000 in five days and arranged to ship 200-odd oxygen concentrators to Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Tamil Nadu," said Dr Karthik Ramakrishnan, who is part of Unite4India. Independent US doctors of Indian origin are also helping by sourcing oxygen vendors, hospital beds and scouting for plasma donors. "I navigate logistics, healthcare systems, acquire resources. I also recruit healthcare workers for Indian hospitals and patients in home isolation," said Dr Priya Jaisinghani, 29, an internal medicine physician. Indians working with US corporate giants, too, have joined hands. "Many warehouses in India that use compressed air systems can be optimised to produce 1 lakh litres of oxygen per hour. We have activated few regions in India and shared this schematic with other corporates," said Praveen, engineer with a food-and-beverage firm.||http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//world/us/young-desi-doctors-in-us-help-get-aid-for-india/articleshow/82448121.cms||Rohan Dua
